+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’ve never been to hell, but I’m guessing it has less humidity. New Orleans hits me like a damp towel to the face the second the truck door slams behind me and rattles off into traffic. I’m left on the sidewalk with my backpack, my skateboard, my hoodie tied around my waist, and the sinking realization that I’m officially alone in a city that smells like sugar, piss, and something fried. “Great,” I mutter. “Perfect. Flawless execution, Taylor.” My phone: 12%. I thumb the screen like I can intimidate it into charging itself. No service for the first few seconds. Then a bar. Mom’s last text, still unread from last night: “Where ARE you. Call me NOW.” No “sweetheart.” No “we’re worried.” Just NOW in caps, like I’m her missing homework assignment. I lock the screen. Screw it. People swarm around me, bright shirts, jean shorts, tote bags. A guy plays trumpet on the corner, brass notes curling through the heat. A woman is yelling at some dude about a scam tour ticket. Everyone is so… loud. So alive. So not Harrison, Tennessee. I start walking because standing still makes me feel like a target. The French Quarter is like Instagram threw up: balconies with ferns and peeling paint, beads tangled in telephone wires, street artists, tarot readers, tourists drunk on daiquiris even though it’s barely past ten. I follow the shade wherever I can find it. My T-shirt clings to my back. I’m aware, suddenly and sharply, of my body: the angles of it, the ways it does and doesn’t match how I want to be seen. I tug my hoodie tighter around my waist even though I’m dying in the heat, like that’ll fix anything. “Yo! Board kid!” I turn. A lanky person a couple years older than me is perched on an overturned milk crate outside a corner store. Shaved sides, dyed blue curls on top, nose ring, chipped black nail polish. Tank top, sports bra strap visible. They look androgynous in a way that makes something warm and aching twist behind my ribs. A skateboard leans against their leg. “Nice deck,” they say, nodding at my board. “You look lost as shit.” “I’m good,” I say automatically. They snort. “That what you tell kidnappers too?” I hug my backpack strap. “Do you lure all your victims with skate compliments, or am I just special?” Their grin widens. “Special, clearly. I’m Pax.” Of course their name is Pax. It fits, annoyingly well. “Taylor,” I say. They stand, stretch, nod toward the store. “You got money? Don’t buy anything here, dude’s a dick, charges tourists triple. There’s a place with two-dollar coffee a couple blocks off Decatur. You look like you need two-dollar coffee.” I definitely do not have “just following strangers” on my smart choices bingo card. But I also don’t have a plan, a charger, or a better option. And Pax’s eyes are sharp, but not mean. Curious, not hungry. And they called me “dude” without squinting at my face to double-check. Internal Risk Assessment, brought to you by my famously stellar decision-making: - Option A: say no, wander aimless, die of heatstroke and anxiety. - Option B: say yes, get murdered, or maybe just get coffee. I hitch my backpack higher. “Lead on.” Pax rolls their board beside me instead of riding. Points for solidarity. We cut away from the fancy balconies into a quieter street, less shiny, more real. Sidewalk cracked, graffiti layered thick. “How long you been in town?” Pax asks. “Like… fifteen minutes.” I cringe at how pathetic that sounds. “Damn,” they say, impressed. “Fresh off the truck. You hitch in?” “Yeah.” “With who?” “Guy with too many air fresheners and a Jesus fish. Dropped me the second he realized Bourbon Street doesn’t literally sell bibles.” Pax cackles. “Welcome to New Orleans, Taylor. Land of bad decisions and worse smells.” “Comforting.” We duck into a narrow cafe that’s more like someone’s hallway with a coffee machine. There’s a handwritten menu on cardboard, two customers, and a bored girl at the counter scrolling on her phone. The AC is weak but still feels like heaven. I stare at the prices; my brain does anxious math. I’ve got $87 total, stuffed in my backpack. Plus my phone at 12%, glaring at me. Pax slaps a five on the counter. “Two iced coffees, extra ice.” “I can pay,” I say, defensive. I hate owing people. I hate feeling like a charity case. Pax shrugs. “You pay next time, if there is a next time.” “Planning my death already?” “Nah,” they say. “Just realistic.” We get our drinks, sweating plastic cups for two sweating people. We slide into a tiny table in the corner. Pax glances at my backpack. “You running from something?” Very casual. Like asking if I’m from out of town. I sip my coffee, brain buzzing with sugar and caffeine and panic. “Maybe,” I say. “Cool,” Pax says. “Me too. We can be mysterious together.” Silence, but it’s not awful. Pax pulls out their phone, which has a cracked screen and a charging cable so frayed it’s mostly vibes. I try to be subtle about checking my battery. 9%. “Shit,” I breathe. Pax notices. Of course they do. “Lemme guess. No charger?” I nod. “There’s an outlet right there.” They jerk their chin at the wall. I stare at it. Empty. “Got nothing to plug in.” They dig in their backpack, produce a tangled cord. “Here. I’ll trade you for a drag of your existential crisis.” I blink. “What?” They grin. “Your whole vibe. It’s like… cinematic. I wanna know.” I should say no. Telling strangers things is how you end up in cautionary tales. But I plug my phone in anyway. Tiny lightning bolt. 8% but stabilized. It feels like buying time from the universe. “I came out,” I say. “Two nights ago. To my family.” Pax leans back, expression sobering. “Oh.” “Yeah.” I pick at the condensation ring on the table. “My mom cried. My stepdad called it a phase. My grandma asked if I ‘caught it off TikTok.’” I imitate her voice, brittle and sharp. “Then the school counselor called, like, ‘Your child’s exhibiting concerning behavioral patterns,’ and I realized if I stayed there, I’d just shrivel up and die or set something on fire. Or both.” “Both is metal,” Pax says. “So I left,” I finish. “Packed a bag, snuck out, caught a ride. Didn’t really think further than ‘away.’” My throat is tight. Saying it out loud makes it more real and more stupid at the same time. Pax taps their fingers on the table. “Taylor… I’m sorry your people suck.” “They don’t all suck,” I say quickly, automatic defense. “Mom’s just… she’s scared. And stubborn. And married to a guy who thinks Fox News is edgy. She’ll come around. Maybe. I don’t know.” “You text her?” Pax asks. I think of the unread messages. The voicemail I didn’t listen to. The possibility of an Amber Alert with my dumb yearbook photo. My chest caves in a little. “I can’t go back,” I say. “Not yet.” “Didn’t ask if you’d go back,” Pax says. “Just if you told her you’re alive.” “Well, that would ruin the drama,” I say, lighter than I feel. Pax watches me with this annoying kind of understanding. “My mom kicked me out,” they say. “When I was fifteen. Church said I was corrupting my sister. So. Different vibes. But similar channel.” The words land heavy. “That sucks.” “Yeah. Anyway. Been here a year. Off and on. There’s ways to get by.” Alarm bells. “Like… what kind of ways?” They smirk. “Relax. Not trying to recruit you into a cult.” Then their face shifts, serious. “Just… before you crash on some random dude’s couch for ‘a night’ in exchange for ‘company,’ maybe let me point you toward people who aren’t predators.” I swallow. Have absolutely thought about couch-surfing. Hate that I’m transparent. “You think I look that clueless?” I ask. Pax raises an eyebrow. “Okay,” I concede. “Fair.” They grab a napkin and a pen from their pocket like they do this all the time. Scrawl a name and address. “Place called The Lantern,” they say. “Youth drop-in. Queer-friendly. No questions asked at the door. You can shower, charge your phone, talk to someone if you want, or don’t. They’ve saved my ass more than once.” “Is this like a shelter?” I ask, skeptical. “Sometimes. Sometimes it’s just air conditioning and people who use your name without being assholes about it.” The thought is so nice it makes my eyes sting. I look away. “What’s the catch?” I ask. Pax chews their straw. “Catch is you owe me one. A big, vague, non-legally-binding favor.” I narrow my eyes. “Like help you move a couch? Or like bury a body?” “Somewhere in between,” they say. They’re joking, but not all the way. I check my phone. 14%. A rush of relief. A buffer. Not salvation, but a cushion. “Why are you helping me?” I ask. Pax shrugs, suddenly serious. “’Cause someone did it for me. And you’ve got that look.” “What look?” “The one where you’re about ten minutes from doing something catastrophically stupid just so you don’t have to feel how scared you are.” I hate how seen I feel. I hate it and I kind of want to hug them and I also want to vanish. “Okay,” I say. “I’ll check it out.” Pax nods like they expected that. “I can walk you.” “You don’t have to babysit me.” “Yeah, but I want to see if you bail,” they say. “Science experiment.” We leave the cafe. The heat slams back into us. My hoodie is now a metaphor for all my terrible life choices. On the way, we pass a guy about my age sitting on the curb with a cardboard sign that says “Need bus fare HOME.” He looks sunburned and fragile. I wonder if he has one. A home, I mean. If he’ll actually go back if he gets the bus fare. “Watch him,” Pax murmurs. “He’s with this older dude who pockets the money. They’re running a sympathy op.” My stomach twists. “How do you know?” “Because I did that gig,” Pax says flatly. I glance at them. They stare straight ahead. I want to ask a million questions. I want to know everything they’ve done to survive, and I’m terrified I’ll recognize some future version of myself in it. We hit a quieter block. The Lantern is a squat brick building with a rainbow flag in the window and a sandwich board that says “YOU BELONG HERE” in chalk. The door is propped open. Cool air spills out. It looks… safe. Safe-adjacent, anyway. “I gotta bounce,” Pax says, stopping short of the door. “What? You’re not coming in?” The panic in my voice is embarrassing. “Nah. I got… other shit today.” They avoid my eyes. “They know me in there. Tell ’em Pax sent you. They’ll hook you up.” “Okay,” I say. I hitch my backpack, suddenly heavier. “Thanks.” “Hey, Taylor?” I look up. “For what it’s worth,” they say, “it’s not drama. You being you. Even if everyone back there acts like it is.” My throat goes tight. I nod. “For what it’s worth,” I say, “you’re a decent cult leader.” They grin, step back, and roll away, weaving into the city like they’ve got roots in the cracks. I stand on the sidewalk, staring into the shaded doorway. My heart’s pounding like I’m about to jump off a cliff. Internal Debate: - Go in: risk feelings, risk help, risk hoping. - Walk away: risk dying on the street or, worse, going back. My phone buzzes in my pocket. 1 new text. Mom: “Please. Just tell me you’re safe.” I stare at the words until they blur. Then I type: “I’m safe.” My fingers hover. I add: “I’m Taylor. Please try.” I hit send before I can take it back. My battery: 9%. Tiny, stupid acts of bravery. One after another. I pocket the phone. I step inside.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional authenticity in portraying a transgender teen runaway's first day in New Orleans. The writing successfully captures Taylor's voice through contemporary, believable dialogue and internal monologue that feels genuine rather than manufactured. The author skillfully balances vulnerability with defensive humor, creating a protagonist who feels real and multidimensional. The characterization is particularly strong. Taylor's internal contradictions - desperately needing help while fearing dependence, wanting connection while maintaining protective distance - ring true for a traumatized teenager. Pax serves as an effective foil, providing just enough backstory to feel authentic without overwhelming the narrative focus. Their interaction develops naturally from suspicion to tentative trust. The setting comes alive through sensory details that avoid cliché while still capturing New Orleans' distinct atmosphere. The author resists the temptation to over-romanticize the city, instead presenting it as both threatening and potentially liberating. Details like the humidity, the mix of tourists and street life, and the contrast between touristy areas and grittier streets feel observed rather than researched. The emotional complexity is handled with particular skill. Taylor's conflicted feelings about family, identity, and survival create genuine tension without melodrama. The text message exchange with their mother provides an effective emotional anchor that grounds the larger narrative in believable human stakes. However, some elements feel slightly convenient - Pax appearing at exactly the right moment with exactly the right knowledge and resources stretches credibility somewhat. The pacing occasionally rushes through potentially deeper moments, particularly around Pax's own backstory, which could have been developed more fully to avoid feeling like exposition. The prose style is generally strong, mixing sharp observational details with authentic teen voice. Some metaphors ("like Instagram threw up") work well, while others feel less organic. The internal "risk assessment" sections effectively convey Taylor's thought processes without becoming gimmicky. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between hope and uncertainty, avoiding false resolution while providing enough forward momentum to feel satisfying. Taylor's small acts of courage - going inside, texting their mother - feel earned rather than imposed. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16

+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 82.5
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
By mutual agreement—meaning Midas was talking to himself and Chewy was staring at him with one eye half-lit and unimpressed—the morning briefing began. “Today,” Midas said, “we do something simple.” Chewy’s left eye pulsed a faint skeptical amber. “Simple,” Midas repeated, in the firm, confident tone of a man who had never quite absorbed the lesson that the universe listened in on this sort of thing. They were in what had once been the sporting goods aisle of a megastore, now home base: tarps for walls, a curtain of tangled fishing line for doors, a roof of corrugated optimism. It did not leak. Much. Anything that didn’t leak much was a luxury these days. “The mission,” Midas said, “is bread.” Bread had acquired the mythic weight formerly reserved for quests involving dragons and rings. Flour, yeast, and something that might have once been olive oil had been scrounged; all that remained was salt—and not the damp, foot-flavored crystals they scraped off the sides of the old desal rigs. Real salt, from the pre-Collapse. Also, and this was new, the neighboring warlord-with-committee—a fellow calling himself Logistics Coordinator Grent—had decided he wanted batteries. “We give them salt, they give us batteries,” Midas said. “And then you don’t have to subsist on whatever sunlight lands on your stupid fuzzy face.” Chewy tilted his head. Both eyes flickered, a weak, glitching green: curiosity, hope, the digital equivalent of “go on, then.” The fur was patchy from smoke and time. One seam at his neck had been mended with iridescent fishing line, giving him the permanent look of having survived a duel with an unskilled knitter. “This is a trade mission,” Midas said. “Diplomacy.” He liked that word. It sounded civilized, unlike “raid” or “accident” or “Midas, what did you do.” Chewy’s right eye blinked aqua: skepticism. It sometimes meant other things, but with Chewy, skepticism was the statistical favorite. “The plan,” Midas continued, counting on his fingers, “is: walk to Grent’s depot, not touch anything that looks cursed, not insult anyone’s home-made insignia, not mention the incident with the propane parachute, and come back with a sack of salt and batteries for your noble little heart.” Chewy’s eyes pulsed a dignified lavender at “noble.” Compliment accepted. “Simple,” Midas said again. Chewy’s eyes rolled a quick red-yellow-red: the color of incoming narrative catastrophe. They left the safety of the Sports, stepping into the city’s skeleton. The pre-Collapse towers leaned together like conspirators comparing demolition notes. Vines had vandalized logos; crows had annexed surveillance cameras. Somewhere, something very large and herbivorous made a morose honking sound that suggested it had evolved poorly. Grent’s depot was only three kilometers away, which in post-technological terms was almost next door, assuming: - you avoided the sinkholes, - you respected the feral drones, - and you didn’t attract the attention of the Reclaimer cult, who believed all metal must be returned to the earth, ideally by removing it from your possessions and, if necessary, your bones. “So we go down Ninth,” Midas said. “No drone-nests, no Reclaimers, and the sinkholes are mostly mapped.” Chewy blinked soothing blue. Ninth was good. They turned onto Eighth. To be fair, the sign for Ninth had fallen off. To be even more fair, Eighth had a tremendous number of helpful arrows painted on the ground. Tragically, all of them were traps. Two blocks in, a hovering box the size of a doghouse drifted slowly down from a sagging balcony and emitted a cheery pre-Collapse jingle. Chewy’s eyes went instant red. “Midas,” said the box, in a voice with absolutely no business still being so upbeat, “congratulations! You’ve entered a Secure Retail Experience Zone!” “Oh no,” Midas said. “A marketing drone.” “Engaging customer!” the drone chirped, and fired a taser. Midas yelped. Chewy, for his part, chose this moment to reboot with a soft ascending chime, the words “FUNTIME COMPANION MODE” glitching across his chest speaker in a voice like strangled helium. “Non-compliant behavior detected!” sang the drone, winding up for shot number two. “Chewy,” Midas hissed, “distract it!” Chewy’s eyes flashed frantic rainbow, and his arms jerked up in an animatronic hug. The drone paused, interest pixels rearranging. “Emotional support asset detected. Initiating Cross-Promotional Cuddle Campaign.” It swept lower. Midas grabbed Chewy by the scruff and hurled him at the drone. It was not heroic, strictly speaking, but it was practical. Chewy slammed into the casing. Something inside the koala sparked an offended electric magenta. Something inside the drone made a noise like a blender meeting a spoon. The drone spasmed, belched a cloud of stale cinnamon-scented gas, and spiraled into a storefront window, exploding into a rain of ancient loyalty cards. Chewy landed on the pavement. Both eyes guttered, then settled to a dim, stubborn teal. “Okay,” Midas said, picking him up and patting his ashy fur. “That was a hiccup. We’re still on plan. Onward. Diplomacy.” They slogged on. The next problem, as was traditional, was human. At the intersection of Wrong Turn and Foreseeable Consequences, three Reclaimers stepped out, wearing patchwork robes sewn with bottle caps and keyboard keys. The tallest carried a crowbar scepter and an expression of serene menace. “Brother,” the tall one said, because Reclaimers believed all people were siblings, especially the ones they were about to rob, “metal yearns to be free.” “Same,” Midas said. “But we’ve got a diplomatic—” Chewy’s eyes flared hot yellow: incoming poor choice. “The artifact.” The tall Reclaimer pointed at Chewy. “Pre-Fall. Corrupted. Must be returned to the soil.” Midas clutched Chewy tighter. “He’s not metal,” he lied. “He’s… mostly fluff.” Chewy blinked hurt blue at “mostly fluff.” “Hand him over,” the Reclaimer said. Now, there are moments where rational calculation prevails, where prudence recommends tactical retreat and the wise survivor nods, compromises, and lives to scavenge another day. Midas punched him. It was not a very good punch. It landed somewhere between the Reclaimer’s jaw and religious convictions, but it was enough. Chaos, which had been fidgeting impatiently on the sidelines, leapt into the game. The next ninety seconds were a blur of: - one grabbed crowbar, - two shouted invocations to “Mother Rust,” - three tactical ducks that were more like panicked collapses, - and several entirely unnecessary but thematically appropriate curses. Chewy contributed by emitting at random: - a pre-programmed giggle track (unhelpful), - three bars of a children’s song about sharing (ironically on the nose), - and, finally, a shrill proximity alarm when a Reclaimer tried to pry open his battery compartment. Midas, operating on a mix of fear and bad instincts, swung Chewy like a blunt instrument. Chewy’s eyes went berserk disco: red-green-purple-white. The Reclaimer took a startled koala to the face and went down swearing eternal vengeance in the gentlest possible theological language. And then Midas ran. It was, in fairness, his best skill. He did not run toward Grent’s depot. He ran in the general direction of Away, which is a very big place. The Reclaimers pelted them with nuts, bolts, and small blessings with sharp edges. By the time he stopped under the shadow of a crushed overpass, panting, knees bleeding, Chewy was dim and silent. “Okay,” Midas said. “Assessment. We have: - angered a cult, - exploded a drone, - gotten no salt, - and are lost.” He looked at Chewy. “Also I hit someone with you. Sorry.” Chewy’s left eye flickered the exhausted beige of a machine reconsidering its life choices. “New plan,” Midas said. “Go home. Regroup. Pretend this was reconnaissance.” Home, as it turned out, had other opinions. They angled back by landmarks: the billboard mangled into a metal flower, the car stack, the dead fountain where frogs now held committee. The route was familiar enough that even Midas couldn’t significantly ruin it. Chewy’s navigation subroutine—long ago meant to guide shoppers to Toy Aisle Savings—pinged faint, helpful arrows across his own optic sensors. He nudged Midas’s collar with one soft paw at each turn. “There,” Midas said, spotting the frayed tarp roof of Sports. “See? Easy. Smooth. We’re practically professionals.” Then he saw the smoke. The entrance to their home base was charred. The fishing line curtain smoldered. Inside, the neat piles (well, relatively neat; meaning there was one pile that was not falling over) had been upended, their treasures rifled. “Grent’s boys,” Midas whispered. On a scorched pillar, someone had painted a tidy symbol: a crate with a crown. They’d come trading. Midas had gone wandering. They’d helped themselves. He stepped over their scattered gear. The flour was gone. The oil. The solar blanket. The emergency yo-yo. Chewy made a tiny, crackling sound and lifted his paw toward an empty spot where a hand-drawn sign had once read: “MIDAS & CHEWY’S STUFF (NO TOUCHING).” His eyes glowed low, furious red. “Oh, that is it,” Midas said. “That is absolutely—okay, technically this is my fault, but emotionally this is theirs.” He paced in a tight circle, then abruptly stopped. “New plan. Again. We get it back. Salt, batteries, our stuff. All of it.” He was bleeding from three places. His ribs hurt. His mission had not just failed; it had pirouetted into farce. He had almost gotten his only friend dismantled by people who prayed at scrap heaps. Chewy looked at him for a long moment. One eye flicked soft blue—affection. The other eye glowed determined, dangerous magenta. “Right,” Midas said. “Tomorrow.” He collapsed onto a surviving camping chair. Chewy climbed—or was placed—onto his lap and went still, humming faintly as his damaged circuits rationed their last reserves. Evening seeped into the wrecked store. Outside, something howled, something else laughed, and a drone somewhere tried to restart an eternal promotional event. Midas stared out through the gaps in the tarp at the bruised sky. “Today was simple,” he said. Chewy’s eyes, without opening fully, flashed once: bright, incredulous yellow. Midas snorted. “Fine. Tomorrow we complicate things on purpose.” He leaned back, closed his eyes, and let the ruins creak around them. They were, by several measures, worse off than they had been that morning: poorer, angrier, marked. But they were still, irritatingly for the universe, alive. And that was where trouble always had to start.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his wry humor, observational wit, and ability to find profound humanity in absurd situations. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both devastatingly real and absurdly comedic, much in the tradition of Pratchett's approach to serious themes. The characterization is particularly effective. Midas emerges as a genuinely sympathetic protagonist whose flaws feel authentic rather than contrived. His relationship with Chewy, an animatronic koala, could have been merely whimsical, but the author invests it with genuine emotional weight. Chewy's communication through colored eye-lights is creative and surprisingly expressive, allowing for a non-verbal character to have distinct personality and agency. The prose demonstrates considerable skill in balancing humor with pathos. Lines like "Bread had acquired the mythic weight formerly reserved for quests involving dragons and rings" perfectly capture Pratchett's ability to find epic significance in mundane concerns. The author maintains consistent voice throughout, never letting the comedy undermine the genuine stakes or emotional core. The plot structure follows the requested format effectively: setup, mission gone wrong, return home worse for wear. However, the escalating complications feel organic rather than forced. The marketing drone encounter and Reclaimer confrontation both arise naturally from the world-building and character choices. The world-building is economical but evocative. Details like "towers leaned together like conspirators comparing demolition notes" and the Reclaimers' theology around metal create a lived-in feeling without excessive exposition. The author shows restraint in not over-explaining the collapse or getting bogged down in apocalypse mechanics. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the Pratchett pastiche becomes slightly self-conscious, and a few descriptions that edge toward the overly clever. The pacing occasionally slows during descriptive passages, though this rarely detracts significantly from engagement. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - they're worse off materially but unchanged in spirit, setting up future adventures without false optimism. The final exchange between Midas and Chewy feels earned and authentic to their relationship. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 81.6
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The brass bell above the door gave a frantic jangle. “Sorry, we’re—” “Hide me.” Eira stopped mid-sentence. The man who’d just stumbled into Gŵyl y Llyfrau was all sharp cheekbones and expensive coat, hair tousled in a way that had definitely taken work. He twisted to peer through the glass of the front door, breathing hard. Outside, a cluster of people spilled from two black cars; camera lenses glinted in the drizzle. One of the paparazzi tried the handle. Locked. Thank God, Eira thought. She took him in properly. Yes, she knew that face. Everyone did. Rhys Hale: blockbuster films, rugby adverts, perfume billboards on Queen Street. Professionally irresistible. He turned to her quickly, flashing that famous grin as if flicking on stage lights. “I’ll buy a book,” he said. “Several books. Encyclopaedias. Just—hide me.” “We close at six,” Eira said, glancing at the old clock. “It’s six-oh-two.” “Time is a social construct,” he said. “The hiding is real.” He shrugged off his coat. Underneath: plain black T-shirt, leather wristband, chain at his neck. Casual, but calculated. He caught her looking and his smile sharpened just a fraction. “I don’t usually take hostages,” she said, “but you look like you’d cry if they caught you.” “I’m very stoic,” he said. “I just have beautiful tear ducts.” She snorted before she could stop herself. He pointed. “See? Progress already. Where can I be… inconspicuous?” “You?” Eira said. “Try the self-help section.” He put a hand to his chest. “Cruel. Accurate, but cruel.” He ducked down behind a bookcase anyway, crouching between “Health & Wellbeing” and “History – Local.” Eira crossed to the door and flipped the sign to CLOSED properly, then drew the curtain halfway, leaving a small strip where she could watch the pavement. The photographers fanned out, peering into shopfronts. One rapped the glass. “You seen Rhys Hale come through?” Eira stepped closer, smile polite. “No. Why? Misplace him?” A huff. Another tried the handle again. “If he comes in, call us. Big money in it.” “A bookshop betraying its customers?” she said. “That’s sacrilege. We only sell out for first editions.” They eventually drifted away, the rain sweeping them down the street. She waited an extra minute, hand still on the door. Behind her, a voice murmured, “I’m not sure whether to be wounded or turned on by that.” She startled; he’d moved silently, now leaning against a shelf with the easy carelessness of someone who assumed they belonged in every frame. “You can go now,” she said. “Looks clear.” “Right,” he said, but he didn’t move. His gaze swept the shop: leaning towers of paperbacks, a chalkboard with “Poetry Night Friday” scrawled on it, a teapot perched on a stack of old crime novels. “It’s… nice,” he said. “Like a set from a film where someone has feelings and reads worn-out copies of—” he grabbed blindly, flipped the cover—“Tipping the Velvet. Christ. Okay. Bold.” Eira made a face. “Sorted stacks. That’s the overflow for the queer lit display. You’re in the future classics.” “Bit presumptuous, calling them that.” “We stock your autobiography next to them,” she said. “Balances out the hubris.” He laughed, quick and bright. Then, too quickly, “You’ve read it?” “No.” He blinked. “Oh. Right. You just… shelve it in good conscience anyway?” “I run a bookshop in Cardiff, Mr Hale,” she said. “I’d be disowned if I didn’t carry the hometown hero’s ghost-written confessional.” “Not ghost-written,” he said, reflexive. “I mean, edited, sure, but those are my words.” He heard himself. Winced. “Wow, listen to me. Defensive about my paperback.” “Bit touchy for someone stoic with beautiful tear ducts,” she said. “I contain multitudes.” He pocketed his hands, leaning further into the persona. “So you do recognise me.” “Again: Cardiff. Also, you are thirty feet tall on the Vue cinema wall.” He relaxed, smile widening, like a plant turned to the sun. “Ah, thank God. For a second I thought I’d lost it. The fame. The… oh, don’t look at me like that.” “Like what?” “Like I’m a tragic clown balloon slowly deflating over St. Mary Street.” “That’s very specific.” “Ha. There she is again. You can pretend you’re immune, love, but you’ve laughed twice. That’s a fifty percent approval rating, minimum.” “Statistically unsound,” Eira said. “Sample size too small.” “So increase it. Keep talking to me.” She crossed her arms, which unfortunately only made her aware she was still wearing her ink-smudged cardigan and one ridiculous sock with tiny books on it. “Are you always like this?” she asked. “The relentless… thing?” “Charming?” he offered. “Performative.” He faltered for half a heartbeat. “It’s a survival mechanism,” he said lightly. “Like camouflage. Or venom.” “Now we’re getting somewhere,” she said. Rhys tilted his head. “You’re very calm. Most people scream, or ask for a selfie, or tell me their cousin’s dog loved my Netflix series.” “Should I fetch a fainting couch?” she said dryly. “I’d never say no to a fainting couch. Really sells the whole tortured artiste vibe.” He moved toward the counter. “What’s your name?” She hesitated. “Eira.” “Eira,” he repeated, wrapping his tongue around the vowels properly. “Snow. Very on-brand for someone giving me the cold shoulder.” “Oh, you think that was clever,” she muttered, but it was, annoyingly. He studied her, seeking the spark of delight he was used to igniting. She looked back, level and unimpressed. Inside, her heart was doing an undignified little trip; up close, his eyes were unfair, fringed and lighter at the edges, his razor-cut charm undercut by a near-boyish hope. “What’s your actual emergency, Mr Hale?” she asked. “Lost the ability to walk unphotographed for five minutes?” “I was having coffee,” he said. “A table of lads tried to film me eating a croissant like it was a nature documentary. ‘The actor in his natural habitat.’” He slipped into a mocking narrator voice. “‘Watch how he pretends the carbs don’t count.’ So I bolted. Ended up here. The sign said ‘Local & Loved’ and I thought, oh good, my people.” “That’s for the shop,” Eira said. “We’ve been here thirty years. Some of us earn the title.” “Ouch. All right. You’ve definitely read the book now.” She smiled, small and quick, then looked down, annoyed at herself. Rhys pounced. “There. That. People usually give me at least ten seconds of adoration without a sarcastic disclaimer. You’re messing with my metrics.” “You can add it to your next memoir,” she said. “‘Chapter Eight: The Day a Woman in a Cardiff Bookshop Did Not Instantly Worship Me.’” “She’s already in chapter titles. This is progress,” he said. “So, Eira-who-doesn’t-worship-me, what do you recommend?” “For your ego?” “For reading,” he said. “Obviously. For my ego I have Twitter. And mirrors.” He expected a laugh. She just raised an eyebrow. It unnerved him more than any heckler. “For reading,” she said slowly. “Okay. What do you like?” “Me,” he said instantly. “I’m joking. I read scripts. Biographies sometimes. History, if it’s got battles and brooding.” “No romance?” “I live it,” he said with a wink. She didn’t laugh. Inside, she noted: of course you do. Out loud: “Nothing where people talk to each other like actual humans. Check.” He pushed a hand through his hair. “You’re brutal.” “You’re not used to anyone telling you no.” “I get told ‘no’ all the time,” he protested. “By directors. By casting. By… my therapist.” “Your therapist says no?” “She says I equate likeability with worth,” he said flippantly, then seemed to realise he’d said too much. His shoulders tightened. “Anyway. Fun little overshare. Book, please.” Eira paused. That had slipped past the performance. “All right,” she said more gently. “Come on.” She led him into the aisles. The shop felt smaller with him in it; his presence filled all the dusty corners. “You want something where people talk like humans,” she said. “Which means no one has a perfect jawline and a tragic monologue in the rain. Sorry.” “I like rain,” he said. “I’m Welsh. It’s genetically embedded.” “Do you ever switch it off?” she asked abruptly. He blinked. “What?” “The… thing. The charming, puppy-in-an-advert thing.” He opened his mouth; his default line queued up automatically. She watched him, waiting. For once, someone wasn’t inviting the performance. They were questioning it. He swallowed. “If I switch it off,” he said lightly, “and you don’t like what’s underneath, that’d be a bit devastating, wouldn’t it?” “Why?” she asked. “You’ll leave in ten minutes. Go back to your cameras. I’ll still be alphabetising dead Russians. Low stakes.” “Low stakes for you,” he said. “For me it’d ruin my whole bookshop fantasy.” Eira blinked. “You have a bookshop fantasy.” “Of course. Everyone does.” “No,” she said. “Everyone has a bakery fantasy. Wrong carbs.” “Fine. Adaptable fantasy. There’s a bell. There’s rain. There’s someone clever behind the counter who sees the real me, et cetera, et cetera.” He tried to smirk it away, but the words rang truer than he’d meant. Heat crept up Eira’s neck. She turned to the shelf to hide it, pulling out a slim novel. “Here,” she said. “Local author. Complicated people, quiet moments. Nobody saves the world. Some of them save themselves.” He took it, brushing her fingertips by accident. Not entirely accident. A tiny current; he felt her flinch, saw her pretend she hadn’t. “You like it?” he asked. “Yes.” “Will I?” “Maybe,” she said. “If you’re not all gloss.” He looked at the cover instead of her. “How much?” “For you? Ten ninety-nine. And anonymity.” He smiled, softer now. “Anonymity is extra. I can’t afford it.” “You can owe me,” she said before thinking. Their eyes met. The joke hung between them, suddenly not entirely a joke. “What, like an IOU?” he said quietly. “Good for one rescue from unwanted photographers… or coffee?” “That escalated,” she said, heart banging. “Also, you give yourself the starring role even in hypothetical debts. Classic.” “I’m very on-brand,” he said. “But… coffee. Not now. Another day. When I can walk down the street without a SWAT team of Nikon lenses.” “Assuming I want coffee,” she said. “You don’t?” Eira opened her mouth to say no. To say she didn’t do complicated, exposed people who trailed chaos in their wake. Instead she said, “I don’t drink coffee after four. It ruins my sleep.” He grinned, sensing the crack. “Great, I’m free most mornings.” “That was not an invitation.” “I heard a door opening,” he said. “Might’ve been metaphorical.” Behind them, the rain intensified, drumming on the glass. He looked toward the window. The pavement was empty now but for a busker packing up. “You’re clear,” she said. “I’d lend you a disguise, but you’d stretch my cardigans.” “I look incredible in cardigans,” he said automatically. Then, more quietly: “Thank you. For not selling me out.” “Bad for business,” she said. “The Local & Loved thing.” “I am local,” he said. “Loved is still under review.” He laughed, but it was gentler, less sharp. “Fair enough. I’ll work on my sample size.” “Don’t,” she said quickly. He cocked his head. “No?” She thought: Yes. Aloud: “You’ve got enough people loving you on autopilot. Try going home without converting the last holdout.” “I wasn’t trying to convert,” he lied. She lifted a brow. He sighed. “I was trying a bit. It’s—habit.” “Get a new one,” she said. “Start with reading that.” He tapped the book against his palm. “If I like it, can I come back and tell you?” “You can leave a thoughtful online review like everyone else,” she said. “Brutal,” he murmured. “And if I hate it?” “Then I misjudged you,” she said. “Which might be a relief.” His smile flickered. “I hope you didn’t.” She hesitated, then unlocked the door. Rhys slipped his coat back on, mask of the rogue settling as if by muscle memory. Hand on the handle, he glanced back. “I’m Rhys, by the way,” he said, as if she hadn’t known from the first second. “I know,” she said. “Right,” he said. The grin crooked. “Just in case you wanted to put a name on the IOU you’re definitely not keeping track of.” “Goodnight, Mr Hale,” she said. He stepped out into the rain, shoulders squaring, charm brightening for the street like another set of lights coming on. Through the pane, Eira watched him pull up his hood, tuck the book under his arm, and walk away fast, alone. Only when he turned the corner did she let out the breath she’d been holding. “Idiot,” she told herself softly, not sure which of them she meant. Behind her, on the counter, his receipt curled as it cooled, blank on the signature line.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and adherence to the prompt requirements. The author successfully creates the requested Welsh bookstore setting and establishes the paparazzi-escape scenario that brings the characters together. The dialogue-heavy approach works well, with each character maintaining distinct voices throughout - Rhys's performative charm punctuated by moments of vulnerability, and Eira's dry wit masking her growing attraction. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Rhys emerges as genuinely complex - his need for validation feels authentic rather than manufactured, and his charm offensive genuinely derails when met with Eira's resistance. The author skillfully shows his fragile ego through dialogue choices and reactions rather than exposition. Eira's character is equally well-drawn; her superficial immunity to his charm while being inwardly affected creates the requested tension effectively. The prose strikes a good balance between literary quality and accessibility. Descriptions are economical but evocative - "camera lenses glinted in the drizzle" and "like a plant turned to the sun" work without being overwrought. The pacing maintains engagement throughout, with natural escalation from initial encounter to tentative connection. The dialogue crackles with wit and subtext. Lines like "Time is a social construct. The hiding is real" and "You can owe me" feel natural while advancing both plot and character development. The banter serves multiple purposes - establishing personality, building attraction, and maintaining reader interest. However, some elements feel slightly predictable within the romance genre framework. The "famous person meets normal person" setup, while well-executed, follows familiar beats. Additionally, a few moments of Rhys's vulnerability feel slightly rushed in their revelation, though they don't derail the overall characterization. The ending strikes an appropriate note - connection established but not resolved, maintaining tension for the larger story this scene inhabits. The final image of the blank receipt signature line is a nice touch that avoids overwrought symbolism while providing closure to the scene. The Welsh setting feels authentic without being heavy-handed, and the approximately 1000-word length is well-utilized without feeling cramped or meandering. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
