+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 80.9
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hinges did not creak. That bothered Aya. The iron door sighed inward on invisible counterweights, smooth as a stage curtain. The air that spilled out was cold as a flooded crypt and heavy with oil, salt, and a faint metallic tang she knew too well but refused to name: spilled blood, old and iron-sweet. “After you,” Simeon whispered, his usual drawl clipped tight. “Ladies first,” Katra muttered. Aya felt fingers brush her elbow, a brief, conspiratorial squeeze. They stepped over the threshold into the underhold. The chamber beyond had been carved long ago from black stone veined with sea-slick salt. Vaulted arches rose like the ribcage of some drowned leviathan, bolted with girder-braces of green-cankered brass. Gas lamps crouched along the walls in ornate cages, their mantles guttering with a jaundiced glow that threw restless shadows into the hollows between support beams. Pipes—fat and sweating—ran like entombed pythons overhead, the steady thrum of pump-engines far above filtering down like a mechanical heartbeat. At the far end of the chamber: the reliquary. It grew out of the floor, rather than sat upon it. A pod of fused bone and oxidized copper, its spires curling upward, entwined with lengths of whale-bone etched in Scythan script. Along its shell were embedded small glass ports that showed nothing but darkness, as though looking into wells sunk through the floor of the world. Rivets like empty eye sockets ringed its seams. Around it, sigils had been burned directly into the stone, blackened grooves glistening with something that smoked faintly, even in the cold. “Rust take me,” Simeon breathed. “That’s—” “Don’t name it,” Aya snapped, too quickly. Her voice bounced off the stone, thin and brittle. “We take it, we go, we breathe later.” Something moved behind the reliquary. Gaslight snagged on brass gorgets, on the oiled gleam of pistol barrels and the curved teeth of boarding hooks. A line of figures stepped out from behind the Scythan thing with quiet, drilled precision. Half a dozen, maybe more. Coats cut in the Morska fashion—high-collared, salt-stained, with whale-sinew stitching reinforced by steel rings. Their faces were half-masked in black leather. No one spoke. “Aya,” Katra murmured, voice almost tender. “I have an objection to this quiet.” Aya’s heart hammered once, hard. The underhold was never unguarded, but they had expected drunk men, dice games, the laxness of the hour. Not formation. Not poise. Not her. From behind the cordon of enforcers, a woman stepped into the lampglow, unhurried. Captain Marella Vance, Warden of Morska’s Deep Markets. Leader of the guild. The woman Aya had watched hauled away in manacles at dawn by the city constables, her hat knocked askew, her face bloody but smiling that wolfish smile. She looked better now. Her long coat, black as bilgewater, hung immaculate. Brass-buckled. The collar was lined with the white fur of some northern beast. Her hair—iron-grey, shorn close on one side, left to fall in loose waves on the other—framed high, sharp cheekbones. The only mark of the raid was a faint bruise at her temple, half-hidden by shadow, as if even injury had been forced to mind its manners. At her hip: a double-barrelled pistol with a mother-of-pearl grip. In her left hand: a narrow-bladed hanger that had tasted more than rope fibre. At her back: a cluster of her best, Aya recognized them with a sick lurch—Grigg the Harpooner, Jansa with the Clockwork Eye, soft-footed Noll whose nickname was “the Last Sound.” “A pretty little procession,” Marella said. Her voice carried, low and smooth, threaded with amusement. “Does my underhold now admit tourists?” Simeon’s hand twitched toward his coat. Three pistols came level with his heart in the same instant. He raised both palms, lips thinning. Katra’s stance shifted, feline, but she did not reach for the knife in her boot. Katra knew odds. Aya stood very, very still and wished that she felt any of the nonchalance she had practiced in the mirror. “You were taken,” Aya said. The words came out flatter than she liked. “We saw.” “Yes,” Marella said. “You did. I let them make a spectacle of it. Very educational.” She inclined her head. “For them.” The nearest gas lamp flickered and popped, casting Marella’s features into a grotesque mask for a heartbeat: teeth too white, eyes too dark. “They’re dead then,” Katra said. Casual, but Aya heard the calculation. “Some,” Marella said. “Some will have the pleasure of living with their mistake.” Aya’s mind spun. The raided safehouses, the whispers of traitors, the carefully timed absence of certain captains. A pattern assembled itself, each piece a tiny, mocking click. She played us. “Thought we’d move while the iron was hot,” Simeon said lightly. He stepped half in front of Aya, as if he could somehow make his slender frame absorb the room’s malice. “No offense meant, Captain. A misunderstanding in the fog of—” “Spare me the smoke,” Marella said. “You came for my heart.” Her gaze moved past him, fixing on Aya. There was recognition there. Too much of it. Aya felt an odd loosening at the base of her throat. She had chosen this. She had donned the mask, slipped from her father’s house to soil her gloves on other people’s gold, coaxed horrors from the Immateria for men who thought it simply a new kind of engine. It had thrilled her. It had made her feel, briefly, like a creature with teeth. Now Marella looked at her as if she were a ledger left open. “Ink,” Marella said. The nickname struck like a slap. Aya’s mask name. The one she used when the whale-barges came in heavy with bone and blubber and men desperate enough to buy a summoning to see their fortunes mended. Simeon swore, too soft for anyone but Aya and Katra. “So,” Marella went on. “Here you stand. My errant shade-summoner. And her two loyal barnacles.” Noll moved—Aya heard him rather than saw him, a soft sluicing of motion. Cold iron kissed the nape of her neck. Another man’s hand closed around her wrist, pinning it before she could reach inward, toward that invisible, forbidden seam in the world that led to the Immateria. “Don’t,” Marella said. Aya didn’t. A strip of rough cloth snaked around her throat from behind, then up over her jaw, pressing cruelly against the porcelain half-mask that covered her nose and cheeks. Fingers untied the mask’s ribbon. The porcelain slipped free, clattering on the stone. For a heartbeat, no one breathed. Gaslight revealed her. High cheekbones, like her mother’s. Mouth too full for Morska’s sharp faces. Eyes: grey, almost silver, with that faint inner sheen that only the very superstitious noticed and crossed themselves over. Her dark hair pinned in a style too careful for the gutters, loosened only slightly by their scramble through the upper corridors. Aristocrat, whispered every line of her. “Well,” Marella murmured. “There you are.” Katra’s facade cracked first. “Aya,” she hissed. It wasn’t a question so much as a condemnation. Simeon stared as if betrayed by geometry. “You…” he started. “Your father’s house on Seabright Row—those carriages—” “Lord Harron’s little darling,” Jansa crooned, her mechanical eye whirring almost hungrily. “The noose-hag’s whelp.” Aya flinched at that. Her mother swinging on the public gallows rose unbidden. The crowd jeering. The official proclamation: witch, immateria, unclean. “Careful,” Marella said mildly. “She’s worth more if her face is unmarked.” Aya found her voice somewhere under the shame. “You knew,” she said to Marella. “All this time.” “Of course,” Marella replied. “You think I’d let a magick-blooded noble girl pluck at the seams of my city without reading the name on her bones? You were an investment.” The word thudded dully. “And tonight,” Marella continued, stepping closer, “you decided to cash yourself out.” Iron bit into Aya’s wrists as they were wrenched behind her and bound. She heard Katra grunt, Simeon curse as they received the same treatment. “A tidy plan,” Marella said. “Use my distraction to pinch the Scythan relic, set yourselves up as new royalty in the stink-alleys. Creative. Ambitious. Stupid.” “We weren’t the only ones who thought you’d hang,” Katra said, chin lifting. “Constables had you on the ropes. Looked convincing.” “That was the point,” Marella said. Aya swallowed. The ropes burned. The room felt smaller, shadows crowding in, drawn like flies to the Scythan reliquary’s dark ports. She needed time. “Captain Vance,” she said, fighting to keep her voice even, aristocratic. The voice she’d learned at salons and hearings. A voice that made men listen even when they despised every syllable. “Marella.” “You’ve not earned my name,” Marella said. “Then the guild has not yet earned what I can still offer,” Aya shot back. Simeon flicked his eyes toward her. Katra’s jaw flexed once: Do it. Marella’s smile was faint, blade-thin. “Proceed. I could use a jest.” “You have in your possession,” Aya said, nodding—carefully—toward the relic, “a Scythan artifact so volatile your men won’t stand within three paces of it. The city wants your head. The Crown wants anything with runes carved in whale-bone buried under a cathedral. And you have me.” “Sharp recounting,” Marella said. “Conclusion?” “I am leverage,” Aya said. “Lord Harron’s daughter, with magick in her blood. The law already strung up one witch in our line. They won’t stomach losing another without spectacle. You keep me alive, you bargain with my father, with the Council, with the Black Office itself if you like. You trade me for papers, for passage, for blind eyes turned to your deeper trades. You let my friends walk out as proof of… goodwill.” “You offer yourself as hostage.” Marella sounded more intrigued than moved. Aya forced herself to meet the woman’s gaze. “I offer you a key that opens doors brass and gunpowder never will. The men upstairs trust gears. They trust machines. They fear what I am. Fear is a currency you can bank.” “The Black Office would as soon cut you open as bargain,” Marella said. “Find out how the Immateria wires itself into pretty flesh. Mount your skull in some lead-lined chapel.” “I know,” Aya said softly. The truth of it settled over her like wet wool. “Which is why I am very motivated to make myself too valuable to waste.” Marella studied her. Around them, the underhold thrummed: pipes ticking, gas mantles sighing, the relic’s dark ports hinting at movement that could have been a trick of the light—or shadows pressing against glass from the wrong side. Katra shifted, rope scraping. “She’s useful,” she said, quickly. “Not just as a bauble. You’ve seen what she pulls through. You’ve profited.” “Ungrateful,” Marella mused. “Conspiring to steal from me.” “You all but invited it,” Simeon said. “Leaving gaps. Whispering the relic’s song through the ranks. A proper captain tends her locks better.” A pistol butt drove into his gut for that. He folded, choking. “Enough,” Marella said, without looking away from Aya. “You want me to see your value. Very well. Display it.” Aya hesitated. Her wrists were bound in iron-linked cord. Cold, dulling. Not perfect, but blunting. The Immateria was close—she always felt it, like pressure before a storm—but calling to it down here, with the Scythan relic so near, with gas and whale-oil and blood in the air… If she reached, something might answer that wasn’t hers to command. Marella watched the calculation flicker across Aya’s face. “Exactly,” she said. “You’re a threat and a promise. Those make excellent hostages.” “So you’ll keep us alive,” Aya said. “To bargain.” The Captain’s expression softened into something almost kind. “You, Aya Harron, I’ll keep breathing. For a time.” She flicked her fingers; Noll’s grip on Aya tightened. “The barnacles… we shall see.” Aya’s stomach lurched. “You harm them,” she said, “and I swear—” “What?” Marella asked, stepping in so close Aya could smell salt and tobacco on her breath. “You’ll hex me? Call down your mother’s ghosts? Child, don’t threaten with a blade you’re not yet skilled enough to swing.” Aya tasted copper on her tongue. She thought of Katra’s laugh in the fog, Simeon’s quick fingers on lockpicks, the dizzy gleam of freedom when they’d first imagined themselves more than Marella’s shadows. She had led them here. “I will cooperate,” Aya said, the words ash. “You have my word.” “Your word,” Marella repeated thoughtfully. “Aristocrats do dote on those.” She nodded once to her enforcers. “Chain them,” she said. “Not too roughly. Ink’s face must be pretty when they come to buy her back.” The nearest gas lamp flickered again, guttering, then steadied. The shadows on the stone floor lengthened, crossing and recrossing until Aya could no longer tell which ones belonged to the men, which to the rafters, and which to things that pressed, patient and eager, against the thinning skin of the world.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This is a skillfully executed piece of creative writing that demonstrates strong technical proficiency and atmospheric worldbuilding. The author successfully creates a vivid "whalepunk" Victorian fantasy setting with gothic horror elements, employing rich sensory details and evocative imagery throughout. The opening line "The hinges did not creak" immediately establishes tension and Aya's analytical mindset. The worldbuilding is particularly strong, seamlessly blending industrial Victorian elements (brass, oil, gas lamps, mechanical pumps) with fantasy components (Scythan artifacts, Immateria magic, whale-bone inscriptions). The author creates a palpable sense of place in the underhold, with descriptions like "carved from black stone veined with sea-slick salt" and "vaulted arches rose like the ribcage of some drowned leviathan." Character voice and dialogue feel authentic to the setting. Marella emerges as a compelling antagonist - intelligent, calculating, and genuinely threatening without being cartoonish. Her revelation that she orchestrated her own arrest shows narrative sophistication. Aya's internal conflict between her aristocratic background and criminal aspirations creates meaningful tension, and her desperation when negotiating for her friends' lives feels genuine. The pacing builds tension effectively, moving from the eerie quiet of entry through revelation and confrontation to capture. The author handles exposition well, revealing Aya's noble background and magical heritage naturally through dialogue and reaction rather than heavy-handed exposition. However, there are some areas where the prose occasionally becomes overwrought. Phrases like "coaxed horrors from the Immateria for men who thought it simply a new kind of engine" and extended metaphors sometimes slow the pace. The ending, while atmospheric, edges toward purple prose with the elaborate description of shadows and "things that pressed, patient and eager, against the thinning skin of the world." The dialogue generally serves the characters well, though occasionally feels slightly formal even for the Victorian setting. Some exchanges between the companions could feel more natural and lived-in. The piece successfully avoids common pitfalls like unearned character transformations or incongruous tonal shifts. The darkness of the ending feels appropriate to the gothic horror elements and the characters' predicament. The author demonstrates good control over the narrative, maintaining tension while developing character relationships and advancing plot. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 78.8
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A lazy ceiling fan barely stirs the smoky air inside the bar. It clicks like it’s considering dying and decides it can’t be bothered tonight. Spike Spiegel leans against the counter, a cigarette loose between his fingers, one elbow planted on wood scarred by ash burns and knife cuts. Neon from the busted sign outside bleeds blue and red across his face, glinting off the faint cloudiness of his prosthetic eye. There’s an untouched glass of cheap whiskey in front of him. He stares through it like he’s trying to see another life on the other side. Door creaks. She walks in like trouble with a hangover. Shorts that probably violate several local ordinances, black crop top clinging to a torso built for recoil, dragon tattoo coiled down her arm like it’s ready to bite. Cigarette at the corner of her mouth, smoke curling around a face that looks carved out of bad decisions and worse memories. A pair of 9mm pistols ride low on her hips like they were born there. Revy clocks the room in one sweep. Dead eyes, live guns, stale smoke. Her gaze brushes over Spike, then stutters back. There’s a half-second of something like recognition—not of him, of his type. The tall, lazy ones. The killers pretending not to be. She snorts. He smiles, slow and sideways. “They let kids in here now?” he asks. She pads over, metal from her boots ticking on the floorboards. “Keep talking, scarecrow,” she says. “See if I don’t ventilate that pompadour.” Spike glances at her guns. “Pompadour survived worse than nine-mils, Two Hands.” Her eyes narrow. “So you know me.” “Employer mentioned you.” He finally picks up the whiskey, swirling it. “Also, you’re loud. Word travels.” She drags on her cigarette, amused despite herself. “Yeah? What’d they tell you?” “That I’d have competition.” He raises his glass to her. “Didn’t say she’d be cute.” Her lip twitches. Not quite a smile. “They tell you it’s my bounty?” “They told me it’s my bounty,” Spike says. “Guess somebody double-booked.” She exhales smoke right at his face. He doesn’t flinch. Just lets it fold into his own. “Then we got a problem,” Revy says. “Looks like.” He swallows the whiskey in one shot. It’s bad enough to bring tears; he looks like he might welcome them, just for the excuse. The bartender pretends to polish a glass and pretends harder not to listen. Revy orders rum, doubles it without asking. She drains half, wipes her mouth with the back of her hand, and looks Spike over like she’s measuring distance, angles, exit wounds. “You the one they call ‘Cowboy?’” she asks. “Sometimes.” He taps out another cigarette. “Depends who’s paying.” She smirks. “Heard you’re supposed to be dead.” “Yeah,” Spike says. “I heard that too.” Their bounty sits in a cracked-leather booth at the back—big guy, black jacket, nervous eyes, trying very hard to be invisible and failing at it. There’s a gun under his coat. There’s always a gun. Revy’s eyes flick that way. Spike’s already seen him. They both know the count, the exits, the likely crossfire. “So here’s how it goes,” Revy says. “You walk away, space cowboy. I take him. Everyone lives. Well. Except him.” She smiles, bright and mean. Spike’s lazy gaze hides a blade. “I’m broke, hungry, and my ship drinks more fuel than you do rum. Not walking away.” “I can make you,” she says. He raises his cigarette, lights it off the dying butt. “Whatever happens, happens.” It pisses her off that it sounds cool. Their client said: no bodies except the bounty, no collateral, high payout. He also said each was hired “exclusively.” Revy’s jaw tightens at the memory. “Motherfucker played us,” she mutters. “Lots of that going around,” Spike says. “We could share.” She barks a laugh. “What is this, some Saturday morning team-up special? I don’t share.” “Money’s just money.” Spike shrugs. “We split it. Nobody loses.” “I don’t split kills,” Revy says. “I earn mine.” “And I’m supposed to what? Be impressed?” he says, but his eye has that amused glint now. Interested glint. Her fingers drum her glass. She’s reconsidering, but pride’s a nasty habit. “I’ll outshoot you,” she says abruptly. Spike exhales smoke toward the ceiling fan. “Sure.” “Loser walks,” she says. “Winner takes the bounty.” He tilts his head. “What’d you have in mind?” Her grin goes wolfish. She spins one of her pistols out, pops a round over her shoulder without looking. The bullet shatters an empty bottle on the far shelf. The bar goes silent for one long moment. Then the low murmur picks up like everyone agreed not to notice. Spike’s eyebrows climb. “Parlor tricks.” “Top that,” she says. Spike sighs, slides off his stool. He doesn’t draw yet. Walks over to the busted jukebox humming in the corner. Taps it. It sputters to life for half a breath of tinny jazz, then fizzles back to dead. He turns, cigarette dangling, and in one fluid, lazy-seeming motion, he draws his Jericho and puts two shots so close through the center of the “No Smoking” sign above the bar that the letters “NO” disintegrate. He holsters without looking, goes back to his drink. “You missed,” Revy says, but it’s thin. “Sign’s more honest now,” Spike says. She wants to be mad. Mostly she’s turned on. The bounty in the booth decides this is his moment to try and slip out. Both their heads turn. “Shit,” Revy says. “Kids these days,” Spike murmurs. The guy bolts for the back door, coat flapping. Revy is moving before thought—gun out, barstool knocked over, boots thudding. Spike cuts sideways, lithe, a sharp pivot of long legs and casual grace. The bar erupts in shouts. The bounty shoves the rear door open and crashes into the humid alley night. Revy hits the door second. Spike’s right beside her. “Get out of my way!” she snarls. “Ladies first,” he says, sweeping his arm. She’s already through. The alley is narrow, wet with something you don’t want to name. The bounty fumbles his gun out, fires wild. Revy doesn’t duck. Her body just leans; bullets pass where she was. She returns fire—controlled, precise, three rounds that stitch the guy’s arm to the wall through his coat. He screams, gun clattering. Spike is on him the next breath, gun up, voice calm. “Bounty says alive, pal. Don’t make her forget.” Revy’s breathing hard, pupils bright. Every nerve singing. Spike can feel her focus like heat. “You tagged him first,” Spike says. “Congrats.” She glares. “Oh, so you’re gonna play nice now?” “Already did,” he says. “Still wanna fight over it?” Her instinct says yes. Her legs say yes. The math says no. Backup could be coming. Employer’s a snake. Too many unknowns. “Fine,” she spits. “We take him in together, split the cash.” He nods once. “Whatever happens, happens.” They move in sync without intending to. Cuff the bastard. Strip his weapon. Spike drags him up; Revy pushes. The guy whimpers. “Walk,” she says, jamming the barrel against his back. They haul him out to the parked car the contact arranged, dump him in, trade a few terse words and a tracking code with the middleman who’s sweating bullets at the sight of them both alive and unsatisfied. When it’s done, the payout dings both their accounts. Not as much as promised. It never is. Revy stands by the flickering motel sign across from the bar, scrolling the numbers. “Cheap-ass prick shorted us.” “Us,” Spike notes. “I’m touched.” “Don’t be,” she says. “I’m gonna shoot him later.” “Get in line,” he says. The motel is the kind of place that charges by the hour and doesn’t ask for names. Spike booked a room to crash; she was going to find one anyway. “You following me?” he asks, as they end up at the same cracked door, same peeling number. “You wish,” she says. “They only had one room left.” He looks at the single key in his hand. “Lucky us.” “Open it or I’ll open it,” she says, tapping her gun. He unlocks it, pushes the door. Room smells like stale sweat and bleach. One bed. One chair. Flickering TV. Thin walls humming with someone else’s bad life next door. She steps in. He closes the door. For a moment, it’s quiet. The shift is small, but everything moves. Revy’s hand slides, almost casual, toward her holster. Spike’s weight shifts, coat whispering as he turns. His gun’s not drawn, but his fingers are close. “We didn’t talk about the rest of the terms,” she says. “Didn’t know there were any,” he replies. “We split the money. No one died who wasn’t supposed to. Happy ending.” “Don’t believe in those,” she says. He smiles, faint. “Yeah. Me neither.” Her eyes are on him like scopes. “So what’s your angle, Cowboy? You gonna try and ghost with my half? You working some other side deal?” “Paranoid,” he says. “Alive,” she snaps. He steps closer, slow. No sudden moves. His cigarette ember paints a small orbit in the dim. “I’m not here to screw you over,” Spike says. “Employer already did that. Kind of redundant.” She laughs, humorless. “Guys like you always got some tragic code. You’ll sell it out when the bullets start flying.” “Maybe,” he admits. It disarms her more than denial would. She lifts her pistol, just enough. “Gun on the bed,” she says. Spike regards her. There’s heat between them now, gasoline waiting for a spark. She smells like smoke and gun oil and cheap rum. Dangerous things he never learned to stay away from. He unclips the holster, places the Jericho on the bedspread. Raises his hands, palms open. “Happy?” “No,” she says. But her arm doesn’t lower. “You trust anyone?” he asks. “Trust gets you killed,” she says. “That your famous line about being dead already? That supposed to impress me?” “Just saves time,” Spike says. They’re close enough that if she pulled the trigger, the powder burns would mark his shirt. Close enough that if he stepped in, he could take her wrist, slam her to the wall, kiss her or disarm her or both. She sees his footing. Knows exactly how he’d do it. Part of her wants to try him. “Two Hands,” he says softly. “You gonna shoot me or strip me?” “Keep talking like that,” she says, pulse stuttering, “and find out.” The TV flickers blue across their faces. Her finger tightens a fraction. His eye never leaves hers. The room hums with all the things that could happen. He says, very quietly, “Whatever happens, happens.” Her jaw flexes. For one long, electric second, she doesn’t know which impulse will win—put a hole in him or drag him down onto that filthy mattress and see if his mouth is as smart there. The tension is a gunshot that never goes off. She lowers the pistol one inch. Not safety, not surrender. Just…postponement. “Don’t touch my cut,” she says. “Wouldn’t dream of it,” he answers. She doesn’t holster. He doesn’t pick up his gun. Outside, the neon flickers. Inside, they stand in stalemate, two wolves in a too-small den, attraction and mistrust coiled tight, knowing the night isn’t done with either of them.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric writing that effectively captures the noir aesthetic of both source materials. The author successfully creates a tense, sexually charged encounter between two well-known anime characters while maintaining their core personalities and speech patterns. The characterization is particularly strong. Spike's laid-back fatalism comes through in lines like "Whatever happens, happens" and his casual approach to danger, while Revy's aggressive, paranoid nature is evident in her constant readiness for violence and mistrust. The dialogue feels authentic to both characters, with Spike's dry wit contrasting nicely against Revy's crude directness. The pacing builds effectively from their initial meeting through the bar confrontation to the motel standoff. The action sequence in the alley is well-choreographed and shows both characters' competence without making either seem significantly superior. The sexual tension is palpable throughout, particularly in the final motel scene where the author skillfully balances attraction with mutual wariness. The prose style is generally strong, with evocative descriptions like "She walks in like trouble with a hangover" and "attraction and mistrust coiled tight." The author effectively uses short, punchy sentences to create rhythm and tension, particularly during confrontational moments. However, there are some weaknesses. Certain descriptions veer toward purple prose territory - "smoke curling around a face that looks carved out of bad decisions and worse memories" being somewhat overwrought. The piece occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly in exposition about the characters' backgrounds and motivations. The ending feels somewhat abrupt and unresolved, though this may be intentional given the prompt's emphasis on "unresolved sexual tension." The standoff maintains the tension effectively but doesn't provide much narrative satisfaction. Some metaphors and descriptions feel slightly forced, and there are moments where the prose becomes overly stylized at the expense of clarity. Overall, this is a competent piece of fan fiction that successfully captures the essence of both characters while creating an engaging scenario that feels true to their respective universes. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16

+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 80.5
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Thick mist clung to the edges of the burial mound, glowing under the moonlight like something alive, something exhaling. Astrid said it was a good sign. “Means it’s awake,” she whispered. “The jordröster like nights like this.” I hugged my jacket closer, glove seams tight between my fingers. It was mid-October but felt like deeper winter to me, all sharp air and wet wool. Stockholm had autumn; up here in Västerbotten it seemed they went straight from summer mosquitoes to frozen breath. “Jordröster,” I repeated, rolling the word on my tongue like a foreign phrase. Earth-voices. Astrid nodded once, blonde braid down her back, as if she were discussing homework and not invisible things in the soil. “They’ve always been here. The mound’s older than the church. Older than Sweden. Don’t stare at the mist too long or you’ll start seeing faces.” “I already see faces,” I muttered, because I was sixteen and pretending not to be afraid was muscle memory. She smirked, the quick, satisfied twitch I’d come to recognize in the three months since I’d met her. Astrid liked finding the boundary where I stopped laughing and started glancing over my shoulder. “Come on. We have to get set up before it’s exactly midnight.” The mound rose from a clearing ringed by crooked birches and damp stone walls. By day it was just an odd grassy hump, something a bored archaeology student had once put a sign next to. By night, with nothing but the pale moon and our cheap flashlights, it looked wrong, like the earth had swollen. I’d told my parents I was sleeping at Astrid’s. Her dad had grunted when we slipped out at eleven, eyes still on the TV. In Stockholm my mother would at least have called after us from the hallway. Out here no one even asked where the girls went at night. Astrid knelt at the base of the slope and pulled off her backpack, the faded Coca-Cola logo nearly worn away. She emptied it with efficient, ritualistic movements: two candles, a chipped enamel cup, a thermos, a packet of sea salt, a folded red cloth, and a small, dark bottle with no label. “What’s that?” I asked, nodding at the bottle. “Tar,” she said. “From far back in the forest. Mor-mor showed me where you can still get it the old way.” “Why do we need tar?” She gave a little shrug. “So the dead know we’re serious.” I laughed, expecting her to. She didn’t. “Is this… actually old?” I asked, careful to keep my tone half-teasing. She twisted the thermos open, poured steaming black coffee into the enamel cup, and breathed in the smell like it was incense. “Útiseta is old,” she said. “Older than church, older than the stupid sign down there. We keep watch. We sit out. We listen. If they want to talk, they talk.” “And if they don’t?” She glanced up at me, eyes catching the moonlight, pale gray and flat. “Then we’re just two bored idiots freezing our asses off. Which we would be anyway.” It was the kind of answer that always kept me hooked—reasonable and crazy at the same time. That was Astrid’s balance: making ancient things sound like dares, not devotions. She stood and walked the circumference of the mound, sprinkling salt from the packet and muttering under her breath. The birch trees loomed, their white trunks ghost-pale in the mist. “What are you saying?” I asked. “Names,” she said. “Border stuff. So if something comes, it stays up here, doesn’t follow us down.” My stomach tightened. “You’re joking.” Astrid squinted at me. “Do you want me to be?” I opened my mouth and then closed it, hearing my breath in the quiet. Somewhere far off, a dog barked once. The village was a cluster of weak yellow lights down the hill, cut off by trees. No cars on the road. No city hum. Just us, the mound, the mist. “Help me,” she said. We spread the red cloth at the flattest part of the slope, near the summit, the grass slick with moisture underneath. Astrid pressed the two white candles into the damp soil at each end of the cloth. She poured a splash of coffee onto the ground between them. “For you,” she murmured. “We’re just here to listen.” I shifted my weight. “So… how does this work? Exactly.” She unscrewed the tar bottle. The smell hit me immediately: sharp, resinous, like burnt pine and old roofs, cutting through the damp. “We sit,” she said. “Backs straight, eyes open, mouths shut. If they tell you something, you don’t speak until we’re off the mound. You don’t stand up until I say. And you never, ever answer if someone stands behind you and asks your name.” “That’s oddly specific,” I said. “Did your grandmother draft a manual?” “She saw a lot,” Astrid said simply, dipping her fingers in the tar. She drew a line with it down the center of her own forehead, then reached for me. I pulled back. “Wait.” “It’s for protection,” she said. “So they know you’re invited. And not… food.” She grinned, but her fingers didn’t waver. “Fine,” I said, too loud, the word bouncing in the quiet. I leaned forward and let her paint the cold, sticky streak on my skin. It tingled, or maybe that was in my head. She lit the candles with a cheap plastic lighter, cupping the flames. The mist seemed to pull closer, brightened at the edges by the candlelight. “It’s almost midnight,” she said. “Sit.” We sat cross-legged on the cloth, our knees almost touching. I tried not to think about whatever lay beneath the mound, bones or stones or nothing at all. Moisture seeped through my jeans. The air smelled of tar, coffee, wet soil, Astrid’s cigarette shampoo. “Now what?” I whispered. Astrid stared straight ahead, towards the far edge of the clearing. “Now we wait. Open yourself. Let your thoughts go flat. If they want to show you something—someone’s secret, something that’s coming—you’ll feel it. Don’t grab. Just receive.” “You make it sound like an antenna,” I said. “We are,” she said. “If you do it right.” Silence slipped over us. No breeze, just the hushed hiss of our breath. My thighs began to ache. The candles burned small and steady, their flames barely moving. I tried to “go flat.” Instead, my mind skittered: my old friends in Södermalm, the bus stop where no one talked to me here, the way the biology teacher had mispronounced my name the first week and no one corrected him. Astrid flicking her lighter behind the gym, asking, “Ever played Svarta Madam properly?” and me saying no too quickly. I stared at the mist. It clung to the mound’s edges in low, luminous collars. Every now and then it shifted. Shapes suggested themselves—a shoulder, a bent head—and disappeared. Don’t stare too long or you’ll start seeing faces. I blinked and focused on the candle instead. My pulse thudded in my ears. This was stupid. It was a game. Morbid rural girl hazing the city girl—except Astrid never laughed at the end, never said “gotcha.” She only watched. A soft crack sounded behind us. I jerked, almost knocking over a candle. Astrid’s hand snapped out, fingers curling around my wrist, nails biting. “Sit,” she breathed. “It’s only the frost.” The trees stood motionless. I didn’t see anyone. Of course I didn’t. But now I was thinking about what she’d said: someone behind you asking your name. “Why can’t we answer?” I asked, barely audible. “Because then they have it,” she said, lips barely moving. “And then they can bring it where you can’t follow.” “Stop,” I said. I meant it to be firm. It came out like a plea. “You wanted to do Útiseta.” She finally looked at me. “You said you wanted to know why Hanna never looks you in the eye. Why Johan Gabrielsson stopped talking to his best friend. You wanted to know what people are hiding.” I did. I had. It had felt safe when I’d said it in her kitchen with the radio on and her dad stomping around. Here, with tar on my forehead and damp in my bones, it felt like something else. “I thought we were just—” I hesitated. Playing. “—messing around.” “We are,” she said. “Unless we’re not.” Something moved at the edge of my vision. My whole body snapped toward it before I could stop. There, between two birches, the mist was thicker, darker, like a shadow where nothing should cast one. A vertical column with the suggestion of shoulders. My heart squeezed. I blinked hard. It was gone. “Did you see that?” I whispered. “Don’t grab at it,” Astrid said. “Just let it be.” I swallowed. My tongue tasted like metal. Minutes passed, or more, or less. Time went strange. My left foot went numb. The tar tightened on my skin. The candle to my right guttered, flame bowing low before straightening again. I could feel a pressure building in my chest, like the charged quiet before a thunderclap. Then someone exhaled right behind my neck. I froze. The warmth of it. The damp. My skin shrieked. Astrid’s fingers dug into my wrist again, iron. “Don’t,” she whispered, barely audible. I didn’t know if she meant don’t turn, don’t speak, or don’t be stupid. A voice followed, so close that my hair stirred. “Vad heter du?” it asked softly. What is your name. My throat closed. It was a man’s voice, or a boy’s, or a woman imitating one; my mind couldn’t catch on it. It had the flat accent of the village, vowels long, familiar. It could have been someone from school hiding in the dark with us. It could have been no one. Astrid leaned toward me, her lips almost touching my ear. “Don’t answer,” she mouthed. I didn’t. But the word rose anyway, my name swelling up of its own accord, pressing against my teeth. The candles flickered violently. A wind I didn’t feel anywhere else hissed across my neck, cold where the breath had been warm. “Linnea,” the voice said. It didn’t sound like a question anymore. My heart battered my ribs. Astrid’s grip on my wrist was painful. “You told someone,” I hissed, my voice breaking its own rules. “You told someone—” “Shut up,” she snapped, and there was real fear in it, not performance. The mist surged, a low, pale tide sliding up the mound. For a moment my vision went white around the edges, and I saw—no, I remembered later that I thought I saw—figures standing in a loose ring beyond the birches. Not moving. Watching. I squeezed my eyes shut. Behind my lids shapes pulsed: Hanna’s turned-away face; Johan’s bruised hand in the locker room; Astrid on the church steps lighting a candle and then wiping her eyes, hoping no one saw. A rush of images that did not feel like mine. Too much, I thought. I don’t want this. “Close it,” I gasped. “Astrid, close it.” She was already moving. She snuffed the nearest candle with her fingers—there was a sharp hiss and the smell of burnt wax. She spat over her shoulder, three quick times, then swept her hand across my forehead, smearing the tar. “Done,” she said, voice shaking. “We’re done. Thank you, that’s enough.” The air seemed to loosen, like someone had unclenched a fist. The second candle steadied. The mist lay flat again, only mist. No ring of watchers. No voice at my neck. I sucked in a breath that trembled. “See?” Astrid said, too bright. “We got carried away. That’s it.” “You heard it,” I said. It wasn’t a question. Her eyes flashed toward the trees and back. “Doesn’t matter.” “You told someone my name. You set that up.” “If I had,” she said slowly, “do you think I’d look this scared?” I searched her face. She did look scared, but Astrid was good at masks. That was what I’d learned, and what I didn’t fully understand until later. “Sometimes,” she added quietly, almost to herself, “they already know who’s sitting out.” I stood too fast, my knees nearly buckling. “I’m going home.” “Off the mound first,” she said sharply. “Three steps backward.” I hesitated, then did as she said, heart thudding with each step. She copied me, clutching the tar bottle. We left the candles, one burning, one dead. The red cloth lay abandoned like a wound. On the path down, the night felt thinner, like the world I knew was sliding back into place. Crickets, a car somewhere, the weak halo of a porch light. I told myself the breath on my neck had been Astrid, playing. The voice had been my imagination wrapping itself around her rules. Still, when we passed the last birch, I felt something like a glance between my shoulder blades. “Don’t tell your parents,” Astrid said. “They’ll freak out.” “Obviously,” I snapped. “I’m not an idiot.” She bumped my shoulder. “You did well.” “I didn’t do anything,” I said. She didn’t answer. Years later—now, telling this—I can list the reasonable explanations. Astrid’s friends hiding in the trees. The wind. A half-dreaming mind eager to be haunted. I stack them carefully, one on top of another, like sandbags against a rising, older tide. But sometimes, if the room is very quiet, I feel that damp breath at the nape of my neck again, and hear it—my name, spoken from the dark by something that hadn’t needed to ask.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and atmospheric writing, successfully creating an authentic folk horror experience set in 1990s rural Sweden. The author establishes an effective narrative frame using Linnea's adult perspective looking back, though this device remains appropriately subtle throughout most of the piece. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Linnea emerges as a believable teenage protagonist - skeptical yet curious, trying to maintain her Stockholm sophistication while being drawn into Astrid's world. Her internal monologue feels authentic to both her age and fish-out-of-water situation. Astrid is more intriguing, portrayed as simultaneously matter-of-fact and mysterious, with her blend of teenage rebellion and genuine belief in ancient practices creating compelling ambiguity about her motivations. The atmospheric writing excels, particularly in establishing the eerie setting. The description of the burial mound, the encroaching mist, and the ritual preparations create genuine tension. The author demonstrates restraint in maintaining ambiguity about whether supernatural events are actually occurring, which is crucial to effective folk horror. The dialogue feels natural and serves character development well, particularly Astrid's matter-of-fact delivery of unsettling information and Linnea's mix of bravado and growing fear. The Swedish cultural details (place names, language, social dynamics) feel authentic and enhance rather than overwhelm the narrative. However, the piece has some structural issues. The pacing becomes uneven during the extended ritual sequence, and some descriptive passages, while atmospheric, occasionally veer toward overwrought territory. The ending, while maintaining appropriate ambiguity, feels somewhat predictable in its execution - the "breath on the neck" moment and voice knowing her name follow familiar horror conventions. The prose quality is generally high, with effective sentence rhythm and strong imagery, though some passages lean toward purple prose. The author successfully avoids major amateur pitfalls like excessive exposition or unearned emotional moments. The piece succeeds in its primary goals: creating folk horror atmosphere, maintaining supernatural ambiguity, and presenting believable teenage characters engaging with ancient practices. The cultural specificity and period details enhance authenticity without feeling researched or forced. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I hear the metronome click of the wall clock before I notice the lavender. One-two-three-four. The same tempo we used for interval splits. Now it’s the rhythm of my ruin. The treatment room is brighter than I’d like—white walls, pale gray mat table, the chrome of adjustable pulleys catching the overhead lights. Everything too clean, too precise. A diffuser hums from the corner, pushing out thin ribbons of scented air. Lavender. Calming. As if I need to be lulled when the real problem is that nothing inside me burns the way it should. Her footsteps approach before she does—the soft rubber hush of clinic shoes, then she rounds the partition, tablet tucked against her ribs. “Hey, you’re early,” she says. Same voice. Lower, steadier than I remember from our training days, but unmistakable. Noah. Once “No,” shouted across lanes, across finish lines. Now it’s “Noah?” whispered over clipboards in the waiting room, patients recognizing the poster that still has my face. I nod without standing. My knee is bent at ninety degrees with the brace open, quad twitching. The scar runs a thick, raised line from mid-thigh across the kneecap, disappearing down the shin. ACL, MCL, meniscus. All the important acronyms. She pulls up the rolling stool and sits close, so close the lavender gets drowned out by her shampoo—something clean and faintly citrus. Her hair’s shorter than it was when she ran heats next to me, dark curls pulled back, one escaping to brush her jaw. She’s in the clinic polo, navy, modest. It still fits in a way that makes my gaze drop before I jerk it back up. Her eyes flicker, catching the slip. She doesn’t acknowledge it. Professional. Of course. “How’s the knee?” she asks, stylus idle over the tablet. “Attached,” I say. “Mostly decorative.” One corner of her mouth tugs. Not a full smile. She’s too disciplined for that on the clock. On me. “Any pain at rest?” “Just when I think.” She exhales, a sound between a sigh and a laugh, then gets up. “Okay, let’s check your range.” She stands at my injured side, left hand bracing lightly just above my knee as her right hand cups under my heel. Her fingers are warm against my Achilles, a broad contact that makes the joint feel smaller. Her grip is firm, neutral. I know what neutral feels like. I used to live there between the gun and the first stride. Now it just makes me aware of how not neutral I am. “I want you to let me take the weight,” she says. “Don’t help.” “I’m not exactly in a helping mood.” “Noah.” This time my name is a warning. A soft one. It lands low in my gut. I exhale and let go. The hamstring slackens; the quad tries to lock, thinks better of it. She lifts the heel, guiding my lower leg into extension. The joint opens, the patella tracking over bone that feels too raw, like an eyelid forced back. “Stop when you hit a six out of ten,” she murmurs. There it is—the familiar clinical cadence. Still, the way she leans in to watch my face is too intimate. Her thumb stabilizes my tibia just below the tuberosity; her pinky rests lightly on the bed. I can map her hand like a pressure chart. “Three,” I say at first stretch. The graft tightens along the inside of my knee, a short, electric pull. She keeps going, slow, deliberate. “Four?” “Five.” The burn crawls up my quad, joins the deeper ache in the joint line. Her gaze flicks to my eyes. “Six?” My teeth clench. The instinct is to push through, to prove something, to outrun even this. Stupid. Dangerous. We both know it. “Six,” I say finally, and she stops, holding me there. “Breathe,” she says. “In through your nose.” The lavender catches with the air. A joke of serenity. Her hand at my knee presses posteriorly, coaxing the last few degrees. It’s clinical, yes, but there’s nowhere for the body to hide from contact like this. My hamstring quivers. She feels it. “There,” she says quietly. “You’re better than last week.” “I was also world champion last year,” I snap. "Look how great that turned out." She ignores the barb. Of course she does. She supports my heel, slowly lowers my leg back to ninety. No sudden release, no letting me drop. She controls the entire descent. “Roll to your side,” she says. “Face the wall. We’ll do hip extension.” I let out a breath between my teeth, shifting. It’s ungainly, the brace catching on the sheet. I used to be all precise lines and acceleration. Now I’m a folding chair. She helps guide the injured leg, supporting under my shin with one hand, the other on my lateral thigh, fingers spread over the IT band. Her thumb near the patella again, careful not to stress the joint into valgus. “Stack your hips,” she instructs. “Right over left.” “You know I hate being told what to do.” “That was true at nineteen,” she says, moving my pelvis half an inch so my ASISs line up. “It’s less charming at thirty-two. Keep your core on. Don’t let your pelvis rotate.” The familiarity needles. Her knowing my old habits, my stubbornness. Her not saying she’s proud I lived to thirty-two when the sport ate so many of us. “Lift your leg straight back,” she says. “From the glute, not the low back. Small movement.” I engage the glute max; the hamstring catches a fraction late, tendon tugging where they harvested the graft. There’s a deep stiffness at the front, around the anterior hip. She feels the compensations. “Stop,” she says. Her fingers press into my glute med, just posterior to the iliac crest, cueing. “Here. Initiate from here.” Her hand is intimate on muscle that used to fire without thinking. Now her touch is the only thing bridging mind and body. I try again, moving the leg back only a few inches, keeping the knee straight, feeling the glute catch first, then hamstring. The knee nags but doesn’t scream. “Better,” she says, close enough that her breath warms the shell of my ear. My skin prickles. “You’re enjoying this,” I mutter. “Making me weak on purpose.” Her thumb presses lightly into my TFL to quiet it. “Strength and control aren’t the same as ego, Noah. Again. Ten reps.” Around rep six, the burn builds in my hip, dull and insistent. My quad trembles. She stabilizes my pelvis with one hand on my sacrum, palm spread, fingers along the PSIS. The contact is broad, anchoring. Too much. “Don’t tilt,” she says. “I’ve got you.” You used to, I almost say. After ten, she says, “On your back again.” I roll. She helps pivot my leg, maintaining neutral tibial alignment, careful, always careful. My brace edges her hip; brief contact of hard plastic to soft muscle. We both freeze for a microsecond, then adjust. She raises the head of the table a bit so I’m half-reclined. “Heel slides,” she says, placing my heel on a towel. Her hand cups the back of my knee, fingers along the hamstring insertions. “Pull your heel toward your butt. No hip hiking.” I drag the heel. The joint compresses, a dense ache under the kneecap, along the medial line. I hit my limit at seventy degrees. My breathing cuts short. “Where?” “Medial. Three. No, four.” Her hand at my knee compresses gently, reassuring, keeping the joint aligned. “That’s within range. Back out.” As I extend, her fingers glide a fraction with my movement, tracking the motion. Heat blooms where she touches. It’s not supposed to be the most acute sensation in the room. “This feels like punishment,” I say. “Slow torture.” Her brow lifts just slightly. “You’ve done ice baths at three a.m. You know torture.” “That was for something. This—” I gesture at the brace, the room, at her. “This is… afterward.” Her jaw tightens a fraction. She reaches for the goniometer, metal cool, and measures my flexion. The straight edge aligns with my femur, the moving arm with my tibia. Her fingers, again, along my shin. “Ninety-two degrees,” she says. “You were eighty-five last session.” “Gold medal,” I say flatly. She sets the tool aside. “Sit up. Edge of the table.” I swing my good leg off first, then she supports under my injured calf, guiding it carefully so my foot dangles. Joint unsupported, gravity pulling straight down. It feels exposed, vulnerable, wrong. She kneels in front of me—doesn’t think about how that looks, or maybe she does and pushes through it anyway. Her clinic badge swings once, settling just above the zipper of her top. Her fingers wrap around my tibia, just above the malleoli; her thumbs rest along the anterior aspect. “Relax,” she says. “We’re doing joint mobs.” “Buy me dinner first,” I say, because I don’t know how not to throw punches. Her eyes cut up to mine—sharp, warning. But her hands don’t falter. “Grade II anterior-posterior glides. This’ll feel weird, not sharp.” She applies a gentle oscillating force, translating the tibia relative to the femur. The motion is small, precise, like a secret handshake between bones. Ligaments and capsule protest, but the rhythm is hypnotic. She watches my face, not my knee. “Pain?” she asks. “Uncomfortable,” I say. “Two. Maybe three.” “Okay.” Her grip firms. Not flirtatious. Not hesitant. Confident. There’s strength in her forearms I remember from block starts, from grabbing my hand after we both crossed a line. I’d thought she’d walk away broken like the rest of us. Instead she’s here, guiding men like me through the aftermath. “I hate that you’re good at this,” I say quietly. She pauses for half a second, then resumes the oscillations. “I like being good at things that matter.” “That implies I don’t matter anymore.” “That’s not what I said.” “That’s what it feels like,” I say. The words surprise me. Too honest. Her thumbs shift up, tracing along the patellar tendon, checking for tenderness. They press gently into the soft tissue just below the patella. It’s electric. I flinch. “Sorry,” she says immediately. “That’s the graft site tension. I’ll ease off.” She softens the pressure, broadens the contact. It becomes almost a caress, except it’s not meant to be. She knows exactly where the line is. So do I. We hover over it. “Look at me,” she says. I do. Mistake. “You’re allowed to be angry,” she says. “At the injury. At the process. Not at moving forward.” “Forward to what?” She swallows. The diffuser hums louder for a second, the lavender pushing into the space between us. “Something that isn’t only what you were,” she says. “Easy for you to say. You walked out before it chewed you up.” It comes out harsher than I intend. Her fingers stiffen on my knee. “I walked out because I saw what it would do,” she says calmly. “To us.” Us. It hangs there. Her hands are still on me, one stabilizing the joint, one supporting my heel now, thumb circling unconsciously against the tendon. The touch is absent-mindedly soothing, almost intimate. When she realizes, she stops, fingers flattening to neutral. “We’re done with mobs,” she says, voice back to clinical. “Straight-leg raises to finish. Then we ice.” She stands, moves to my side again. Places my injured leg straight on the table, toes pointing to the ceiling, ankle in neutral dorsiflexion. “Tighten your quad,” she says, tapping just above my patella with two fingers. “Push the back of your knee down. Then lift to match the height of the other knee. No lock at the hip.” I squeeze. The VMO fires, sluggish but present. I lift. The quad screams at once, tendon pulling along the graft line, the kneecap feeling like it’s being dragged uphill over gravel. My hip flexor tries to take over; she notices and her palm lands gently on my anterior hip. “Don’t hike,” she says. “From here,” another tap to the quad. “Control it.” It’s ten inches of hell. I make it to level, my breath hissing, hands fisting in the sheet. “How much?” she asks. “Seven,” I breathe. She nods. “Hold for three. One… two… three. Down slow.” Her hand hovers above my shin as I descend, ready to catch if I drop. I don’t. I won’t give her that. By the fifth rep, sweat beads at my hairline. The lavender feels sickly sweet. “Last one,” she says. I lift. The quad quivers violently. My jaw locks. Her hand comes down, very lightly, over my shin—not lifting, just there, contact without rescue. A tether. “Three,” she counts. “Good. And down.” I lower. The leg touches the table. I exhale like I’ve run a 400. She steps back, exhaling too, then quickly schools her features. “Nice work,” she says. “Ice pack’s coming. Keep it elevated twenty minutes.” “So we’re done,” I say. “For today.” She strips off her gloves—when did she even put those on?—and drops them in the bin. Without the barrier, I’m acutely aware that most of what I felt was her, not latex. At the door, she pauses. “Noah?” I look up. “You’re not decorative,” she says. “And this isn’t punishment. It’s a different kind of discipline. You know how to do that.” The word discipline curves between us. It used to mean 5 a.m. runs together, shared lactic acid, missing parties. Now it’s her hands on my ruined knee, guiding me through every humiliating inch. “Yeah,” I say. “We’ll see.” She gives the smallest nod, professional and something else, then slips out. The lavender ghosts the air, trying and failing to cover the sharp scent of effort, of something raw reopening.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional technical mastery in several key areas. The author has meticulously crafted a narrative that fulfills the complex prompt requirements with remarkable precision. The physical therapy sequences are anatomically accurate and spatially coherent—every movement, stretch, and manipulation is described with clinical precision while maintaining narrative flow. The author clearly understands both athletic training and physical therapy protocols. The characterization is sophisticated and nuanced. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery is palpable and psychologically believable, manifesting through defensive sarcasm and reluctant vulnerability. Noah (the therapist) is equally well-drawn, maintaining professional boundaries while revealing glimpses of their shared history. The sexual tension is expertly handled—present but restrained, communicated through subtle physical responses and carefully controlled professional interactions. The prose quality is consistently high, with precise sensory details that create vivid imagery. The lavender scent as a counterpoint to clinical sterility, the metronome clock echoing past training rhythms, and the specific anatomical terminology all contribute to immersive worldbuilding. The writing demonstrates technical sophistication in balancing medical accuracy with emotional resonance. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively—revealing character, advancing plot, and maintaining tension. Lines like "Buy me dinner first" followed by the therapist's sharp warning show how humor becomes a defense mechanism, while the exchange about "discipline" carries layered meaning referencing their athletic past and current situation. The emotional complexity is notable—anger, attraction, professional distance, shared history, and grief for lost identity all interweave naturally. The ending avoids false resolution while providing subtle forward momentum, which feels earned rather than imposed. Some minor weaknesses include occasional clinical terminology that might challenge general readers, and a few moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly overwrought. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece that successfully navigates multiple challenging requirements while maintaining literary quality throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell had rung six when I slipped ashore, though the heat already rose thick as broth and the river lay flat and green as old glass. A haze of incense and coal smoke hung over the factories. Canton hummed along its narrow piers—hawkers, coolies, comprador’s men. My orders were to inspect provisions on the Larne by eight. My body’s orders were different. “Merrick! Lieutenant Merrick!” I turned. Harding came down the landing-steps in a hurry, hat under his arm, the braid on his cuffs catching the weak sun. “Sir,” I said. “You’re bound for the provisioning godowns, are you?” he asked, breathless. “Directly.” “The Captain wants confirmation on those biscuit weights by ten. No mistakes this time, James.” “I understand.” My tongue felt swollen with lies. He narrowed his eyes. “You look damned tired.” “Chinese air,” I said. “Smells like a perfumer’s privy.” Harding snorted. “Get on, then. And keep clear of the hongs. We’re watched.” He clapped my shoulder and went back up. Once his footfalls were gone, I veered left instead of right, past hulking American hulls and shabby lorchas, through a forest of masts and drying laundry. The factories loomed white and stiff along the riverfront, as though England had planted teeth in Chinese mud. Clerks shouted in English, Portuguese, Bengali. Somewhere a hymn floated from a missionary chapel, thin as paper. I kept my head down, hand on the small of my back where my purse should have been heavy and was not. The alleys behind the foreign row took me in like a throat. Brick dripped. Flags of damp laundry sagged overhead. The scent changed, as it always did: the clean river tar and pepper and tea turning rank—fish guts, night soil, and, strongest, the rotting sweetness of mangoes turned to liquor and pulp. At the turn by the cracked shrine, the smell hit like a wall. “Morning, Lieutenant,” a voice sang out in Canton English. Chen, the boy with the harelip, leaned against a stack of bamboo cages. Chickens wheezed inside. “You’re early,” he said. “Sun not hot, yet you sweat.” “You seen Ko?” I asked. “He see you.” Chen nodded into the dark of the lane. “But first, Fragrant Flower.” “I’ve nothing today,” I said, too quickly. “I just—” He smiled. “You always have something.” He darted ahead, bare feet splashing through last night’s filth. The alley narrowed. The mango reek grew heavier, underscored by sour wine and the faint, metallic breath of the river. My stomach clenched in a dry, angry knot. An English voice barked behind me. “Merrick! That you?” I flinched but didn’t turn. Only Blakely would sound that cheerful in a place like this. He caught up. Younger than I, midshipman’s face still not hardened by command, though the lace on his coat was new. He smelled of cheap cologne over stale smoke. “Ducking the Captain again?” he said, grinning. “You’re becoming a legend in the gunroom.” “Provisions,” I muttered. “I’ve a man to see about salt beef.” “In Hog Lane?” He laughed. “You take me for a fool?” “Go back, Blakely.” “Thought I’d see where you vanish every morning.” His eyes flicked past me, to where Chen waited. “What’s this, your native sweetheart?” Chen spat tannin on the stones. “Go back,” I repeated. Blakely’s grin faltered. He leaned in, sniffed. “You smell like a spice chest that fell in the bilge. Christ, Merrick. Is this about opium?” My jaw tensed. “Get back to the ship, Mr. Blakely. That’s an order.” “We’re not aboard.” “Nonetheless.” He held my gaze a long second, weighing insolence against curiosity. Then he shrugged. “You miss inspection again, the Old Man’ll have your stripes.” He tapped two fingers to his brow in mock salute. “Happy shopping.” He turned away, whistling too loudly. My skin crawled. Chen snickered. “He talk too much.” “Move,” I said. We passed a heap of blackened mango skins humming with flies. Runnels of orange pulp streaked the wall, rank and cloying. The scent of rotting fruit wrapped everything, thick enough to taste, sweet rotting over salt rot, over the sharper, smoky-sweet promise I couldn’t yet smell but knew was there. Fragrant Flower’s sign was a rotted plank with flaking paint. We ducked under it into a courtyard open to a square of pale sky. A woman with green-glass bangles sat by the door, slicing mango flesh from a bruised pile, her knife ticking on the board. “Lieutenant,” she said in lilting Portuguese. “You’re late.” “I’m early,” I said, switching to her language. My mouth felt slow. “You are late every day you come without silver.” “I’ll have payment by evening, Mei.” “No credit,” she said. “Ko is not a missionary.” A narrow shape appeared behind her. Ko wore a dirty cotton jacket and a scholar’s queue; his eyes missed nothing. He’d once taught calligraphy, he said. Now he sold dreams to foreigners whose own country had flooded his with gunboats. “Good morning, Lieutenant Merrick,” he said in careful English. “I need a pipe,” I said. “Just one. I’ll have funds by second watch.” “No credit,” Mei repeated. Ko considered me. “You owe for three days.” “Tomorrow, then.” “Always tomorrow.” He stepped closer, close enough I smelled stale smoke in his sleeves and some faint, bitter spice. “You have rank,” he said softly. “You have ships. You bring things. I give you credit, you bring things.” “What things?” “Powder,” he said. “Lead. A barrel falls from ship. Very sad. I find it.” “I’m not a thief,” I snapped, too fast. Mei’s laughing breath whistled through her teeth. “You are not thief,” Ko said. “You are sick man. Sick men make business.” “I’ll have silver tonight.” “No,” Ko said. “You have something now. Watch, ring, shoes, coat.” I hesitated. The heat climbed my spine; my hands trembled. In the doorway behind him, in the darkness, I glimpsed the low couches, the brass lamps, the curled shapes. I imagined the smoke, dense, forgiving. “Coat,” Mei said. “You don’t need in this summer.” My coat was regulation, with the King’s buttons. The thought of appearing aboard without it, hat in hand, explaining its loss, made me nauseous. The thought of not lying down with a pipe made everything else irrelevant. “Not the coat,” I said. “The watch.” I drew out my father’s watch, brass worn smooth by generations. Ko weighed it in his palm, flipped it open, listened to its ticking. The little engraved initials—J.M.—winked in the dim. “English heart,” he said. “Fine.” He nodded to Mei. “One pipe.” “One now; one later,” I said. The desperation in my own voice disgusted me. “One,” Ko said. “You pay, you live. You don’t pay, you swim.” I followed Mei inside, the day shrinking away to a slit of gray. The den smelled of opium’s bitter syrup over sweat and unwashed bodies, threaded oddly with that drifting perfume of rotten mango from the courtyard. Lamps glowed like small, sullen moons. “Quick today,” Mei said. “You have your Queen’s work.” She pressed the stem to my lips. I watched the bead darken and bubble, inhaled as she warmed it with slow, practiced turning. The smoke came thick and velvety, herbal, then deeper, dark honey burnt on iron. It slid down, a hot hand around my lungs, then unfurled along my limbs, smoothing the spikes of need. Voices outside dulled to a hum. The knot in my belly unwound. Time loosened its grip. The weight of epaulettes, of oceans crossed, blurred. Mei’s face swam near mine. “Finish,” she said. “No sleep. You promise Ko.” I coughed a little laugh. “I’m not sleeping.” But color ran like ink in water. When I forced myself upright, my legs were hollow bamboo. I stumbled out into the courtyard. The sky had climbed. Sweat prickled under my shirt. Ko handed back the empty pipe stem. “Tonight,” he said. “You bring silver. And we talk of barrels.” “I told you. I’m no thief.” He smiled. “Then you drown sooner.” Chen led me back through the alleys. The mango stench, which had assaulted me, now seemed distant, folded under a lingering note of smoke in my nostrils. Still, it clung. A hand reached out from a doorway, grasping at my cuff; a man’s cracked voice begged in Cantonese. Chen kicked him away. “Be careful,” Chen said to me quietly. “Ko’s river deep.” “I can swim,” I muttered. He laughed. “Your legs jelly. How you swim?” At the mouth of Hog Lane I straightened, wiped my mouth, pinched my cheeks to raise some color. The riverfront had grown brighter and louder. Sailors jostled with Chinese porters; sedan chair poles clacked; a missionary’s bell rang thin and insistent. Harding appeared as though conjured, face thunderous. “Where the devil have you been?” he demanded. “Checking the east godowns,” I lied. “The tallyman—” “You look like death. And it’s past eleven.” Spit flew. “The biscuit counts are a shambles, and the Captain’s been roaring for you since eight bells.” “Sir, I—” “I vouch for you, Merrick,” Harding snapped. “Don’t make me a liar. You’re on cable duty this afternoon; perhaps some honest work will clear your head.” “Yes, sir.” He leaned closer, sniffed. For a terrible second I thought I smelled of smoke.
