+ Surreal horror: Caribou Season at the Lodge — Score: 84.5
Prompt:
Caribou Season at the Lodge Genre: Surreal Horror JT knew something wasn't right from the moment they'd pulled up to the lodge. It looked exactly as it had every autumn of his life—the cedar shingles silvered with age, the porch sagging gently under weight of winters past—but the air felt thicker, somehow, as if the woods had leaned in closer, waiting. He thought maybe he was just tired. Maybe it was nothing more than the long drive north, cramped in the back of the truck beside his older brother Mike -- and a stack of rifles wrapped in oily canvas. Still, the feeling lingered. The first caribou they found that season hadn't bolted. It had just watched, ears flicking lazily, waiting for the shot. JT had felt a crawling in his gut watching it die, noticing how it fell with a quiet dignity—as though it had wanted nothing more. Nobody else seemed to find it odd, or at least they didn't say so. JT kept his mouth shut. Always safer that way. Then there was the moment in the clearing. JT had fallen behind, fumbling with bootlaces stiff from the cold, and by the time he'd caught up with his father and brother, they'd already stopped. JT slowed instinctively, ducking behind a tangle of brush, staring out into the open space where a massive buck stood utterly still, chest rising and falling in slow, deep breaths. The animal looked…wrong, somehow. Maybe it was the eyes—dark and flat, calm in a way that made JT's neck prickle. Or maybe it was something deeper, something in the way the buck stood close enough for his father to reach out and touch it. JT watched as his father raised a trembling hand toward the animal's muzzle. His father's face had a strange expression, eyes too bright, lips parted slightly, like he was on the verge of whispering something—a secret, maybe. The rifle hung uselessly at his side, forgotten. Mike had the same dazed look in his eyes. JT's breath stopped short, his mind suddenly shouting at him to look away, turn around, just run—but he couldn't move. And then, as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. The buck shivered, startled by something unseen, and disappeared into the brush without so much as a sound. The two of them looked around, confused, seemingly surprised to find themselves where they stood. JT stayed hidden, breathing shallowly, fear mingling with a confused sense of shame. His father had failed to take the shot. To even think about mentioning what he'd seen would have felt like betrayal—or something worse. JT waited until the others moved on before stepping out from cover. He stared into the empty clearing for a long, uneasy moment, wondering if anything had really happened at all, or if he was losing his grip. Maybe the woods were finally getting into his head. Writing Instructions: Continue with the next chapter of the story, maintaining a style reminiscent of Stephen King—grounded realism blended seamlessly with unsettling surrealism. The atmosphere should convey subtle dread, isolation, and psychological ambiguity. JT's perspective is crucial, yet he is an unreliable narrator, caught in uncertainty about what he's perceiving. Establish an undertone of creeping dread, establishing the isolation of JT's perspective, which he largely keeps to himself. Incorporate some dialogue. Build tension towards a payoff. 1000 words.
Model Output:
JT lay awake that first night, listening to the lodge breathe. Old places like that, they had lungs. The logs settled and sighed, the rafters ticked in the cold, the stove in the corner of the main room exhaled smoke up the chimney with a low, patient animal sound. JT lay on the narrow bed shoved against the wall under the window and listened to all of it and tried very hard not to think about the buck. Through the glass, the woods crowded close. They seemed closer than last year. The black pines climbed the slope and stopped just short of the clearing as always, but it felt now like a pause, not a boundary. Waiting, he thought. The same way the buck had waited. JT turned his face into the pillow, breathed in the smell of old laundry soap and dust and faint mildew, and told himself to sleep. He woke unsure if he’d ever really fallen asleep. His dreams, if he’d had them, left only taste: metal on his tongue, something sour at the back of his throat, and a heavy pressure on his chest like an invisible hand pinning him down. The light through the window was gray. The woods out there were silhouettes and fog. Down the hall, he heard the bathroom door close, then the old pipes complain. Mike’s voice, a low murmur. Their father’s answering grunt. JT slid his feet onto the cold floor, pulled on his jeans and flannel, and pushed open the bedroom door. The smell hit him in the hallway: coffee, bacon, gun oil. For a moment everything seemed the way it always had. That helped. It always helped to find familiar things and stack them up in your head like sandbags against whatever was leaking in. Dad was at the stove in his thermal shirt and faded pajama pants, a cigarette pressed into the corner of his mouth, turning bacon with a fork. Mike leaned against the counter, already in camo, cleaning a rifle with slow, practiced hands. “I got your boots by the door,” their father said without turning around. His voice sounded rougher than it should have, like he’d been up all night barking orders instead of sleeping. “Eat quick. We’re losing light.” JT glanced at the digital clock on the microwave. 6:02 a.m. He wanted to make some joke. What, we’re on the moon now? But the words didn’t come out. Instead he just muttered, “Yeah,” and poured coffee into a chipped mug that said WORLD’S OKAYEST DAD, a gag gift from Mike three Christmases back. He watched his father’s shoulders as he moved around the stove. The old man’s hands, thick and sure, shook faintly when he turned the bacon, when he reached for the salt. The clearing pressed into JT’s mind: that trembling hand, reaching out. The absence of the gun between them and it. “Hey, Dad,” JT said. The words surprised him. “Yesterday. With that buck.” Mike looked up. Just a quick flick of his eyes, but sharp. His father stiffened, then shrugged. “What about it?” “Nothing,” JT said. “Just—thought you had a clean shot.” A moment too long passed. Dad slid bacon onto a plate and set it on the table. “Could ask the same of you,” he said, without looking at him. “You were dragging ass. Fall behind again today, I’ll leave you to the bears.” It was a joke. Or it wore the shape of a joke. No smile to go with it. His voice landed heavy, dull. Mike smirked but didn’t laugh. “Speed it up, little brother.” “Yeah,” JT said. “My bad.” It was like that. The clearing had been edited, the film spliced. No conversation about the way Dad’s hand had been reaching not for a shot but for a touch. No mention of the blank serenity in the buck’s eyes or how Mike’s mouth had been slightly open, like he was about to say “please.” It had not happened. That was the ruling, and the court was in session over coffee and bacon. JT tried again, later. He didn’t mean to. The question just slipped. They were outside, loading the rifles into the truck. Frost glazed the ruts in the driveway, crunching under their boots. The sky was a pale, thin blue, colorless and brittle. The woods loomed at the edges, tree trunks like bars. “Dad,” JT said, keeping his eyes on the bed of the truck. “You feel okay?” His father paused. The weathered, bearded face turned toward him, and JT saw something flat move behind his eyes, like a fish turning deep in murky water. “What kind of question is that?” “You…spaced yesterday,” JT said. “That’s all. Thought maybe your sugar was off.” Mike shot him a quick warning look. Don’t. Dad huffed. “I’m fine.” “I mean—” His father stepped closer, close enough that JT could smell the smoke in his flannel, the cold on his skin. “I said I’m fine.” The words came out very slow. “Nothing happened yesterday. You understand me?” JT nodded before he even meant to. “Yeah. Sure.” Still, something in his father’s expression lingered for half a heartbeat too long, a stiffness around the mouth as though the words he'd chosen hurt to shape. Then it was gone, and Dad was slapping the truck bed. “Let’s move. Caribou ain’t punching their own tags.” Out on the trail, the air felt wrong. It wasn’t the temperature. The cold was normal—the kind that bit your fingers and came up through your boots, that familiar needling northern chill. It was the way sound carried. Their boots on old snow and frozen ground, the distant crack of ice shifting on the lake, the whisper of wind in the branches—all of it seemed muted, as if wrapped in gauze. JT’s breath sounded too loud in his own ears. He fell into his usual place: a few paces behind Mike, more behind Dad, where he could see the line of their backs and feel safely unimportant. He preferred it that way. It gave him room to watch. Twice, maybe three times, he saw caribou watching them from between the trees. They weren’t spooked, not like he was used to. They didn’t bolt at the stink of human or the shine of metal. They stood in small knotted groups, legs thin and black, hides a patchwork of brown and white and dirty cream, watching with a dull composure that made JT feel like the one trespassing. “Left,” Mike said once, nodding toward a pair of them. It was a half-hearted call, the kind meant to be heard by someone already taking aim. But Dad didn’t stop. Didn’t even turn his head. JT looked at Mike. Mike looked confused for half a second, then smoothed it over. “He’s saving it,” he said. “Waiting on a real trophy.” JT almost laughed. He’d grown up under the gospel of You do not pass on meat. If it’s clean, you take it. Now, his father walked past guaranteed kills like he had someplace better to be. By noon, they’d seen more caribou than JT could remember seeing that early in the season. None of them ran. They moved instead with a measured calm, stepping out of the brush to stand parallel to their path, watching. Eyes dark. Ears twitching once, twice. Presenting themselves, almost. Offering angles. What set JT’s teeth on edge was how aware they seemed. Not smart, not like in a Disney movie, but awake. Participating. He said nothing. Partly because they’d already decided nothing was happening, and partly because every time he opened his mouth, he could feel something in the air lean closer, listening. Late afternoon, they came to a stretch of marsh they always crossed early in the trip. The reeds stuck up stiff and rattling through the ice crust, and those black pools of half-frozen water gleamed here and there like open eyes. Dad stopped suddenly. “There,” he said. A lone caribou stood about forty yards out where the marsh curved. Big one. Heavy antlers tangled like crooked fingers, muzzle dusted in frost. It was already turned toward them. Standing still. Waiting. JT felt his heart pick up. Not just from the size, but from the familiarity. The angle of the head, the set of the shoulders. He could have sworn— “Good bull,” Mike whispered. “You want I should take it?” “No,” Dad said. “This one’s mine.” The words came out soft, not boastful. Almost tender. JT swallowed. Something in the back of his throat tasted like pennies again. Dad raised his rifle. The caribou did not move. Its eyes were so dark they might have been holes. Empty. Or not empty. Too full. “Wind’s right,” Mike murmured. “You got him.” The air felt thick as cotton. JT’s ears rang like he’d been sitting too close to speakers at a show. The world tunneled down to his father, his rifle, the animal. For a second—a blink—JT saw something else overlaid on the caribou. The shape of a man standing in the same place, tall and pale and naked as birch wood, antlers blooming from the skull like living bone. Its eyes were pits. Its mouth was a slit, not opening, but he felt words moving inside his skull anyway, wet and slow as worms: Come home. JT flinched. The world snapped. Just the caribou, just his father, just the gray day. He’d imagined it. He had to have imagined it. Dad’s finger tightened. The caribou dipped its head. Not down to graze. Down like a nod. The shot cracked the quiet in two. The bull jerked once, then folded, legs collapsing in on themselves. It went down with that same terrible dignity JT had seen in the first kill. Like it had done exactly what it came to do. “Perfect,” Mike said. “Yeah,” Dad said, but his voice seemed far away. They slogged out to where it lay. Its eye, glassing over, still seemed too aware. JT avoided looking at it. His stomach rolled. “Tag it,” Dad said to Mike. “Field dress.” “You okay?” Mike asked. “Fine,” Dad said. But he was staring at the dead animal like he’d expected something else to happen. Like he was waiting on a response that never came. JT knelt, pretending to study the entry wound, and saw it: faint marks in the frozen mud around where the bull had stood. Not hoofprints. They were longer. Narrow. Like the impressions of bare feet, toes splayed, sunk deep enough to crack the thin ice. He blinked, looked again. Hoofprints. Just hoofprints. Ordinary as dirt. He opened his mouth to say something and felt that invisible attention again, pouring into him from the treeline, from the sky, from the dead thing at his knees. “If you’re gonna puke,” Mike said lightly, “do it away from the meat.” JT shut his mouth. On the way back, the woods seemed even closer, bristling at the edge of his vision. His father didn’t talk at all. Later, at the lodge, as the sky bled out into a dull, early dark and the men in orange from the neighboring camps drove in to trade stories and beer, JT watched his father through the kitchen doorway. Dad stood alone at the sink, hands braced on either side, staring out the window into the trees as if there were something out there looking back. “Good shot today,” JT said, stepping closer, trying one last time to ground them all in the old ritual. His father didn’t turn. Didn’t answer. “Dad?” When the old man finally spoke, the words were soft enough JT almost missed them. “They came early this year,” he said. JT frowned. “What?” “Nothing.” Dad straightened, forced a smile over his shoulder. It didn’t reach his eyes. “Get washed up. We’ll hang the quarters.” But in the glass, reflected over his father’s shoulder, JT thought he saw shapes between the trees. Pale and waiting. Antlers scraping the low clouds. He blinked, and they were gone. Maybe he was tired. Maybe it was just last year’s stories rattling around in his skull. Maybe he’d never seen anything strange in the clearing at all. That night, lying awake in the breathing lodge, listening to his father’s slow tread pacing the floors when he should have been asleep, JT decided two things: Something was wrong. And if he said it out loud, whatever was listening in the pines would hear him.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the Stephen King-inspired surreal horror aesthetic, maintaining the established tone and unreliable narrator perspective effectively. The writing captures JT's psychological isolation and internal conflict well, showing rather than telling his growing unease while others deny what happened. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - revealing character dynamics, establishing the family's tendency to suppress uncomfortable truths, and building tension through what's left unsaid. The conversations between JT and his father are particularly effective, with the father's defensive responses and JT's cautious probing creating palpable tension. The imagery is consistently strong throughout, from the opening description of the lodge "breathing" to the marsh scene with its "black pools of half-frozen water gleamed here and there like open eyes." The author maintains atmospheric dread without relying on overwrought descriptions, striking an appropriate balance between concrete details and unsettling ambiguity. Character actions remain believable within the established supernatural framework. JT's reluctance to voice his concerns, his father's denial, and Mike's warning looks all ring true to family dynamics under stress. The escalation feels organic, building from subtle wrongness to more overt supernatural manifestations. The piece successfully builds toward the climactic hunting scene, where the supernatural elements become more pronounced while maintaining plausible deniability. The vision of the antlered figure overlaid on the caribou is effectively jarring, and the ambiguous footprints that transform into hoofprints maintains the unreliable narrator conceit. The pacing is well-controlled, moving from the claustrophobic lodge interior to the hunting scenes with appropriate rhythm changes. The writing avoids purple prose while maintaining evocative descriptions that serve the horror atmosphere. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the supernatural elements feel slightly predictable within the genre, and a few instances where the metaphorical language borders on overwrought, though these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The ending maintains appropriate darkness and ambiguity, with JT's realization that "something was wrong" and his decision to remain silent creating a satisfying sense of dread and isolation. The piece successfully builds toward future developments while providing a complete chapter arc. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
There is, to Lucifer’s mind, nothing more undignified than having your ex walk in on you while you are reorganizing the Plague Pits. He is knee-deep in the reclassification of Sins (they keep cross-filing Envy under Pride; an honest mistake, but still) when the obsidian doors to the Panopticon sigh open without a knock—that will be Raziel forgetting, again, to recalibrate the wards—and Lilith steps in as if she owns the place. Which, to be fair, she sort of does. Historically. Emotionally. Metaphysically. A soft drizzle of ash filters through the vaulted ceiling’s fissures, settling in her hair like a morbid halo. She brushes a fleck off her leather jacket, looks down at the pit of writhing unfortunates, and then at him. “That one’s upside down,” she says. Lucifer doesn’t look. “It’s Enforced Interpretive Karma. Very in this century.” “You’re mixing hypocrisy with securities fraud.” “It’s called synergy.” She smiles faintly. “You’re lonely.” “I’m busy,” he says. This is not untrue. A million souls arrived in the night after a minor financial glitch topside. The Damned are packed six to a spike, the paperwork is apocalyptic (ironically, this is the one apocalypse humans never wrote about), and HR has sent a memo about workplace torment ceilings. Something about burnout. Lucifer pinches the bridge of his nose, smearing ash and a little blood. “What do you want, Lilith?” She strolls along the balcony, trailing a fingertip along the basalt railing, leaving clean streaks through centuries of soot. “I can’t visit an old flame?” “You set my bed on fire. Literally. Twice.” She considers. “To be fair, you liked it the first time.” The second time had required an insurance claim and a new river of molten damnation, so he says nothing. Below, a sinner screams for the seventeen-thousandth time that hour. It has the rhythm of a smoke alarm you learn to live with. Lilith leans against the railing, eyes on the pit. “Your ratios are off. Too many ad men in Cirque of Liars. You’ll throw the ecosystem out of balance.” “Everyone’s a critic,” he mutters. Then, because the silence between them has the shape of something fragile and unfinished, he adds, “Coffee?” She glances at him, surprised, then hides it. “If you’re making some.” In the staff kitchen—etched obsidian, fluorescent strips that always flicker slightly too slowly, demon-safe ergonomic stools—Lucifer wrestles with the industrial espresso machine. It hisses like a small dragon with intimacy issues. “It’s still raining ash?” Lilith asks. “It’s a light blight. Forecast says scattered despair by noon.” He taps the side of the machine. “The filters keep clogging.” “Maybe stop sourcing them from a lake of congealed guilt.” “It’s ethically sourced.” She chuckles. It’s a dangerous sound, like a knife deciding it could, if it wanted to, fall point-first. They drink in a silence that is almost companionable. Ash drifts in through the extractor fans. The clock ticks in uneven heartbeats, a gift from a poet who thought he’d invented ennui. “Why are you really here?” Lucifer asks. Lilith studies the coffee in her mug. “I had business in the Seventh. A usurper incubus thought he could brand without permission. Trademark infringement. I corrected him.” Lucifer nods. “And you just happened to swing by?” “Maybe I missed the décor.” She gestures at the humming fridge, which is full of stolen hotel minibar contents and human souls in Tupperware. “You redecorated. Less flayed maiden, more… startup.” “Streamlining,” he says. “Hell has deliverables now. Metrics. You leave for a century, you miss things.” She freezes for half a beat, the century he mentioned hanging there. The last time they’d broken up, it had involved three drowned cities and one awkwardly worded prophecy. “I didn’t miss things,” she says coolly. “I just saw other things.” “Of course,” he says. “How are they?” “Disappointing.” He can’t help the small, traitorous satisfaction. “Occupational hazard.” A demon assistant, all teeth and clipboards, pokes its head in. “My Lord? The Committee for Eternal Punishments is here about the budget.” “Tell them to impale themselves on their own red tape,” Lucifer says. “They did, sir. They say it’s symbolic, not binding.” “Fine. I’ll be there in ten.” He waves the demon away and drains his coffee. It tastes like scorched hope. He invented it. “You have a budget committee now,” Lilith says. “Adorable.” “Do not start,” he says. “We had to. Do you have any idea what eternal torment costs?” She tilts her head. “I ran Hell before you wore your first stolen suit.” “Yes, and your approach to fiscal management was ‘set it on fire and see who screams loudest.’” “It worked.” “It was chaos,” he says. “And not in the fun way.” Her eyes flash. “You loved the fun way.” He did. That was, in many ways, the problem. He is late for the committee. They walk together down the long corridor where ash drifts in through fractures in the vaulted stone. Portraits of disgraced popes glare down at them. One weeps pus. It’s in the contract. “Do you remember,” Lilith says idly, “the time we rerouted the Dreaming through the Subterranean Lust Furnace because you wanted to make a point about ambition?” “It was a solid allegorical gesture,” Lucifer says. “Gaiman thought so.” “Mm. Until we had mortals waking up with an inexplicable urge to unionize their nightmares.” “That was my favorite week in centuries,” Lucifer says. “The petitions.” “You stapled one to a cherub,” she reminds him. “It was a small cherub.” They arrive at the conference pit. A few mid-level devils and three unfortunate philosophers sit around a basalt table shaped like a broken halo. PowerPoint flickers against an obsidian wall, the slide perpetually loading. “We’ve overspent on bespoke torments,” says Belial, adjusting his tie of writhing serpents. “The individualized ironic punishments are lovely, but they’re killing us on scale.” “We do not kill,” Lucifer says automatically. “We eternally torment.” “Yes, sir.” Lilith watches from a shadowed corner, expression somewhere between amusement and critique. Lucifer feels her gaze; it tightens the set of his shoulders, sharpens his smile. “Standardize despair for social media influencers,” Belial continues. “Same loop, minor variations. Offers great ROI.” “Fine,” Lucifer says. “But keep the unique sets for the truly inspired monsters. Dictators, war profiteers, landlords: they still get the boutique experience.” A collective murmur of assent. “And,” Lucifer adds, “someone sort out the ash. It’s getting into everything.” “It’s eternal, sir,” a lesser demon says. “Part of the ambience.” “So are you,” Lucifer says. “And I replace you yearly.” The demon scribbles a note. The meeting drags on. Spreadsheets. Soulflow projections. An argument about whether late-stage capitalism counts as self-service damnation. Through it all, ash falls in slow, steady gray. When it’s over, Lilith is still there. “You’ve gone corporate,” she says lightly. “It’s called adapting.” “It’s called boring.” “Coming from the monarch of weaponized chaos.” She steps closer. The ash outlines the sharp line of her jaw, collects in her eyelashes. “They’ve domesticated you.” “I am domesticated by nothing,” Lucifer says. He smiles in a way that makes the room colder. “Except, occasionally, IKEA.” She snorts. “I warned you about flat-packed thrones.” “The Allen key is my true adversary.” A shared grin. This is how it happens: not with grand gestures, but with remembering the same joke. They drift, inevitably, back toward his private apartments. It’s not intention so much as gravity. The ash is thicker here, falling like slow rain through the high black windows. He clicks his fingers; the hearth ignites with green-blue flame. “You’re staying for dinner?” he asks, too casual. “Depends,” she says. “Still doing the flayed-patriarch fondue?” “On Tuesdays. Today is… existential consommé.” “Mmm.” He hesitates. Then: “You could consult. On the redesign. Of the Third Circle.” She arches an eyebrow. “You mean move the gluttons.” “Rebrand them,” he says. “Modernize. People don’t just gorge on food now. They gorge on outrage, content, other people’s lives. We need something more… contemporary.” Lilith considers. “An infinite buffet of notifications they can never catch up with. Every time they scroll, it resets.” A slow, delighted smile touches Lucifer’s lips. “See? You still think like Hell.” “And you still flirt like a fallen seminarian,” she says. He takes a breath he doesn’t need. “We work well together.” “We burn well together,” she corrects. “Semantics.” “No,” she says. “You do semantics now. That’s new.” There is a small, awkward pause. The ash taps softly at the windows like dirty snow. “For what it’s worth,” he says, staring into the unnatural fire, “I didn’t replace you. In the hierarchy.” “I know,” she says. “They gossip.” “Incessantly.” “And for what it’s worth,” she adds, “none of them made me want to burn down a moon.” He looks at her. “High praise.” “I’ve mellowed,” she says. “That is a lie,” he says, almost fond. “Yes,” she agrees. They eat (for form’s sake; neither of them needs food). The consommé is surprisingly good. Lilith critiques the seasoning; Lucifer pretends to be offended. The conversation circles from historical grievances to celebrity arrivals to the absurdity of mortals inventing new sins faster than Hell can file them. “You know they’ve started charging other mortals to live in houses they themselves don’t own,” he says. “Just pure made-up numbers.” Lilith blinks slowly. “You’re joking.” “I wish I was that creative.” “That’s… impressive.” “I sent a fruit basket,” Lucifer says. “Rotten, obviously.” “Obviously.” They end up on the obsidian balcony, looking out over the infinite terraces of Hell. The ashfall is a fine mist now, gray against the red-gold glow of distant fires. Screams rise and fall like traffic. “This place,” Lilith says, almost softly. “You’ve tidied it.” “I’m trying to make it… functional.” “You’re trying to make it something you can live with,” she says. “And you?” he asks. “Can you live with it?” “I never had a problem living with Hell,” she says. “It was living with you that was complicated.” “That’s fair,” he says. “And you were insufferable,” she adds. “Also fair.” “But,” she says, and the word is heavier than ash, “you are less insufferable when you’re not alone.” He turns that over. “Is this an application for a part-time arrangement?” “Don’t get greedy,” she says. “Call it… consulting.” “Consulting,” he repeats. “And,” she adds, flicking ash from his lapel with unnecessary intimacy, “I like the ash. Constant, inconvenient, inescapable. Feels honest.” “At least something falls for me consistently,” he says. She groans. “There it is. That’s why we break up.” “I regret nothing.” “Yes, you do,” she says. “That’s why Hell is so tidy now.” They stand there, side by side, not touching, watching their kingdom smolder under its gentle, never-ending fall of ash. Below them, someone screams creatively. “Tomorrow,” Lucifer says, “we move the outrage gluttons.” “Tomorrow,” Lilith says, “I might still be here.” He nods. In Hell, there is no sunrise, only slight adjustments in the shade of darkness. The ash continues its soft descent. For now, that’s enough.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully executes the challenging premise of blending cosmic supernatural elements with mundane relationship dynamics. The author demonstrates strong command of the requested Neil Gaiman-esque style, particularly in the understated irony and dry wit that permeates the narrative. The characterization of Lucifer and Lilith is nuanced and believable within the fantastical context. Lucifer's transformation from chaotic ruler to bureaucratic administrator feels organic rather than forced, and his loneliness is palpable without being overwrought. Lilith maintains her dangerous edge while showing vulnerability in her gradual warming throughout the day. Their dialogue crackles with history and tension, revealing character through subtext rather than exposition. The prose strikes an excellent balance between literary sophistication and accessibility. Lines like "She chuckles. It's a dangerous sound, like a knife deciding it could, if it wanted to, fall point-first" demonstrate elegant metaphorical thinking without veering into purple prose territory. The author maintains consistent voice throughout, blending the mundane (budget committees, IKEA references) with the infernal in ways that feel natural rather than forced. The world-building is particularly strong, with details like "demon-safe ergonomic stools" and the modernization of Hell's punishments for contemporary sins creating a believable fantastical bureaucracy. The recurring motif of falling ash works both atmospherically and symbolically, representing the constant, inescapable nature of their situation. The emotional arc is well-calibrated. The tentative reconciliation feels earned through the accumulation of small moments rather than dramatic gestures. The ending strikes the right note of cautious hope without being unrealistically positive given their history. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the dialogue becomes slightly too quip-heavy, potentially undermining emotional weight, and a few instances where the comedy threatens to overshadow the underlying melancholy. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. The story adheres well to the prompt requirements, delivering dark comedy, fantasy elements, and relationship drama while maintaining the requested understated ironic tone. The author demonstrates strong control over pacing, building tension and release through the day's progression. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The roar rolled over the wall before the sun had cleared the upper tiers. I lay on my pallet and felt it through the stone: a low, steady vibration that rose and fell like a tide. Not our fight. Not yet. The morning bouts—beast hunts, executions, the comic duels meant to make the senators laugh as they arrived late with their perfumed hangers-on—had begun. The iron stink drifted in already, thin but familiar, threaded with the sour-sweet reek of spilled wine and the acrid smoke of cheap incense vendors burned to flatter the gods or themselves. Rome liked all its smells strong. I slid my hand to the short sword beneath my straw-filled mattress and wrapped my fingers around the worn grip. The leather, darkened with the sweat of a decade, fit my hand as if it had grown there. My gladius. Others named their blades with grand heroes' names, but mine had no name. It had weight instead, and memory. The door-bar scraped and lifted. Light knifed in, hot and dusty. “Up,” called Felix, the lanista’s assistant, in his rough Campanian Latin. “Inspection. And wash your face, Iberus, you look like a corpse.” I sat up. “If I look like a corpse,” I said, “no one will bet against me.” He snorted and moved on, his sandals slapping the worn stone, unlocking the row of cells: iron bars, rough walls, old straw. Men stirred and cursed awake. A few murmured prayers. The sound of chains—psychological more than iron now—clinked as someone shifted too close to the door ring. I rose, every muscle informing me of yesterday’s drills: the wooden sword smashing against my raised shield, the sand grinding into my knees when I fell, the heavy helm baking my skull. I stretched, vertebrae cracking, then lifted the gladius fully into the light. The blade was the Mainz pattern: leaf-shaped, broader at the middle, tapering to a point meant for thrusting under ribs, up beneath the mail, neatly between them. Not the long, flashy spatha the cavalry boys liked to brandish, not one of those exotic curved blades the rich demanded for their toy Thracians. It was the soldier’s weapon. The empire’s tooth. They had issued it to me when I first put on the red stripe of the legion, fifteen years and a lifetime ago. I had carried it across half the world and then back in chains. I knew its balance so precisely that I could tell if dust clung to one edge by the way it pulled at my wrist. “You talk to it again?” came a voice from the cell opposite. I glanced over. Diodoros, the Greek, grinned at me through the bars, olive skin slick with sleep, dark curls matted. He spoke in Greek; I answered in Latin, our usual compromise. “If I do, it says cleverer things than you,” I said. “Wash, they want us.” He shrugged and reached for his own helmet, with its ridiculous tall crest. A Thracian-type, though he had never seen Thrace. The crowd didn’t care. They liked categories, signs: Thraex, Murmillo, Retiarius. They liked knowing who to hate. I stepped into the narrow corridor. Felix walked along, eyeing us for bruised faces that might devalue the afternoon’s program. My turn. He tilted my chin, checked my teeth as if I were a slave on a block—not inaccurate—and grunted. “Pontius wants you at the top today,” he said in a lower voice. “The final bout?” I asked. He nodded. “Governor’s orders. He wants a good show. Emperor’s eyes, all that.” I almost laughed. “The emperor is two hundred miles away.” “And yet his eyes are everywhere,” Felix said with a twist of the mouth. “Don’t be clever today. Just be alive.” As he moved on, Diodoros hissed softly. “Pontius puts you last, he wants blood.” “He always wants blood,” I said. “But today more,” Diodoros said, and his gaze flicked to the small barred window where a square of harsh blue sky glared. “News came. Some senator denounced him in the Forum last week for misusing funds meant for road repairs. So he answers: ‘Look how generous I am, I give the people games.’ And you, my friend, are part of his defense.” I already knew. The whispers slithered through the ludus faster than rats. Grain shortages up the coast. A legion muttering on the Rhine. Some governor recalled in disgrace, another exiled, another “invited” to open his veins. In Rome, Cicero’s old dreams of the Republic were a ghost everyone pretended not to see and everyone feared might return teeth-first. But here, in this provincial amphitheater of heat-baked stone, power asserted itself with a simpler language. Our language. Felix clapped. “Wash, oil, eat.” We filed to the washing troughs in the central yard, blinking as we emerged into the full assault of the day. The sun pressed down like a hand. The training ground’s sand was pale and blinding. Sweat, oil, wet leather, rusted iron, shit—it all rose together in a solid wave. A few of the newer men gagged. After a while, your nose surrendered. We bent over the troughs. The water was warm already, tasting faintly of metal and last night’s dust. I cupped it over my face, letting the rough shock wake me fully. A cicada shrilled somewhere in the cracked plaster. Outside the walls the city hummed, a sound like distant bees: hawkers calling figs and fish, mule carts grinding over stones, women yelling at children, someone chanting a half-remembered hymn to some eastern god who promised better worlds than this one. I rubbed down my arms. Scars moved under my fingers, some smooth, some ridged: Parthian arrow, German spear, gladiator steel. Each a line in the story of how a Roman citizen became a commodity. At the food line, we held out wooden bowls. Barley porridge, thick and gray. A strip of salted pork. I ate standing, the way we all did. You didn’t sit before a fight; it made you feel slow. “Remember when the legions ate better than this?” asked Marcellus, behind me. He was older, scarred, branded on both cheeks—a runaway who’d been caught and “redeemed” into the arena. I swallowed. “I remember when we ate standing in the rain and thought it noble.” “What do you think now?” he asked. “That we were fools,” I said. We both chewed in silence. Across the yard, Pontius himself appeared on the raised walkway, flanked by two scribes, their wax tablets ready. He wore a clean white tunic edged in purple and a wreath already, as if the applause were a foregone conclusion. He looked down on us like a farmer examining livestock. “My champions!” he called. His voice carried, trained in the law courts of Rome, now employed in this dust. “Today, we are honored. The governor attends, with his household and with envoys from the emperor. They come to see the strength of Roman discipline and the mercy of Roman justice. Some of you will receive that mercy today.” His gaze brushed me, assessing. He saw a veteran with enough victories that the crowd knew my name. Iberus, they called me, though I had not seen Hispania since I was a boy. Names were props, like helmets. “I remind you,” Pontius continued, “the eyes of the people are upon you. Their joy is your glory. Their favor is your path.” He did not say “freedom” aloud. You never promised freedom; you let it shimmer unspoken, like water at the edge of a desert. Beside me, Diodoros muttered in Greek, “Their joy is our entrails.” “Smile when you say that,” I murmured back. I thought of the governor’s visit. He would sit under a striped awning in the shade, with cool water and imported pepper on his meat. He would watch us bleed and feel the warmth of the crowd’s roar as if it were approval of his governance. Bread and games: that old, lazy magic. The empire cracking at the edges, and here we were, plaster for the fractures. After the speech, armorers checked our gear. I presented my gladius for inspection, hilt first. The armorer eyed the blade, thumb skimming the edge. “You’ve kept it better than I keep my wife,” he said. “It was mine before it was yours to lend,” I answered. He raised a brow. “You soldiers,” he said. “You never learn when to give things up.” He handed it back, and I slid it into the worn scabbard at my side. The weight at my hip steadied me. This sword had served Rome. It had cut down those who stood against the eagle. Then I had stood against an order I called unjust, or perhaps I had just been tired and drunk and loud in the wrong commander’s tent. It hardly mattered now. Rome had decided I was more useful as spectacle. We retreated to the shadowed antechamber just behind the gate that opened into the arena. The stone here pulsed faintly from the sound outside. I sat with my back against the wall, knees up, gladius resting flat across my thighs, the iron cooling my skin through the thin cloth. “You think of home?” Diodoros asked after a while, voice soft. “Sometimes,” I said. “I don’t,” he said. “Home thinks of me as dead. It’s simpler to agree.” I thought of a river in Hispania, cold and clear, where my brother and I had thrown stones. I had not seen him since before Actium. He might be a grandfather now. He might be bones. “Why that sword?” Diodoros asked, nodding at my gladius. “You could take one of the new ones. Flashy. The crowd likes flash.” “They liked this well enough when I wore the legionary shield,” I said. “And it reminds me.” “Of what? Glory?” “Of who I used to be,” I said. “And of who made me what I am now.” He studied me, then laughed once. “You’re going to get yourself killed thinking like a philosopher.” “Philosophers die in bed,” I said. “I’m not so lucky.” A horn blared outside, sharp as a stab. A handler’s shout, the crack of a whip, the roar cresting with some new cruelty. Dust filtered down from the brick vault in a thin veil, gilded by light streaming through the high slits. Felix appeared in the passage. “Half an hour,” he said. “Iberus, you’ll face the retiarius from Capua. The one with the scar across his nose.” “I’ve seen him,” I said. “He’s quick, but showy. Crowd loves him. Governor wants a good fight, so make it look as if he has a chance.” Felix hesitated. “Pontius says if you please them today, he’ll…consider your petition.” There it was. The shimmer of water. “Consider,” I said. Felix nodded once. “Make them believe in Rome,” he said, and left. Make them believe in Rome. I ran my thumb along the hilt of my gladius, feeling the impressions where my fingers had pressed over years. This sword had once been a tool of conquest, claimed by the state to bring order to edges of the world. Now the same state used it to cut its own citizens for applause. Still, when my hand closed fully around it, something in me settled. If I must be their spectacle, I thought, I will also be their mirror. Outside, the crowd roared again, and this time, under the blood and wine and dust, I swore I could hear something else. A crack.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong craftsmanship in historical fiction, successfully creating an immersive slice-of-life narrative set in ancient Rome. The author effectively follows the prompt requirements: first person past tense, approximately 1000 words, focusing on a gladiator's non-combat experience while weaving in political and social commentary. The characterization of Iberus is particularly well-developed. He emerges as a complex figure - a former legionnaire turned gladiator who maintains his dignity and philosophical outlook despite his circumstances. His relationship with his gladius serves as an effective symbolic thread, representing his past identity and current predicament. The supporting characters, particularly Diodoros, feel authentic and serve to illuminate different aspects of gladiatorial life. The historical atmosphere is convincingly rendered through sensory details: "iron stink," "sour-sweet reek of spilled wine," and "acrid smoke of cheap incense." The author demonstrates solid knowledge of Roman military equipment, social hierarchy, and political tensions. References to grain shortages, mutinous legions, and provincial corruption effectively contextualize the broader imperial situation. The prose maintains an appropriately grave, contemplative tone throughout. Sentences like "Rome liked all its smells strong" and "Names were props, like helmets" demonstrate economy and insight. The narrative voice feels consistent with an educated Roman soldier - neither overly modern nor artificially archaic. However, the piece occasionally veers toward purple prose, particularly in metaphorical passages like "Light knifed in, hot and dusty" and "This sword had once been a tool of conquest, claimed by the state to bring order to edges of the world." While evocative, such language sometimes feels overwrought for the character's voice. The dialogue generally feels natural and serves character development well, though some exchanges between Iberus and Diodoros feel slightly constructed to deliver exposition about the political situation. The ending, with its metaphorical "crack" suggesting imperial decay, works effectively as both literal description and symbolic commentary. It avoids false optimism while maintaining the story's contemplative tone. The piece succeeds as a "slice of a larger story," feeling like an excerpt from a longer work while providing satisfying character development and atmospheric immersion. The exploration of themes like identity, power, and the cost of spectacle feels earned rather than imposed. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
1 June 1976 Dunbrae Light, Moray Firth To: Mrs. Morag McKinnon 43 Wester Row Greenock Ma, They’ve put me further north than I thought. Dunbrae’s not even a village, just the light, a bothy the size of a biscuit tin, and a road that finishes in a puddle. The boat dropped me and my kit yestreen. The men were in a hurry, no ceremony, no jokes. The old keeper, Macready, shook my hand once and said, “Mind the lens and mind your footing,” and off he went with his trunk. I watched the boat shrink to a dot. That was the first time it hit me nobody’s walking past here by mistake. The tower is grand, though. Cast iron stairs, a lens like a glass cathedral. The foghorn could wake God. I’ve three lights to mind — main, standby, and the wee paraffin lantern for when the power goes sulking. I’m on probation still, so I’ll no say too much in case they’re reading, but it’s mostly honest work. Oiling, cleaning, logging, watching. Nights are long. The radio crackles with fishing boats and one fella in Wick who coughs down the microphone like the sea’s inside his lungs. I’ll send my first wages next month. Don’t worry about me. Your son, Ian 6 June 1976 Greenock To: Mr. Ian McKinnon Lighthouse, Dunbrae Son, Your letter came with the gas bill, which is the Lord’s sense of humour. I am glad you got there safe. I don’t like the sound of “no ceremony.” A proper job deserves a handshake and a cup of tea. I hope you made your own. Mind and eat. The money can wait. I get hours at the bakery still. They like my rolls better than the factory’s. Of course they do, I’ve hands. Do they give you proper bedding? If not, I’ll send your father’s heavy blanket. It smells of the wardrobe but it’s warm. Write again soon. Don’t be proud. Love, Ma 18 June 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Stop asking about bedding. I’ve a mattress like concrete and two blankets that smell of old rope, but it’s fine. Don’t send Dad’s. It’d stink of him and you’d be cold. The days all run the same: - 04:30: Check lamp, curse midges. - 06:00: Log weather nobody reads. - 10:00: Tea, tins, boredom. - 14:00: Paint something that’s already painted. - Evening: Wait for dark. There’s no pubs, no neighbours, just gulls that scream like bairns. Nights I hear them and my chest tightens. Once it was an actual kid’s voice on the wireless, from some trawler, shouting about his da. Was nothing wrong, just excitement, but it sounded like fear. I keep thinking about the yard at home. Concrete, sirens, your laugh from the close. Never thought I’d miss the shipyard stink. Here the air’s clean and it makes too much room for thinking. Tell me if your ankles are bad. Don’t lie. Ian 22 June 1976 Greenock To: Ian Don’t take that tone with me about blankets. I will mother you if I like. My ankles are my business. (They are swollen. Don’t you write back fretting. I’ve the doctor Tuesday.) I like your list of the day. Shows you’re paying attention. That’s your father in you. He always said, “You do the boring bits, you won’t get surprises.” You say there’s no one there. Nonsense. There’s you. There’s the men at sea watching your light. They don’t clap, but they’re glad of you. Next letter, tell me something beautiful about the place instead of your complaints. Love, Ma 1 July 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, A beautiful thing: Yesterday at 3 in the morning the fog went off like a curtain and there was the whole sea lit silver, as if somebody had left heaven’s lamp on. A pod of dolphins cut under the beam. Each time they came up the light caught their backs and they flashed like knives. No sound but the sea breathing. Even the gulls shut up. For once I didn’t feel like the last man on earth. Was all of us, me and them and some Russian tanker sliding west, together. That do? Mind your ankles. If you collapse in the bakery they’ll shove you in the pie oven to save time. Ian 16 July 1976 Greenock To: Ian That does. Dr. MacLeod says my blood is “lazy” and I should rest more. I said, “Tell the gas man that.” Cheeky wee goth he is now, with his long hair. He gave me tablets. Don’t joke about ovens, I’m working next to one. Have you made any friends? Is there a cat? A lighthouse should have a cat. Love, Ma 29 July 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, No cat. I tried befriending a gull. It shat on my boot and stole my bread. Friends: There’s a supply lad, Alastair, who comes every fortnight with diesel and gossip. He’s twenty with a beard that looks glued on. He asked if it’s “terrifying at night.” I said only when I think too much. He didn’t get it. Nights are longer now, somehow. The wireless is patchy. Last week the foghorn jammed and groaned one long note till I hit it with a spanner. Maybe that’s the job: keeping things going with a spanner, including myself. Send word of the street. I’m starting to forget the pattern of shouting and buses. Ian 10 August 1976 Greenock To: Ian The street is the same. Mrs McAllister downstairs won £3 on the football. You remember Rab Fleming with the tattoo? He drove his motor into a lamppost. No one hurt, just his pride. He told everyone the lamppost moved. Your brother hasn’t written you. Don’t take it to heart; he thinks feelings are a weakness he’ll catch. I went through your room. Your old cassette player is there, and that silly carved stone you brought back from Oban. The one with the spiral. You held it like treasure. Do you want it sent up? It might weigh your pockets down if the wind tries to steal you. Rest when you can. Love, Ma 14 August 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Aye, send the stone. It’s not silly. Fella on the pier sold it for 50p. Said his grandfather carved spirals as “reminders.” I asked of what. He said, “Things don’t end, they go round.” I was fifteen and took it serious. Carried it in my pocket for Dad’s funeral. Kept the church smell off my hands. Forgot about it after. Wouldn’t mind having it here. Tell my brother I know he’s useless at paper and that’s fine, but he can sign his name on a postcard at least. Ian 3 September 1976 Greenock To: Ian Parcel posted with the stone, two packs of biscuits, and a jumper I knitted. Don’t mock the colour; it was on sale. I told your brother. He shrugged like a theatre curtain. Then he left a postcard on the table addressed to “Big Eejit in the Big Lamp.” No words, just his signature. That’s effort, for him. I am… a bit more tired lately. Nothing dramatic. Don’t go racing home. Just knowing you are set and steady is a comfort. Write soon. Not about seagull shite. Love, Ma 9 September 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Your parcel arrived. The jumper is orange. I look like a traffic cone. It’s warm. Thank you. The stone fits in my palm like it’s remembering. I keep it in my pocket on night watch, smooth side to my thumb, spiral cut rough. It anchors me when the black comes pressing at the glass. I’ve been meaning to say something less daft. Some nights, when the weather’s clear and there’s no traffic on the wireless, I get this… urge, I suppose, to switch the light off. Just to see. One wee click. Dark. Then see which ships shout first. Like testing devotion. I don’t do it, obviously. I’m not a maniac. But it comes, like a thought that isn’t mine, and it frightens me that I have it. I’m telling you so it’s not just rattling in my skull. Don’t “just tired” me. If it gets worse, I come home. A job’s a job. Ian 15 September 1976 Greenock To: Ian Your honesty makes me proud and cross. Firstly: don’t you touch that light. Men in boats you’ll never meet say goodnight to their weans trusting you’re not in a mood. If a daft idea comes, let it pass like wind. You don’t open windows for every fool who knocks. Secondly: I’m seeing the hospital next month for tests. That is all I know. If it was dreadful they’d be quicker, so calm your ashes. Thirdly: You are not coming home to sit on your arse and watch me wheeze. You chose this, see it through at least the winter. Please don’t keep dark thoughts as pets. Write them down or send them here. I’ve room. Love, Ma 2 October 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Storm last night. Proper one. The whole tower shook. The light swung through sheets of white like the sea was throwing itself at us. A trawler called in, “Dunbrae, keep her bright, we’ve no eyes.” I said, “Light’s on, lads.” Felt like I was doing something that mattered. The bad notion came again, and I held the stone so hard it marked my hand. I thought of you giving rolls to the old boys at the yard gate, extra butter “by mistake.” Body doesn’t let go of kindness easy. Tell me what hospital says as soon as they say it. No brave nonsense. Ian 20 October 1976 Greenock To: Ian Hospital says I have “shadowing” and “we’ll monitor” and “further tests.” They are cowards with big words. I am not impressed. I am more tired. The bakery said I can do fewer shifts. That’s code, but I’ll take it. I reread your letters when I can’t sleep. I can hear your voice wrong, deeper, not that boy shouting for his boots. Keep writing, so I get the sound right. Don’t argue with me in your next one. I can feel you winding up. Wait for facts. Love, Ma 1 November 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Telegraph came from Head Office: they’re automating three lights next year. Not sure if Dunbrae’s on the list. Thought I’d be relieved. Instead it felt like somebody planning to tear the heart out of a clock. If they shut us, I’ll get posted or get nothing. The idea of going back to the yard… I’d rather weather storms. This isn’t the argument letter. Just telling you things might shift. Hold onto what the doctors actually say, not what they don’t. Ian 19 November 1976 Greenock To: Ian Facts: I have lung cancer. It is not tiny. It is not enormous. It is itself. They are going to “try a course.” I said, “I’ll try a few of my own words too,” and they looked at me like furniture. Poor souls. You are not to come rushing. I mean this. Those boats need their silly stubborn keeper. I have neighbours to fetch bread, and your brother, useless as he is with pen, can carry coal. Write me more about the light. I like the thought of you high above idiots, seeing clear. Love (a lot), Ma 25 November 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, I read your letter on the stair halfway up and had to sit down. Felt like the tower had gone hollow. I wanted to be on the next bus, boat, donkey. I understand your “not rushing.” I’ll wait until you say. But I will come. Non-negotiable. Head Office sticky note: Dunbrae to be automated “within 18 months.” Like I’m a kettle. I had the dark thought again last night — to switch off, just for a second, to match how it feels inside. I didn’t. Instead I polished the lens until I could see my red eyes in it and said, “Right, we stay on.” The stone was in my fist. There’s a groove now where my thumb sits. I’m scared, Ma. There it is. Ian 2 December 1976 Greenock To: Ian Good. I’d worry if you weren’t scared. I am, too. We can do it honestly, at least. I’m glad you kept the light on. That’s you, for all your daft ideas. Don’t talk about being like a kettle. When that machine comes, let it. You are not your job. You’re the boy who brought me a spiral stone because some old liar in Oban told him stories. When it is time for you to come, I’ll tell you straight. Until then, I want letters. That’s the bargain. Love, Ma 24 December 1976 Dunbrae Light Ma, Christmas Eve. Got a tin of mince pies from Head Office. Practically an apology. There’s snow clinging sideways, but the beam cuts it. I’m on till dawn. Thought a lot about that stone spiral. “Things don’t end, they go round,” the old fella said. I used to think that meant nobody really dies. Now I think it means what we do bends back, echoes. Your kindness at the bakery. My stupid orange jumper. The trawler’s voice in a storm. It all loops. I keep wanting to say something properly big and it comes out daft. Just: you’re what I steer by, is all. Happy Christmas. Ian 28 December 1976 Greenock To: Ian You managed “properly big” fine. The treatment is tiresome. My hair is sulking off. If I go bald I’ll send you a photograph so you can laugh and not be scared of it. I told Dr. MacLeod about you and the light. He said we’re lucky to have men like you. I said we’re lucky to have lamps; men are trouble. He laughed. When you feel the switch calling, remember: it’s not the sea asking. It’s only the dark. The sea wants you shining. I’m more breathless now. We’re edging, son. Not there yet. Love, Ma 5 February 1977 Dunbrae Light Ma, Didn’t hear from you in January. Wrote, didn’t post; the words kept tripping. The automation crew were here. Young lads with shiny tools, all apologies. They’ve fitted the new gear. Official handover in June. I trained the stupid machine like I was teaching my replacement to walk. How are you? That’s not a polite phrase; answer it. If I don’t hear soon I’m coming regardless. Ian 9 February 1977 Greenock To: Ian You’re right to threaten. I’d been in hospital a spell. Pneumonia on top, greedy sods. I’m home now. Smaller than I was, but still me. Your brother is fussing like a hen. Don’t tell him I said that. The neighbours bring soup that tastes of guilt. I can’t climb stairs easily. I sleep in the sitting room, next to the window that looks at the docks. I watch ships and think, “My boy’s light is somewhere out there.” Come in March. Not yet; too many germs kicking around. Early March. Bring that stone. Love, Ma 3 March 1977 Dunbrae Light (Last Entry Before Leave) Ma, Leave approved. I’ll be down on the 6th if the sea behaves. Tonight is my last full winter watch. The machine can handle most, but they still have me sitting here like a chaperone, listening in case it coughs. The urge to switch off came once, soft as ever. I took the stone out and set it on the sill. The spiral caught a little of the lamp’s sweep each turn. I thought, daftly: if I turned it, I could throw wee circles of light out into the dark. Like writing my name on the sea. I won’t be here forever. You won’t, either. None of us. But I’ve kept this lamp burning, and you kept me burning, and the boats passed safe. That’s something that doesn’t just drop into black. I’m bringing the stone to you. You had it all these years anyway. Leave the window unlatched in case I’m late. Your daft, scared, stubborn son, Ian 20 March 1977 Greenock To: Dunbrae Light (Returned to Sender, Unsent Draft Found in Drawer) Ian, You are asleep in the chair as I write, open-mouthed like when you were five. Your coat is on the peg dripping sea. You put the stone on the mantel beside your father’s picture without a word. I pretended not to see you wipe your eyes. The doctor says there’s little road ahead but we can walk it how we like. I choose slow. I choose watching ships with my boy and letting him make tea badly. You said earlier you don’t know what you are if you’re not “the keeper.” Listen: you are the light, not the tower. You were shining long before Dunbrae. When I go (not today, so shut that face), I want you to keep the stone. Not as a weight, as a reminder. Things go round. You’ll go somewhere else, maybe another coast, maybe inland with noisy children banging pots. You’ll switch other lights on. You’ll write to someone who thinks they’re alone. This is my last letter because now I can just shout through to you from the sofa. It’s a good ending. Put the kettle on, son. Love, Ma
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional resonance. The author successfully creates two distinct voices - Ian's working-class Scottish perspective comes through authentically in his direct, sometimes gruff language ("Don't 'just tired' me"), while his mother Morag displays warmth, wisdom, and stubborn maternal authority ("I will mother you if I like"). The Scottish dialect feels natural rather than forced, avoiding stereotypical excess while maintaining authenticity. The story structure effectively uses the correspondence format to reveal character and advance plot. The gradual revelation of Morag's illness creates genuine tension, while Ian's isolation and psychological struggles with the lighthouse posting feel believable. The author avoids melodrama by grounding emotional moments in concrete details - Ian polishing the lens until he sees his "red eyes," or Morag sleeping in the sitting room watching ships. The imagery throughout is consistently strong without becoming purple. The lighthouse beam cutting through snow, dolphins flashing "like knives" in the light, and the carved stone's spiral catching the lamp's sweep all serve both atmospheric and symbolic purposes. The recurring motif of the spiral stone provides elegant thematic coherence about cycles, continuity, and connection. Character development feels earned. Ian's transformation from someone battling dark impulses to understanding his role as "the light, not the tower" emerges organically through the correspondence. His struggle with isolation and the urge to "switch off" the light provides genuine psychological complexity. Morag's voice remains consistent even as she weakens, maintaining her protective instincts and dry humor. The ending avoids false optimism. Morag's final unsent letter acknowledges death's approach while finding meaning in their connection. Her cancer isn't miraculously cured, nor does Ian's job situation improve - the lighthouse will still be automated. Instead, the resolution focuses on understanding and acceptance, which feels authentic to the characters' journey. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the symbolism becomes slightly heavy-handed (the stone metaphor, while effective, borders on over-explanation), and some letters feel slightly too polished for working-class characters writing informal correspondence. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall achievement. The prose flows naturally throughout, maintaining period-appropriate language and avoiding anachronisms. The emotional complexity never becomes overwrought, and the Scottish setting feels genuine rather than performative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 79.8
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I spot three vulnerabilities before I see her. One: the router on the back wall, elevated but not high enough, antenna pointing like a flag. Sticker on its side: default SSID, default brand. Hope they at least changed the admin password. Two: the POS system under the bar, USB ports exposed. No port blockers. The bartender’s phone is plugged into one of them, screen lit, notifications spilling across like an RSS feed of poor decisions. Three: the WiFi password is taped to the counter in 24-point Comic Sans. “W1ne&d1ne” with the little note: “Ask the staff if you have trouble logging in! :)” Cute. Also: bad. I could— Stop. Breathe. This is a date. You’re not on an engagement. You’re not at work. You are here to be a person. She walks in and everything soft-resets. She’s in a denim jacket with a faded Lightning Bolt patch on the pocket. I don’t register her face first; I register the patch. Lightning Bolt. Magic. My brain: new process spun up, high priority. “Hey,” she says, and it’s so normal it throws me. “Sorry if I’m late, parking is a dungeon.” “You’re right on time,” I say. Human words, good. “Nice patch.” She glances down. “Oh, thank you. I was going to say something about your Sol Ring pin, but I didn’t want to assume you’re actually a nerd and not just a poser.” I grin. “Name one poser who voluntarily runs commander at a card shop on a Friday.” “I can think of at least three,” she shoots back, smiling, and just like that: handshake successful, encrypted tunnel negotiated. Social TLS established. We order drinks. She gets a red; I get an IPA I’ll regret if I start analyzing the hop distribution curve instead of listening. The server points at the password taped to the counter. “WiFi is there if you need it.” He smiles like he’s proud. I do not look directly at it. It’s like averting my eyes from an eclipse. Focus. She leans in a bit. “So… you’re a security consultant?” “Yeah,” I say carefully. “Pentesting, audits, that kind of thing. But I used to be, uh… less official about it.” “Black hat?” she asks. No judgment. Just curiosity. “Gray,” I say automatically. Old reflex; damage control, plausible deniability. I adjust. “Okay, like… charcoal. I was young and stupid and thought root access to everything was some kind of moral right. Then I learned better.” “And now you wear the white hat,” she says. “When it matches my outfit.” She laughs; it lands warm. Okay. Good. We talk Magic and the pretense of small talk dissolves almost instantly. She’s a Grixis player; I’m Selesnya with a side of Orzhov when I feel like disappointing my friends. She tells me about her favorite commander deck—Jeleva, built to make the table nervous. I tell her about the time I built a Trostani deck so oppressive people negotiated treaties before sitting down with me. We compare banned cards, complain about companions, share trauma about Oko. This is easy. This is… suspiciously easy. I’m starting to relax. The scripts in my head quiet. The impulses—to map the network, to fingerprint the router, to read body language as an attack surface assessment—drop from high alert to background services. She talks about work: UX design at a mid-sized fintech; “I’m the one yelling at devs not to put dark-gray type on a black background.” “Hero,” I say. She asks me about an engagement I liked. I give her the sanitized version of the hospital gig: how we chained misconfigurations until we could change pharmacy orders; how scared everyone was; how relieved. I skip the part where the exploit felt like flying. I emphasize the ethics. She nods in all the right places. “You must see holes everywhere,” she says. “Kind of,” I admit, then soften it with a shrug. “Wholesome ones too, sometimes.” That’s a lie. My head is a vulnerability scanner that never times out. As if on cue, her phone lights up on the table. It’s face up. Of course it is. Pattern lock, green, that standard grid. Her finger hovers. I don’t mean to watch. I absolutely watch. And the pattern is: down, right, up, up, left. Oh my god. It’s the kind of pattern they use in training slides labeled “Don’t do this.” Five nodes, no overlaps, a literal checkmark rotated ninety degrees. I can already see, in the reflection on her wine glass, clear grease trails like crime-scene string. Don’t say it. “You know that pattern is super guessable, right?” I say. Mouth, what the hell. Her hand freezes above the screen. She blinks at me. “What?” Abort. Roll back. Patch. I try a smile. “Sorry, that sounded… judgey. Occupational hazard. I, uh. I notice those things.” She sets the phone fully down, not unlocking it. “You memorized my unlock pattern?” “Well, I mean, not memorized,” I say too fast, which everyone everywhere always hears as “memorized in 4K HDR.” Her expression tilts. The warmth drains a few degrees. Here comes the ice. “I didn’t mean I was trying to—” I start. “You watched me go to unlock my phone,” she says slowly, “and you intervened to tell me my pattern is insecure. On a first date.” “When you say it like that,” I say, “it sounds worse than it is.” Stop. Terrible line. “I’m sorry,” I add, quick. “Reflex. I used to break into stuff for fun. Now I get paid to tell people when their stuff is bad. Sometimes my brain doesn’t clock that I’m not on the clock.” She studies me. I can practically see gauges in her eyes: Creepiness: 62% Honesty: 74% Charm: recalculating… “Did you get it?” she asks. “…Yeah,” I say, because if I lie and she calls me on it, it’s game over. “It’s just a super common pattern. I’d recommend something longer, maybe use a passphrase pin instead. Or biometrics if you—” “Are you assessing my threat model right now?” she asks. I stop. Because I am. “I might be,” I say. Tiny wince. “And I shouldn’t be. I’m sorry. Seriously. That was not me trying to neg you or flex or—” “Or demonstrate your l33t skills?” Her mouth twitches. I groan. “Please never say ‘l33t’ again.” She exhales, halfway between a laugh and a sigh. “You really can’t turn it off?” “I’ve been trying,” I say. And it’s more honest than anything else tonight. “It used to be a rush. Seeing how systems fail. Getting in where I shouldn’t. Now it’s a job, but the pattern recognition part—my brain just runs it. Like how you probably see bad kerning everywhere.” Her eyes flicker. “Oh my god, yes. The restaurant sign outside made me physically upset.” I seize that like a life raft. “Exactly. You’re not going to redesign their logo on the first date, but you noticed it.” “Yeah,” she says slowly. “But your version can break into people’s lives.” “Also yes,” I say. No deflection. “That’s why I put so many guardrails on myself. My accounts, my machines, my habits. I don’t touch anything I don’t have explicit permission to. I try not to even comment if I can help it. Tonight I slipped. You pulled your phone out, my brain went, ‘oh no,’ and my mouth followed without asking.” She picks up the phone again, then sets it back down. Not unlocking it. A deliberate choice. “So could you unlock it if you wanted to?” she asks. Potential answer space: A) Joke. "Only if you say the magic word." B) Brag. "In thirty seconds." C) Reassure. "Not going to." D) Over-explain. Fifteen-minute lecture with diagrams. Minimal viable damage: C. “I’m not going to,” I say. “Ever. Because that’s the line. I keep the door locked in my own head, not just in code.” Her shoulders loosen, just a bit. “You didn’t answer the question.” Shit. “Yeah,” I admit. “I probably could. But consent matters. With people. With systems. That’s kind of the whole modern arc of my life.” “So you’re saying you’re the guy who could ruin my week and is choosing not to.” Her tone is dry, but not frozen. “I’m saying,” I counter, “I’m the guy who sees the leak in the boat and can’t help yelling ‘hey, leak,’ even on a date, because I would hate to sit here and say nothing while water comes in.” We both pause. That wasn’t terrible. She snorts. “That was almost smooth.” “Almost?” I ask. “You still told me my lock pattern sucks on a first date.” “That’s fair,” I say. She lifts her glass, thinking. “Okay,” she says finally. “Boundary: no live-fire demos of hacking my stuff.” “Agreed,” I say. “Boundary,” she continues, “no more unsolicited critiques of my security choices tonight.” I mime zipping my lips. “Locked down.” “You can answer direct questions, though,” she says. “If I invite the infosec goblin out, that’s on me.” “Deal.” “Okay,” she says, nodding once like she’s committed this to an internal spec doc. “So now that we’ve done threat modeling on my phone, can we go back to judging each other on something truly important?” I blink. “Like…” She grins. “Your opinion on hybrid mana.” I exhale, tension bleeding out. We’re not fully out of the woods, but we’re not 403 Forbidden either. Partial content. I lean in. “It’s elegant in theory, chaos in execution.” “So you’re wrong,” she says immediately, pleased. We’re moving again. She’s teasing. That’s good. That’s salvage. Over her shoulder, my eyes catch the WiFi password at the counter again. W1ne&d1ne. Idiotic. The router’s admin panel is probably “admin/admin.” I could— No. I focus on her. She’s telling me about the first deck she built, how she netdecked something awful and then slowly iterated it until it was hers. “It started as this obnoxious blue control thing,” she says, “and then I realized I hated who I became when I played it. So I tore it apart and rebuilt around spells that made the table laugh.” “How very white hat of you,” I say. She smiles. “Growth arc.” I feel that in my throat. My phone buzzes in my pocket. Monitoring alert from a client system; I know the pattern without looking. For a second my hand twitches toward it. Incident? Exploit? Root cause? My brain queues up five possible attack vectors. I don’t take it out. Her eyes flick down, sees I’m ignoring the buzz, then up to me again. That earns me a microscopic nod. I stay in this moment. This table. The condensation on her glass. The way her nails tap a little rhythm when she’s thinking about her mana curve. The fact that she’s still here. “By the way,” she says, casual, “when this goes well and we have a second date—which I’m not saying we will, don’t get cocky—you can help me set up something safer than kindergarten zig-zag, okay?” Warm bloom in chest. “Only if you ask nicely,” I say. She raises an eyebrow. “Consent-based security consulting,” I clarify quickly. She laughs. “Better.” I don’t tell her the router needs help.
