Breath’s thinner these days with all the blue light and melatonin gummies. The field was open. I saw an unattended threshold of vulnerability. I occupied it. Classic nightmare precedent.” “The locus,” First Love protested, “was under my custodianship. There are boundaries.” “He literally invited me,” Mora said. “Physiologically. Elevated heart rate, constrained airflow, limb atonia. This is my ecological niche. Check the bylaws.” All eyes, metaphorical and otherwise, turned to Dream. Dream sighed so faintly it created a minor windstorm in three nearby fantasy realms. “The Charter of Dreams,” he said, “does recognize nightmare entities’ feeding rights within medically and symbolically appropriate parameters.” First Love brightened hopefully. “But surely not at the expense of essential developmental—” Dream raised one hand. The room stilled. “The Court will hear arguments as to consent, territory, and narrative coherence,” he said. “First Love. Mora. You will restrain yourselves to relevance.” “Yes, lord,” murmured First Love. Mora gave a lazy salute. “Scout’s honor. I ate the scouts, too.” “Objection,” said First Love. “On what grounds?” asked the bailiff’s gavel-head, rotating slightly. “Tone.” “Overruled,” Dream said. The clerk, wings dusting sleep sand, spoke up. “Note: Subject Max Kowalski reports higher recall of this dream sequence, increased morning distress, but also persistent preoccupation with Amelia Reyes and a… complicated attraction to dangerous women, horror aesthetics, and throats.” First Love paled. “That is exactly the kind of thing I am meant to calibrate gently, over years, with harmless pining playlists. If this trajectory continues, by twenty-one he will only fall for people who threaten to chew on his soul. I do heartbreak. Not… predation.” “I heard ‘only,’” Mora said. “Proud of that.” Dream’s gaze slid to her. Stars dimmed behind him. “You modified the dream-form of Amelia Reyes without authorization.” She shrugged. “I amplified. He already put her on a pedestal. I made the pedestal grow teeth. Metaphorically. And literally.” “Unauthorized likeness alterations are a violation,” the clerk whispered, scandalized. Mora clicked her tongue. “You all get so precious about continuity. It’s a dream. Not a museum installation. Kid’s endocrine system lit up like a funeral pyre. Nutritionally dense terror. Also, not for nothing, the confusion was very on-brief for Teenage Romantic Experience. Congratulations to us all.” First Love spread his hands, helpless. “I sculpt epiphanies. She is serving trauma tapas.” Mora smirked. “He bookmarked it.” The gallery rippled with quiet, awful amusement. Dream’s fingers tapped his throne. It sounded like a gavel; the actual gavel-headed bailiff looked mildly put out. “You trespassed upon an allocated dreamscape,” Dream said to Mora. “However, you responded to a genuine somatic opening and remained within your mythic function. You,” he turned briefly to First Love, “constructed an experience so delicate that a single intrusive shadow unraveled it.” First Love flushed. “I can adjust. Strengthen. We could add a hand brush with concrete reciprocity. A text message after school. Something resilient.” “We’re litigating a flower field, not a franchise,” Mora muttered. Dream glanced at the sideways hourglass. A few grains had decided to loop in place, indecisive. He was tired of this particular flavor of soap opera. There were wars of gods to choreograph, revolutions to prime with prophetic dreams, a poet somewhere begging for a line. And here: seating arrangements on a thirteen-year-old’s subconscious picnic. He considered, for a moment, letting the dream go feral. See what the boy made of it. But that would be… irresponsible. Deliciously so. A very small smile ghosted at the corner of his mouth. The chamber flinched. “Judgment,” Dream said. The air tightened. “First Love shall retain primary custodianship of the recurring field dreamscape. The wildflowers, the afternoon light, the almost-kiss: these remain. They are necessary.” First Love exhaled, hand over his heart. A few petals appeared and then, bashfully, vanished. “However,” Dream continued, “Mora is recognized as having a legitimate claim to opportunistic manifestation when the subject’s physiology and latent fears render the moment unstable.” Mora’s grin sharpened. “Intermittent haunting rights. I can work with that.” “With conditions,” Dream said. Her grin faded a millimeter. “Knew there’d be those.” “You will not permanently overwrite the likeness of Amelia Reyes. You may… suggest. Distort, when called. The nightmare iteration must be clearly other. You may posture upon his chest three nights in ten when the boy’s sleep is shallow and his search history asks for monsters.” “And the rest of the time?” she said. “The rest of the time, you leave my carefully curated ‘harmless pining playlists’ alone,” First Love put in. Dream ignored him. “The co-presence will create tension. Ambiguity. The Court finds that… educational.” The clerk hesitated. “Educational, my lord?” “Instructive,” Dream said. “Max Kowalski will learn that desire carries risk. That adoration can shade into fear. He will not be granted the courtesy of simple narratives. This is the Dreaming. We are not in the business of tidy.” Mora eyed him appraisingly. “That’s almost nasty, even by my standards.” First Love looked wounded. “But he’s so young.” “He is nearly fourteen,” Dream said. “He dwells in theater club. He will survive nuance.” Mora snorted. “If theater doesn’t kill him first.” “Additionally,” Dream went on, more softly, “on nights of genuine terror—storm, illness, shouted argument down the hall—you, Mora, will abstain from feeding and permit First Love or Comforting Dream Entities to preside. You are not to starve him.” Mora’s eyes narrowed. “You’re no fun.” “You will find I am,” Dream said, “when disobeyed.” The shadows tightened around her like an unspoken warning. Mora lifted her hands in surrender. “Fine. Fine. I’ll skip the kid on plague nights. Let the plush-animals-with-swords brigade tuck him in.” From the benches, a small cluster of stuffed bear spirits waved cheerfully, knives glinting. “Enforcement?” asked the clerk. Dream flicked his fingers. Threads appeared in the air: one pastel, one ink-black, both twined together and speared down toward a waiting sleeping boy in the Waking. They entwined over a painted field, converged at a familiar shape on the horizon: a girl walking toward someone lying in flowers. “He will dream both,” Dream said. “He will never be entirely sure which version waits when she leans in. He will wake breathless. He will, in time, become very interesting.” First Love opened his mouth, then shut it. “If he grows up… maladjusted about affection…” “Blame humanity,” Mora and Dream said together, then looked at each other, faintly displeased by the alignment. “Case concluded,” Dream said. The giant hourglass shivered. For a moment the sand reversed, then decided not to, and carried on. As they dispersed, Mora drifted close to First Love, bumping him with a bony shoulder. “Face it,” she murmured. “We make a good team.” He colored, horrified by the implication. “This is strictly court-mandated collaboration.” “Sure,” she said. “Call me when his first breakup hits. We’ll do a cross-over event.” She melted into shadow. First Love straightened his tie and, after a moment’s thought, added a few extra wildflowers to the invisible design. He, too, faded. On the throne, Dream remained, chin resting on one hand, watching Max Kowalski’s tangled dream-thread with an expression that—on anyone else—would have been called amusement. The bailiff’s gavel-head rotated toward him. “Next petition?” Dream closed his eyes briefly. “Bring it,” he said. The hourglass dripped. The Court of the Dreaming endured.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates remarkable adherence to the complex prompt, successfully creating a courtroom scene in the Dreaming that balances dark fantasy with understated comedy. The writer captures Dream's characteristically aloof yet irritated demeanor perfectly, showing familiarity with Gaiman's Sandman universe while creating an original scenario. The characterizations are particularly strong. Dream maintains his enigmatic, slightly weary persona throughout, with his small smile and final judgment revealing both his mischievous nature and deeper understanding of human complexity. First Love is endearingly earnest yet professional, while Mora strikes an excellent balance between predatory nightmare and pragmatic entity just trying to make a living. The dialogue crackles with personality - Mora's "a girl's gotta eat" defense and casual cruelty, First Love's flustered propriety, and Dream's measured pronouncements all feel authentic to their mythic roles. The worldbuilding is economical yet vivid. Details like the gavel-headed bailiff, the sideways hourglass with upward-falling sand, and the clerk made of moth and archivist parts create a surreal courtroom atmosphere without overwhelming the narrative. The prose maintains an elegant, slightly archaic tone appropriate to the setting while remaining accessible. The comedy emerges naturally from the absurdity of litigating teenage romantic dreams, with moments like First Love's objection based on "tone" and the revelation of Max's browser history providing genuine humor without undermining the story's internal logic. The dark elements - the nature of Mora's feeding, Dream's somewhat cruel final judgment - blend seamlessly with the comedic ones. The resolution is particularly sophisticated, avoiding simple binary outcomes in favor of a complex shared custody arrangement that serves Dream's larger purpose of making Max "very interesting." This feels true to Dream's character and creates narrative tension going forward. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose edges toward preciousness, and some descriptions that while atmospheric, don't always serve the forward momentum. The ending, while thematically appropriate, rushes slightly through the implications of Dream's decision. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The cart wheel lies split and abandoned in the mud by the village gates, still faintly warm from a recent touch. Hoofprints, heel prints, and something like claws furrow the road in frantic overlapping smears. Whoever left did so in haste. Alucard stands beside the broken wheel, coat whispering in the night breeze, hat shadowing a grin too wide for a human face. The village behind him is quiet now but for a distant sob, the creak of a shutter, the sluggish drip of blood. The moon above is swollen and red. “Interesting,” he murmurs. His orange lenses glint, catching the crimson light as though amused. “I smell no fledgling. No half-thing. But something powerful left in a hurry.” Lilac. Gooseberries. The delicate perfume threads through smoke and iron and offal, so out of place he laughs. She’s already watching him. Yennefer of Vengerberg stands ahead in the road, a dark slash against the rust-red sky, hair whipping about her pale face. Her violet eyes are fixed on him with narrow, measuring disdain. The stones at her boots glow faintly with residual heat; where her temper had flared moments ago, an illusion of fire and teeth had sent the peasants scrambling, carts overturning in their panic. She had not expected to find…this. “Vampire,” she says. No fear. A statement. “Witch,” he replies, tasting the word, savoring it. “No. Sorceress. You reek of politics and desperation.” Her chin tilts. “And you reek of old graves and cheap theatrics. Take off those ridiculous glasses.” Alucard chuckles. “You’ll have to make me, girl.” Her lip curls. “Try that again and we’ll find out how quickly your kind can burn.” He steps forward. Leather creaks; the black hellhound-shadows under his coat twitch. Behind the lenses, scarlet eyes gleam. “The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame,” he intones softly. “You don’t want me tame.” Flickers of power gather at her fingertips, white-violet sparks. “I don’t want you at all.” A lie. He smells the tight interest beneath her disgust. Yennefer has lived too long to be bored willingly. An anomaly in this backwater—ancient, brazen, unafraid—intrigues her like a rare spell. He cocks his head. “You used an illusion to send the cattle fleeing. Why? No slaughter. No bodies gutted for some demon. You frightened them, then let them go. How…merciful. Or indecisive.” Her expression hardens. “I needed them gone. Their prayers were getting on my nerves.” His grin shows teeth. “Ah. We share that sentiment.” The moon sinks lower, deeper into its blood hue, and the air shivers. She feels it: a wrongness, oily, sliding beneath her wards. A conjunction out of step with the Continent she knows. Ripples of another world, another metaphysical law, scraping against her own. “What are you doing here?” she demands. “This isn’t your world, leech.” “One might ask the same of you,” he says mildly. “This is not your beloved Continent. Different kings. Uglier churches. Same stench of fear.” Her eyes narrow. “You know my home.” “I know stories,” he says. “Sorceresses who break their spines for beauty. Children turned weapons. Witches who scream that they are not maidens in distress while the world begs them to be.” His smile is soft and cruel. “You resonate.” Rage flares bright in her chest, but she cages it. He wants it. Wants her hot, careless, exposed. She gives him instead a bored glance at his guns, the lining of his coat. “Those oversized toys compensating for something?” she asks. He laughs, genuine delight spilling out. “Sharp little viper.” “I prefer ‘viper’ to ‘girl,’ yes.” He licks a fang. “Then show me your fangs, viper.” The wrongness in the air intensifies, a pulse from the forest beyond the path. Yennefer’s gaze flicks past him, toward a ring of ancient oaks silhouetted black against the red moon. Something is trying to push through. She had come to stop it, or harness it, or twist it toward her own impossible wish. She has not decided which. Alucard notes the shift of her eyes. “Looking for something, sorceress?” “Not anymore,” she lies. “It appears it has found me in another form.” He steps closer. She holds her ground, though every instinct tells her to burn this thing to ash and salt the remains. “You’re not like the vampires I’ve met,” she says. “They hid in crypts, skulked, starved. You stand in the road like you own it.” He spreads his arms theatrically. Shadows unspool from his sleeves, tendrils tipped with eyes and teeth. “I own much more than that.” The display should repulse her. It does. It also fascinates. He watches the flicker of calculation in her eyes. Good. She is not screaming or begging or praying. She is measuring him. A predator’s gaze. “Impressive parlor tricks,” she says. With a lazy gesture, she twists reality around him. The road bends. The world folds. The air compresses. For a human, for most creatures, it would be crushing disorientation. Alucard stands unchanged, boots still planted by the broken wheel. He tilts his head, amused. “Spatial distortion? Cute.” Her jaw tightens minutely. He saw that. He raises a hand. Guns appear, massive and gleaming. He fires. The bullet should take her forehead. Yennefer is already aside, a blur of black and violet. The round hits an invisible plane and dissolves in a flash of molten silver. She snaps her fingers. The mud at his feet becomes a quagmire of grasping hands, spectral limbs clawing, dragging. A wave of white flame roars over him, hot enough to slag steel, tear screams from lesser monsters. His laughter comes from inside the inferno. The flames shudder, twist, and die, devoured by rising blackness. Eyes blossom in the smoke, red upon red, all of them fixed on her. A dozen hounds crawl out of him, their bodies made of shadow and blood. “That tickled,” he says. She feels the strain of drawing that much power in this alien place. The rules here are different. Her usual anchors are dim. She cannot afford waste. “Resilient,” she allows. “Like a fungus.” He bares his teeth, delighted. “You wound me.” “Not yet.” She slashes the air. A storm of obsidian shards materializes above him, each loaded with a binding sigil in Elder Speech. They rain down, piercing coat, flesh, shadow. Alucard’s body spasms, studded and pinned. The earth splits beneath his boots into a sigiled circle. Binding, banishment, disintegration layered at its edges. The grinning mouth falters for a breath. “Oh,” he purrs, voice bubbling through spilled black blood. “Now that is interesting.” “On your knees, monster,” Yennefer says, voice low, sure. He laughs, choked but ecstatic—and collapses willingly into the circle, letting it bite. His form liquefies, flesh unraveling into a swarm of bats, then dragged back together as the sigils flare. She steps closer, testing the prison. “You’re full of yourself,” she says. “Let me guess. You think no one can end you.” He looks up at her through dripping hair and cracked lenses, grin slowly returning. “I’ve been ended many times. It never takes.” “I could make it take.” He believes she might. That amuses him more than it should. “Would you?” he asks, silky. “You’re curious. You want to know why the moon is bleeding, why the worlds are overlapping at the seams. You think killing me will answer that?” She hesitates only in the chamber of her mind. Outwardly, her stare is flat. “You’re an anomaly. A threat. I tidy threats.” “But useful ones,” he presses. “You want power. A path to your lost womb. A way to rip law and causality until they give you what they took. This convergence?” He nods to the blood moon, ignoring the binding’s pull. “It’s born of monsters like me. Kill me, and you close a door.” The words cut close. Too close. “Stay out of my head,” she snaps. He chuckles. “I’m only in your eyes, Yennefer of Vengerberg.” Her name in his mouth raises a shiver she refuses to acknowledge. She answers by tightening the circle. The sigils flare, searing his skin. For a moment, his smile distorts with something nearing pain. His shadows recoil, shrieking. Yennefer leans down, voice soft as a blade’s kiss. “I’m not sweet, and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving. If you become nuisance instead of tool, I’ll end you.” A beat. Then he surges. The binding cracks with a shrill, crystalline scream. Black spears of his will punch through the runes, devour the sigils, drink her power instead of repelled by it. He rises, reforming, taller, broader, coat flaring like a living thing. “Good,” he says, towering over her. “Because I don’t save maidens. I devour them.” For a heartbeat, the power balance flips: his aura floods the road, oppressive, colossal. The villagers whimper behind barred doors. The very shadows bend. Yennefer straightens, shoulders back, face cold as carved obsidian. She will not yield in front of him. She draws from the bleeding sky, from the wrongness, harnessing what should have unmade her. Blood-moon light coils around her like a crown. It’s his turn to pause. “Oh,” Alucard murmurs, eyes bright. “You learn quickly.” “Try me again,” she says. Around them, reality hums warily. “See how tame I make you.” The standoff crystallizes. Two ancient predators framed by an abandoned wheel and a village that will speak of this night only in whispers. He tips his hat, just enough. Respect. Mockery. “I’ll be watching, Yennefer.” “I know,” she says. “I’ll be ready.” They break apart in the same breath. Alucard dissolves into a murder of bats that blot the red moon, then scatter. Yennefer steps through a portal of violet fire, lilac and gooseberries cutting through the stink of blood, vanishing toward the forest and the wound between worlds. The cart wheel lies where it fell, mute testimony to the first meeting of monster and sorceress beneath the blood moon, where neither bowed, and both left hungry.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric writing, successfully capturing the essence of both characters while creating a compelling supernatural encounter. The author effectively establishes the medieval European setting with vivid imagery of the abandoned cart wheel, blood moon, and fearful villagers, creating an appropriately dark and foreboding atmosphere. The characterizations are notably strong. Alucard's sadistic playfulness, arrogance, and philosophical musings about his nature come through authentically, while his distinctive visual elements (red coat, orange glasses, massive guns) are well-incorporated. Yennefer's prideful refusal to show weakness, her calculating nature, and her underlying desperation for what she's lost are skillfully woven throughout. The author captures her signature disdain and sharp tongue effectively. The power dynamic shifts are handled with sophistication - neither character dominates completely, and their mutual fascination beneath the surface hostility feels earned. The magical combat sequence is well-choreographed, with creative use of both characters' abilities. Yennefer's spatial distortion and binding circles contrast nicely with Alucard's shadow manipulation and regeneration. The dialogue crackles with tension and personality. Lines like "Those oversized toys compensating for something?" and Alucard's delighted responses feel true to character while advancing their psychological sparring. The incorporation of their signature quotes feels natural rather than forced. However, the prose occasionally ventures into purple territory with phrases like "coat whispering in the night breeze" and overly elaborate descriptions that slow the pacing. Some metaphors feel overwrought, particularly in the more atmospheric passages. The piece also relies heavily on descriptive telling in places where showing through action might be more effective. The ending strikes an appropriate note - neither character yields, both remain intrigued, and the encounter feels like a beginning rather than a resolution. This aligns well with the prompt's requirements about their circling dynamic. The writing maintains consistent voice and tone throughout, and the 1000-word length is used effectively to develop both characters and their interaction without feeling rushed or padded. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 78.7
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chain-link fences within the yard rattle whenever an inmate passes by. It’s the first sound Jolyne hears when they move her. Different van, different guards, same clang of cheap metal and bad intentions. The sky is a flat slab of gray over the new facility—taller walls, slicker cameras, watchtowers that look more military than correctional. This place smells less like sweat and more like antiseptic and something burnt. She’s walked through enough nightmares to know when something’s wrong in the air. Jolyne steps out in cuffs, butterfly tattoo flexing as she tugs against them. She chews her gum too loud on purpose. Guards flank her with rifles that aren’t standard issue. Their eyes aren’t normal either: flat, glassy, like they’ve had something important scooped out. “Welcome to our special unit, inmate Cujoh,” says a woman in a neat black suit. Jolyne clocks her immediately. Auburn hair, braided back. Perfect uniform, no wrinkles, no badge. The woman’s smile is too soft for this place, like she’s acting in a PSA about kindness. Yellow ringed eyes that look at Jolyne the way someone might look at a stray dog: estimating how quickly it can be trained. “I’m Makima,” she says. “I’ve heard a great deal about you.” “They got fan-mail at this joint now?” Jolyne snorts. “If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney. So what’s with the secret dungeon?” Makima’s expression doesn’t change. She steps closer. The guards don’t move, don’t warn, don’t breathe wrong. They’re already hers. “This facility houses particularly gifted inmates,” Makima says. “Individuals whose abilities are… disruptive. But I’m not your enemy, Jolyne. I’m here to help you make good use of what you can do.” The way she says “what you can do” makes Jolyne’s skin prickle. Stone Free hums in her muscles. Threads of her unravel just enough beneath the skin to taste the air, to feel the tremor of security cameras pivoting, the twitch in the fingertips of a guard who desperately wants to scratch his nose but doesn’t. His hand doesn’t move. Jolyne narrows her eyes. “Funny. Usually when people want to help me, they don’t show up with a pack of meat puppets.” Makima’s gaze flicks to Jolyne’s bound wrists. “If you’d like, I can have those removed. You won’t try to escape.” It’s not a question. “Lady,” Jolyne says, leaning in, “you don’t get to tell me what I will or won’t do.” Makima just keeps smiling. “Take her to Yard C,” she tells the guards. They move like synchronized machinery. Jolyne walks, because walking is better than getting shot, and because she can feel. Every chain-link segment they pass sings a different little note through Stone Free’s awareness: pressure, resonance, pattern. Cameras in overlapping arcs. No blind spots. Some of the guards’ hearts beat too slowly, like someone’s hand is wrapped around them. Yard C is empty. No smokers, no weight benches. Just concrete, high fencing, and a chalk line in the middle like some kind of private arena. The sky presses low. Her cuffs click open. Jolyne rolls her wrists, stretching. “VIP treatment. What, am I supposed to dance?” Makima steps into the yard, hands folded behind her back. The door clanks shut. For a second, all sound dampens. Like the prison is holding its breath. “I requested you,” Makima says. “I oversee certain international concerns. When I heard about a woman whose body becomes string—who can turn herself into something that can bind, infiltrate, connect—I was impressed.” Stone Free unspools from Jolyne’s hand with a soft whisper, coiling loosely around her like a defensive halo. “Yeah? Most people just think it’s weird,” Jolyne says, eyes tracking every subtle movement. “You must be really into arts and crafts.” Makima’s tone never loses its gentle cadence. “Think of this place as an opportunity. Work with me, and your sentence becomes… flexible. Your friends get protection. Your father’s safety improves.” The mention of Jotaro is a thin knife. Jolyne’s strings go taut. “What did you say?” Makima’s eyes brighten minutely. “Much has happened to him, hasn’t it? People who hurt their families are terrible. I dislike terrible people. If I could make sure no one ever touches those you care about again, would you be my dog, Jolyne?” The yard goes cold. Jolyne’s lip curls. “Try that again.” Makima tilts her head. “Be mine. I’ll give you a purpose. A collar is a small price for certainty. I make sure my dogs are… appreciated. They die for me with pride.” Her voice, sweetening, wraps around every word like honey. It wants to sink in. It wants to be believed. Jolyne feels Stone Free quiver; not in fear, but in fury. She’s been pulled, pushed, lied to, locked up. She’s seen people bleed. She’s clawed her way through fates worse than death. No way in hell is she kneeling because some pretty-eyed freak said please. “You talk like the guy who sells candy outside a van,” Jolyne says slowly. “I’ve met priests with god complexes. You’re giving me déjà vu.” She flicks her fingers. String snakes invisibly along the concrete, into the cracks, up the fence. Outward, thin and patient, probing the silent guards on the perimeter. She nudges one’s wrist with a hairline filament. No response. No flinch. “Don’t bother,” Makima says without turning. “They’re mine.” There’s a ripple at the edge of the yard—guards drop to one knee in eerie unison. At Makima’s smallest gesture, they stand. At another, they turn their guns on themselves. Jolyne tenses. “Hey—” “Stop,” Makima says. All motion freezes. Guns lower. Makima looks at Jolyne, eyes soft as ever. “I want you to understand the difference between us. I prevent chaos. I turn worthless fear into order. Men like these, they’re better as tools than as monsters. I can make you better too.” Jolyne bares her teeth. “You touch them like they’re strings on your fingers. You really think I’d look at that and go, ‘Sign me up’?” Makima walks closer, heels ticking against the concrete. The closer she gets, the more Jolyne feels that pressure, like a weight settling onto her shoulders, a tide rising around her ankles. “I think,” Makima says, “you don’t fully grasp that you’re already in my cage. Stone Free is fascinating. Such potential. You turn yourself into chains and thread and nets, but you haven’t seen what true control is. Help me, and I can refine you. Refuse, and I’ll break you into something more useful.” She’s close enough now that Jolyne can see faint shadows beneath her eyes that aren’t human fatigue. Echoes of something older. Stone Free bursts out, full-bodied behind Jolyne: blue skin, visor gleaming, fists clenched. Strings crisscross the yard in a heartbeat, weaving a lattice between them, along the fence, up to the cameras. “Lady, I don’t do leashes,” Jolyne says. “And I sure as hell don’t belong to anyone.” Makima looks up at the Stand. Unimpressed. Interested. “So this is Stone Free,” she murmurs. “You unmake yourself and call it freedom.” She lifts a hand. The guards on the wall lift their rifles, not at Jolyne, but at themselves. “Don’t,” Jolyne snaps. Makima’s ringed eyes don’t leave Jolyne’s face. “Tell me you’ll sit.” The word slithers under Jolyne’s skin, tries to hook into something— —but her strings are everywhere now: woven into the fences, through the rifles, brushing against throats. She feels each body, each gun, like extension of herself. She yanks. Bullets fire upward, into empty air. Guns wrench sideways, ripped by sudden invisible tension. A guard’s finger breaks with a sharp crack as his weapon is torn from his grip. Makima’s hair flutters in the shockwave of displaced gunfire. She doesn’t blink. “Interesting,” she says softly. Jolyne pants, sweat breaking at her temple. “You don’t get to use people like that.” “They’re safer this way.” Makima doesn’t sound defensive. She sounds like she’s correcting a child’s misunderstanding. “You care about them. About everyone. Your father, your friends, strangers. It makes you easy to use. I could make that burden lighter.” Jolyne steps forward through her own web, strings humming like high-tension wires. “Try,” she says. “Try and use me.” Makima’s smile barely widens. “You already are being used. Just not by me yet.” Her fingers twitch. Invisible pressure slams down. Jolyne feels her knees threaten to buckle; Stone Free flickers. The air thickens, tightens, like hands closing around her limbs. A command pulses at the edge of Makima’s lips, not spoken but implied, something that would seize her spine and force it to bow. Sit. The pressure crashes against something that isn’t just flesh. Jolyne’s body is not where Makima expects it to be. She’s string—split along the ankles, laced already through fence, grounded in a dozen points. The command hits, but the target is scattered. She grits her teeth. “You wanna control strings?” she growls. “Bitch, I am the strings.” Stone Free surges, reassembling, her punch rocketing through the tension. Concrete cracks at Makima’s feet as shockwaves blast the yard. Makima tilts her head; the air in front of her shudders. The force disperses, peeling her coat back, but doesn’t break her. Yellow eyes sharpen. For the first time, genuine interest. “Oh,” Makima says. “You might require more… precision.” Sirens begin to scream. Doors clank. But the guards don’t rush in. Not without her say-so. Jolyne’s strings lash out, looping around Makima’s wrists, waist, throat—not quite strangling, but there. Testing. “You’re not sweet,” Jolyne says, voice low. “You’re poison in perfume. I’ve seen enough manipulators to know your type. You talk about making things better, but you don’t feel a damn thing for anyone.” Makima doesn’t resist the bindings. She lets them lie on her like jewelry. “You’re projecting,” she responds kindly. “You’re angry because I understand you. You want to protect everyone, and you’re furious you can’t. I can. If you were mine, you wouldn’t have to be strong all the time.” “Yeah?” Jolyne leans in, strings tightening. “And what happens to your ‘dogs’ when they’re not useful?” Makima’s answer is instantaneous, serene. “It’s okay,” she says. “Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Revulsion spikes through Jolyne. Stone Free’s fists clench. “Then listen up,” Jolyne says. “I’m not your dog. I’m the girl who chokes you with your own leash.” She jerks the strings. Makima’s body snaps forward—then dissolves wetly into a curtain of blood that spatters the concrete. Jolyne’s eyes widen. “The hell—” A drip lands on her shoulder. Makima’s voice comes from behind her. “Execution by compression,” she says mildly. “A clever attempt. You remind me of someone.” Jolyne spins. Makima stands at the edge of the yard, spotless, adjusting her cuffs as if nothing happened. “Persistent,” Makima says. “I like that. You would’ve made a remarkable pet.” Jolyne’s breath saws, heart pounding. She just killed her. She felt the body break. But she didn’t. Something about contracts, immortality, a country bearing the damage in her stead. A devil that never dies right. Jolyne realizes, coldly, that this woman isn’t a Stand user or some random devil. She’s something that rewrites rules. Something that believes everything she sees is hers by default. Makima walks backward toward the door, eyes never leaving Jolyne. “I’ll give you time,” she says. “This facility is mine. The people here are mine. Sooner or later, you’ll either be mine…” Her gaze drops to the strings still threaded through guns and fences. “Or you’ll break trying not to be.” The door buzzes. Opens. She steps through without looking back. Chain-link fences rattle as she goes, a chorus of iron teeth. Stone Free looms at Jolyne’s side, ready. Jolyne spits her gum onto the concrete, jaw set. “Yeah, keep walking, dominatrix discount,” she mutters. “Let’s see who breaks.” In the trembling vibrations of the yard, in cameras she’s secretly strung, in guards’ sleeves and vents and wiring, Jolyne leaves her web. Makima wants a battle of control. She just stepped into the wrong spider’s prison.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt requirements, successfully capturing both characters' distinctive personalities and abilities within a supernatural prison setting. The author shows clear understanding of both source materials, presenting Jolyne's hot-headed defiance and string-based powers alongside Makima's manipulative nature and control abilities. The characterization is particularly strong. Jolyne's voice feels authentic - her profanity, impulsiveness, and fierce independence come through consistently. The famous quote integration feels natural rather than forced. Makima's unsettling pleasantness masking her manipulative nature is well-executed, with her treating humans as disposable tools while maintaining that soft-spoken demeanor. The prose quality is generally solid with some standout moments. The opening with "Chain-link fences within the yard rattle" establishes atmosphere effectively, and descriptions like "Yellow ringed eyes that look at Jolyne the way someone might look at a stray dog: estimating how quickly it can be trained" are vivid and character-revealing. The dialogue crackles with tension and personality. Jolyne's lines like "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney" and "dominatrix discount" feel authentic to her character, while Makima's polite menace comes through in exchanges about dogs and ownership. The conversation builds naturally toward conflict. The action sequences demonstrate creativity in showcasing both characters' abilities. Jolyne's string-based powers are used tactically - spreading through the environment, disrupting weapons, creating a web of control. Makima's instant regeneration after being killed provides an effective demonstration of her otherworldly nature and the futility of conventional attacks. However, the piece has some weaker elements. Certain descriptions verge on overwrought, particularly in the middle sections where the prose becomes slightly dense with metaphor. The pacing occasionally slows during exposition dumps about the characters' abilities. Some dialogue exchanges, while generally strong, occasionally feel slightly stilted in their delivery of exposition. The ending successfully establishes the ongoing conflict without forcing resolution, appropriate for this type of confrontational scene. The final imagery of Jolyne creating her web throughout the prison provides a strong visual conclusion that promises future conflict. Technical execution is mostly solid, with good paragraph structure and scene transitions. The third-person present tense is maintained consistently throughout. The length requirement is met effectively without feeling padded. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 8 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 8.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Euclid (Pending reclassification) Special Containment Procedures: As of this report, I—Dr. Elias Mercer, Research Division, Site-73—am both subject and primary documentarian of the events described. Per O5 directive, the following baseline measures were in place during the period of interest: - All handwritten notes discovered in my office, lab, quarters, or adjacent corridors were to be: - Photographed in situ; - Collected using sterile tweezers and sealed in tamper-evident evidence bags; - Logged under Incident Series MERCER-TEMP/01–██. - All writing instruments in my possession and in my department’s inventory were cataloged, chemically profiled, and RFID tagged. - Continuous CCTV and audio surveillance was maintained for my office, lab, and quarters. - Weekly psychological evaluations were mandated; frequency increased to daily after MERCER-TEMP/07. - Access restrictions were implemented to limit my exposure to cognitohazardous SCPs, temporal anomalies, and any entity with known reality-altering capacities. I have been advised that if this document is determined to be the product of memetic infection or anomalous coercion, it will be reclassified. Until then, it stands as my formal SCP report. Note: Portions of this report are interspersed with direct transcriptions of the notes I found. These are marked as such. — I first found a note on 2025-07-02, at 08:11, on my desk beneath my security badge. [NOTE 01] Elias— Do not request reassignment. You stay at Site-73. You survive that way. (I know you don’t trust this yet. But I remember not trusting it.) —E.M. The handwriting was mine. Not “similar to mine,” not traced, not an imitation. It was mine in the way you recognize your own signature: the slight rightward hook, the habitual pressure on downstrokes. I had not written it. My initial assumption was a prank or a test. I logged it as an anomalous occurrence per protocol. Security confirmed no unauthorized entries to my office. CCTV footage showed my desk from 06:00 to 08:11. The paper was not present at 08:10:16. It was present at 08:10:17. No visible insertion, no distortion, no frame glitch. Ink analysis (Lab Report CHM-73-021) showed a black ink with trace elements of molybdenum, osmium, and an unidentified organometallic compound not matching any registered office pen, Foundation-standard or commercial. That was enough to flag it as an anomaly. At the time, I still thought: test. The second note appeared three days later, taped inside my locker. [NOTE 02] You think this is a temporal anomaly test. It’s not. Triple-check SCP-████’s secondary seals on 07/19. The technicians will miss a microfracture. Don’t confront them. Just fix it. —Future You I reported it. Containment specialists were called in. On 07/19, we inspected SCP-████’s containment chamber. There was, in fact, a hairline microfracture in one of the secondary seals; pressure readings were anomalously low by 0.3%. It would likely have been caught on the next scheduled inspection, but the timing matched the note exactly. Correlation is not causation, but causation was suggested. Temporal analysts from Site-19 reviewed the materials. Hypotheses ranged from: - Localized short-term retrocausality. - An infohazard using “future self” as narrative packaging. - Psychological manipulation by an entity with limited omniscience. We did not, at this point, have an entity that fit. The third note disturbed me. It appeared in my pocket. [NOTE 03] Check inside your left coat pocket at 13:27. (See? Now can we stop pretending?) The event starts 08/04. It looks small. It’s not. Found at 13:27 exactly, 2025-07-23, in my left coat pocket. Security footage from that morning showed me hanging the coat up at 08:02 with empty pockets (they had been inspected earlier). The coat remained in view. No one approached it. No paper was visible until I reached into the pocket and removed it. I began having trouble sleeping. Not because of the notes themselves, but because of the precision: the flat, unremarkable tone of my own handwriting, speaking from a place just beyond my timeline. I requested amnestics as a control. Denied. Instead they gave me more observation. As the notes continued, their content escalated. [NOTE 04] Do not evacuate when the first alarm sounds. It’s a false trigger. If you go to the stairwell, you die. Lock your office door. Wait. Watch for the second alarm. You can save eight if you move then. I didn’t, the first time. These instructions had specific timestamps. On 08/04, a containment alarm did sound—malfunction in a Tier-2 wing. Evacuation order followed protocol. I had a choice: follow the note or follow training. I locked my office door. Security later confirmed the first alarm was indeed a malfunction, traced to a faulty sensor. The stairwell I would have used was briefly compromised due to a collapsed light fixture; the probability of lethal injury was non-zero. The second alarm, at 14:32, corresponded to an actual breach in an adjacent wing. I acted then—pulling two technicians and a research assistant away from Corridor D-4 moments before it flooded with anesthetic gas. It looked like I’d had sharp instincts. I showed them the note. By then, no one was laughing. We increased scrutiny. All notes were logged, scanned, analyzed. The ink remained chemically anomalous: same nonstandard trace elements, same unknown compound. Paper stock was Foundation generic, but batch numbers didn’t match Site-73 inventory. A minor temporal offset was detected in three samples: a statistically significant deviation in radioactive decay products consistent with aging of 12–19 days beyond their documented time of discovery. “Evidence of temporal displacement,” they said. “Or extremely careful forgery,” they also said. Then the contradictions started. [NOTE 07] You remember when SCP-2215 breached last year and took Kaur’s eyes? That escalates here. Containment fails on Level 3 at 02:17. Do NOT let them send Kaur downstairs this time. There is no SCP-2215 at Site-73. Dr. Anjali Kaur was alive, uninjured, and assigned to a separate project. She had both eyes. No record—no redacted history, no sealed archive—indicated any prior breach matching the described event. When I raised this, they told me: “An inaccurate future memory. Either error or manipulation.” The notes, however, began citing highly specific internal file designations I had never accessed: - [REDACTED] project codes, - Timestamped security reports from branches I’d never worked with, - Personal secrets of staff members later confirmed in private interviews. If it was psychological manipulation, it was thorough. My own perception began to fray. Recognition impulses misfired. I would glance at a new note and know what it said before reading it, like remembering writing it and also not writing it. My handwriting on incident forms started to drift toward the slightly more cramped form seen on the later notes. The next relevant note read: [NOTE 10] You’re starting to question your own memory. Good. You should. They’re already in it. Check the ink again. It’s not just from “now.” Look at the decay curves. Look at ME. We’ve done this so many times. Ink analysis was repeated using more sensitive equipment. This time, they found something else: in several samples, isotopic ratios suggested not just a small temporal lead, but inconsistent aging in opposite directions—some appearing “younger” than their collection date. The report used the phrase “nonlinear chronology.” A meeting was convened: temporal department, psych division, Site command. Two main proposals: 1) Temporal anomaly: - Genuine information leakage from a near-future self across small intervals. - Nonlinear or branching timeline structure, with notes bleeding through iterations. - Contradictions attributed to different timeline histories. 2) Cognitohazard/Entity interference: - An entity, potentially contained at Site-73, mimicking my handwriting and knowledge. - Goal: engineer specific actions or paranoia. - Ink and isotopic anomalies the result of anomalous manufacture, not time travel. I sat there while they debated whether I was talking to myself across time or to something wearing my face. I was not given a vote on which possibility hurt less. The notes grew more frantic. [NOTE 14] This is the iteration where you try to ignore me. Don’t. You thought the breach was SCP-████. That was never the real event. It’s ███ in Lab 5. It learns your patterns. It fakes errors. It fakes alarms. It fakes ME. Trust me: at 03:12, when the siren sounds steady, stay put. At 03:13, when it stutters, RUN. Lab 5 contained SCP-████-B, an infohazardous pattern-recognition parasite under study, with no known temporal properties but some capacity for influencing selective attention. It was a candidate. Psych suggested the entity could be extrapolating from surveillance and text samples to create personalized intrusive content. But: - Notes contained secure data from air-gapped archives. - Notes manifested physically in secure spaces with no recorded ingress. - Observed temporal offsets in material composition remained unexplained. “We cannot rule out that SCP-████-B is learning in ways we do not yet understand,” they said. “We also cannot rule out Mercer as an unwitting vector,” they said. They moved me to an observation suite. No personal pens. No private access. Everything recorded. Notes still appeared. On the wall above my bed: [NOTE 17] You volunteered for this part. We thought if we boxed ourselves in, they couldn’t get to us. They can. Stop looking for the ‘real’ one. There isn’t one. Just don’t go to the door when they say Kaur is hurt. It’s not her. I opened it. That’s how we died that time. Two hours later, at 01:46, an urgent knock on the observation room door. A voice: “Dr. Mercer, it’s Kaur. I need your help. They locked me out.” CCTV later confirmed: no one in the corridor. Motion sensors registered nothing. The voice, however, was recorded. It matched Dr. Kaur’s vocal profile at 98.7%. I did not open the door. I watched the handle twitch without moving. After that incident, even the skeptics stopped calling this “just stress.” The notes became less predictive, more contradictory—insisting on mutually exclusive events: [NOTE 21] SCP-2215 is in the vents. (There is no SCP-2215.) [NOTE 22] You never worked with SCP-████. (I did; I had clearance.) [NOTE 23] Kaur is already dead. Stop talking to her. (Kaur was alive; I spoke to her that morning.) [NOTE 24] You’re remembering the wrong version. They’re feeding you the one where you’re sane. I could feel my own memory restructuring around the words. Moments of double-exposure: seeing my hand seal a fracture I had never, in this line, encountered. Smelling smoke from a fire that hadn’t happened. Hearing a siren pattern I could describe in perfect detail but had never lived through. Psych evals started listing: - Emerging dissociation. - Early-stage temporal dislocation syndrome (unconfirmed). - Possible infohazard exposure; recommended isolation, possible amnesticization. Temporal division recommended: - Immediate quarantine of all MERCER-TEMP materials. - Provisional designation SCP-████-M. - Termination of my access to predictive content. I objected. They recorded my objection as “increased identification with anomaly.” The final note I will include (subsequent ones are under separate clearance) appeared inside this very report draft while I was typing. I watched the page. It was blank. I blinked, and the ink was there. [NOTE 29] We keep trying to write it as an SCP so it becomes containable. Neat. Classified. Past tense. It isn’t. When you sign this, they’ll think it’s just you unraveling, or a clever temporal loop. Either way, they won’t listen when it matters. So this time, leave this sentence: The breach has not happened yet. Make them read it. — Addendum (Personal): My name is Dr. Elias Mercer. I am aware that some of the content above is unverifiable or self-contradictory. I am aware that my testimony may be compromised, whether by an temporal anomaly, by SCP-████-B, by some as-yet-unidentified entity, or by my own deteriorating mental state. I am also aware of the ink: - It is mine and not mine. - It comes from no pen in this Site. - It ages at the wrong speed. You will classify this as you see fit. I am writing this in the hope that, in at least one version of events, someone reads it before the breach I have been warned about—but not yet lived—occurs. As of the time of submission, Site-73 has not experienced the catastrophic containment breach described in several of the notes. As of the time of submission, I remember it anyway.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional craft in executing a complex SCP Foundation narrative that skillfully blends psychological horror with temporal anomaly themes. The author maintains the clinical, bureaucratic tone characteristic of SCP documentation while weaving in first-person uncertainty that creates genuine unease. The structure is masterfully handled, using the format of an SCP report interspersed with the discovered notes to create escalating tension. The progression from skepticism to confusion to terror feels organic and well-paced. The handwriting analysis, isotopic dating, and other pseudo-scientific elements are convincingly presented without becoming overly technical. The central conceit - notes from a future self warning of a containment breach - is executed with remarkable sophistication. The author cleverly introduces contradictions and impossible information that force both protagonist and reader to question what's real. The notes themselves feel authentically desperate and fragmented, with the voice shifting subtly as they progress. Character work is strong within the constraints of the format. Dr. Mercer's voice remains consistent while showing believable psychological deterioration. His scientific training conflicts with increasingly inexplicable evidence, and his responses feel genuine - neither too credulous nor stubbornly skeptical. The horror elements are particularly effective. The fake voice of Dr. Kaur, the door handle twitching without moving, and the final note appearing while the protagonist types create visceral moments of dread. The ending's ambiguity - leaving unclear whether this is temporal anomaly, entity manipulation, or psychological break - is perfectly pitched. The prose is clean and purposeful, avoiding both clinical dryness and overwrought description. Technical elements like isotopic analysis and containment procedures feel authentic without overwhelming the narrative. The piece maintains excellent pacing throughout its considerable length. Minor weaknesses include occasional repetitive phrasing around the uncertainty theme, and some SCP elements that feel slightly generic (the pattern-recognition parasite, standard containment procedures). However, these don't significantly detract from an otherwise exceptional piece of speculative fiction that fully realizes its ambitious premise. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 84.3
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: All instances of SCP-████-A (hereafter “doors”) are to be secured in place and concealed within existing abandoned structures using standard perimeter protocols (false demolition notices, restricted-zone designations, embedded security teams). Mobile Task Force Tau-9 (“Stack Watchers”) is assigned to locate, document, and—where feasible—quarantine new SCP-████-A instances. Doorways are not to be opened without Level 4/████ approval and a designated exploration team equipped with: - Full-body recording systems. - Tethered guidance line. - Portable wayfinding beacons (note: standard GPS nonfunctional). - EM, thermal, and cognitohazard monitoring suites. All personnel entering SCP-████-B (the interior space) must undergo post-mission debriefs including Class-K mnestic screening. Unauthorized access by personnel of any clearance is grounds for immediate detainment. Protocol ARX-Null is in development for direct O5 oversight. Until ratified, any attempt by any O5 Council member to access SCP-████-A or SCP-████-B without recorded consensus vote is to be logged as a Priority Alpha ethics violation. Description: SCP-████ is a network of anomalous entryways (SCP-████-A) manifesting inside abandoned structures worldwide, all leading to a shared non-Euclidean extradimensional environment designated SCP-████-B. SCP-████-A instances: - Appear as plain, unmarked metal doors with a single horizontal push-bar and no visible lock. - Are architecturally inconsistent with host buildings (non-matching hinges, frame alloys, etc.). - In multiple cases exhibit corrosion, wear, and stratified paint layers older than both the structure and recorded construction on the site. Carbon dating of removed particulates returns inconsistent results, including pre-human dates and values exceeding test baselines. Opening any SCP-████-A from the host side reveals SCP-████-B. Closing the door and reopening from the host side consistently re-establishes connection with SCP-████-B. Attempts to open the door from within SCP-████-B lead to additional corridors of SCP-████-B; subjects are unable to exit via these interior doors unless guided to the original frame. SCP-████-B is a massive, architecturally impossible archive composed of: - Vast aisles of shelves, cabinets, and compactors containing paper records, magnetic tapes, optical media, unidentified crystalline storage units, and devices not matching any known technological chronology. - Ceilings and support structures shifting between architectural styles (brutalist concrete, eroded stone vaulting, metallic trusses) without transition. Sightlines extend beyond visible limits; laser range-finding yields variable distances. - Environmental conditions of stable ~18°C, low humidity, and subdued, sourceless illumination. The majority of accessible records within SCP-████-B: - Are labeled in English or close cognates, with standardized indexing codes inconsistent with Foundation filing systems. - Reference a global human civilization maintaining a centralized anomaly-containment directorate. The organization is referred to across documents as “The Custodial Authority,” “The Directorate,” or “The Continuity Commission.” - Describe the systemic containment of anomalous objects, entities, and phenomena, structurally analogous to modern Foundation practices. - Refer to an unspecified “Global Cascading Containment Failure” culminating in Class-Ω (“Terminal”) restructuring events. No direct cause is documented in plain text; numerous files terminate with [UNSPECIFIED REDACTION] or “ACCESS REVOKED BY DECREE OF THE THIRTEEN.” Notably, multiple sections of SCP-████-B contain personnel dossiers, incident reports, and site schematics for the present-day SCP Foundation and its staff. Many such documents: - Are dated between 300–900 years prior to current CE. - Contain accurate biographical details of currently active personnel (including dates of birth that match our reality), with projected career trajectories and termination causes not yet occurred. - Reference our organization under alternate names (“Second Foundation,” “Residual Commission,” “Post-Custodial Regime”) before converging on “SCP Foundation.” Cross-comparative analysis indicates continuity of institutional identity between the Custodial Authority and the SCP Foundation may be implied, recursive, or externally enforced. Investigation is ongoing. Addendum ████.1 — Initial Discovery: SCP-████-A was first confirmed in an abandoned textile mill in ███████, Latvia. The door was visibly older than the surrounding 1950s brickwork; metallurgical analysis suggested at least three distinct refurbishments across several centuries. Opening the door revealed SCP-████-B. Subsequent searches of abandoned facilities worldwide (factories, hospitals, Cold War bunkers, derelict commercial buildings) located 37 additional SCP-████-A instances. All granted access to SCP-████-B. Clock-synchronized teams entering through different SCP-████-A locations have achieved visual and radio contact with one another, confirming a shared topology. Addendum ████.2 — Exploration Logs (Excerpted) All logs presented from third-person operational perspective. Nonessential chatter removed. Exploration 1: Survey Entry Team: E-3 (“Card Catalog”) Lead: Agent Mercer Objective: Initial mapping and document retrieval. Summary: Upon entry, E-3 encountered a primary atrium: shelving reaching an estimated 40 m, metal gantries crossing at inconsistent angles. No dust, no insects, no visible power sources. Ambient hum at 60 Hz equivalent. E-3 progressed 600 m along Aisle Designate ALPHA-17 before returning due to tether tension limit. Recovered Documents (Excerpts): Doc-████-B-12: “Continuity Commission Central Archive / Incident Family: Ω-Chain / Note: Global structuring complete. All anomalies either integrated or neutralized save for [UNSPECIFIED REDACTION]. Thirteen authorize transfer of residual records to Deep Archive. Post-Custodial Regime to inherit under sealed mandate.” Doc-████-B-19: “Personnel: PROVISIONAL SITE-19 ADMINISTRATIVE TRAINEE FILE Name: Sophia Mercer Clearance: Pending Level 3 Projected Service Period: 20██–20██ Notes: High compliance probability. Candidate suitable for frontline archive-contact operations.” Agent Mercer of E-3 denied prior knowledge of this file. Biographical data matched her Foundation HR record, including a childhood medical incident never documented outside secure files. Exploration 4: Deep Access and Hazmat Entities Team: E-5 (“Loose Pages”) Objective: Penetrate deeper; identify technological or temporal markers. At 1.8 km from origin, E-5 entered a wide corridor marked with black-on-yellow chevrons and text in English: “RECLAMATION IN PROGRESS — AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY.” Team observed three humanoid entities at end of corridor, height approx. 1.9 m, wearing matte white full-body hazmat suits with opaque faceplates and no visible logos. Entities were transferring file boxes and bound volumes from shelves into featureless black containers. No ambient sound aside from movement. On noticing E-5, all entities: - Exhibited startle response. - Sealed containers via a rapid, fluid mechanism. - Retreated around a corner at speeds exceeding human sprint capability. - Ignored verbal hails; one glanced back, faceplate briefly transparent, revealing no facial features, only dark, depthless interior. Pursuit resulted in spatial distortion. Corridor elongated; wayfinding beacons indicated contradictory headings. Short pursuit (~30 seconds subjective) ended with E-5 returning unintentionally to original entry atrium. Attempted re-navigation to “Reclamation” corridor failed; signage absent. Recovered Fragment: “Reclamation Directive 7: Removal of unstable or contradictory chronicle lines awaiting consolidation. Field archivists to prioritize materials referencing non-viable Second and Third formations. Contact with derivatives is non-permissible.” Exploration 7: O5 Correlation Team: E-7 (“Margin Notes”) Objective: Targeted search of labeled “Governance” and “Council” sections. At approximately 2.3 km from entry, E-7 discovered a mezzanine reading hall. Furniture layer styles inconsistent by century. Central table bore open folders and a silver access keycard (design not used by Foundation). Documents recovered included: Doc-████-GOV-03: “Thirteenfold Council — Membership Roster Rev. 7 Chair: O5-1 … Note: Cross-iteration variance stabilizing. Prohibition on direct Archive ingress reiterated. Violations by members 3, 7, 11 recorded; disciplinary measures pending. Repeated infractions may induce bleed-through with successor formations.” Doc-████-GOV-09: “Memorandum: Any Councilor entering Archive without collective assent risks contaminating ongoing Reconstruction. Their appearances in prior layers compromise narrative integrity. Last warning issued following unauthorized visitations logged under identities: — ‘O5-3’ — ‘O5-7’ — ‘O5-11’” Margin annotations (same handwriting, different ink colors) read: - “It won’t matter if we are the last.” - “We were not first.” - “They think they’re external. They’re not.” Security Audit Correlation: Foundation access records show no authorized SCP-████ entries by O5-3, O5-7, or O5-11 prior to this exploration. Unexplained gaps of 3–7 hours exist in their personal itineraries corresponding to approximate time stamps in Doc-████-GOV-09. Exploration 9: Active Removal, Direct Observation Team: E-9 (“Index Error”) Objective: Confirm prior references to “Reclamation,” observe entities. Four hazmat-suited entities were observed clearing an aisle marked: “POST-CUSTODIAL REGIME / SCP FOUNDATION / REVISION 2–5 (NON-STABLE).” They loaded boxes labeled with familiar containment designations into black containers. Labels included SCP-███, SCP-2000, SCP-001 (multiple variants), and “PROJECT O5 EMERGENCE — FAILED.” When E-9 approached within 20 m, entities froze. One raised a hand in a recognizable “stop” gesture; another produced a device emitting a narrow beam of violet light over the shelves. Text on box spines faded, leaving blank cartons which then dematerialized. Third-person observation noted: - Entities moved with urgency but without overt hostility. - Their behavior was analogous to evidence technicians compromised mid-operation. Upon E-9 closing distance to ~10 m, entities abruptly retreated. Aisle elongated; lighting dimmed. Audio captured a brief, artificial whisper: “Derivative contact. Seal corridor.” E-9’s beacons registered overlapping coordinates; visual feeds cut to static for 3.2 seconds. When signal returned, team was positioned two aisles away with no recollection of transition. Target aisle gone. Fragment retrieved from floor (Doc-████-R-21, partial): “—Failure of primary Continuity (Custodial Authority) necessitated seeding of successor paradigms. Most remain non-viable. The SCP Foundation variant shows partial adherence but increasing self-referential instability. Reclamation Teams will continue to remove deprecated narratives and personnel iterations. Thirteen are advised: DO NOT ENTER ARCHIVE PHYSICALLY. Your presence generates bleed. This is the last stable shelf.” Note ends in abrupt ink smear. Addendum ████.3 — Internal Commentary and Status: - Cross-testing confirms multiple recovered “personnel files” for current Foundation staff are exact or near-exact matches to secure HR records, including materials never digitally stored. - Dated centuries-old references to current O5 designations, Sites, and SCP numerical frameworks suggest either: - Recursive documentation from prior cycles. - External authorship treating our history as one branch of controlled experiment. - Evidence that SCP-████-B perceives or indexes temporal development non-linearly. - O5-3, O5-7, and O5-11 jointly deny unauthorized ingress. No explanation is provided for itinerary gaps. When confronted with Doc-████-GOV-09, all three display statistically significant stress markers but maintain denial. Ethics Committee Note: The explicit warnings within SCP-████-B suggest that direct high-level interaction with the Archive may contribute to systemic destabilization of our own continuity. Until further notice, SCP-████ is to be considered both: - A critical informational asset regarding at least one prior failed global containment paradigm; and - A potential vector for the same class of failure. All proposals involving exploitation, retrocausal editing, or preemptive alteration based on SCP-████ records are suspended pending conclusive determination of whether we are: - inheritors of the Custodial Authority, - one of multiple experimental “successor regimes,” - or an already archived, soon-to-be-removed iteration.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional adherence to the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving a complex narrative about recursive containment failures and temporal loops. The author successfully captures the distinctive voice of SCP documentation - dry, technical, yet building an underlying sense of existential dread. The piece excels in its structural authenticity, following SCP format conventions precisely while embedding genuinely unsettling implications. The concept of hazmat entities removing documentation about the Foundation itself creates a compelling meta-textual horror - the organization discovering it may be merely one iteration in a cycle of failed containment regimes. The exploration logs effectively build tension through measured revelations, particularly the discovery that current personnel have centuries-old files and that O5 members are secretly accessing the archive. The writing maintains consistent clinical tone throughout, which serves the horror well - the matter-of-fact documentation of reality-breaking discoveries creates cognitive dissonance that enhances the unsettling atmosphere. Imagery is precise and evocative without breaking voice: "faceplates briefly transparent, revealing no facial features, only dark, depthless interior" effectively conveys alien menace within technical constraints. The narrative structure builds logically from initial discovery through increasingly disturbing revelations to the final existential uncertainty about the Foundation's nature. Each exploration log reveals new layers of the mystery while maintaining internal consistency. The hazmat entities' behavior - retreating when observed but methodically removing evidence - suggests purposeful activity that adds to the paranoid atmosphere. However, the piece occasionally becomes dense with technical details that, while authentic to the format, can impede narrative flow. Some exploration logs feel more procedural than dramatically necessary. The ending, while thematically appropriate, leaves perhaps too many threads unresolved even for the SCP format's typical ambiguity. The meta-textual elements work particularly well - having Foundation personnel discover their own files dated centuries ago, and the implication that they may be unwitting participants in a larger cycle, creates genuine philosophical horror about identity and agency. The warnings against O5 involvement that are apparently being ignored add immediate dramatic irony. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first time he stepped alone into the streets of Kharas Port, Rian felt the cloak on his shoulders like a declaration of foreignness. He had been warned. Envoys did not walk without escort, not on a world whose reports used words like “tensions,” “episodes,” and the careful euphemism “speciative divergence.” He had been told that Kharas had delicate balances, that his person was both symbol and target. He had been told many things in the briefings aboard the relay station.
