But the shuttle down that morning had skimmed over folded ranges the color of dried blood, and the light—even behind the shuttle’s filters—had been a pale, hard gold, and something in him said: I cannot speak for a world I have not walked. So when the ceremonial luncheon stretched long, when the local Delegates’ talk frayed into repetitions and compliments, he excused himself on the pretense of fatigue, slipped past the adjutant guarding his door, and found the service stair that smelled of dust and metal. No one stopped him. No one expected the offworlder to be foolish. Outside, the light struck him like a hand. The buildings of Kharas Port were low and pale, stone or something that looked like stone, beaded with embedded glass to throw heat back into the white sky. The streets were narrow and shaded by cloth canopies—faded reds and blues, hung with bits of polished bone and bright metal that chimed in the wind. The air carried sand and spice and the faint, sweet-bitter tang of the native vegetation he had read about and not really imagined. He had been told the colonists had adapted, been altered, become multiple. In the briefing holo, the Minister’s voice—formal, patient—had described “variant clades, distinct phenotypes, fully interfertile where not culturally constrained, classified under unified citizenship law.” It had sounded clean. Contained. The first person to pass him was a child. She stared unabashedly. She wore only a short dark wrap, twisted neatly at the hip, bare torso and arms sun-brown and dust-dappled. Along her ribs and shoulders, the skin had a faint patterned thickening, a matte sheen, like fine overlapping scales. Her hair was colorless white, like fibers sun-bleached too long. Her pupils were narrowed to vertical slits against the light. “You’re covered,” she said, and laughed as if it were preposterous. “Are you cold?” Rian drew the cloak closer by reflex. It was thin filtration weave, standard issue for offworlders on high-UV planets; its dark hood cast his face in shadow. He wondered how he looked to her. “No,” he said. “I’m not used to the sun here.” She considered this, decided it was an acceptable explanation, and ran off, feet sure on the hot stone. He walked. The market opened like a sudden garden between buildings: stalls of woven shadecloth, tables layered with goods. Fruit with translucent skins, beading with clear juice. Woven mats of plant fiber patterned in spirals. Vials of concentrated pollens, bright as ground gemstones. Tools of pale metal, jointed like insect limbs. The sound of bargaining rose and fell, a language of clipped consonants, with another language braided through it, softer vowels, the official Standard they had been required to keep. People noticed him. He saw three men with deep chests and long, ridged necks, skin dark and smooth, who moved with a slow deliberation that made the air around them seem thicker. A young courier streaked past in a flash of limbs, his toes elongated, gripping the street as if every surface belonged to him. Two women stood together in disputing postures, one fine-boned and tall with membrane-thin webbing between finger and thumb, the other shorter, solid, with hair coarse and dark, her eyes wide and round. They were arguing over the price of grain; their words were sharp, intimate, nothing to do with gene-flow charts and legal categories. The official briefing had spoken of “clades.” Here, he heard other words: - “Sky-bloods,” hissed by a man half in shade when Rian passed. - “Stone-sisters,” said with teasing affection. - “Sandkin, come on, you’re slowing us—” And: “Offworlder,” murmured, speculative, from a stall he had paused beside. The stall mistress was old, or what passed for old here: her skin a network of fine creases, her shoulders strong. Thickened dermal plates along her jaw caught the light. She sold nothing obvious, only small gray cylinders laid out on cloth. “What are those?” he asked. Her nostrils flared; she was not smelling him, not exactly. “Filters,” she said. “For the western wells. We make them. Your ships don’t drink this planet raw; why should we?” He had read about contamination, about engineered microbes and native biochemistry. “In the reports, it says the wells are under central regulation.” “In the reports,” she agreed, the corner of her mouth twitching. “We sell them anyway. You walk alone, envoy?” “I do,” he said. “Hmm.” She tapped a cylinder against her palm. “They told us you would come with guards and numbers. That you would speak only to Minsters and Chairs.” She nodded toward his cloak. “That you would wrap yourself as if our air were a poison.” “Is it?” he asked, before he could stop himself. “Not to us,” she said. “Tell them that.” He moved on, feeling watched but not threatened, not yet. Two boys called something after him he did not catch; a woman in a shaded doorway studied him as one might a tool that had not yet proven its use. Above, between awnings, he glimpsed the high pale sky, the hard light under which these people had remade themselves. He saw no separate districts for clades, no colored bands or armlets as the more alarmist memos from Command had suggested “might eventuate.” He saw people who bore their differences on their skin and in their bones, and went about the work of being alive. He lost track of time. By the time he found his way back to the Administration House, the light had shifted perceptibly. The adjutant at the entrance stepped forward, face set. “Envoy,” she said. “You are requested. Now.” They did not walk him to the main conference room, but to a smaller secure chamber off his assigned quarters. The walls had the dull finish of sound-dampening. The table recognized his handprint and brought the waiting call to life: Commander Halden’s face, narrow and controlled, floating above the interface. “Envoy Rian,” Halden said, no courtesies wasted. “You left secured premises without escort.” “Yes,” Rian said. His mouth was dry. The cloak had trapped all the heat of the day against his skin; he did not take it off. “You are aware that this constitutes a breach of protocol under Article—” “Yes.” Halden’s gaze sharpened. “Explain.” “I went to see the city,” Rian said. He thought of the girl’s laughter. The old woman’s dry amusement. The layered voices of the market. “My mandate is to facilitate negotiation between the local administration and the Council. I cannot do that from a series of controlled briefings and luncheon speeches. The situation on the ground—” “The situation ‘on the ground’ is volatile,” Halden cut in. “Our intelligence indicates rising agitation among several clades. There have been attacks on offworld assets. You are a symbol. You do not freelance. Understood?” “Yes, Commander,” Rian said. He kept his voice level. “Understood.” Halden studied him, then leaned back. “Given your…initiative, you can discharge a useful task. The Minister of Science wishes to meet. You will attend on her within the hour.” Rian blinked. “Within the— I just returned.” “You are the Council’s envoy,” Halden said. “Not a tourist. The Minister is a political appointee with considerable influence over local policy and narrative. Her support is essential; her opposition could derail this mission. You will confirm for her that our objective is stability within the framework of Unified Law.” Rian hesitated. “And if her understanding of ‘stability’ conflicts with ours?” Halden’s mouth thinned. “Then you will test her thinking without provoking a breach. That is what you were trained for, is it not? We will be listening. Don’t go off-script again.” The transmission cut. Silence returned, thick as the heat under his cloak. Rian let out breath he did not quite remember holding. He was escorted this time. The Minister’s office occupied the uppermost level of the Administration House, where the windows were shielded but wide, looking out over the city toward the pale line of the horizon. She rose when he entered: tall, slender, wearing a simple tunic the color of old paper. Her skin was unremarkable, her features almost textbook human-standard, save for a faint spectral luminosity in the whites of her eyes, as if they caught a broader band of light. “Envoy Rian,” she said. Her voice was warm, textured with age and something like amusement. “You look overheated. The cloak is unnecessary inside; this glass drinks most of the UV.” He did not reach for the clasp. “Minister Sera,” he said, inclining his head. “Thank you for seeing me on such short notice.” “I requested you yesterday,” she said. “Command delayed you. Sit.” He sat. The furniture was local: pale, light, subtly curved, shaped for bodies he now knew might be broader in the chest, differently jointed at knee or hip. It made him aware of his own proportions. “First,” Sera said, folding her hands, “tell me where you have been.” He kept his face neutral. “My shuttle landed this morning. I attended the welcoming luncheon—” “After,” she said. He met her gaze. “I walked in the market.” A flicker. Not surprise. Confirmation. “Alone?” “Yes.” “And how did our deviations appear to you?” she asked lightly. “Threatening? Pitiful? Picturesque?” He thought of the little girl’s vertical pupils, the stall mistress’s dermal plates. The webbed fingers, the ridged necks. He thought of the easy mingling, the arguments over grain. “Adapted,” he said. “Varied. Alive.” “One out of three will irritate Command,” she said. “The others will baffle them.” She leaned back. “Halden would prefer you see only what comes through approved channels. Data curated. Encounters staged. An envoy who wanders unchaperoned introduces noise.” “Truth is noisy,” Rian said, before he could stop himself. Her smile did not quite reach her eyes. “Oh, the Council has sent us an idealist.” She turned her chair slightly, glancing at the hazed view beyond the glass. “You’ve read the files. Tell me, then: what is wrong here?” Rian heard the soft hum of the room’s recorders; he imagined parallel channels routing to Command. He chose his words. “The reports emphasize the risk of ‘speciation’ as a political fracture,” he said. “They frame clades as potential factions, manipulable identities. They suggest re-standardization measures: incentives for interbreeding, restrictions on further environmental tailoring. But in the streets I saw…less fracture than I expected, and more resentment than the numbers show. Toward offworld directives. Toward the sense of being managed.” “Managed,” she repeated. “By whom?” “By the Council,” Rian said. “By you.” “Good,” she murmured. “You are not entirely naïve.” She regarded him. “Tell me: if Command instructed you to advocate for forbidding further adaptive lines on Kharas, would you do so?” It was too direct. It was deliberate. “I am here to represent Council law,” he said carefully, “but also to listen. Law that refuses to see what is real breaks.” Her gaze sharpened, assessing; he felt the weight of her attention like additional gravity. “That is not an answer.” “It is the only honest one I have after a day,” he said. He let her see that he was tired, but not yielding. “I won’t pretend certainty that I don’t possess.” “Most politicians do,” she said. “With flair.” She studied the cloak over his shoulders. “Do you know why your presence offends some of us, Envoy?” “Because I arrive as if from above with authority.” “Because you arrive wrapped,” she said. “Protected. As if we are all glare and poison and hazard. And yet you walked out there alone today. That contradiction interests me.” “I wore the cloak because my body isn’t built for your sun,” he said. “I walked because my position demands I see you as you are, not as we’ve written you. If that offends, I would rather offend honestly.” For the first time, she laughed, a low, genuine sound. “Better,” she said. “Halden thinks in lines and orders. He wants your mouth as relay. I prefer my interlocutors with some spine.” She tapped the desk, and a pale map bloomed between them: zones of settlement, colored bands of clade concentrations, layers of resource and heat and water. “Here is the problem,” Sera said. “We are diverging. In gene, in body, in story. Command fears that divergence. They will use you to press for cohesion. I will use you to test how flexible that cohesion can be before it cracks.” He looked at the map, the colored swirls like overlapping wings. “Then we are both being used,” he said. “Of course,” she said calmly. “But only one of us came here by choice.” He met her eyes. “Do you truly want stability, Minister?” “I want my people to survive,” she said. “In all their forms. If the Council’s stability allows that, I will be its staunchest advocate. If it does not—” She let the sentence rest between them, unfinished, heavy. The recorders hummed softly, catching everything. Rian sat very still, feeling the weight of his cloak, the memory of the sun outside, the scrutiny of Command somewhere above the sky. His training unfurled in his mind: how to concede without yielding, how to promise nothing in words that sounded like promise. “Then,” he said carefully, “our work is to find a way that it does.” Sera watched him a long moment more, then inclined her head as if acknowledging a move in a game. “We will see, Offworlder,” she said. “We will see what you are made of.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Le Guin's distinctive voice and thematic concerns, successfully capturing her measured, thoughtful prose style and her fascination with anthropological observation of human societies. The writing exhibits sophisticated restraint, avoiding melodrama while building tension through political maneuvering and cultural observation. The adherence to instructions is excellent - all requested elements are present: the diplomatic envoy, the unauthorized exploration, the diverse human subspecies, the reprimand from Command, and the challenging conversation with the Minister. The 1000-word length is respected, and the Le Guin style is convincingly executed. Character development is nuanced and believable. Rian's actions feel genuine - his curiosity overriding protocol, his careful diplomatic responses when tested, his honest admission of uncertainty. The Minister Sera is particularly well-crafted as a seasoned political operator, testing the envoy through pointed questions and strategic revelations. Her dialogue crackles with intelligence and barely contained threat. The world-building is elegant and efficient. Rather than dumping exposition, the author reveals the adapted human subspecies through vivid, specific details: the child with vertical pupils and scale-like skin patterns, the webbed fingers, the ridged necks. The market scene effectively shows rather than tells, demonstrating social dynamics through interaction rather than explanation. The prose maintains Le Guin's characteristic rhythm - measured, observational, with moments of poetry ("light struck him like a hand") that never become overwrought. The author successfully captures her technique of revealing character through small, precise details and her gift for making alien familiar through humanizing moments. The political tension is well-constructed, building naturally from the street observations to the confrontation with Command to the verbal chess match with Sera. The dialogue feels authentic to each character's position and intelligence level, particularly effective in the final scene where both parties acknowledge they're being used while maneuvering for advantage. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the diplomatic language feels slightly mechanical, and some transitions between sections could be smoother. The ending, while appropriate, might benefit from a slightly stronger sense of the stakes involved for both parties. The piece succeeds in creating the sense of larger forces at work - the Council's desire for control, the colonists' adaptation and resistance, the envoy caught between competing loyalties. This captures Le Guin's gift for embedding personal stories within broader political and social currents. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 76.3
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The canister was still warm when they slid it across the table. Rook’s fingers hovered above the dull white cylinder, tracing the faded corporate logo flaking off its side: HELIXON LIFEWORKS – PROPERTY OF. The rest was heat-scabbed to oblivion. “Came in on the eastward caravans,” said Mira, the broker. “Out of the Annapolis ruins. Freighters found a vault. Thirty-seven intact containers. Twenty-three are already spoken for.” Rook lifted it. Light. Empty, as promised. A dead vessel from a dead empire. “Contracts?” they asked. Mira’s scarred lips twitched. “We like to call them partnerships now. ‘Contract’ sounds so… pre-Fall. But yes.” The room was shielded with scavenged copper mesh stapled to mud-brick. A fan moaned in the corner, drawing power from the settlement grid. Outside the cracked doorway: acrid cook-smoke, the distant whine of a jury-rigged turbine. Inside: the smell of ethanol, sweat, and battery ozone. “What’s in it?” Rook turned the canister. An etched code caught the dim light. “PX-9 agriplex. Root-boosters, mineral chelators—the kind they used right before things went sideways. Expired, obviously.” “Obviously,” Rook said. Built to expire. Genomes that self-erase after one generation, like rental software. Corporate anti-theft logic etched into the alphabet of life itself. The obsolescence curse. Mira leaned forward. “Can you squeeze one more harvest out of it?” Rook didn’t answer right away. They popped the canister’s seal. A faint puff of cold, synthetic lemon. A smear of viscous residue clung to the bottom. “Maybe,” Rook said. “Depends how much of the scaffold is intact.” Mira slid a paper—the thick, hand-pulped kind—across the table. On it: a list. “We need thirteen cultivars,” she said. “Rice, amaranth, three tubers, beans, mildew-resistant squash. All patched to grow in salt-pissed soil. Black-sun tolerant. You have three weeks until the next caravans move. Payment is major: solar glass, medical filters, and one vial of K-strain.” Rook’s throat went dry. “You have K-strain?” “We do,” Mira said. “Clean, pre-lock. Unshackled germline stabilizer. Good for your… condition.” Rook tried not to rub their forearm, where faint bioluminescent whorls pulsed under the skin like tired constellations. K-strain meant freedom—from the creeping cascade of corporate junk-DNA they had been using to stay alive. “And the catch?” Rook asked. Mira’s smile sharpened. “These seeds will go to my people, yes. But also to some who don’t like your settlement much. Their caravans pay better. You deliver, you get paid. What they do with the crops after… isn’t your concern.” So that was it. Food for enemies. Possibly for raiders. Possibly for the syndicates that ran the river guns, the ones who shot at their water convoys. “Say no,” Mira went on, “and I ask the next gene-slinger downriver, who’ll botch the run and kill a few hundred with misfolded proteins in their bread.” Manipulation, but not wrong. Rook capped the canister again, reverent despite themselves. “Okay,” they said. “I’ll need clean ice, old primers if you’ve got them, and a way to keep my rig running.” “We’ve already paid for your power rations for the month,” Mira said. “Black grid. Off the books.” “Then we have a deal.” They shook. Mira’s hand was rough and hot. On their way out, Rook cradled the white cylinder like an infant bomb. — The lab was once a laundromat. Rows of gutted washing machines lined the walls, their drums ripped out and repurposed as Faraday cages, fermentation vats, and one makeshift laminar flow “hood” that hummed with an overclocked CPU fan and two HEPA filters stolen from dead hospitals. The sign above the entrance still read SPIN CITY in sun-faded bubble letters. Rook set the canister down in their “clean” corner: a washing-machine shell lined with plastic, front patched over with melted PET bottles and taped gloves. The “airflow” came courtesy of scavenged computer fans wired to an improvised UPS. They took inventory: - Two thermal cyclers: one old-school block machine running off scraped firmware, and one hacked from a sous-vide heater strapped to aluminum heat-sinks and a Raspberry Pi. Both temperamental. - Gel rig: a cracked baking dish full of agarose boiled from seaweed, wired to a solar-charged fence battery. An LED strip and salvaged phone camera for imaging. - Centrifuge: reconstructed from a ceiling fan motor, with 3D-printed tube holders Mira’s people had sintered from melted bottle caps. - Pipettes: one functioning adjustable microliter pipette, plus three glass droppers marked by hand. - Reagents: scavenged Taq analogs from pre-Fall field kits, freeze-dried polymerases whose activity curve was a whispered prayer; half a bottle of ethanol distilled from denatured windshield wiper fluid; buffer salts crystallized and scraped from the inside of a ruined pharma plant. And, empty canisters. Dozens of them lined a shelf: HELIXON, GENEKRAFT, NOVAFOOD. Once pressurized with proprietary mixes and short-lived plasmids, now rinsed and repurposed. Rook unscrewed four, sniffed. Ethanol. Bleach. Just-metal. They’d become their reagent library: marker scrawl on the sides—“MgCl2,” “dNTPs??,” “Do NOT DRINK.” They cleaned another for the PX-9 residue. No drop wasted. The lights flickered as the settlement grid hiccuped. Somewhere, a child screamed, followed by a parent’s tired hush. Overhead: the distant stutter of the turbine catching wind again. Rook worked. They scraped the canister’s interior with sterile swabs made from charred chopsticks and clean cotton, suspending the film in a makeshift buffer. Their hands shook, not from nerves but from the stimulant side-effects of the last mod they’d taken: “Focus-Plus,” a pre-Fall neurotropic gene patch designed to upregulate dopamine metabolism for three days, meant to burn out before a subscription renewal. It hadn’t burned out. It had mutated under the radioactive sky and the soup of other patches swimming in their bloodstream. Now, Rook’s heart ran a little hot all the time. Upside: clarity in the lab, long work hours on little sleep. Downside: occasional arrhythmias that made the world tilt. They set up the first PCR runs to amplify the fragments of PX-9’s engineered promoter regions; these, if resurrected, could be spliced upstream of hardy heirloom genes to force high-yield growth even in poisoned soil. Untested, unstable, possibly deadly. To themselves, they muttered: “Denature, anneal, extend. Be a good little ghost and come back.” The hacked thermal cycler wheezed as the Pi clicked relays, dragging the aluminum plate’s temperature up and down in crude waves. At cycle 23, the power sagged. The turbine squealed. The machine died mid-anneal. “Shit.” Rook slapped the casing, then reached for the manual override: a kettle of hot water and another of cold, a stopwatch. Old-school. They alternated, dunking the reaction tubes in water baths at eyeballed temperatures, counting under their breath. “Ninety-four. One, two, three… Fifty-eight. One, two, three… Seventy-two…” Their own body shivered in sympathetic rhythm—whether from the Focus-Plus jitters or the K-weakness creeping in, they couldn’t tell. Years of using off-label genetic medicine had left detectable signatures: - Bioluminescent tracer-loci glowing faint cyan in their veins whenever their blood sugar dipped. - A patch of keratin overgrowth along their spine—the ghost of a subdermal armor mod that never fully took. - Slight lens opacities that at night, refracted any available light into halos. But there were upsides too. They healed fast, almost rudely so. Cuts closed in hours. Their liver shrugged off bad moonshine. Once, in the early days, they’d walked through a fungal bloom that rotted another woman’s lungs in a week; Rook coughed for a day and then stabilized, some buried booster sequence kicking in. The cost: they didn’t know when the obsolescence curves would catch up. Corporations had designed their therapeutics to disintegrate, but broken civilization turned those decay paths unpredictable. Overlapping patchwork left Rook as a live archive of incompatible design philosophies. They finished forty cycles by hand, forearms aching. The gel came next. They poured the agarose into the baking dish, slotted combs carved from credit cards. Once it set, they loaded the PCR products with a syringe, hands steady now. They flicked on the fence battery. A low hum. Bubbles. The bands crawled across the gel. No real UV transilluminator here. Instead: an LED strip under a blue filter cut from an old advertisement, and a DNA dye they’d hacked together using fluorescent proteins from a long-expired aesthetic bio-ink kit. Bands glowed. Faint. But there. “Hello, PX-9,” Rook whispered. “You’re late to your own extinction.” They captured an image with an old phone taped to a stand. Cracked screen, but the camera still sharp. The fragments were partial, degraded, but enough to reconstruct. They could graft these promoter sets onto banked heirloom seeds, forcing them to cheat. One generation of obscene vigor before the edits fell apart, leaving no stable IP to be stolen—a dead man’s kill switch repurposed for life. Mira’s timeline loomed. Rook worked through the next nights, brewing chimeras: rice with PX-9 roots and salt-sponge genes from glasswort; squash with fungal blockers stolen from Helixon antifouling paints; amaranth that could drink graywater laced with motor oil. Each step was held together with prayer and duct tape: - A laminar flow hood that barely pushed enough clean air to dissuade spores. - A CRISPR assembly using guide RNAs transcribed in vitro in jars once home to instant coffee. - Empty corporate canisters labeled and relabeled in frantic marker: “Cas9 mix,” “Guide cocktails,” “Seed coat infusion.” Between protocols, Rook injected themselves. Not K-strain—Mira hadn’t paid up yet. This was something else: an inflammation mod hacked from veterinary gene-therapy ampoules. Their joints had begun to swell from constant pipetting, from crouching over improvised optics. The new mod promised reduced joint degradation, faster collagen turnover. Needle in. Push. Cold bloom. Their fingertips tingled. The bioluminescent tracers along their veins flared briefly, starry under the skin. Thirty minutes later, the pain ebbed. Their shoulders loosened. Upside. Two hours later, they realized they could hear Mira’s boots in the alley before she even reached the door. Hypersensitivity, Rook noted. Potential auditory gain-of-function. Might be useful. Might be hell. Mira appeared as dusk bled into the laundromat. She surveyed the chaos: gel trays, steaming kettles, rows of seeds drying on fine mesh—every grain a tiny bomb of outlaw biology. “Tell me you’ve got something,” she said. Rook pointed to the labeled packets. “I’ve got enough PX-9 grafts for your list. High-yield, salt-tolerant, black-sun hardy. They’ll burn out after one generation, same as the old stuff, but they’ll give insane calories first pass. You’ll need disciplined seed saving: keep some heirlooms unedited on the side.” “I’m not paying for lessons,” Mira said. “You’re paying for not starving,” Rook shot back. Their new hearing picked the faint acceleration of Mira’s pulse. Lying or angry. Or both. “And the price?” Mira asked, softer. “The solar glass. The filters. And the K-strain. All of it. No splitting doses, no bullshit.” Mira hesitated. That pulse again. Rook’s heart answered, arrhythmic. “You understand,” Rook said, “I know you’re funneling some of this to the river guns. I can’t stop you. But if I crash, there’s no one else up-grid who can keep your crops viable when these edits shred themselves. You want a relationship, not a one-night stand.” Mira studied them. “Arrogant,” she said. “But correct.” She snapped her fingers at the doorway. A runner came in, setting down two crates lined with straw: thin solar glass sheets, pristine filter cartridges. And, reverently, a small vial in shock foam. Clear fluid. Black marker: K. “You test it,” Mira said. “If it’s fake, you know where I drink.” Rook took it. The vial weighed more than any canister. “This stays between us,” Mira added. “If your council knows you’re feeding their enemies…” “They already think I’m feeding ghosts,” Rook said. “They don’t ask. They just eat.” Mira’s mouth curved. “Three weeks from now, we’ll need a second run. PX-9 won’t stretch forever.” “It’s designed not to,” Rook said. “But I can bend its curve. For a price.” “Then we’ll talk.” She left with the seed packets tucked in lead-lined cans. The black market flowed on. Rook locked the door, hands trembling. The lab’s cheap LEDs buzzed like angry insects. Their augmented hearing picked up the hum of DNA in tubes, the creak of settling bricks, their own ragged pulse. They unstoppered the K-strain vial. This would overwrite some of the corporate entropy ticking away in their cells. Might dull the glow in their veins, might steady their heart. Might wipe out some of the accidental upsides, too. The world outside ran on failing patents and stolen tools. People lived and died on one-season miracles. In their gutted washing-machine hood, under fans held together with zipties, Rook filled a syringe from a vial born in the labs that had ruined everything. “You belong to us now,” they told the clear fluid. “Not them.” They pressed the needle into their arm, through luminous skin. Outside, the turbine caught wind again. The lights held. For one more cycle.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong worldbuilding and technical competence in the biopunk genre, successfully creating a vivid post-apocalyptic setting where corporate genetic engineering's built-in obsolescence has created a desperate scavenging economy. The author shows impressive attention to detail in describing jury-rigged laboratory equipment and scientific procedures, making the technical aspects feel authentic rather than hand-wavy. The protagonist Rook is well-developed with clear motivations and interesting physical manifestations of their genetic modifications. The bioluminescent tracers, enhanced healing, and sensory changes create a compelling portrait of someone living as a "live archive of incompatible design philosophies." The character's expertise and desperation feel genuine, and their moral compromise regarding feeding potential enemies adds complexity. The prose is generally strong with evocative imagery ("tired constellations," "tiny bomb of outlaw biology") and maintains a consistent dystopian tone throughout. The pacing builds effectively from the initial deal through the laboratory work to the final injection scene. The technical descriptions of PCR procedures and improvised equipment feel researched and authentic without becoming overly dry. However, the piece has some weaknesses. The dialogue, while functional, lacks distinctive voice - characters speak in fairly generic post-apocalyptic vernacular without much personality. Some descriptive passages border on purple prose ("acrid cook-smoke, the distant whine of a jury-rigged turbine") though they generally serve the atmosphere well. The ending feels somewhat predictable - the moral compromise and injection of K-strain follow expected beats without surprising twists. The black market contract plot works adequately but doesn't drive much character development beyond establishing Rook's desperation and skill. The relationship with Mira remains fairly surface-level, more transactional than emotionally engaging. While the piece succeeds at worldbuilding and atmosphere, it doesn't achieve deep emotional resonance or surprising narrative turns. The writing shows technical competence and good research, creating a believable future world with compelling details. The scientific elements feel authentic and the post-apocalyptic setting is well-realized. However, the story plays things relatively safe within genre conventions rather than pushing boundaries or offering fresh perspectives. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 12.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Iteration 2 — Avg Score: 82.9
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 75.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A small display screen on the wall cycled endlessly through system diagnostics in green text: CABIN PRESSURE: NOMINAL. O2 MIX: NOMINAL. HULL INTEGRITY: NOMINAL. ARTIFICIAL GRAVITY: NOMINAL. Arthur Neegan decided that nominal was a lying word. The hum of the transfer vessel had a different timbre than the rigs, higher, tauter, with a faint harmonic that vibrated along his molars. The seat webbing cut across his shoulders. Opposite him, two Antares men in slate uniforms sat with pistols holstered open, the muzzles black and indifferent. They had offered him coffee before they’d buckled him in. That, more than the guns, had unsettled him. He cleared his throat. “You’re Antares Diplomatic Corps, is that it?” The man on the left, the one who’d introduced himself as Major Halvern with the carefully pleasant tone of a professional kidnapper, considered Arthur with a mild expression. “Functionally,” Halvern said. “The precise organizational nomenclature is unimportant.” “What’s important,” Arthur said, “is you showed up at my dome with four armored crawlers and a gunship. That’s not what I call diplomatic.” Halvern actually smiled. “On Mars, Mr. Neegan, diplomacy is merely the continuation of siege warfare by better funded means.” Arthur snorted. “Clauswitz in a pressure suit.” “Quite so.” The display: FUEL STATUS: NOMINAL. “Where are we going?” Arthur asked. “You were informed,” Halvern said, “that a party wishes to speak with you concerning a mutually beneficial arrangement. We’re four minutes from docking.” “Docking with what?” Halvern’s eyes shifted, just slightly, toward the forward bulkhead. “You’ll see.” Arthur watched the green letters crawl. NOMINAL. NOMINAL. NOMINAL. His life had never been nominal and was now asymptotic to something worse. Three days ago he’d been recalibrating slag monitors. Two days ago the subsurface spectrographs had punted out impossible densities. One day ago, he’d realized the void beneath his rocky, unimpressive homestead was Azra-rich—orders of magnitude beyond any recorded deposit. Three hours ago, the Antares gunship had cast its shadow over his dome. The vessel shuddered, a delicate, practiced bump. The display updated: DOCKING SEQUENCE: ENGAGED. Halvern unbuckled, smooth as if gravity were a personal favor. “If you’ll come with us, Mr. Neegan.” Arthur hesitated. “I have a choice?” “There is always a choice,” Halvern said. “The options are merely not symmetrical.” The airlock cycle was brisk, impersonal. Beyond, instead of the cramped industrial interface he expected, was a surprisingly spacious docking foyer with polished bulkheads and an understated blue-green carpet that looked absurd in orbit over a red planet. Soft lamps glowed without visible fixtures. Someone had decided that metal and vacuum should be softened by the suggestion of a respectable hotel lobby. “Up,” said Halvern, gesturing toward a lift with a gold inlay around its rim. The elevator ascended only for seconds, but gravity subtly shifted, as if someone were indecisive about which way was down. The doors whispered open on a lounge. It could have been pulled from an old Earth film: curved panoramic ports framing Mars like an enormous wound below; walls paneled in simulated mahogany; shelves bearing real paper books that had never smelled dust; a low table of brushed metal with a bowl of artificial fruit polished to perfection. Near the window stood a tall man in a dark, impeccably cut suit, hands clasped behind his back, a faint shimmer at his lapel where a small, unfamiliar insignia caught the light. “Mr. Neegan,” the man said without turning. “Thank you for accepting our invitation.” “Interesting verb,” Arthur said. “Who am I thanking?” The man turned. He was in his fifties, perhaps, with the kind of face that made people underestimate it—a mildness at the eyes, a touch of tired kindness at the mouth. Asimov would have given him spectacles, Arthur thought incongruously; instead, the man had a single lens implant, almost invisible, tinting one iris faintly silver. “My name is Dr. Elias Koren. I speak on behalf of an interested consortium.” “Antares?” Arthur asked. Halvern, who had taken up a position by the door, did not answer. Koren’s gaze flicked to him, then back to Arthur. “Let us say,” Koren replied, “I speak for a configuration of concerns that finds the label ‘Antares’ convenient, sometimes.” Arthur remained standing. “I have a claim on that land. Azra regs. Quadrant seventeen, parcel C-two. All proper. I’ve filed with Colonial Bureau. Whatever you want, you can send a lawyer like anybody civilized.” Koren smiled thinly. “You are correct that you have a claim, although whether it remains uncontested is a legal question, and legal questions, Mr. Neegan, proceed at a glacial pace. Markets do not. Nor do weapons designers. Please sit.” Arthur sat, if only to avoid making a point that might cost him air. “May I offer you a drink?” Koren said. “Coffee, tea, something stronger? We synthesize an acceptable approximation of bourbon, I’m told.” “I’m fine.” His mouth was dry. “Most people, when told they are sitting on the largest known Azra vein in the system, are not fine,” Koren said conversationally. Arthur’s stomach tightened. “You’re very sure about that vein for someone who only grabbed my scans yesterday.” “Oh, not yesterday,” Koren said lightly. “The moment your rig’s instruments twitched, three separate corporations mirrored the data. Antares among them. Forecast models flagged your coordinates. Eventualities were prepared.” “Three?” Arthur asked. “Titanium Crown,” Koren said, counting off on a finger. “Antares, naturally. And a charmingly discreet concern calling itself the Selenian Mediation Fund. Each tied by a thousand invisible threads to nation-states, fleets, think tanks, ideologies. You triggered a kind of… bell, Mr. Neegan. Everyone who can hear Azra, hears that bell.” “So this is a race,” Arthur said. “It is worse,” Koren said gently. “It is convergence.” Arthur glanced out at Mars. From here the planet was whole again, no dust storms, no mining crawlers, just a red coin against the velvet. “What do you want from me?” he asked. “Azra,” Koren said. “Naturally. But not only the ore. You know what Azra does?” “It accelerates decay. I’ve read the briefs. You line reaction chambers with it, you pull more energy out faster. You put it next to fissionable stock and you get a flood instead of a trickle.” He paused. “You make engines that leap between stars. And bombs that don’t care about armor.” Koren inclined his head. “Elegant summary. As always, the line between starship and weapon is the thickness of an accountant’s pen stroke.” “And you’re the accountant?” Arthur said. “I am,” Koren said, “the man who would prefer that the pen not be held by the most frightened hands.” Arthur studied him. “You’re talking like a moralist. You came with guns.” “Because others will,” Koren said. His calm did not waver, but the silver lens in his eye caught a reflection of Mars like a burning coin. “Let me be precise. “In approximately nine days, Titanium Crown’s local proxies will present the Bureau with a mineral rights challenge, claiming procedural irregularities in your filing. In eleven days, a delegation under Selenian cover will arrive ‘to investigate safety protocols.’ In thirteen days, Antares Central will receive reconnaissance data confirming the depth of your Azra seam. In fifteen days, if events proceed without intervention, there will be, at minimum, three competing armed ‘security audits’ aimed at your homestead. Pressure domes are not built to withstand crossfire.” Arthur pictured his dome rupturing like an egg. “You’re very specific.” “Physics is specific. Politics wishes it were. Intelligence, executed properly, bridges the gap.” “So your ‘consortium’ wants to intervene,” Arthur said. “In what way?” “By making all that unnecessary,” Koren said. He leaned forward for the first time, forearms on knees, a conspiratorial posture that rang false precisely because it was textbook. “Arthur—may I call you Arthur?” He didn’t wait. “Arthur, your claim grants you not only rights to the ore, but influence over extraction protocols, export destinations, technology licensing. You are, by unhappy accident, a hinge point. The simplest approach for any actor who wishes unencumbered access to that Azra is to remove you.” “And your approach?” Arthur asked. “To keep you alive,” Koren said, “in exchange for your cooperation.” Halvern stirred by the door, but said nothing. “Cooperation meaning what?” Arthur said. “Form a joint development company,” Koren said promptly. “You contribute your claim and your local expertise. We contribute protection, capital, legal shelter under a multi-jurisdictional charter. In practice, you sign a set of binding agreements that gives our consortium controlling interest in your Azra.” “In return for… not killing me?” “In return for preserving your life, securing your claim against predation, and ensuring that Azra is introduced into the interstellar calculus in a controlled, rational manner. You will also become very wealthy, which I have observed to be a non-trivial factor in human decision-making.” Arthur rubbed his face. His fingers smelled faintly of regolith dust that wasn’t there. “If I say no?” Koren’s answer was unhurried. “Then I inform you of several forthcoming attempts on your life from parties less invested in negotiation. I wish you luck you will not have. Antares Command will approach you less politely inside forty-eight hours. Titanium Crown will approach you not at all; you’ll simply be declared in arrears on some obscure equipment lease, and repossession crews will arrive with magistrate seals and quiet rifles. The Selenians will smile, invoke the word ‘stability’ repeatedly, and escort you somewhere off-record.” “So you’re… the kind option,” Arthur said. “I am the option,” Koren said, “that understands you are not merely an obstacle but a variable. Azra is not just ore; it is leverage on centuries of doctrine. On who controls drives, who controls deterrence, who decides how far and how fast mankind disperses. The physics is absolute. The human response need not be panic.” Arthur’s voice came out harsher than he intended. “Your guns downstairs don’t look like calm.” Koren spread his hands. “Would you have us come unarmed, when others do not? We cannot afford moral gestures that end in our corpses. We must be…nominally pragmatic.” Arthur flinched at the word. “The Bureau,” Arthur said, clinging to something. “They’ll—” “The Bureau,” Koren cut in softly, “is underfunded, overextended, and governed by statutes written when Azra was an obscure entry in a xenogeology appendix. They will be two years rewriting protocols while battleships reposition. If you place your faith in their timeline, you will be a corpse with excellent paperwork.” Silence settled. Beyond the port, Mars rolled along, patient and unaware. Arthur asked, “Who exactly is in your ‘consortium’?” Koren regarded him for a long moment, as if measuring how much future burden the man could carry. “Elements within Antares,” he said. “Certain terrestrial blocs who prefer balance to hegemony. A Martian civic union that fears becoming merely a quarry. A few individuals of means and conscience. It is an unnatural alliance, and therefore, paradoxically, a stable one—so long as Azra is scarce and centralized.” “And if someone else gets my Azra?” Arthur said. “Then scarcity ends,” Koren said. “And with it, the restraint born of vulnerability.” Arthur exhaled slowly. The green text on the lounge’s side console reflected in the window: ORBITAL PARAMETERS: NOMINAL. He said, “Why me? You don’t need me to dig. You’ve got fleets.” “We can seize your land,” Koren agreed. “But we cannot seize legitimacy without cost. You are a first-generation settler, legally documented, with a record of technical competence and no political allegiances. You are narratively convenient.” The faintest trace of irony. “In unstable times, the story matters as much as the guns.” “And if I agree,” Arthur said, “I become your… what, mascot?” “Our partner,” Koren said. “Our shield. And, I would hope, our conscience. I am not naïve; nor should you be. We will profit. We will maneuver. We will withhold knowledge and accelerate some developments while suppressing others. But there is a range between catastrophe and tyranny. Help us hold to it.” Halvern shifted. “Doctor,” he murmured. Koren nodded. Time was shorter than his tone admitted. “Arthur,” Koren said, more briskly now. “You are, as of this hour, in play. Saying ‘I want no part of this’ is no longer a functional option. You can choose which hands move you, not whether you are a piece. I am offering you a seat nearer the center of the board.” Arthur thought of his little dome, the patched air recycler he’d coaxed through dust storms, the photo of his parents pinned above the workbench. They had come to Mars to get away from being pawns. Mars, it turned out, merely had a different board. “And if I say yes,” he said, “how long before someone tries to kill me anyway?” Koren’s expression did not soften, but it became, briefly, honest. “Oh,” he said. “Almost immediately. But they will have to be clever about it. That is a kind of progress.” Arthur barked a short, humorless laugh. “You don’t sound like a diplomat.” “Diplomats soothe,” Koren said. “I allocate inevitabilities.” He reached into a case on the low table and withdrew a slim pad, its surface dark. Laid beside it, a stylus gleamed. “This contains the foundational agreements,” Koren said. “We can refine terms. But the structure stands. Joint development. Controlled extraction and distribution. Security guarantees. In exchange, you place your Azra under our stewardship.” “Suppose I want to read it,” Arthur said. “I would be disappointed if you did not,” Koren said. “We are not in the habit of recruiting fools.” “I mean all of it,” Arthur said. “Every clause. Every ‘heretofore’ and ‘notwithstanding.’” “Then we will need more coffee,” Koren said, with the ghost of a smile. “Major, see to it.” Halvern went to a wall console. Arthur picked up the pad. Lines of dense, precise legal text scrolled under his touch; signatures of entities he recognized and others he very much did not flickered past. Every sentence smelled faintly of traps. He didn’t look up when he asked, “Doctor Koren. One more thing.” “Yes?” “If I sign this,” Arthur said, “and play piece and symbol for your balancing act, and if—some day—you decide the balance is better without me. What then?” There was a silence long enough to mark. “Then,” Koren said softly, “I will have miscalculated. And I do not enjoy miscalculations.” Arthur looked up, met the mismatched eyes: one human, one silver. He wasn’t sure if that was an answer. He suspected it was the only one he’d get. Outside, Mars turned. Inside, green letters on a secondary screen whispered a single word down the column of readouts: NOMINAL. Arthur Neegan, the new hinge of a system, set his jaw and began to read.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and successfully captures the Asimovian style requested. The author establishes an effective retrofuturistic atmosphere through details like the diagnostic displays, pressure domes, and the juxtaposition of advanced technology with familiar human elements. The world-building operates on both micro and macro levels - from Arthur's immediate predicament to the larger galactic political implications of Azra discovery. The dialogue carries the story effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Koren emerges as particularly well-crafted - his polished menace and philosophical approach to coercion feel authentically Asimovian. His line "Diplomats soothe. I allocate inevitabilities" exemplifies the kind of memorable, character-defining dialogue that elevates the piece. Arthur's responses feel genuine for someone thrust into circumstances beyond his control, balancing resignation with defiance. The pacing builds tension naturally, moving from Arthur's confined confusion aboard the transport to the increasingly claustrophobic realization of his situation. The author effectively uses the recurring "NOMINAL" display as both atmospheric detail and thematic element, highlighting how Arthur's previously stable life has become anything but normal. However, the piece suffers from some predictability. The setup - reluctant protagonist with valuable resource being courted/coerced by mysterious powerful factions - follows familiar patterns. While executed competently, it doesn't surprise or subvert expectations in meaningful ways. The ending, while appropriate, feels somewhat inevitable rather than dramatically satisfying. The prose occasionally becomes dense with exposition, particularly in Koren's longer speeches about galactic politics. While this serves the world-building, it sometimes slows the dramatic momentum. Some descriptions, while vivid, border on overwrought - the "wound" description of Mars and multiple references to the silver lens implant feel slightly forced. The character work is solid but not exceptional. Arthur remains somewhat reactive throughout, and while his situation is compelling, his personality doesn't emerge as distinctly as it might. Koren is more successful as a character, but falls into familiar archetypes of the polite, philosophical antagonist. The technical execution is strong - sentence structure flows well, the voice remains consistent, and the piece maintains coherence throughout. The author demonstrates good control over tone and atmosphere, creating the requested classic sci-fi feel without resorting to pastiche. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 81.6
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The problem with the darkroom is it feels like a church. The red light hangs there like a low, watchful moon. Everything quiets. Your voice. Your posture. All your posturing. Even mine. I’m not used to feeling small in a room. “Timer?” Elliot asks. I check my phone, the screen dimmed. “Thirty seconds.” He hums in response—some half-remembered melody, soft and low. He always does that when he’s waiting for something to reveal: a print, an answer, himself. The tune threads through the chemical tang like incense. “Okay, pull it,” I say. He slides the paper from the developer with those careful, ink-smudged fingers. It’s our third attempt at this shot: his silhouette against the cracked glass of the studio window, lace curtains and his chipped black nail polish catching light in ways that are weirdly holy. The theme we pitched: “liminal bodies.” It sounded smart at the time. It’s starting to feel like a confession. He sets the print in the stop bath. The liquid laps at the edges like it’s eager. “How’s it look?” I ask, stepping closer. He leans in, dark hair falling forward, the silver ring in his ear glinting dull red. “Better,” he says. “Your focus is sharper.” “My focus is always sharp,” I say automatically, with the little smirk people expect of me. He huffs something that’s almost a laugh. “You bossed the enlarger into submission.” “Damn right.” That’s the role everyone hands me, and I rarely argue: Dani, the girl with the shaved undercut and the eyeliner like war paint, the one who never shuts up in crit, the one who takes your hand and leads you to the party and back out again. The one who knows exactly what she wants. For three months I’ve been watching Elliot out of the corner of my eye while pretending I’m not. Nineteen, which I told myself is too young for me—and then immediately argued with myself about, because it’s six years, not a felony. He’s all soft-spoken analysis and deliberate thrift-store goth: long black skirts over torn tights one day, high-waisted trousers and sheer mesh the next, boots always a little scuffed, eyeliner crooked like he did it on the bus. He talks about light and shadow like they’re moral forces. He holds himself like he’s apologizing for taking up air. He scrapes a nail along the tray edge, humming almost inaudibly. Tonight’s outfit is a black tank top under an oversized, off-the-shoulder sweater with metal eyelets. Collarbone, fine chain, a faint down of hair. His jeans are tight, his belt has little silver bats on it. If you handed that description to first-year Dani, she’d say: not my type. My type used to be capital-M Men, clear lines, broad shoulders, defined. Easy. But the first time I saw him adjusting the focus on the enlarger, tongue peeking out at the corner of his lip, fingers steady, I felt something flick sideways inside me. He lifts the tongs. “You wanna…?” “Yeah,” I say, and step in, our shoulders bumping. Electric. Stupidly electric, given how many people I’ve touched and then forgotten. The image in the stop bath is ghostly but there, a strange delicate defiance. Him, but not how the world sees him between classes, slouched and folded into himself. Here he’s taller somehow, blur around the edges like he’s in motion, lace sleeve raised, jaw set. “I like this one,” I say. It comes out softer than I mean it to. He glances up at me in the red light. “Yeah?” “Yeah.” I clear my throat. “Timer?” “Oh—uh—fixer. Three minutes.” He starts humming again. I recognize it now: some slow, looping tune he did last week too. The sounds wedge under my ribs. We stand there with our hands too close on the tray, the smell of fixer sharp in my nose. The silence stretches out, comfortable and not. He breaks first. “Can I…ask you something?” This is where I usually shine. People tell me things. I don’t flinch. I know how to be the one who knows. “Always.” He gives this half-smile. “You say that like you mean it.” “Maybe I do.” His fingers drum the tray. “You ever feel like your body is…assigned a story you didn’t write?” “Yes,” I say. Too fast. He blinks. I shrug. “My parents decided I was their nice little girl who’d get a tattoo ‘phase’ out of her system. The art department decided I was aggressive because I speak in full sentences.” He shakes his head. “I mean. Yeah. But…more…literal.” Ah. The red light flickers. Somewhere down the hall, a door shuts. The rest of the building is bone-quiet; it’s just us, the hum of the ventilation, and his question hovering between us like unexposed film. I lower my voice. “You mean like…gender literal.” He flinches, just around the eyes. “Yeah. That.” I grip the edge of the sink, nails pressing crescents into my palm. This is the part where I usually grab the steering wheel. Ask direct questions. Cut to the conclusion. Instead, I take a breath and decide—for once—not to. “Tell me?” I say. I hate how tentative it sounds, but his shoulders drop a millimeter, like it was the right choice. He stares at the developing print. His humming stops. “It’s like…” He swallows. “I look in the mirror and it’s not that I hate what’s there. It’s more like I’m reading a translation of a book I love. Close, but…off. Certain words wrong. And I don’t know if I want to change the language or if I just want more options for how to…read it, I guess.” It’s such an Elliot answer it makes my chest squeeze. “Okay,” I say. “Yeah. That makes sense.” He flicks me a disbelieving look. “It doesn’t.” “To you, maybe. It sounds clear to me.” He hesitates. “I like wearing skirts. I like eyeliner. I like the way people look at me when I’m…ambiguous. When they don’t know what box I’m in.” “Good,” I say, immediately. My voice has steel in it again. I can’t help it. “That’s hot.” He flushes, the color visible even in red light. “Dani.” “What?” I grin, but I bite down on it quick. Make a softer version. “I’m not joking.” “That’s the problem,” he mutters. The timer buzzes on my phone; we both jump. He lifts the print into the fixer. His hands are shaking a little. I want to grab them and still them and I want to shove my hands in my pockets and never touch him again, just to not ruin this. “So you’re…what?” I ask, trying to keep it open. “Questioning? Genderqueer? Boy-with-an-asterisk?” He chews his lip ring. “I don’t know. ‘Elliot’ feels right. ‘He’ still mostly feels okay. Sometimes. But also sometimes I want someone to look at me and think…something else. I don’t know the word for it.” “Words are overrated,” I say before my brain can workshop it. “We can make new ones.” He actually laughs at that, a small, disbelieving thing. “You make it sound easy.” “It’s not,” I say, quietly. “But it doesn’t have to be lonely.” He goes very still. His eyes find mine. The air feels thick, like the dark is pressing in, listening. “What if I change,” he says, “and people decide I’m not…valid? Or I change and I hate it? Or I don’t change and I hate that more?” There it is: the center of him, laid bare between trays of toxic chemicals. I want to step into the space, wrap myself around him, bare my teeth at the abstract “people” he’s afraid of. I want to say, I’ll decide. I want to dictate: You’re allowed. You’re real. You’re— But it’s not my decision, and if I bulldoze now, I’m just another story written over him. I take a breath. “Then you try,” I say slowly, “in small ways. With people who don’t make your choices about them.” “You’d be one of those people?” he asks, tiny voice. Nothing like his class crit voice, which is precise and devastating. “I volunteered,” I say. “Extremely enthusiastically, if you missed it.” He looks down, and his hair falls forward again. I want to tuck it back; I don’t. “What does that mean for you?” he says. “I mean, you liked…” He gestures vaguely. “Guys.” I laugh once, sharp. “You say that like you’re not… Guys.” He blinks. “Am I?” “Do you want to be?” It slips out. His eyes widen. “Sorry,” I add immediately. “Too much?” He shakes his head. “No. Just…no one asks it like that.” “Well,” I say, softer. “Do you?” He stares at the print. The Elliot-in-the-photo stares back, all shadow and lace and possibility. “I don’t know yet,” he says. “Some days yes. Some days I want something…less rigid.” His throat works. “If I wasn’t, would that—change things? For you?” This is the question I’ve been not-looking at all semester. I’ve always liked clarity. Men who growl and smirk and take up space, so I can push back. Women who are sharp and bright and know they’re women. I’ve liked having my attraction map neatly color-coded. But lately there’s this glitch whenever I look at him. The map blurs. He looks beautiful in a skirt and beautiful in jeans, and I don’t know what that means, only that I want to put my hands on his hips in either. I step closer, slow enough he can move away. He doesn’t. “It might change the label I’d slap on my own forehead,” I say. “But not the way I’m standing here looking at you.” His breath hitches. “How are you looking at me?” “Like I’m extremely into the person who hums to his photos while they develop and wears eyeliner better than I do on a bus. And like I’m trying really hard not to be a creep about it.” He stares at me, stunned. “You’re…into…this?” He gestures down his body, awkward, like it betrays him. “I’m into you,” I say, and my voice doesn’t shake. “The ‘this’ is part of that. Maybe it’s even the point.” He swallows. He’s so close I can smell laundry detergent and the faint sweetness of his shampoo under the chemicals. “I didn’t tell you so you’d feel obligated,” he says. “I don’t do obligated.” “Yeah,” he says faintly. “I know.” “Also, you’re nineteen,” I add, because I have to. “You get full veto power on any of this. I’m not—” I wave a hand. “I’m not trying to steer your gender journey by making out with you in the darkroom or whatever.” He flushes so red I can see it. “That was…specific.” “I like specificity.” He wets his lips. “What if I want you to be part of it?” That lands in my sternum like a dropped brick. “But I don’t know who I am yet,” he rushes on. “And it doesn’t seem fair to drag you into that and then—change. Or not change. Or—” “Elliot.” I keep my voice low, but firm. The way I speak when a first-year is about to cry in crit. “You’re allowed to be in progress and still be…wanted.” He looks at me like I’ve said something indecent. “What if I wake up one day and I’m not your type anymore?” he whispers. I almost laugh, because: too late. “You realize that’s already happening and I’m still here,” I say. He goes quiet. The only sound is the ventilator fan and the drip of chemistry. “Can I try something?” he asks. “Yeah,” I say, immediately. “Will you…call me pretty?” His voice is so small I almost don’t catch it. A beat. My chest does something painful. “I already do,” I say. “Out loud.” Gentle. Careful. This is where I could tease. Lean into my persona. Make it a joke to defuse the tension. I don’t. “You’re pretty, Elliot,” I say into the red-lit stillness. He closes his eyes, just for a second, like it stings. When he opens them again, they’re glossy. “Okay,” he says. “Okay. That…felt good.” “Good,” I murmur. “Do it again?” “You’re really pretty,” I say. It feels like touching a bruise that’s healing. “And I like how you’re figuring yourself out. It’s brave.” He huffs. “It’s scared.” “Brave is scared plus forward motion,” I say. “Trust me.” He laughs again, wet at the edges. “You make it sound like you’re this seasoned adventurer of identity.” “Compared to you? I’m the grizzled old man on the mountain.” “You’re twenty-five,” he says, rolling his eyes. “Basically ancient.” He bumps my shoulder. It’s intentional, this time. “So,” I say carefully. “You want me to be part of this? That what you said?” He nods, once. “Then you tell me how,” I say. “You drive. I’m serious.” His brows twitch up. “You don’t drive. You hijack.” “Special occasion.” I attempt a smile. “I don’t want to turn you into a project. Or a prop. Or something I…curate.” He’s quiet, considering. Then: “You could…hold my hand sometimes. Use ‘pretty’ as much as you want. Let me try on looks without making it a big performance.” “I can do that,” I say, throat tight. “And if I…veer,” he says. “If I decide I’m not your neat ‘guy’ box anymore…” “Then I adjust,” I say. “If I can. If it hurts, we talk. But that’s…later. This is now.” He looks at me for a long time. Longer than is comfortable. He’s searching my face for something; I let him. “Can I—” he starts, then stops. “You can,” I say. He reaches for my hand, slow. When our fingers lace, my heart does something humiliating. His palm is cool and slightly damp. He squeezes once, like testing reality. “This okay?” he asks. “Yeah,” I breathe. “This is very okay.” We stand there, hand in hand, while our photo of him becoming himself fixes in its final bath. He hums his soft tune again, and now I recognize it as something like a lullaby to us both. When the timer goes off, neither of us lets go right away. “Wanna hang it up?” I ask. “Together,” he says. So we do.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional sophistication in exploring themes of gender identity, attraction, and vulnerability. The narrative successfully captures Dani's voice as an assertive art student grappling with unexpected feelings and situations beyond her usual comfort zone. The darkroom setting is expertly utilized as both literal workspace and metaphorical space for revelation and intimacy. The red light serves as an effective atmospheric device that transforms ordinary interactions into something more confessional and sacred. The author skillfully weaves photography terminology and processes throughout, creating authentic texture without overwhelming the narrative. Character development is nuanced and believable. Dani's internal struggle between her natural take-charge personality and her desire to give Elliot agency feels authentic and emotionally complex. Her self-awareness about potentially steamrolling over Elliot's journey shows sophisticated character writing. Elliot emerges as more than just a catalyst for Dani's growth - his vulnerability feels genuine rather than performative, and his articulation of gender questioning through the metaphor of translation is particularly effective. The dialogue flows naturally and serves multiple functions - advancing plot, revealing character, and building intimacy. Conversations feel organic rather than constructed, with realistic hesitations, interruptions, and the kind of careful negotiation that occurs in sensitive situations. The use of "pretty" as a repeated motif works well without becoming heavy-handed. The prose strikes an effective balance between literary sophistication and accessibility. Sentences vary in length and structure, creating good rhythm. The writing avoids purple prose while maintaining strong imagery - particularly effective are descriptions like "voice threads through the chemical tang like incense" and "like reading a translation of a book I love." The emotional trajectory feels earned rather than rushed. Both characters undergo subtle transformations - Dani learning to relinquish control and Elliot gaining confidence to articulate his needs - but these changes emerge naturally from their interactions rather than being imposed by the narrative structure. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the dialogue becomes slightly expository, particularly around Dani's explanations of her attraction patterns. The ending, while sweet, edges toward being slightly too neat given the complexity of the issues raised, though it doesn't fully cross into incongruent territory. The piece successfully addresses the prompt's requirements for exploring complex attraction, the intimate darkroom setting, and the tender awkwardness of the characters' situation. It handles sensitive subject matter with appropriate care while avoiding didactic or preachy tones. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 7 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 7.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 82.8
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The motorino screams around the corner like a thrown stone. Ben has one foot on the rim of the Trevi Fountain, guidebook open, lips moving as he reads. He’s trying to pronounce “Fontana di Trevi” properly, under his breath, tongue tripping over the r. “Tre-vee. Treh-vi. Tre—” He steps back. A horn rips through the air. “Ma sei scemo?” a voice explodes. He feels heat scrape his leg—the brushed kiss of metal—then the bike lurches sideways and skids to a halt inches from his knee. Ben freezes, one shoe in a puddle of coins and wish-water, the guidebook flopping shut in his hand. People gasp around them. Someone swears. Someone laughs. She swings her leg off the bike in one smooth, furious motion. Helmet under her arm, hair tumbling dark and wild, eyes like lit fuses. Leather jacket, scuffed black boots, a messenger bag slung across her chest. She’s all sharp angles and fast breath. “Guardi dove metti i piedi, turista!” she snaps, in rapid-fire Italian, stalking up to him. “I—I’m so sorry,” Ben blurts, already tugging at his glasses, cheeks burning. “Entirely my fault. I didn’t see— I was just—” “Reading,” she says in English, mocking, her accent rich and amused. “‘Rome in One Day.’” She plucks the guidebook from his hand with two fingers before he can react. “Congratulazioni. You found the fountain. Questione: you try also looking instead of reading?” He blinks. “Well, the book says the baroque façade is best appreciated from—” “From not under my wheels,” she cuts in. “Holy shit.” She exhales a laugh, the anger cracking into disbelief. “You almost died in the stupidest way.” “I am terribly sorry,” he insists. “Let me—eh—buy you a coffee? Or pay for any damage I’ve caused to, um, your vehicle, or your, er, schedule.” She eyes him, taking in the neat button-up shirt, the careful watch, the earnest disaster of him. “You English?” “Yes. Ben.” He almost offers a handshake, then aborts halfway. She smirks at his hovering hand. “Of course you are. I’m Alessandra.” “Alessandra,” he repeats, and it sounds like something from the guidebook; he instantly hates himself for thinking it. She flips through the pages she stole, scoffing. “‘Authentic Rome in five easy walks.’ Santo cielo. They sell this to you?” “Well, yes, that’s kind of the—” She closes the book with a snap. “No.” “No?” “No. You walk around reading this, you die under a bus. Or in my bumper. Or you eat bad carbonara and cry. Give.” She taps the cover against his chest, then pulls it away when he reaches for it. “Today, I am your guidebook.” He laughs, uncertain. “That’s very kind, but I really couldn’t impose, you’re working, and I—” She jerks her chin at her messenger bag. “Courier. I know this city like my ex-boyfriends’ passwords. I have deliveries. You walk with me, we don’t die. Maybe. Come.” Before he can argue, she shoves the guidebook into her own bag and starts walking. It takes three seconds for Ben to realize she’s actually leaving with his book. “Sorry—er—my guidebook,” he says, hurrying after her. “I do rather need that.” She throws him a look over her shoulder. “Trust issues already, Ben? Don’t worry. I bring it back. Eventually.” Scene Two: The Alley They cut away from the crowd, into a narrow spill of shadow and laundry lines. Vespas lean against graffiti-scarred walls. The city presses close here. Alessandra walks fast; he nearly trips over cobblestones keeping up. “Should you, uh, park…?” he gestures vaguely. She shrugs. “It will be there. If not, Rome wanted it more than me.” “That seems...illegal.” “Everything fun is,” she says. “So. Ben. Why are you in my city? Besides trying to throw yourself under my bike.” “I’m on sabbatical,” he says, dodging a hanging bedsheet. “Research.” “Boring.” “I haven’t told you what it is yet.” She slides him a glance. “If it was interesting, you would start with that.” He falters. “Well—Roman urbanism. Eighteenth-century travel narratives. The English in Rome, you know, the Grand Tour—” “There.” She grins. “Boring. But cute.” His ears go hot. “I suppose that’s…fair.” She stops abruptly; he nearly collides with her this time.
