They stand close for a beat, his breath catching the scent of her: coffee, smoke, something citrus-sharp. She tilts her head, studying him. “Relax, professore. I tease because you almost killed my front wheel.” “I thought you said I almost died?” “Both things true. Multifunzionale.” A flash of white teeth. Then, lightly, “Rule one: stop saying sorry every five seconds. It’s very…United Kingdom.” “I’ll do my best. Sorry. I mean— Right.” She laughs, pleased. Her hand brushes past a stall window, so casual he almost misses it. A lighter, bright red, vanishes from the cluttered display into her palm. She rolls it over her fingers like a coin, face innocent. Ben’s looking at her, not her hand. He doesn’t see. Scene Three: The Caffè They burst back into sunlight on a small piazza, less crowded, more local. Alessandra steers him to a narrow bar where old men shout over espresso. “Due caffè,” she calls, slapping coins on the counter—more than necessary, Ben thinks. She palms a biscotto while the barista’s back is turned, slipping it next to Ben’s saucer. He frowns at it. “I didn’t order—” “Ben,” she says solemnly, “it fell from heaven.” He studies her for a moment, then smiles. “Miraculous.” She taps her chest. “Santa Alessandra dei Turisti Idioti.” He almost spits his espresso. “Blasphemy.” “Shh. Don’t tell the Pope.” She leans on the bar. “So. What do you want to see? The guidebook would send you now to the Pantheon. Very respectable. Very…beige.” “The Pantheon is hardly beige,” he protests. “It’s—” “Or,” she cuts in, “we see the Rome the tourists don’t. Black markets. Love stories. Ghosts. Terrible decisions.” He hesitates. Then: “Show me your Rome.” Her gaze lingers on his face, as if measuring the risk. “Careful,” she says lightly. “You sound serious.” “Maybe I am.” She smiles slowly. “Bene. Finish your miracle. We go.” Scene Four: Trastevere They cross the river; the city shifts, tightens, loosens. Laundry flaps, scooters snarl, church bells argue with each other. On a side street, Alessandra points to a crumbling palazzo. “There, a countess kept three lovers. One for morning, one for afternoon, one for night. Very organized.” She nudges him. “You academic types like footnotes; she liked footmen.” He chokes on air. “That’s historically dubious.” “Everything is a story,” she says. “You choose which one to believe.” Her hand slides behind her back as they pass a souvenir stand. A postcard of the Trevi, vivid blue, disappears up the sleeve of her jacket. She taps it, unseen, against her wrist. Ben’s looking at the street musicians, distracted. “Were you born here?” he asks. “Si. Born screaming on a hot day in August, they say. My mother cursed, my father smoked, Rome yawned.” She shrugs. “You?” “Oxford.” She grimaces. “Even the word sounds like an old chair. Why you left?” “Because I know every stone there,” he says slowly. “I came to be surprised.” She barks a delighted laugh. “I am very good at surprise.” Scene Five: The Warning In a crowded vicolo near Piazza Trilussa, a man calls out, “Ale!” She stiffens almost imperceptibly, then turns. “Dio mio. Luca.” He saunters toward them, all cologne and smirk, gold chain glinting. “Still alive, streghetta?” “Unfortunately,” she says. “Luca, this is Ben. English. Academic. Almost a stain on my tire this morning.” Luca looks Ben up and down with amused pity. “Condoglianze, Professore.” Ben offers his hand. “Nice to meet you.” Luca ignores it, eyes on Alessandra. “Picking up strays again?” “He picked me,” she says. “Stepped right in front of me like a suicidal pigeon.” Luca tuts. Then, to Ben, in accented English, “Careful with this one, okay? She smile, you think it’s summer. Then you check your pockets.” Ben laughs politely. “I’m sure I’ll manage.” Luca raises his brows. “Everyone thinks that. Ask my cousin. Can’t, though. He still looking for his car keys. And his car.” “Va via,” Alessandra says, half-playful, half not. “You’re scaring my tourist.” “Only a warning.” Luca backs away, winks at Ben. “Occhi aperti, Professore.” As he disappears, Ben says lightly, “Colorful acquaintance.” “Old mistake,” she says. “Ignore him. He likes drama.” She hooks her arm through Ben’s, pulling him onward before he can reflect on Luca’s words. He notices, distantly, that his guidebook is no longer peeking from her bag. He also notices he doesn’t care as much as he should. Scene Six: The Rooftop Late afternoon drenches the city in gold. Alessandra leads him up a stairwell in a building he’s certain they’re not supposed to be in. “Is this…allowed?” he asks as she jimmies a stubborn door with a hairpin. “No,” she says cheerfully. “Hold this.” He takes the helmet she shoves at him. The lock clicks. They climb out onto a rooftop terrace overlooking terracotta chaos and dome-studded skyline. Ben steps to the edge, stunned. “Good Lord.” “Better than your book?” she asks. He glances at her. “Yes.” She leans on the low wall, wind ruffling her hair. “You know, when I was little, I climbed roofs to see if Rome ended. It doesn’t. Just keeps going, old bones, new mistakes.” He looks at her like she’s part of the skyline. “Why courier work?” “Fast,” she says. “No boss in my ear. Whole city my office. Also, I like riding things I can crash.” He laughs. “That’s not comforting.” “I haven’t killed anyone yet.” “Comfort level marginally increased.” She watches him soften into the view, that careful English posture unraveling by degrees. Without thinking, she slips her hand into his trouser pocket—not deep, just two fingers—pulls out a crumpled receipt, a coin. He startles at the touch, turns. “What are you doing?” She flips the coin in the air. “Lightening you.” He flushes. “Is that— Are you stealing from me?” “Just your change. Consider it my fee.” He can’t tell if she’s joking. He hears Luca: check your pockets. “Should I be worried?” he asks, half-playful, half not. She holds his gaze, coin glinting between them. “Only if you’re afraid of losing something you actually need.” He realizes, then, how close they’re standing. The air between them tightens. She’s smiling, but there’s something guarded under it, a challenge and a dare. He clears his throat. “So far, just coins.” She steps back first. “Then we are okay.” Scene Seven: The Ride Dusk. Back at her motorbike, miraculously untouched, she tosses him the spare helmet. “Oh, I don’t— I’ve never—” he sputters. “Rule two,” she says. “If you come with me, you don’t walk all the time. Put it on.” “I should probably refuse on the grounds of self-preservation.” “Too late,” she says. “You’re already in my day.” He hesitates only a moment before pulling the helmet over his messy hair. She swings on; he climbs behind, awkward, hands hovering in the air until she reaches back, grabs his wrists, and wraps his arms firmly around her waist. “There,” she says. “Otherwise you fall, I have to explain to police. Troppo lavoro.” The bike roars to life. Rome becomes streaked lights, close calls, curses, laughter. Ben clings, heart thudding in his throat, every turn a tiny death and resurrection. Alessandra is sure and fast, slicing between taxis. He should be terrified. He is. He’s also alive in a way his library never touched. She brakes hard at a red, glances back over her shoulder so their helmets almost touch. “You okay, professore?” He hears his own breath echoing in plastic. “I think—yes,” he says. “I think I love this.” “Careful,” she says. “You say that too easily, Rome believes you.” Scene Eight: The Fountain (Again) Night. They end up back near the Trevi, the circle closed. The crowd is thinner; the fountain glows electric white and impossible. She parks haphazardly. Ben peels off the helmet, hair utterly ruined, cheeks bright. “I look ridiculous,” he says. “You look less…Oxford,” she replies. “It’s an improvement.” She retrieves something from her jacket and tosses it to him: his guidebook. “You had it all along,” he says. “Of course. You trust me now, no?” He flips through it. On the page about the Trevi, a postcard is tucked. The same one she’d slipped earlier. On the back, in rushed, looping handwriting: Real Rome is off the page. —A. He glances at her. “Is this your subtle way of annotating my research?” “Maybe I like leaving evidence,” she says. “Maybe I like seeing if people notice.” He does notice now: the lighter, the postcard, his coin. The edges of her mischief. Luca’s warning echoes, but so does the feel of her steady in front of him on the bike. “Should I be taking notes?” he asks. “You already did. All day, with your eyes.” Her tone makes the air thinner between them. She steps closer, crowd noise fading. “So, professore. Tomorrow you go back to your libraries? Behave? Read your dead men who wrote about my city and never saw half of it?” He swallows. “That was the plan.” “And now?” “Now I’m considering revising my methodology.” “Big words,” she teases softly. “You want to see more?” It feels like the most dangerous question anyone’s asked him. “Yes.” Her gaze holds his, amused, assessing, a flicker of something less guarded. Then she slips a small piece of paper into his shirt pocket, fingers warm against his chest. “My number,” she says. “Or maybe a pizza menu. You call, you find out.” He huffs a breath. “You enjoy tormenting people, don’t you?” “Only the interesting ones.” A beat. She could kiss him; the charged air says so. Instead, she leans in and presses her lips to his cheek, just at the corner of his mouth—a location chosen for maximum confusion. He goes stock-still. “Grazie for not dying,” she murmurs. “Thank you for…kidnapping me,” he manages. She grins, steps back, helmet on in one fluid movement. “Occhi aperti, Ben.” “I’ll keep them open,” he says. “If you keep trying not to run me over.” “No promises.” She revs the engine, slips into the Roman night without looking back, a streak of noise and taillight. Ben stands in the fountain’s glow, fingers brushing the scrap of paper in his pocket, the phantom heat of her mouth on his skin. He’s utterly disoriented. And completely, irretrievably, smitten.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining the requested contemporary romance structure. The author successfully creates two distinct, believable characters whose personalities emerge naturally through action and dialogue rather than exposition. Alessandra's kleptomaniacal tendencies are woven subtly throughout the narrative - the lighter from the stall, the postcard, Ben's coin - creating layers of characterization that reward careful reading. The dialogue feels authentic and serves multiple purposes: revealing character, advancing plot, and building romantic tension. Alessandra's mix of Italian phrases and accented English reads naturally, while Ben's academic politeness contrasts effectively without feeling forced. The banter has genuine wit and avoids clichéd romantic comedy exchanges. The pacing is well-controlled, moving between intimate character moments and kinetic action sequences. The motorcycle scenes provide genuine tension and serve as metaphors for Ben's journey outside his comfort zone. The structure of returning to the Trevi Fountain creates satisfying circularity while showing how both characters have changed. The prose style is clean and evocative without becoming overwrought. Sentences like "The motorino screams around the corner like a thrown stone" and "She's all sharp angles and fast breath" create vivid impressions efficiently. The sensory details ground readers in Rome without resorting to tourist-brochure descriptions. However, some elements feel slightly convenient - Luca's warning arrives precisely when needed to create doubt, and Alessandra's decision to take Ben along lacks complete motivation beyond plot necessity. The ending, while charming, edges toward predictable romantic comedy territory. The characterization shows genuine complexity. Alessandra isn't simply a manic pixie dream girl; her guardedness and the hints about her past create depth. Ben's transformation feels earned through the accumulation of small moments rather than sudden revelation. The romantic tension builds organically through physical proximity, shared experiences, and gradual revelation rather than forced chemistry. The writing demonstrates professional-level control of voice and tone, maintaining consistency while allowing for emotional range. The piece successfully balances humor with genuine romantic stakes. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 5.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 78.0
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double.” The tentacled dreads are the first thing I notice—midnight blue, beaded, fraying like he’s been running a while. The second is the way his hands shake. Not big tremors, but the kind you get when you’re past exhausted and you’ve outrun something that isn’t tired yet. I’m already wiping the same circular patch of counter with my rag, so I don’t have to start. “Tough night?” I ask. “Just the whisky,” he mutters. “Sure thing.” I reach up, snag the Vega bottle from the top shelf—fake scarcity, real burn—and pour a meticulous double. Slide it to him. He downs half in one go. No savoring. Just survival. “Another?” I ask. “Finish it first,” he says, voice rough. “Otherwise, it starts to feel like hope, and I’m not sure I can afford that.” “You’re on the Outer Rim,” I say. “We do wholesale hopelessness, retail apathy, and the first glass of denial is on the house.” That earns a snort. “You Nets?” I pause, just a fraction. “Who’s asking?” He glances sideways, checking the room. The Outpost is in its usual evening drift: a low hum of languages, engine grease on miner sleeves, two traders arguing softly over docking tariffs at a corner table, Loq the six-limbed mechanic nursing a phosphor ale, and Zaii humming tunelessly near the holo-pool table, their iridescent frills shifting lazy pastels. Nothing immediate. Nothing new. The stranger lowers his voice. “Name’s Rian.” “That your real name, Rian?” I ask. “Is Nets your real name?” “My friends call me Nets.” He takes that in like it’s a puzzle. “Then I hope I’m a fast learner.” I keep wiping the same spot. Old habit. Anchor habit. It keeps my hands busy when my brain starts connecting dots it shouldn’t. “You running from someone?” I ask. “Something.” I hate that answer more. The door to the docking corridor sighs open, letting a brief breath of cold metal and ionized dust roll through. My shoulders tense. It’s not for him; I know that before I turn. It’s just two belt miners, laughing too loud, shedding rock chips like dandruff. Still, the stranger tracks them with a predator’s awareness, one hand sliding under his coat, fingers brushing something at his hip. “You can leave it holstered,” I say quietly. He downs the rest of his whisky instead. “Another.” I pour. Not a word about creds yet. That’s its own flag. While I’m at it, Zaii drifts closer to the bar, their voice low. “Your new friend smells like burnt conduits and regret,” they murmur in their melodic Andromedan. “I speak three forms of regret,” I reply, still watching Rian. “This one’s new.” Zaii snickers, then flares their frills in subtle sign. “Also smells tagged. Someone else’s transponder dust.” “Got it,” I say. Rian pretends not to hear us, staring at the scarred countertop. The Vega bottle catches the light; his reflection is split by a crack in the lacquer. “You’re a long way from central lanes,” I say. “Miss a jump?” “Several,” he says. “One of them on purpose.” “Can’t imagine why anyone would come here on purpose,” I say. “You did,” he shoots back. I blink. “Who’s been talking to you?” “No one,” he says. “Just a pattern. Woman running a no-questions bar at a station nobody cares about. The way everyone glances at you before they start trouble. You didn’t land here by accident.” I keep wiping. The spot’s clean enough to eat off, but that’s not the point. “You’re observant,” I say. “Occupational hazard.” “Which occupation are we discussing?” He hesitates. Then: “Courier.” “Legal?” I ask. He gives me a look. “Thought so.” He pushes his empty glass forward with two fingers. “Last one, Nettles. Then I’m out of your hair.” “Nets,” I correct automatically, pouring. “And out of my hair to where?” “Ship’s docked on C-Ring. I’ll be a ghost before anyone knows I stopped.” Zaii, leaning on the bar, hums thoughtfully. “Interesting,” they say in Trade. “Customs sweep scheduled on C-Ring in fifteen.” “Zaii,” I warn. “What?” They bat innocent translucent eyelids. “Public notice. Not my fault if our guest forgot to check the bulletins.” Rian tenses. “C-Ring,” he repeats. “Customs doesn’t sweep C-Ring. It’s all miner junkers and broken haulers.” “Tonight they do,” I say. “Randomized interval. Started last month.” “That’s impossible,” he says. “I scrubbed my registry. No one should be able to track—” He stops. I set the bottle down. “Tracked, huh?” He stares at his drink. “I said ‘should.’ Didn’t say they couldn’t.” “Who is ‘they’?” I ask. He exhales, a thread of air as if that might deflate the mess. “Nexus Crown.” The rag stills in my hand. Zaii’s frills go dull. “You brought Crown heat here?” they hiss. A soft laugh from the other end of the bar; Loq raises one of his glasses. “Bad form, courier.” “Keep your voice down,” Rian snaps. “Nexus Crown doesn’t like me,” Zaii says sweetly. “I am very at peace with them not liking me from far away.” I swallow the prickling on the back of my neck. Nexus Crown. Corporate empire, pseudo-government, very good at pretending they’re benevolent while they grind planets into quarterly reports. They also sponsor a particular security branch that used to sign my paychecks. “Why are they after you?” I ask Rian. “I didn’t say they were.” “You did, actually.” I gently tap the bar between us. “Bringing Crown business into the Last Outpost is… impolite.” “It wasn’t supposed to be here,” he says. “I had a quiet refuel planned on an anonymous rock. Then they pushed that security notice live twenty minutes after I docked. Someone’s got a line into my route calcs.” Zaii’s eyes narrow. “Telemetry ghost.” Rian nods. “Or worse.” I lean closer. “What did you steal?” He hesitates long enough to answer the question without words. “Information,” he says finally. “Class?” I press. “Black,” he replies. Zaii inhales. Loq laughs, but it’s strained this time. “Get up,” I say. Rian blinks. “What?” “Get off my barstool.” He doesn’t move. “Look—if it’s money—” “I don’t care about your money.” I jerk my chin toward a side door. “Private booth. Now. You sitting in the open talking about black-class Nexus Crown data on my main floor is how we all end up airlocked.” He slides off the stool, still wary. I nod at Zaii. “Watch the counter. Don’t thin the Vega too much.” “Who, me?” Zaii flutters. “Never.” I lead Rian past the row of booths to the tiny alcove screened with aging holo-beads. The beads flicker, trying for privacy shimmer and getting static. He ducks in; I follow, letting the familiar claustrophobia press against my ribs. He studies me. “You’re awfully invested for someone who doesn’t care.” “I care about this place,” I say. “And the people in it. Now talk fast. What did you move, who did you cross, and how long until they knock on my door?” He rubs his forehead. Close up, he looks younger, under the stubble and the exhausted eyes. “Package run out of a Nexus research node. I pulled a data core. Not for me. For a client.” “Client’s name?” “Can’t give you that.” “Can’t or won’t?” “Both.” I chew on that. “Why steal from the Crown?” “Have you met them?” “Unfortunately.” “They’re working on something in the belt,” he says. “Off-grid. Military signatures masked as ore processors. My client wanted proof. I got them a copy. Slice-and-dash. Except Crown security wasn’t as blind as advertised.” “Lucky you.” “They traced the breach to my ship. I scrubbed, bounced, took the dirtiest, no-signal routes out here. Should’ve bought me time. Only way they’re still on me is a tap in my nav, or someone in this halo’s feeding them pings.” “And you docked here anyway.” I fold my arms. “With black-class data.” “Like I said,” he mutters. “One jump on purpose. I heard the Outpost was a place that doesn’t ask questions. A place that can… disappear things.” I stare at him. “You heard wrong,” I say, a little too sharp. “We pour drinks and fix leaky life support. That’s it.” His gaze flicks to my hands. I realize the rag is clenched tight, knuckles white. “You don’t have to help,” he says. “Just needed ten minutes to think where to run next. I’ll be gone.” “You won’t make it past the C-Ring customs sweep,” I say. “If they’re Crown plants, they already flagged your transponder. You undock, you light up like a distress beacon.” “So I burn the ship,” he says quickly. “Lifepod out of a service hatch. Hide on some miner barge. Shuffle out-system. There’s always a way.” “Sure,” I say. “If you want to roll those dice.” His jaw tightens. “You got a better idea?” “No,” I lie. He leans forward. “Your rep says you do.” “Who’s been selling this ‘rep’?” I hiss. “Because they’re going to get my foot in their—” The overhead lights flick once. Twice. Then shift from warm gold to muted blue. I look up. That’s not our normal cycle. Zaii’s voice crackles over the local comm from the bar. “Nets? You’re going to want to see this.” Rian swears under his breath. We slip out of the booth. The main room’s quieter now. Conversations folded inward, napkins forgotten mid-air. Loq is staring up at the far wall where the old holo-projector whirs, dredging itself awake. Station-wide bulletin: ATTENTION OUTPOST RESIDENTS AND VISITORS. BY ORDER OF NEXUS CROWN SECURITY DIVISION: MANDATORY ID VERIFICATION AND CARGO SCAN IN EFFECT. NON-COMPLIANCE WILL RESULT IN DETENTION. Underneath, a logo I know too well blooms like a bruise. “Fantastic,” I say softly. “They never come this far out.” “They do now,” Rian mutters. Zaii sidles over, whispering fast in my ear. “Dockside cams show three Crown cutters already latched. Security teams in black armor. Their insignia—N-7 division.” My mouth goes dry. N-7. My old unit. “They’re early,” Rian says. “I thought I had time.” “You don’t,” I say. He turns to me, eyes suddenly very clear. “You help me vanish, I make it worth your while.” “And if I don’t?” He scans the room, the miners, Zaii, Loq, the mismatched crowd. “Then everyone in here gets very familiar with a black-site debrief.” Inside my chest, old training grinds against the quiet life I built wiping this bar. Nexus Crown wants something on this station, and it’s not just him. They wouldn’t roll N-7 for one courier. This is bigger. It always is. I shift the rag to my other hand, fingers steady now. “Sit back down,” I tell him. He blinks. “What?” “Last Outpost rule,” I say. “No one panics until I say so. Sit. Look like you belong. Don’t talk to anyone in armor unless they talk to you first.” “Nets,” Zaii whispers. “What are you doing?” “Buying time.” I force my voice light. “Pouring drinks.” Rian stares at me like he’s trying to read a language he almost knows. “You going to turn me in?” he asks quietly. I don’t answer. I just pick up his glass, start wiping the same circle on the counter beside it, and watch the doors as Nexus Crown security steps into my bar.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt requirements, delivering a cozy sci-fi chapter set in The Last Outpost with Nets as the bartender protagonist. The author successfully establishes conflict through Rian's arrival with stolen Nexus Crown data and the subsequent appearance of security forces, while appropriately leaving the conflict unresolved. The dialogue ratio appears to meet the requested 60%, and the first-person present tense narration is consistently maintained throughout. The characterization is notably strong. Nets emerges as a complex protagonist with a mysterious past connected to Nexus Crown's N-7 division, revealed through subtle hints rather than exposition dumps. Her protective instincts toward the Outpost community and her measured responses to crisis situations feel authentic. Rian is portrayed believably as a desperate courier making increasingly poor decisions under pressure. The supporting characters like Zaii and Loq add texture to the world without overwhelming the scene. The world-building is efficiently handled, establishing the asteroid belt setting, the diverse clientele, and the corporate-dominated political landscape without excessive exposition. The author demonstrates skill in weaving backstory elements naturally into dialogue and action, particularly regarding Nets' history with Nexus Crown. The prose maintains an appropriate tone throughout—neither too casual nor overly literary for the space opera setting. Dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes: character development, world-building, and plot advancement. The banter between characters has authentic rhythm, particularly the exchanges between Nets and her regular patrons. However, some elements feel slightly predictable. The revelation that Nets has connections to the pursuing security forces follows familiar patterns, though it's executed competently. The pacing occasionally slows during exposition-heavy moments, and some descriptive passages lean toward the mechanical rather than atmospheric. The tension builds effectively toward the cliffhanger ending, with the arrival of N-7 forces creating genuine stakes. The author successfully balances the "cozy" element with meaningful conflict—the bar feels like a lived-in community space while still being threatened by outside forces. Technical execution is generally solid, with clear sentence structure and good paragraph flow. The action sequences are easy to follow, and the emotional beats land appropriately without feeling forced. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 14.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 9.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder. I hitch it back up for the fiftieth goddamn time and squint down Canal Street like maybe I accidentally dropped my entire life somewhere between the Walgreens and the guy selling knockoff beads. It’s early, but New Orleans doesn’t seem to have an “off” setting. The air is already thick, like somebody drank a humidifier and is breathing on me. I smell sugar and piss and stale beer and beignets and car exhaust and weed. A trumpet blares something messy but hopeful from somewhere I can’t see. I rub grit from my eyes. Last real sleep was… what, Arkansas? In the back of that eighteen-wheeler that smelled like onions and old coffee. I mutter under my breath. “Great decision, Taylor. Big-brain move. Run away to a city you’ve only seen on Netflix and true crime podcasts.” My phone is at six percent. I’m at maybe three. A woman in a red visor brushes past me, frowning, like my existence is an inconvenience. She’s not wrong. My t-shirt clings to my back; my binder is a damp band of “you asked for this” across my ribs. The strap slides again. I want to scream. Two nights since I told them. Since Mom’s face had done that thing, like she’d been slapped. Since Dad said, “Don’t be ridiculous,” and my brother laughed and then tried to act like he hadn’t. Since the school counsellor’s voicemail: “concerning behavioral patterns.” Like wanting to be alive and honest is a behavioral pattern. I’d picked “b. invent some drama” my whole life. This wasn’t that. They couldn’t tell the difference. The strap slips. I yank it up. “Fuck.” “You kiss your mother with that mouth?” someone says behind me. I whirl around, heart jumpstarting. The voice belongs to a person about my age, leaning against a lamppost, one sneaker up on the metal, arms folded. They’re wiry, dark-skinned, hair in a mess of twists pulled back with a faded bandana. Oversized denim jacket despite the heat. Their eyes are sharp and amused, and weirdly tired. “If I kissed my mother,” I say, “she’d probably schedule an exorcism. So, no.” A corners-of-the-mouth smile. “You look lost.” “Do I?” I try to stand straighter. The backpack strap abandons me again. Perfect timing. I grab at it, juggling my entire worldly possessions like a drunk circus clown. Bandana Kid’s smile spreads. “You kind of do,” they say. “And like your bag hates you.” “It does,” I say. “It’s homophobic.” They snort. “Or transphobic. Gotta be precise.” My stomach flips. I didn’t say trans. They did. I narrow my eyes. “What makes you think I’m—” They raise an eyebrow. “You’re in a binding shirt in Louisiana July, with a Tennessee accent and a run-away-from-home backpack. I played this level before.” My throat goes tight. “Cool,” I say. “You win Creepy Observant Stranger Bingo.” They push off the lamppost. “Relax. I’m Jai.” “J-A-Y?” I ask automatically. “J-A-I,” they say. “Pronouns they/them, unless you wanna fight about it.” “I don’t—” I catch myself. “Same. He/they.” “Nice,” Jai says. “You eaten?” I blink. Flag. Stranger danger. Rule number one. “I’m good.” My stomach picks that moment to growl so loud a passing tourist looks over. Jai’s eyebrows go up. “That’s a bold interpretation of ‘good.’ Come on. Café down the street. My treat.” “I’m not—” I start. “I can’t pay you back.” “Did I ask?” Jai shrugs. “Consider it a welcome-to-the-chaos tax. Or I can let you pass out dramatically on Bourbon Street, which, hey, mood, but seems inefficient.” Bourbon Street. Right. Danger. Or Instagram. Or both. I should walk away. My mother’s voice in my head says, You don’t know what people like that are capable of. People like that. Queer. Poor. Unbothered. I follow Jai. The café is small and sort of peeling at the edges, the sign missing a letter, but it smells like actual food. I stand awkwardly while Jai orders two iced coffees and a plate of something powdered-sugary. I fumble to pull out a crumpled ten. Jai puts a hand over my wrist. “Put it away,” they say. “You’ll need that more than me.” “I’m not a charity case.” Jai looks at me dead-on. “Okay. Then think of it as investment. Maybe one day you stop me walking into traffic. Balance.” I hate that it makes sense. I shove the ten back into my pocket. We sit in a shadowy corner. Air conditioning whirs like a comforting monster. I take a sip of iced coffee. It hits like a minor miracle. “I’m not staying,” I say too fast. “Just… passing through.” “Sure,” Jai says. “What’d you tell the trucker that dropped you off?” “What?” “You got here somehow.” They tear a beignet in half. Powdered sugar explodes over their fingers, dusts their jacket. “What’s the cover story?” Heat floods my face. “I don’t— I didn’t think—” “Yeah,” Jai says gently. “You didn’t.” I want to punch them. I also want to ask them to make a spreadsheet of my life choices. “So what’s your deal?” I deflect. “You just… patrol Canal Street for lost trans kids to feed?” Jai grins. “Maybe. Maybe I’m running recruitment for a cult.” “Do you have matching tracksuits?” I ask. “Only in summer,” they say. “Seriously, though. You got somewhere to sleep?” I picture: the sidewalk. A park bench. The truck stop where the guy in the cap kept asking if I had a boyfriend. “I’m figuring it out,” I say. “Gotcha,” Jai says. “That’s a ‘no.’” “Do you always translate people?” I snap. “Only when they’re lying,” Jai says. Something flickers in their eyes. “Look, there’s a drop-in center a few blocks from here. For youth. Queer, trans, whatever. Showers. Lockers. Food sometimes. You don’t have to play lone-wolf in a city you don’t know.” “I’m fine,” I say. “I can handle myself.” Images: Dad’s face going red. Mom saying, “Where did you pick this up?” like I’d caught transness from a gas station bathroom. Me packing a backpack with shaking hands. Me thinking, anywhere but here, anywhere. “Sure,” Jai says. “You handled yourself all the way to six-percent battery.” I jolt. “You reading my soul or my screen brightness?” “Both,” they say. “Plug behind you.” There is, in fact, an outlet. I plug in like my life depends on it. It kind of does. “What if they track me,” I blurt. “My parents. Find My Phone.” “Airplane mode,” Jai says. “Then turn off location. Or ditch the SIM. We can get you a cheap one later if you want.” “We?” I echo. They shrug. “I’m invested now. I bought you coffee.” “That doesn’t make us a we,” I say, but it lands weaker than I mean it. Jai’s face goes a little closed, like I stepped on something. “Right,” they say. “Noted.” Guilt pricks. “I didn’t mean—” “It’s cool,” they say too quickly. Silence stretches between us. The café hums. Outside, a siren wails, someone laughs too loud. I shake sugar off my fingers. “I came out,” I say. Not sure why I’m telling them. Maybe because they asked nothing but the right things. “Two days ago. To my family.” “How’d that go?” Jai asks, like they don’t already know the answer. “Bad,” I say. “Nuclear. My mom cried. Dad said I was doing it for attention. They said it’s a phase. They said I embarrassed them. So I fixed the embarrassing part.” “By leaving,” Jai says. “Yeah.” “That’s not the embarrassing part,” they say quietly. My chest tightens. I shrug like it’s whatever. “I just… couldn’t breathe there. Counsellor called it ‘concerning behavioral patterns.’ Like I’m a raccoon.” Jai lets out a laugh that feels like it’s scraped out of them. “That what they say now? That your life is a pattern?” “Guess so,” I say. “What about you?” They pick at a crumb. “Came down from Jackson last year. Dad said he’d rather have a dead daughter than a non-binary kid. I chose ‘neither’ and a bus ticket. Been here since.” “Oh,” I say. “Oh,” they echo, mocking my tone soft, not mean. “Got hooked up with the center. Couch-surfed. Figured out the hustle.” Something in their voice suggests “hustle” covers more territory than I want to think about. My shoulder itches under the strap. I shift. It slides again. “Dude,” Jai says. “You and that bag are in a toxic relationship.” “I know,” I say. “It’s my emotional support bad decision.” They actually laugh. For real this time. “You should come by the center,” they say. “They don’t ask too many questions the first day. You can shower. Charge fully. Sleep without getting robbed.” I hesitate. Every cop show I’ve ever half-watched plays in my head. “Is it like… a trap? For runaways?” “That’s the streets,” Jai says. “The center’s run by this lesbian couple who collect strays like you. And me. They’ll nag you about school and jobs and condoms, but they won’t call your mom unless you ask.” “That sounds fake,” I say. “Okay,” they say, standing. “Stay suspicious. But walk with me. Worst case, you bail. You look like you could outrun me.” “I can’t,” I say. “P.E. was the one class I failed enthusiastically.” “Relatable,” Jai says. “Come on.” I follow. We step back into the soup of air. Noise slams into me. A guy in a feather headdress shoves beads at a family. A woman yells about a riverboat tour. A cop car creeps by, slow. I flinch. “You got any IDs in that thing?” Jai nods at my backpack. “School ID,” I say. “Birth certificate copy. Nothing exciting.” “Keep ‘em close, but not all in one place,” Jai says. “If someone jacks your bag, you don’t exist.” “Comforting,” I mutter. We cut down a narrower street. Less tourist, more cracked paint, more locals side-eyeing us. Jai walks like they belong anywhere they touch. I try to match it. “You trust them?” I ask. “The center? Yeah,” they say. “The city? No. People? Depends.” “On what?” “On whether they think I’m disposable,” Jai says. I think of my dad’s words. Dead daughter. I swallow. “And me?” I ask, before I can stop myself. “You think I’m—” “New,” Jai says. “And exhausted. And about five minutes from crying or punching someone.” I bristle. “I’m fine.” They glance at me. “Okay, Fine. We’re almost there.” We turn a corner. The building is old brick, painted bright teal that’s peeling like a sunburn. There’s a rainbow flag in the dusty window, and a handwritten sign: “Youth Resource Drop-In. No cops, no creeps.” A woman in her forties with silver hair and a tattoo sleeve leans in the doorway, smoking. She sees Jai and her face softens. “Hey, trouble,” she says. “You bring us a new duckling?” “She’s not a duckling,” I snap, before realizing I gendered myself wrong. Or right? My stomach flips. “She,” the woman repeats, watching my face. “He? They?” “He/they,” I mumble. “Got it,” she says smoothly. “I’m Rena. You’re safe here. You hungry?” “No,” I say. My voice cracks. “Yes.” “Come on in,” Rena says. “We got leftover red beans and rice. And AC.” Jai touches my arm, just a brush. “Told you.” Inside, it smells like cleaning supplies and cheap food and something floral. Kids sprawl on mismatched couches. A bulletin board screams about support groups and free testing and job fairs. There’s a sign over the desk: “You Belong. No Bullshit.” My throat closes. I joke when I’m about to break. That’s the rule. “So this is like… gay Hogwarts?” I say. Jai snorts. Rena laughs. “Sure,” she says. “Except we give out Narcan instead of wands.” The words land heavy. This is real. Real survival, real stakes. Not Tumblr drama, not me making up problems to feel less numb. I don’t know this world. I don’t know its dangers. I also don’t know when I last felt a room that wasn’t actively pushing me out. “House rules,” Rena says, like she’s given this speech a thousand times. “No violence, no hard drugs inside, no outing people, and if you steal from another kid, you’re gone. Shower’s down the hall. Crash room in the back if you need a nap. You can put your name on a list if you’re looking for longer-term stuff. We don’t call home unless you want us to. Questions?” “What’s the catch?” I ask. It comes out harsh. Rena’s mouth goes rueful. “Catch is, we’re broke and full,” she says. “But we do what we can.” I stand there, backpack strap biting into my shoulder, sweat drying sticky on my skin, exhaustion like concrete in my bones. I should leave. I should keep distance. I should operate like this is enemy territory. Jai bumps my elbow. “At least shower,” they say. “You smell like Tennessee.” I huff out a laugh that tastes like crying. “Fine,” I say. “One shower. Then I’m figuring things out.” “Absolutely,” Jai says, clearly not believing me. I peel the backpack off. The strap slides down in a final, sulky swoop. I clutch the bag to my chest, suddenly terrified of losing it. It’s everything I have left that proves I exist. Rena nods toward the hallway. “Fresh towels in the bin on the right. Door locks.” I walk down the hall on rubber legs. The bathroom is cramped and clean. I lock the door, slide the bolt three times just to be sure. I set my backpack in the corner like an altar. When the water hits me, it’s almost cold, and I suck in a sharp breath. Dirt and sweat swirl down the drain. I press my hand flat over my binder and feel my heart pounding. You did it, I think. You got out. Then: What if you can’t do this. What if this was a mistake. What if they’re right about you. I rest my forehead against the tile. The water drowns the noise from the street and the kids and my own head, just for a second. I don’t know if I trust Jai. I don’t know if I trust Rena. I don’t know this city, its rules, its traps. But I’m here. Breathing. The strap will slip again. The dangers will come. I turn my face into the spray and decide—for today, for just today—to stay.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and authentic voice work within the young adult drama genre. The author successfully captures Taylor's distinctive narrative voice through a blend of cynical humor, vulnerability, and teenage bravado that feels genuine rather than performative. The first-person mixed tense approach works well, creating immediacy while allowing for reflection. The characterization is particularly strong. Taylor emerges as a complex protagonist whose defensive mechanisms (humor, deflection, suspicion) feel earned given their recent trauma and current precarious situation. The internal contradictions—wanting help while rejecting it, craving connection while maintaining distance—ring true for a traumatized teenager. Jai is equally well-developed, avoiding the trap of being either purely helpful or obviously dangerous. Their own guardedness and street wisdom create a believable dynamic. The dialogue excels throughout, capturing authentic teenage speech patterns without falling into caricature. Exchanges like the backpack being "homophobic" and the "gay Hogwarts" comparison demonstrate how humor functions as both character development and tension relief. The conversations between Taylor and Jai build their relationship organically while revealing backstory naturally. The New Orleans setting is effectively rendered through sensory details—the mix of smells, sounds, and oppressive heat—without becoming tourist-brochure purple prose. The author demonstrates good restraint in world-building, giving enough detail to establish place without overwhelming the character focus. The emotional complexity is well-handled. Taylor's conflicted feelings about their family, their simultaneous desperation and pride, and their struggle with trust all feel authentic. The piece avoids simple victim narratives while acknowledging real trauma and danger. However, there are some minor weaknesses. Certain moments edge toward being slightly overwrought, particularly in the shower scene's ending. Some transitions feel slightly rushed, and occasionally the internal monologue becomes somewhat mechanical in its self-awareness. The pacing works well overall, moving from disorientation through tentative connection to a moment of precarious stability. The ending strikes an appropriate balance—hopeful enough to avoid bleakness but realistic about ongoing challenges. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 84.1
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The day began, as so many bad decisions did, with a staff meeting. Midas sat cross-legged on the cracked tile floor of the old service tunnel, staring at a hand-drawn map that could, under certain generous interpretations, be mistaken for cartography. Chewy, an animatronic koala patched with duct tape and optimism, leaned against an overturned crate, one glass eye glowing faintly. "Right," Midas said. "Agenda for today. Item one: not dying." Chewy whirred softly. His head did a slow, grinding swivel. "Unleash the fun—for the whole family," he chirped, in a tinny, anachronistic falsetto. "I feel like you're not taking this seriously," Midas said. Chewy blinked out of sync. It wasn’t entirely clear if he’d meant to. They were holed up beneath what once had been a shopping mall and was now, through the gentle caress of entropy and looting, a hollowed-out mausoleum for brand loyalty. Their base was a former maintenance closet with a door that only squeaked ominously on alternate Thursdays. It was home: three blankets, a bin of semi-edible cans, a solar lantern, a bucket system nobody talked about, and Chewy. Midas pointed to the map. "We are here. The legendary Canned Goods Emporium is here." He pointed at a scribbled rectangle three sectors over. "Between us and it, we have: maybe-feral ex-urbanites, two collapsed intersections, a waterlogged food court, and rumors of a vending machine cult." Chewy’s eye brightened. "Taste the future. Available for a limited time." Midas sighed. "Exactly. We’re running out. That 'limited time' is now. We’re down to pickled something and Not Beans." Not Beans was a mystery can the color of regret. They had agreed not to make eye contact with it. "So, objectives," Midas continued. "Get to the Emporium. Salvage canned goods. Do not engage lunatics or biohazards. Return before sundown. Minimal screaming." He waited, because the only thing worse than arguing with yourself was not having anyone there to half-argue back. Chewy rustled faintly as some long-forgotten servo tried to find its life’s purpose. "Always follow your dreams," he said. "Close enough." They set out. The corridor beyond their closet base smelled like dust and nostalgia. Emergency exit signs still glowed with a wan green luminescence, courtesy of pre-collapse glow-paint that would outlive them all, smugly. Midas had a spear. This made him feel heroic until he remembered it was a broken curtain rod with a bread knife taped to the end. But it was pointy, and in the new world, pointy counted for a lot. Navigating the substructure of the mall was relatively easy, if you knew the signs. Fresh footprints? Avoid. Weird chanting? Avoid. Smear marks at about shoulder height? Definitely avoid. The last was a lesson Midas had learned from the Salad People, who had strong feelings about ranch dressing. They reached a maintenance hatch and climbed up into a gutted department store. Sunlight lanced in through holes in the ceiling, illuminating ragged clothing racks and a collapsed cosmetics counter that had never been more honest. Midas checked the route. "If we cut through here, go down the escalator, over the indoor decorative river, under the food court, we hit the loading bays. Then three blocks to the Emporium. In and out. Easy." Chewy’s mouth clicked. "Just do it." They both paused. "Don’t say things like that," Midas muttered. "That’s the kind of phrase that makes the universe pay attention." They made it as far as the escalator before the day remembered who Midas was. The escalator, to its credit, waited until they were halfway down. It emitted a deeply suspicious thunk, then a shriek of ancient metal. A step dropped out from under Midas’s foot. He plunged through up to the thigh, yelping, spear clattering away. Chewy, mercifully light, rolled a bit and bonked his head on Midas’s shoulder. "Ow," Midas grunted, flailing. The escalator groaned ominously. Additional steps sagged, threatening to transform him into a diagram used in Safety Trainings They’d Ignored Back Then. Chewy’s LED eye flickered like a tiny, unhelpful lighthouse. "Batteries not included," he said. "Very constructive," Midas hissed, bracing on three suspect metal teeth. He heaved himself free with all the grace of a distressed walrus and sprawled onto the landing. The escalator, offended at being survived, spit a few bolts and went still. Midas inspected his leg. Torn jeans, a long slice along his calf. Bleeding, but not "definitely going to die," more "going to sting all day and attract judgmental flies." "Okay," he panted. "Setback. Not a sign. We're flexible, we adapt." The universe, having clearly marked that down, queued the next item. They crossed the decorative river via a series of fallen planters, ignoring the carp skeletons that suggested the fish had eventually taken up minimalism. On the far side lay the old food court, half-flooded, smelling faintly poisonous. The water reflected cracked logos of extinct franchises. At the center of the shallow brown pool, an island of piled vending machines. Midas froze. "Oh no." Chewy’s head creaked. "New! Improved! Now with extra flavor." "No," Midas whispered. "No commentary." Figures moved among the machines, draped in foil wrappers and plastic bottle charms. One of them spotted him. "Pilgrims!" she cried. The others turned, eyes fever-bright. "Do you seek the Dispensing?" "We're just passing through," Midas said quickly. "Wrong religion. Allergic to corn syrup." The leader stepped forward, a crown of melted credit cards on her head. "None are wrong before the Holy Vender. All may press the Sacred Buttons." A ragged chorus: "Press! Press! Press!" Chewy, traitorously loud: "Refuel your life!" They gasped. A murmur: "The Jingle." Midas closed his eyes briefly. "Okay, look," he said. "He's broken. He says things. It's not—" "The Prophet is among us," breathed the leader. She pointed at Chewy. "He bears the Voice of Before. You must present Him to the Slots." Midas considered running. He estimated their odds at "trampled into symbolic confetti." "Great," he said weakly. "Love your... shrine. But we really—" Hands grabbed him. Others lifted Chewy high, careful and reverent, as though he might at any moment disgorge a limited-time offer. They were swept onto the vending-island. A vending machine loomed, its glass spiderwebbed with cracks, its innards long looted. Someone had painted eyes on it. They had also painted teeth. They had not done so reassuringly. "Offer the Prophet," intoned the leader. Midas clutched Chewy as long as he could. Unfortunately, that was about three seconds. Koalas were built to be adorable, not aerodynamic; Chewy popped from his grasp like a plush bar of soap and was seized. The cultists held Chewy up to the cracked keypad. "Speak, Prophet!" they chanted. Chewy’s servos hummed. "Family fun never tasted so good." A shudder of awe. "The Code!" someone shouted. They mashed the keypad: F-A-M-1-L-Y, more or less. The dead machine beeped a sound that might have been purely mechanical or mildly annoyed. Nothing dispensed. A tension. Perhaps it was the moment the faith needed. "The Prophet demands a sacrifice," the leader whispered. "We must feed the Slot." Several heads swiveled toward Midas in a way he found pessimistic. "Right," he said. "Nope." He lunged, grabbed Chewy, and bolted. The edge of the island was right there, and the water only looked moderately infectious. He jumped. He made it as far as "oh, this might wor—" before hitting the surface. The food court pond accepted him with the loving embrace of lukewarm soup. He surfaced, sputtering, Chewy tucked to his chest. "Now with extra crunch," Chewy said, because of course he did. Behind them, the vending congregation wailed. "Blasphemer!" "Get him!" Midas slogged through chest-high muck while his leg wound reminded him that bacteria existed. He reached the far edge, scrambled over broken tiles, and limped for the maintenance corridors. By some perverse mercy, no one followed him into the dark. Possibly their sacred jurisdiction ended at the waterline. Possibly even zealots had standards about wading through whatever that had been. Midas did not stop moving until the chanting faded. He leaned against a wall, dripping. Chewy sagged in his arms, water trickling from his fabric ears. "So," Midas gasped. "Recalibrating expectations. Maybe... skip the Emporium." His leg throbbed in answer. They continued anyway, because food was a democracy but hunger was a coup. Aboveground, the world was a patchwork of collapsed office blocks, stubborn weeds, and distant, unhelpful birds. The city had taken the collapse personally and thrown most of itself on the floor. They kept to alleys. Midas scouted with his noble spear of Mild Encouragement. Chewy occasionally clicked, startling rats. As they neared the marked location of the Canned Goods Emporium—a squat, windowless building with "MEGA VALUE" still flapping from its façade—the sky darkened. Clouds. Fast ones. "Great," Midas muttered. "Weather." They reached the alley behind the Emporium to find: a broken loading door hanging open. Good sign. Footprints in dried mud. Bad sign. A smell like rancid metal and victory. Mixed sign. Inside was gloom and shelving and, on the floor, torn-open cardboard boxes. Empty cans lay everywhere. Midas picked one up. The label: "CHEF RUDY’S AUTHENTIC PASTA PRODUCT (CHEESE-LIKE)." It had been licked clean. He moved deeper. A skittering echoed between aisles. Midas froze. From behind a stack of boxes emerged a rat. Then several more. Then a swarm. Their eyes had that special gleam of animals that had discovered human-grade calories. Midas took a step back. They advanced. "Limited time offer," Chewy whispered. "Not helping." Midas bolted for a side door. It resisted, then burst open so suddenly he fell out of the building and into the remains of a loading dock, sliding down a heap of loose gravel. He came to rest beside a dented crate. Inside: actual sealed cans. He laughed, slightly hysterical. "See? We just had to suffer a bit first." The first cold drop of rain hit his forehead. Then the sky poured. The slope turned to mud. The crate shifted. Midas lunged to grab it. The crate, obeying the basic laws of comedy, dragged him along as it slid off the dock and into the open storm channel running along the mall’s edge. "We are not doing this," Midas informed nobody. They did it. The improvised raft of Midas, Chewy, and sixteen cans of something took off down the flooded channel, bumping off broken concrete, under collapsed walkways, past a truly judgmental heron. Rain battered his face. His leg sent up regular status reports that all translated to "you idiot." "On the bright side," he wheezed, "we’re making good time." A chunk of rebar scraped their crate. A can tumbled away into the murk. "Some time," he amended. By the time the channel spat them out near the skeletal back entrance of the mall, he’d lost three cans, a layer of skin from his palms, and any illusion that today might still be salvaged. Hauling the crate inside took most of the rest of his dignity. Twilight seeped through broken skylights now. Midas limped along maintenance corridors until the friendly flicker of their glow-painted mark showed the turnoff to home. He shouldered into their closet. The door gave way with its traditional reluctant squeak. He set Chewy down on the blanket and collapsed beside him, chest heaving. They had eight cans of "Pasta Product," one gouged calf, the enmity of a vending cult, a growing rat-based problem on the western flank, and a new awareness that storm channels really should come with brakes. Chewy’s eye dimmed and flared as water dripped out of his seams. His voice unit crackled once, then twice. "Today," he said, slowly, as if accessing a deeper subroutine untouched in years, "is the first day of the rest of your life." Midas stared at him. "That," he said, "is technically true." He pried open a can with his knife. The contents looked like regret in sauce, but it smelled miraculously edible. He handed the first bite ceremoniously toward Chewy, caught himself, and instead raised it in a wobbly toast. "To not dying," Midas said. Chewy’s eye glowed faintly. "Satisfaction guaranteed," he whispered. Outside, the ruined world rumbled and rearranged its next attempt. Inside the little maintenance closet, they ate their dubious pasta product and considered the day, which, by all known metrics, had gone sideways. It was, Midas reflected, still a win. He was home. He had food. His apocalypse buddy was still glitching out optimistic nonsense in the dark. Tomorrow would almost certainly be worse. But for now, for one more limited-time offer of a night, they’d survived the sale.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his dry wit, observational humor, and knack for finding profundity in absurdity. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both believable and satirical, using the collapse of consumer civilization as fertile ground for dark comedy. The characterization is particularly effective. Midas emerges as a genuinely sympathetic protagonist - competent enough to survive but hapless enough to be relatable. His relationship with Chewy, the malfunctioning animatronic koala, provides both humor and surprising emotional depth. The author cleverly uses Chewy's corporate catchphrases as commentary on the old world while giving him moments of unexpected wisdom. The prose flows naturally with excellent pacing and rhythm that mirrors Pratchett's style. Phrases like "through the gentle caress of entropy and looting" and "the universe, having clearly marked that down, queued the next item" demonstrate sophisticated comic timing and voice consistency. The author maintains the wry, observational tone throughout without slipping into parody. The world-building is economical but vivid. The flooded mall, vending machine cult, and various hazards feel both absurd and plausible within the established reality. The author shows restraint in not over-explaining the collapse, letting details emerge naturally through the characters' experiences. The story structure follows the prompt perfectly - deliberation, mission gone sideways, return home worse for wear. Each mishap builds logically from character actions and world conditions rather than feeling arbitrary. The vending machine cult sequence is particularly creative, turning consumer worship into literal religion with both humor and mild horror. The dialogue, while limited, serves its purpose well. Midas's internal monologue carries most of the narrative weight, and Chewy's corporate-speak provides consistent comic relief while occasionally hitting unexpectedly poignant notes. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - not triumphant, but not despairing either. The modest victory of "not dying" and acquiring some dubious pasta feels earned given the day's trials. The final line about surviving "the sale" brings the consumer culture metaphor full circle cleverly. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the Pratchett pastiche becomes slightly self-conscious, and some descriptions that border on being overly elaborate. However, these don't significantly detract from an otherwise accomplished piece that successfully meets all the prompt requirements while delivering genuine entertainment and subtle depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 83.7
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell on the shop door jangled hard enough to sound offended. “Sorry, sorry—just, er—” The man backed in, one hand on the handle, the other clutching a cap low over his face. Driving rain blew in with him. “Hi. You’re open.” “It’s half three,” Carys said, from behind the counter. “Not exactly the witching hour.” He shut the door, pressed his back to it, listening. Outside, tyres screeched. Voices shouted. “Are they with you?” she asked. “In a manner of speaking.” A beat. She took him in: drenched leather jacket, black T-shirt, jeans, the unmistakable face she’d seen one too many times in slow motion on cinema screens. Hair darker with rain, jaw stubbled, eyes too bright. “Hm,” she said. “You’re him.” “Depends which him,” he said quickly. “If you mean the taxidermist from the butcher’s calendar—” “The movie star,” she said. “The one who jumps off exploding things and broods at helicopters. Rhys Lyn.” He brightened, relieved. “Yes. Brilliant. We’ve established I exist. Any chance I could… hide in your fine establishment for, say, the rest of my natural life?” Carys eyed the rain-streaked glass, where distant shapes now gathered. “They’ll try the café next door first. You’ve about five minutes before someone remembers books exist.” “I knew I liked this place,” he said. Then, turning it on: the grin, the slight crook of his head. “I’m Rhys.” “I just said that.” “Right, but this is the bit where you’re meant to say your name back. That’s how people are sure I’m not a waxwork.” She held his gaze a second too long, then looked down at the invoice she’d been pretending to study. “Carys.” “Well, Carys,” he said, tasting it, “can’t throw me to the wolves now. Could ruin your TripAdvisor rating.” “This isn’t a tourist attraction.” He glanced around. Shelves uneven, paint peeling in romantic ways, stacks of second-hand paperbacks, and, by the front, a cardboard cutout of a dragon wearing reading glasses. “Could’ve fooled me. I’d buy tickets.” “You don’t buy books, then?” she said. He pressed a hand to his heart. “That’s cruel. I buy loads of books. Sometimes I even read them before they turn into scripts.” “Mm.” “Is that skepticism?” He stepped closer to the counter. “You know, most people, when they see me, it’s a lot more—” He put on an exaggerated gasp. “Oh my God, Rhys, I loved you in Space Pirates 3, sign my—whatever. You’re very calm. Are you… alright?” “I shelve biographies,” she said. “Illusion immunity comes with the job.” He laughed, quick and delighted. “Ouch. That’s me told.” A fist thumped on the glass. A camera flash popped against the wet pane, ghostly. Rhys flinched. “Bloody vultures.” Carys moved to the door, flipped the hanging sign to CLOSED with a decisive flick, then locked it. He watched her. “You trust me not to rob the till?” “You’re wearing two-thousand-pound shoes,” she said. “If you’re here to rob me, you’re going about it inefficiently.” He glanced down, suddenly self-conscious. “They were a gift,” he muttered. “From a costume department.” Then, because he could not resist: “They’d suit you, though. You’ve got the… presence.” She snorted. “Right. I’m five foot four and selling used paperbacks in Aberfelen.” “Exactly,” he said. “Terrifying. Very… editorial chic.” She felt her cheeks warm and hated it. “There’s a loo at the back if you want to… not drip on the signed copies.” He perked up. “You have signed copies? Anyone I know?” “Real writers,” she said. He put a hand to his chest again, theatrically wounded. “You wound me twice in as many minutes. I might faint. You’d get sued.” “By your fans?” “By my publicist. Much scarier.” He headed towards the back, then hesitated by a small display. His hand hovered over a worn hardcover. The gold on the spine was cracked: The Odyssey, translated into Welsh. “Oh,” he said softly, genuine slipping through. “You’ve got the old Gwynfor edition.” She blinked. “You can read the old Gwynfor edition?” “I can mangle it with feeling,” he said. “Mam used to read bits out when we were kids. I’d copy the words, pretend I knew what I was doing.” His thumb brushed the spine. “Haven’t seen this one in years.” Something in her face shifted. “She’s from here?” she asked. “Anglesey. Long way from your dragon with glasses.” He glanced at her. “You’re local, yeah? You said ‘Aberfelen’ like you believed in it.” “I run its only bookshop. That’s practically mayor.” He smiled. “Well, Madam Mayor, could I beg asylum for ten minutes? I swear I won’t autograph anything I haven’t paid for.” “You’re right,” she said. “You should probably hide. Before they start licking the windows.” He winced. “They’ve done that.” She pointed towards a narrow aisle. “Back corner. Behind the gardening. They never go there. Apparently photographs of hoes are less lucrative.” He choked out a surprised laugh, the sound too loud in the cozy space. “Carys, you’re—” He stopped himself. The line had been: you’re funny, you’re sharp, you’re not like the others, something from the arsenal. But under her steady look, it felt cheap. “I’m trying to work,” she said, but her mouth twitched. “Right. Working. Of course.” He retreated, then called, “If anyone asks, tell them you saw me running towards the estuary, dramatically, in slow motion.” “That what you do? Run in slow motion for a living?” “That and brood,” he said. “I’m very expensive at brooding.” She heard him move among the shelves, muttering appreciatively at odd titles. The rain drummed harder. The shapes outside re-formed, uncertain, some peeling off down the street. After a minute, she drifted towards the back, under pretext of rearranging local history. Rhys stood in the gardening aisle, staring, incongruously intent, at a shelf of bird guides. “You look busy,” she said. He jumped. “Christ. You’re quiet.” “It’s the soles,” she said. “Not a gift from costume.” He pointed at a spine. “You’ve got the RSPB migratory atlas. In a village shop.” “People here look up sometimes,” she said. “Sky’s free. Why, do you?” He hesitated, then shrugged, but it came out shy. “Birds are… good background actors,” he said. “I like knowing who’s heckling me.” She considered him. “…You’re into birdwatching.” “‘Into’ is a strong word,” he said too fast. “I may possess binoculars. Of my own. And a notebook. With columns.” She grinned before she could stop herself. “Columns.” “Don’t,” he said, but he was laughing. “You can’t laugh. It’s very serious. Mixed flocks. Plumage differences. Danger everywhere.” “Rhys Lyn, action hero and secret twitcher,” she said. “That’s not in the biographies.” “I keep some things for myself.” He tilted his head, wary. “You? You sound like you know the atlas isn’t for décor.” “I do the BTO counts,” she said, trying for casual. “Coastal. Winter waders.” His eyes lit up, unexpectedly bright. “No. You’re joking. Here?” “Where else?” “That saltmarsh by the old slate quay,” he said, quick. “We drove past. I saw a curlew. Nearly wept. Driver thought I’d lost it.” She blinked. “You can ID curlews from a car.” “The beaks are a clue,” he said. “And the melancholy. They look like they’ve read the reviews.” A laugh escaped her, real and delighted, and his expression faltered for a second, as if he’d surprised himself. “That,” he said quietly, “is a good sound.” She busied herself straightening a stack of field guides. “You’re less annoying when you’re talking about birds.” “I’m devastatingly likable when I’m talking about birds,” he corrected. “Besides, you should have seen me at twelve, doing impressions of lapwings. Won a school talent show. That’s where it all went wrong.” “Tragic origin story,” she said. “From lapwings to Lycra.” He grinned, pleased. “You do know who I am, then.” “I live on the internet occasionally,” she said. “And my cousin dragged me to see you punch an asteroid once.” “And? Did we save the world adequately for you, Carys?” “You were fine.” She moved past him to a lower shelf. “The asteroid had more depth.” He clutched the bird atlas theatrically to his chest. “You’re brutal. I like you.” “You like everyone to like you,” she said, without looking up. The words hung there. A flush crept up his neck. “That’s…” He tried on a smile; it didn’t quite fit. “Wow. Straight in.” “Heroes are predictable,” she said lightly. “I’m not—” He stopped. “Look, I don’t— It’s not…” He exhaled, deflated. “Alright. Maybe I do prefer when people don’t actively loathe me. Shocking revelation.” “I didn’t say I loathed you,” she said softly. He watched her for a beat. “No,” he said. “You’re just… immune.” “Don’t take it personally.” “I’m terrible at not taking things personally.” “That sounds exhausting.” “It is.” He met her eyes. The charm dropped, like a cloak shrugged off. Underneath, he looked younger, and tired. “But. I do genuinely care if you like me. Which is inconvenient, as you are currently rating me below a rock in space.” She swallowed. “I said the asteroid had depth, not… charisma.” His mouth tugged at one corner. “Oh, so I’ve got charisma.” “Tragically, yes,” she muttered, too quick. He stilled. “Tragically?” he echoed, low, something sparking. “Tragically for my concentration,” she said. “I’m trying to work and now there’s a global celebrity cataloguing waders in aisle four.” “I knew it,” he crowed, delighted, charm returning but warmer now. “You are charmed.” “Moderately,” she said, cheeks hot. “It’s an occupational hazard. I like people who know curlews exist.” “I’ll take moderately,” he said. “It’s better than Space Rock with Feelings.” A tap at the front window echoed down the aisles. Both of them went still. “They’re thinning,” Carys said after a second. “Rain’s winning.” “Rain always wins,” he said. “That’s why I keep coming back here. Nobody recognizes you under a hood in Barmouth.” “You could wear a hood here,” she pointed out. “True,” he said, but his eyes were on her. “But then I wouldn’t have met the terrifying BTO volunteer who refuses to be impressed.” She rolled her eyes. “I didn’t refuse. I’m just… cautious.” “Of actors?” “Of people who live on giant posters.” He laughed, soft. “Fair.” He glanced at the bird atlas again, then back at her. There was a question in his gaze now, tentative. “If I were to, hypothetically, come back when I’m not being hunted,” he said, “would you recommend anything? Bird-wise. Or book-wise. Or coffee-wise.” “We don’t do coffee,” she said. “Tea, if you don’t mind rogue kettles.” “I’m Welsh,” he said. “I’m built on rogue kettles.” She hesitated. “We’ve got a hide near the estuary. Locals use it,” she said. “Gulls, knots, the occasional lost film star.” He smiled slowly. “Is that an invitation, Carys?” “It’s information,” she said, but her voice had gone a shade softer. “Bird counts on Sunday mornings. Seven sharp. Miserable weather preferred.” “I’m excellent at miserable,” he said. “You might’ve noticed.” “I’ve seen the brooding,” she allowed. He stepped past her, close enough that she caught rain and cologne and something sharper, then paused by the counter. Outside, the last of the lenses pointed elsewhere. “Thank you,” he said. The flippancy was gone. “For not selling me out. And for insulting me accurately.” “You’re welcome,” she said. “Try not to get run over by your fan club.” He reached into his pocket, pulled out a receipt crumpled from some other shop, and a pen. “No autographs,” she warned. “It’s my number,” he said, scribbling. “In case you need help identifying a suspiciously handsome heron.” “I know what a heron looks like.” “Humor me,” he said, tearing it off and sliding it onto the counter. She looked at it, then at him. “If this is a charm offensive—” “It was,” he said. “Now it’s just… I’d like you to call. Or text. Or send a carrier curlew. Whatever’s least offensive.” She hesitated, then took the paper, folding it once. “Maybe,” she said. He grinned, dazzling and oddly boyish. “I’ll take maybe.” He pulled up his hood. “See you Sunday, Carys.” “You don’t know I’ll be there.” He opened the door. The rain reached for him. “You’re always there,” he said. “You’re the mayor.” The bell jangled again, and he was gone, swallowed by grey and gulls and the distant flash of cameras, leaving the shop suddenly, inexplicably brighter. Carys looked down at the folded scrap in her hand, then over at the bird atlas. “Tragic,” she murmured, feeling the smile she hadn’t meant to let through. She flipped the sign back to OPEN.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and good adherence to the prompt requirements. The Welsh setting is established effectively through place names (Aberfelen, Anglesey, Barmouth) and cultural references, while the bookstore environment feels authentic and lived-in. The core premise of a celebrity hiding from paparazzi works well as a meet-cute setup. The characterization is notably well-developed for such a short piece. Rhys exhibits the requested "rogue with fragile ego" qualities convincingly - his charm offensive is palpable, but so is his vulnerability when it doesn't work on Carys. The revelation of his genuine interest in birdwatching provides an effective character depth beyond the surface charm. Carys maintains consistent skepticism toward his celebrity while being inwardly affected, creating the requested dynamic of surface immunity masking attraction. The dialogue carries the story effectively and feels natural throughout. Both characters have distinct voices - Rhys's theatrical, slightly desperate charm versus Carys's dry, grounded wit. Their exchanges about birds, books, and his celebrity status feel organic rather than forced. The banter has genuine spark and the shift from performative charm to authentic connection is well-managed. The Welsh cultural elements are woven in naturally rather than feeling token - the Gwynfor edition of The Odyssey, the BTO bird counts, and the landscape references all contribute to authentic sense of place. The shared interest in birdwatching serves as an effective bridge between their worlds. The pacing works well, moving from initial suspicion through tentative connection to genuine interest.
