+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
1 March 1987 Lyness Lighthouse, Hoy Sound Orkney Mum, Made it. The boat lad soaked me right through hauling my trunk, then laughed when I asked how often supplies make it over in winter. “When they can,” he said, which is another way of saying “Not enough.” It’s an ugly wee tower, ours. White paint coming off like sunburnt skin. The lamp room is sound, though. I’ve a narrow bunk under the stairs, a stove that sulks, and a radio that only likes BBC if I stand touching the aerial. It’s quiet. That’s a lie: it’s loud with sea, but quiet of folk. Feels like I’ve fallen off the edge of the map. I start proper tonight. Don’t fuss. I’m fine. Love, Robbie 5 March 1987 Greenock Son, You write like you’re sending a postcard, not moved your entire life north. Are there other men? What do you eat? That stove better “sulk” its way hot enough, or I’ll be on the next train to smack sense into the shipping office. You say “ours.” Are you proud of it already or trying to talk your way into it? Don’t pretend with me. I know the tone you use when you don’t want me worrying. You had it when your da’ didn’t come home. Write more. Mum 18 March 1987 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, There are three of us on the rota. Me, McKinnon, and old Alec. Two on, one off, but the other two are in Kirkwall this month while they patch the cottages. A storm took half a roof in January. So just me till they’re done, three weeks they said. It’s not legal, I hear you say. It’s flexible. Anyway, the local ferries keep an eye. There’s a wireless. Food’s fine. Tins. Oats. Spuds. Got a ham the size of your temper at Hogmanay. The lamp’s a hungry beast: oil, wicks, glass, gears. Everything wants cleaned and wound and checked. It’s work I can see when it’s done. That helps. Proud? Aye. Feels honest. Boats look for this light. They trust I’m not sleeping. I like that. Don’t talk about Da’. Love, R 22 March 1987 Greenock Robbie, Boats trust you. I trust you. That doesn’t mean everyone else deserves your clever hands as cheap as they get them. I will write the Board about leaving you alone out there. I might sign it “concerned parish” to sound scarier. Have you met any locals? Or are you sulking like the stove? I won’t mention your da’ if you don’t hide behind jokes with me. Keep the light steady. Mum 3 April 1987 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, If you write the Board, make sure you spell my name right so they ken who the troublemaker belongs to. Locals: there’s a fisherman, Euan, who brings mail when the weather’s civil and asks if I’ve “seen ghosts yet” and then waits too long for my answer. Told him the only ghost here is a mother who can hear when I skip meals. He laughed. Had my first real blow last night. Wind like it wanted the stones down. The lamp stuttered once when the mechanism jammed. I had half the housing apart with the glass screaming in the gusts. Fixed it. Hands shaking all to hell after. Thought of you looking out our tenement window when I was late from shifts at the yard. Felt the same: someone trusting a light I hadn’t lit yet. That’s the hardship, if you need a tidy line for it. Knowing that if I slip, if I get tired or lazy or just human, someone else pays for it in the dark. It’s a wee weight. I’m all right with it. Mostly. Love, R 17 April 1987 Greenock Son, That’s not a “wee” weight. That’s a boulder you’ve named and made tea for. Eat, sleep, wind your gears. I’ve written the Board. I spelled everything right, including the words “negligent” and “not amused.” Send a shopping list for when your month’s up. Unless you’re eloping with this ham. Mum 2 May 1987 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Ham’s finished. If it was an elopement, it was short and greasy. Repairs delayed. Kirkwall boys caught up with another job. I’ve another fortnight solo, at least. The Board sent a telegram saying they “appreciate my flexibility.” They can appreciate it with a bonus, but I’m no’ holding my breath. Had a funny thing two nights ago. Foghorn blowing, cloud so thick even the lamp looked lost in it. Radio crackled all night, voices in snatches, none clear enough to call. Kept me wired. I caught myself talking back. To nobody. Don’t look like that; I can hear your eyebrows. I’ve started keeping a proper log, even for my own thoughts. “2200 hours: thought I heard Da’ clear his throat in the stairwell. 2201 hours: no sign of Da’, assume draught.” Turns the ghosts into ink. Makes them smaller. Love, R 5 May 1987 Greenock Robbie, If you start hearing your da’ offering advice, ignore it unless it’s about knotwork. They extended you alone and didn’t send another man? I’ll write again. This time I’ll underline. There’s a vacancy back at the Inverclyde yard. Your old union pal mentioned it. You could come home, work a crane instead of wrestling the North Sea. You don’t have to prove anything up there. Mum 12 May 1987 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, If I come home every time something’s hard, I’ll spend my life on our couch watching quiz shows with you, which is your dream, not mine. I like the work. And I like being good at something no-one sees unless it’s gone wrong. Last night I watched a cargo ship slide by, just the shape of it, lights low. She dipped her horn. They dinnae do that for everyone. Storm season will ease. Then the others join. It’s just a bad start, that’s all. Don’t worry. Love, R 20 September 1987 Greenock Son, Don’t worry, he says, after four months with barely a postcard. You went quiet. I pictured you blown off the stairs mid-cuppa. Are there men with you now? Are you eating, you skeleton? Mum 23 September 1987 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Sorry. Summer went in a blink. There was fog for a week straight in July. Felt like living inside a lung. We’re fully crewed now. McKinnon swears like a poet and cooks like a saint. Alec cheats at cards. It’s almost busy. I drink too much tea. Still thin. Not a skeleton, more “economy model.” Had my first rescue, if you can call it that. Wee motorboat lost her bearings, choked engines. I flagged Euan by lamp and mirror; we went out and hauled them in like stray cats. They were tourists. The man offered me money. I said I’m already paid, which made him laugh louder than it deserved. Felt good, though. Like the job’s not pretend. I kept the letter from the yard vacany. I’m not saying never. But not yet. Love, R 31 December 1987 Greenock Robbie, They’re doing fireworks outside; I’m pretending they’re for you. I’m proud you pulled those folk in. Don’t get too pleased with yourself. One rescue and suddenly you’re Poseidon with a union card. Come home for a visit before the year gets too old. I’ve made tablet. Mum 8 January 1988 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, I’ll aim for February shore leave. If I don’t, send the tablet north; we’ll call it a morale operation. Nothing big to report. That’s how I like it. Love, R 14 February 1988 Greenock Son, You “aimed” for shore leave and missed. Again. I know you swapped shifts so Alec could get to his granddaughter’s birthday. Don’t deny it. He wrote a thank you on a postcard with a puffin, like an assassin leaving evidence. You’re a good man. Try extending the same care to yourself. Mum 1 March 1988 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Your birthday letter, late as usual. Happy 55th, even if you’ll say you’re 49 until the grave. You’d have liked yesterday’s storm, looking at it from behind glass. Proper brute. Took the radio out for four hours. Waves over the lantern gallery. I was out tying down the fuel shed door when a gust near took me. I got the rope on but felt something go in my shoulder. Bruise like a map of Skye. Here’s the stupid bit: for a moment, flat on my back on the wet slab, I thought, “If I just stay down, no one would know.” The sea loud as a train, the whole tower shuddering, and me negotiating with myself about standing up. I did. For the record. But that wanting-to-stay-down feeling… that’s new. Don’t panic. I’m tellin you, so it’s in the log. Love, R 5 March 1988 Greenock Robbie, I won’t panic if you don’t dramatise it like a library book. New feeling or not, you get that shoulder seen to. And you tell McKinnon and Alec you nearly went over. If you keep scares to yourself, they stay big. I’m glad you wrote it. Not glad you felt it. Don’t romanticise lying down in storms. That’s for heroes in daft films. You are not allowed. You can come home, you know. “Not yet” is starting to sound like “never.” Mum 12 March 1988 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Doctor came on the supply boat. Shoulder’s just strained. I’m to “lift like an old man” for a fortnight. Told Alec about nearly going over. He nodded like he’d been waiting. Said, “Tower gets inside your head if you let it.” His solution is card games and yelling at the radio. The wanting-to-stay-down thing… it’s less about dying, more about stopping. Stopping the watching, the winding, the being the last wee line between rock and hull. Some nights it feels like I’ve got my hands up holding the sky. You saying I romanticise it makes me laugh. There’s nothing romantic about damp socks. I’m not done yet. But I heard your “you can come home” louder this time. Love, R 30 November 1988 Greenock Son, Long gap again. At least this time Alec phoned from Kirkwall to say you’re alive and “brooding like a wet gull.” I got a letter from the Board. Your station’s going automatic late next year. Is that true? What does that mean for you? Mum 5 December 1988 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Aye. True. We had the briefing. They’ll fit sensors and remote controls. “Unmanned operation,” they call it. Like we’ve just been mannequins with mugs. They offered redeployment “subject to vacancies.” Yard work, buoys, maintenance crews. It should feel like escape. Instead it feels like being told I was temporary in a place I’d started to think needed me. Challenge enough for you? Being turned into spare parts. Don’t worry. Practical bits are fine. I’ve skills. And you’ve always fancied me back under your feet. Love, R 10 December 1988 Greenock Robbie, You are not spare parts. They’re wrong if they think nobody’ll notice the light’s kept by wires instead of hands. I am, however, delighted by any excuse that gets you on a bus south. I’ve already told Mrs. Boyd you’ll fix her leaky tap. She cried. Prepare yourself. Let yourself be sad about it. Don’t turn it into a joke straight away. (Look at me, the hypocrite.) Mum 1 August 1989 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, They’ve started fitting the new kit. Young engineers full of computers and certainty. McKinnon grumbles they’re stealing the romance. I tell him there was no romance climbing icy stairs to unblock a vent. Had a bad week in June. Weather clear, mind foggy. Forgot to eat. Forgot what day. Caught myself staring at the lens turning and feeling nothing. Went down to the rocks and scared myself with how easy it’d be to keep walking. I stopped. Sat instead. Counted waves till my head came back. I’m telling you this because I want a record of all the times I did not do the stupid thing. It makes it further away. I’ve put my name in for a shore-based job in Greenock. Maintenance at the depot. Don’t redecorate my old room yet. I might hate it. Love, R 6 August 1989 Greenock Son, I’m glad you sat. I’m twice glad you told me. I will not wrap you in bubble wrap when you get here, but I reserve the right to overfeed you. They’ve all heard about “my boy at the light” for years. You coming home will be hell for your ego and free biscuits for life. Whether you stay or go again, I want you choosing from a full deck in your head, not from the edge of a rock. Mum 30 November 1989 Lyness Lighthouse Mum, Last entry from up here. Automation test successful. Tomorrow they shut her to us for good. They had us standing outside while a man in a yellow jacket pressed a wee button and the lamp came on like a trick. Alec cried, actually cried, old bastard. McKinnon muttered about “trusting a blinking toaster with lives.” I stood there wanting to pat the wall. Tonight they gave me the last watch. “For sentiment,” the supervisor said like it was a dirty word. So it’s just me and the lamp, like the first nights, and the sea sounding exactly the same as it did before computers. Here’s the hardship I never told the Board: it wasn’t just the storms. It was the small hours when nothing happened at all, and still you had to believe your being here mattered. That someone out there was using a light they never saw the keeper behind. That the ache in your bones bought them an unremarkable passing. I think that’s why I’m crying now that nobody’s looking. Not because it was too much, but because it was finally exactly enough to make sense of myself. I’ll be on the Tuesday ferry. Keep the key under the pot. Pretend to be surprised. Love, Robbie 4 December 1989 Greenock Robbie, I cleaned your room and immediately made it a mess again so you’d feel at home. I am proud of you. For going. For staying. For knowing when to come back. For writing every time it hurt. Your light did its job. So did theirs. So did mine. Get home safe. I’ll leave the stair light on. Mum
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements, presenting a compelling correspondence between Robbie, a Scottish lighthouse keeper, and his mother spanning nearly three years. The story demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining consistent quality throughout. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Robbie's voice feels authentically working-class Scottish without relying on excessive dialect or stereotype. His evolution from defensive brevity in early letters to more vulnerable openness creates a believable character arc. The mother's voice is equally distinct - protective, practical, and emotionally intelligent, using humor to deflect her own worry while still providing genuine support. Both characters feel fully realized rather than serving merely functional roles. The narrative structure builds effectively toward its emotional climax. The progression from initial isolation through growing competence, deepening psychological struggle, and eventual acceptance of change feels organic. The automation subplot provides external pressure that catalyzes Robbie's internal journey, avoiding the trap of purely introspective naval-gazing. The prose maintains an elegant restraint throughout. Phrases like "wind like it wanted the stones down" and "living inside a lung" during fog demonstrate strong imagery without overwriting. The author shows particular skill in conveying the lighthouse work's physical and psychological demands through specific details rather than abstract statements. However, some elements feel slightly predictable. The arc from isolation to breakdown to recovery follows familiar patterns, and certain moments (the near-accident, the automation announcement) arrive with expected timing. The resolution, while earned, doesn't offer particular surprise or insight beyond the competent execution of the expected trajectory. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - neither falsely optimistic nor unnecessarily bleak. Robbie's decision to return home feels genuinely motivated by his experiences rather than imposed by plot convenience. His final reflection on the work's meaning demonstrates psychological growth that has been building throughout the correspondence. The technical execution is strong. The letters feel authentic to their time period and circumstances, the voices remain consistent, and the pacing allows for both plot development and character exploration. The writing avoids common pitfalls of forced sentiment or overwrought drama. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 85.5
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I notice her before I notice the vulnerabilities. That’s new. I’m nine minutes early, already seated—habit—and I’ve done the perimeter sweep: visible cameras (three, one fake), back exit (blocked by a recycling bin, tsk), point-of-sale tablets (outdated, unpatched Android 8, yikes), the unsecured staff Wi‑Fi SSID, and the QR-code menus—one of which is clearly misaligned and could easily be replaced with a malicious sticker. I catalogue them without trying to. Reflex. Then she walks in. Green hair, Planeswalker symbol hoodie, slight hesitation like she’s about to roll for initiative before committing to the room. I recognize her from her profile picture, plus a ten percent bonus charisma in person. She spots me, smiles, and the scan stutters. Focus. Human connection. Don’t lead with “the bathrooms’ smart locks are vulnerable to replay attacks.” “Hey,” she says. “Hey,” I reply, and it doesn’t sound broken, so we’re off to a decent start. She sits. No obvious tells of immediate regret. Good. I put my phone face down, silent, a symbolic firewall between me and my comfort zone. She does the same, though her phone lights briefly—Android, custom case with a foil Jace. My brain registers possible attack surface area, then I shove that thought into quarantine. “So, you actually picked this place,” she says. “I’ve only been here once. Good fries. Weird bathroom.” Weird bathroom. God, marry me. We talk casual first: work, commute, the usual sanitized disclosure. She asks about my job. I say “security consulting,” and leave out the part where I used to be the reason companies hire people like me. “And you?” I ask. “Front-end dev,” she says. “I make things pretty. You make things safe. We’re like… the UX and AV of the internet.” “AV sounds like antivirus,” I say. “I was thinking audiovisual, but sure. We can be antivirus.” If you only knew. The server drops water. She thanks them by name, reading from their badge. Good social engineering instinct. I catalog the thought and hate myself a little. Then it happens. “You play Magic, right?” she asks. This is the pivot. Her profile had one blurry card image. I’d hoped it wasn’t just a prop. “Yeah,” I say, trying not to sound like I’ve been waiting all week. “Mostly modern. Bit of Commander. You?” Her eyes light up. “Commander. And cube sometimes. I’ve got a stupid Gisela voltron deck I’m too attached to.” Gisela, Blade of Goldnight. Aggro, combat-focused, doubles damage, prevents your damage. Signal: she likes skewing math in her favor, warping the rules, winning through pressure and resilience. Notes: favors straightforward dominance with a side of splashy inevitability. Attractive. “What else?” I ask. She takes a sip of water, thinks. “Let’s see. Kess, Dissident Mage storm list that everyone hates. A Muldrotha pile that’s basically a second graveyard. And I’ve been brewing Isshin go-wide because apparently I hate having friends.” Kess. Muldrotha. Isshin. I feel the familiar sorting process spin up in the background: - Kess: recursion, efficiency, spell-based value loops. She likes lines, sequences, mental flowcharts. - Muldrotha: resource recycling, inevitability, grinding people out. She’ll sit in the long game and not flinch. - Isshin: leveraging the attack step, multiplying triggers, overwhelming the board. Entropy disguised as enthusiasm. She’s a synergy player with a mean streak. Precise, recursive, comfortable with complexity. My people. “No blue/white control?” I tease. She makes a face. “I play to have fun, not to become the villain in everyone’s origin story.” I laugh. “Good. Azorius is how I know someone can’t be trusted.” “You say, working in security,” she counters. “Reformed,” I say. “I help lock the doors now.” And there it is. Not a lie, but not the whole log history. She taps the table. “Okay, reformed how?” I give her the safe version. Teenager with too much time, some low-level mischief, realized companies will actually pay you to break their stuff on purpose. The legal stuff, with paperwork, scopes, contracts. Bug bounties, red-team gigs, threat modeling. I skip over the time I owned an entire regional ISP’s billing system because their password was literally “Password1” and the ethics came after. She listens, head tilted. No immediate recoil. “So you’re like… a professional paranoid.” “Professional cautious optimist,” I say. “I think systems can be better. I just can’t stop seeing how they fail.” “Must be exhausting.” “It is,” I say, and I’m surprised by how easily that comes out. Our food order goes in. She gets a burger medium with extra pickles. I get a grain bowl because my cardiologist—and by cardiologist I mean the one friend who survived our twenties—made me promise. We talk about pre-bans, metas, which Commander precon had the best value. “Remember when they first printed Dockside Extortionist?” she says. “Format-warping on arrival,” I reply. “Red finally got to be disgusting.” She laughs. “My Kess deck runs Dockside loops. Of course.” Of course: efficient combo lines, ruthlessly exploiting under-costed effects. She sees the gaps and squeezes through. Of course I like her. I’m present, more than usual. I notice how she gestures when she talks about stack interactions, using her hands to layer invisible cards in the air. The way she mentally goldfishes a line mid-sentence, lips pressing together, eyes unfocusing for a half-second. She’s modeling the game state. Familiar. For a while I forget to threat-model the restaurant. Then her phone buzzes. She glances at it. “Sorry. One sec. Roommate.” She picks it up, screen facing me for a moment. My brain does what my brain does. Nine-dot Android unlock pattern. Grease smears, faint but legible at this angle under the overhead lighting. Starts bottom left, drags up, over, down. Classic “Z” with a tail. At most eight nodes. Muscle memory of a thousand CTFs wants to grab a napkin and sketch it out. The success probability spikes in my mind: 85% on first try. Stop. Look away. I look back too late. She’s tapping it in and my mouth is already moving. “Oh,” I say. “You might wanna change that pattern. It’s super easy to shoulder-surf.” Her thumb pauses mid-air. Idiot. Her gaze flicks up to me, surprised. “Excuse me?” Abort. Or salvage. Don’t double down. Do not recite NIST guidelines at her. I raise my hands slightly. “Sorry, that came out… wow, that came out wrong. Force of habit. I, uh, security brain. I notice stuff.” She narrows her eyes. Not hostile yet. Assessing. “You just saw my unlock pattern?” “I saw enough to guess it,” I say, because my mouth hates me. “I swear I’m not—” I almost say “I’m not going to use it,” which would be the worst possible sentence. “—I’m not trying to snoop. It’s just, patterns like that, you can reconstruct them from smudge traces. It’s a known thing.” Known thing. Great, now I’m a PSA poster. She sets the phone down slowly, screen dark, like containing a spill. “So you were… watching my hand?” “Yes. No. Not like that.” Good. Perfect. Sound more creepy. “I was looking generally, and my brain auto-completed the pattern. That’s… what I used to get paid to do. Still do. Find weak points.” She’s quiet. The air shifts. The conversation stack gains a priority trigger: “Are you safe to be around?” on the stack, waiting to resolve. I feel the old defensive scripts start to load. I could pivot: joke, deflect, minimize. Or I can do what I allegedly came here to do: be honest enough to earn trust, if not forgiveness. “I’m sorry,” I say. Simple. “I know that’s invasive. I am trying really hard to keep it in check. I don’t want to be that person on a date.” She studies me. I can see her running her own evaluation: threat level, sincerity score, historical logs from my earlier self-description. Kess lines in her brain: if X then Y, if Y then concede. “That’s exactly the kinda thing a creep would say,” she says finally. “Yep,” I say. “Unfortunately for me, it’s also the kind of thing that’s true.” She snorts. A tiny crack in the defense. “So what, you notice everyone’s passwords?” “No. Almost never. I try not to. It’s like… once you’ve trained your brain to see patterns, you can’t completely unsee them. I pick up on the obvious stuff. The low-hanging fruit. Same way you probably can’t look at a website without noticing all the bad CSS.” She grimaces. “Okay, that’s fair.” “If it helps,” I add, “I report this stuff for a living. Responsibly. Legally. I don’t weaponize it in personal life. That’s my line. And I’m breaking another line by even bringing this up right now, so I will drop it unless you want practical advice.” She looks down at the phone, then back at me. “So how bad is it?” “Honestly?” I say. “If someone got your phone for thirty seconds with good lighting, they’d almost certainly get in. That’s true for a lot of patterns. It’s not about you. It’s about how humans are predictable.” “And you’re… less predictable?” she says. Oh, no. Far from it. “I’m predictable in different ways,” I say. “You put a weak system in front of me, I’ll see the path into it. It’s the same part of my brain that loves figuring out how to chain a Jeska’s Will into Underworld Breach into Brain Freeze into ‘oops, I win.’” Her eyebrows lift incrementally at the reference. “You play Breach in Kess?” “Sometimes,” I say. “Graveyard is just extended hand, right?” She smirks despite herself. “Okay, points.” That’s a good sign. Or a trap. Or both. The food arrives, mercifully interrupting the cross-examination. Fries. Grain bowl. She picks one fry off her plate and points it at me like a wand. “So, Mister Security,” she says. “Since you’ve already ruined my sense of safety, what should I use instead of my cute little pattern?” “I can shut up,” I say. “That’s one option.” “I asked,” she says. Consent acquired. That’s different. “All right,” I say. “Short version: six-digit PIN at minimum. Longer if you can tolerate it. Or biometric plus strong fallback. Disable lock-screen notifications. Honestly, it’s less about hackers in hoodies and more about ‘phone gets stolen off a bar table.’” “Reasonable,” she says. “And you swear you’re not memorizing my stuff.” “I am aggressively uninterested in your private data,” I say. “I like the part of you voluntarily sitting here.” Her ears go a little pink. “Okay, that was smooth.” It was, and I didn’t even fuzz the output. We eat. Between bites and sips, the tension dissipates. Not fully, but enough. She tells a story about a guy at FNM who tried to rules-lawyer her out of a legal line; she responded by going infinite with Deadeye Navigator and made him sit through every loop. She loved having that leverage. She loved executing it cleanly. Control tendencies, expressed through combos, not counters. She values agency, hates being underestimated. Important. I talk about a client who insisted their system was unbreakable until my team popped admin with a phishing email about free pizza. I truncate the ugly parts. Emphasize the lesson: humans are always the easiest in-road, which is why being gentle matters. She sighs. “So we’re all just soft targets.” “We’re all running unpatched firmware,” I say. “But that doesn’t mean we don’t try.” She looks at me for a long second, something evaluating, something almost soft. “Okay,” she says. “I will change my lock later. Out of spite.” “Spite security is still security,” I say. She laughs again. Less guarded. As the plates clear, I catch myself scanning the room again—card skimmers potential on the portable terminal, visibility line from the front door, couple behind me talking too loudly about their banking app passwords—and I consciously pull focus back to her. Human connection. Stay. “So,” she says. “Second date condition.” Oh. “Condition?” I ask. “If we end up playing Commander,” she says, “you’re not allowed to rules-splain or security-splain unless I ask. And you have to bring a deck that doesn’t try to win on turn three.” Reasonable constraints. Strict, but with clear boundaries. Like a well-written engagement scope. “I can agree to that,” I say. “Can I bring a deck that threatens to win on turn four?” She pretends to consider. “Only if you promise not to guess my new PIN.” I meet her eyes. “I won’t look.” For once, I mean it as more than a joke. For once, the exploit path is obvious and I enjoy not taking it. “Then maybe,” she says, “we can keep talking.” The attacker in my brain notes the new access vector: trust, tentative and revocable. The reformed part of me looks at it, tags it “do not exploit,” and hopes my better processes hold. I reach for my water instead of my phone. “Deal,” I say.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and creative vision in portraying a reformed hacker's mindset through the lens of a first date. The author successfully maintains the protagonist's analytical, pattern-recognizing voice throughout, seamlessly blending cybersecurity terminology with dating anxiety and Magic: The Gathering references. The characterization is particularly well-crafted. The protagonist's internal monologue feels authentic—simultaneously self-aware and compulsive, trying to reform but unable to fully suppress their analytical nature. The constant threat assessments and vulnerability scans happening in parallel with genuine human connection attempts create compelling internal tension. The date character is also well-developed, showing her own analytical tendencies through her Magic deck choices and her measured response to the protagonist's social breach. The Magic: The Gathering shared interest serves as more than mere color—it becomes a vehicle for character development, showing how both characters think systematically and strategically. The author demonstrates genuine knowledge of the game while using it to reveal personality traits and create authentic connection between the characters. The prose is generally elegant, with cybersecurity metaphors woven naturally throughout ("the conversation stack gains a priority trigger," "consent acquired"). The voice remains consistent—technical but not impenetrable, self-deprecating but not pathetic. The pacing builds tension effectively toward the phone pattern incident and handles the fallout believably. The emotional complexity is notable. The protagonist's struggle between their nature and their desire for connection feels genuine, and their mortification at their social blunder rings true. The ending strikes an appropriate note—cautiously optimistic without being unrealistically positive. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical metaphors feel slightly forced, and the resolution, while earned, comes perhaps a touch quickly after the tension of the phone incident. The piece also occasionally borders on being too clever with its terminology, though it generally stays on the right side of that line. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I know exactly how this is supposed to go. Option A: “Hey, Ethan, do you think we should divide the data tables and graphs, or just work through them together?” Casual. Efficient. Like I don’t care that his sleeve just brushed my notebook and my brain lit up like a Bunsen burner. Option B: “Cool hypothesis.” No. Too vague. And he’d ask, “Which part?” and I’d have to remember exact wording, and I’d go blank, and then my face would do that hot prickly thing and I’d look like I compliment people as a hobby instead of forming actual thoughts. Option C: Make a joke. Something MIT-level clever but disguised as normal. “If our enzyme lab fails, at least we’ll contribute qualitative data to human disappointment.” No, that’s too much. Also sounds like I spent lunch writing that line in my head, which I did not. Mostly. “Okay, guys, so… enzymes,” Mrs. Feldman says, clapping once. Our table: me, Ethan, loud Alex, and half-asleep Jenna. Random group draw that felt like rigged fate. Ethan’s pen is already uncapped. Of course. He’s the sort of person who does things like that without stabbing his fingers with ink. I look at the lab sheet. Then my own hand, already drawing a tiny circle in the corner. Circle with glasses and frizzy scribble-hair: me. Circle with tiny football and stupidly neat hair: Ethan. Circle with open mouth and jagged lines for volume: Alex. Circle with Z’s: Jenna. I make the Ethan circle’s eyes too big and now it looks like he’s surprised. Or terrified. Accurate. “We should start with the procedure,” Ethan says. His voice lands in my chest like someone dropping a science textbook. I nod. Say something. Option A. Say Option A. “Y-yeah,” I say, and the letter catches like it’s tripping out of my throat. Perfect. Wow. Iconic performance. “Cool,” he says, like I have not just failed basic speaking. “I can start reading, unless someone else wants to.” Say, “Go ahead.” That’s all. Two easy words. You know all the polysyllabic Greek and Latin roots but sure, let’s hesitate on “go ahead.” “G—yeah,” I say. I want to punch myself. Gyeah is not a word. Maybe it’s a German particle. Maybe he doesn’t notice. Everyone is gathering test tubes and pipettes, nobody cares. My pencil is moving again. Tiny Ethan-circle now has a test tube. He starts reading. His voice is steady, not too loud, not mumbling. It’s ridiculous how well-modulated he is. Probably doesn’t even know his decibel level. Meanwhile, I am thinking about my shoulders. Am I hunching? Sit up. But not soldier-straight; that’s weird. Casual straight. How do you casually spine. “Who wants to measure the substrate?” he asks. This is it. I am good at measuring. Numbers and volumes and watching the meniscus at eye level, more reliable than my vocal cords. “I can,” I say. It comes out almost normal. Yes. Okay. I reach for the graduated cylinder, knock a pencil off the table. It clatters. Of course. Gravity is my enemy. “Thanks,” Ethan says as I hand him the cylinder. Our fingers don’t touch; I am overly aware of this non-event. Option D materializes: “You’re good at organizing stuff.” Too complimentary. No. Option E: “Your handwriting is really neat.” No. That sounds like I’m staring at his notes. I am, but I’m not supposed to admit it. Alex is talking about how he “totally failed this last year but it’s chill” and Jenna is staring at the ceiling. Good. Less attention on me. My brain can beep quietly in the background. Enzymes. Lock-and-key model. I doodle a little key next to Ethan-circle, then panic and scribble it out. Too metaphorical. My subconscious is unsubtle. “So we’re supposed to do three trials for each concentration,” Ethan says. He’s leaning over the instructions, brow furrowed. It’s my favorite expression on him, which is such a weird favorite to have. Brow-furrow appreciation club, population: me. “You guys fine with splitting tasks?” he asks. “Like, someone timing, someone measuring, someone recording?” He’s looking at me now. Possible eye contact warning. Do not over-interpret. He’s not “looking into my soul,” he’s checking if I understand “three roles.” Calm down. “I can time,” I say. Too fast. Too eager. Desperate. Congratulations, you’ve volunteered like it’s the Hunger Games. “Okay, cool,” he says simply. He doesn’t think you’re desperate. People are allowed to have preferences. Breathe. I prep my phone’s stopwatch. My hand is only shaking a little. I tuck it under the table edge so no one sees. Alex is measuring substrate “kinda close” to the right line. It’s infuriating. My fingers itch to fix it, but if I say something I’ll sound controlling. Options: Option F: “Careful, it has to be exact.” But that’s bossy. Option G (revised): “Let’s try to get it at eye level, just so our results aren’t super off.” Slightly self-deprecating, includes us, not you. Yes. I lean in. “If we angle it a little… yeah, like that,” I say. “Nice catch,” Ethan says. He noticed. A microscopic sun flares in my chest. Absolutely chill, we are maintaining a calm and scholarly demeanor. Option H: “I just hate bad data.” Ugh. Psychopath. No. I settle for a tiny nod. Doodle Alex-circle pouring a crooked stream of liquid. Doodle Ethan-circle giving a thumbs-up. We run the first trial. I hit start on the timer. The solution clouds slowly. I call out, “Stop,” and my voice doesn’t crack. Good. Rational, professional. Alex writes the time. Too sloppy. No. Leave it. Stop. You’re not quality control for humanity. Ethan leans closer to the beaker, close enough that I can smell his shampoo. Citrus. Of course he smells like something clean and awake. I probably smell like pencil shavings and cortisol. He glances at my page. “Nice drawings,” he says. Oh God. Abort mission. He means the diagrams of enzymes, right? Not the circles. Not the tiny Ethan with the test tube. My hand slams down over that corner of the page like it’s a classified document. “They’re just—just silly,” I say, which is the worst possible defense. Just say “thanks,” normal people say “thanks.” He smiles, small and quick. “They’re cool.” Say thank you. You know this one. Two syllables. “Thanks,” I manage. That wasn’t so hard. Except for the part where my heart is punching my ribs like it’s trying to escape. He turns back to the beaker. I let my hand slide away from the corner, slowly, like the doodles might explode. I add little arrows to the enzyme sketch to make it look intentional. Label: “active site.” Label the circles? Absolutely not. I write “data” above them, pretending they’re part of some chart. Second trial. Third trial. We fall into a rhythm. There’s a moment where our hands move at the same time and almost bump, but don’t. My brain screenshots it anyway, high-resolution embarrassment potential for later. Option I, out of nowhere: “So, um, I like your shirt.” No. No I don’t. It’s just a gray hoodie. I mean, I do like it, but I like him in it which is a different, more pathetic thing. Complimenting a hoodie is basically confessing you’re in love. Jenna mutters, “I’m so tired,” and Ethan says, “Same,” and laughs softly, and I want to say “I stayed up reading about enzyme inhibitors last night” but that is social suicide. Instead I press my lips together and they probably look weird now. Relax them. Not that much. Now I’m half-smiling at nothing. Great. Serial killer face. “Temperature’s off,” Ethan says. “We should note that as a possible error.” “Yes,” I say, then add, “Good catch.” Too enthusiastic. Are you grading him. Tone it down. But he just writes it, nodding. Like I’m a normal lab partner. Like I exist in his mental file as “competent teammate,” not “malfunctioning crush robot.” We’re averaging data. Numbers feel safe. I can talk numbers. “If we drop the outlier from trial two, the average is 34.6,” I say. Full sentence. No stutter. Nice. “Yeah, that makes more sense,” he says, looking over. “You’re fast at that.” I shrug, instantly regretting the motion because what if it looked smug. “I just… like math,” I say quietly. He smiles again. “I don’t. So, useful combo.” Combo. As in, we complement each other. As in, mathematically compatible lab pairing. Stop it. He didn’t propose. I hatch another tiny Ethan-circle next to mine, both under a big rectangle labeled “Group 3.” That’s all it is. Scientifically accurate representation of members. Totally not hearts. (No hearts. Never hearts. Hearts are high-risk imagery.) Mrs. Feldman circles by. “Looking good, Group 3.” “Thanks,” Ethan says. Alex says something loud. I say nothing. Which is fine. One representative per group, that’s a thing. “If you finish, start working on the conclusion together,” she adds, moving on. Together. This is the part where people lean in, brainstorming, laughing at mistakes. My chest tightens. Words. You’re good at words, remember? Twelve-page stories, overachiever essays, vocab lists for fun. Say something. Ethan taps his pen. “So, like, our data mostly supports the hypothesis, right?” he says. “Yeah,” I say. Expand. Come on. “The reaction rate increased with substrate concentration until it plateaued, so that matches the saturation concept.” There. That’s what your brain sounds like. Look at that. “Exactly,” he says, and I watch the small nod he does when he agrees with something. File it away. I add, “We should mention possible errors. Like Alex almost spilling the peroxide.” Risky joke. I glance at Alex to make sure he’s not offended. He laughs. “Yo, I didn’t spill it.” “Almost,” I say, a little bolder. They laugh. Not at me. With me. My shoulders loosen half a centimeter. Ethan writes: “Sources of error included temperature variation and imprecise measurements.” “Harsh,” Alex says. “Accurate,” Ethan replies, grinning. I let myself smile for real, just a sliver. It’s okay. They’re joking. This is what people do. Say something not about enzymes. Something non-desperate. Option J: “Are you doing the science fair?” Too aggressive. Option K: “Do you like science?” That’s like asking if he likes oxygen, we’re literally in science class. “Do you, um… like labs better than lectures?” I ask. There. Neutral. About class. He thinks for half a second. “Yeah. I like doing stuff. Less chance of falling asleep.” I nod. “Same.” Say more. Ask what he likes. No, that’s interview-y. But if you don’t, the conversation dies. It’s on life support now. Quick. “What’s your favorite… subject?” I ask. He looks genuinely into the question. “Probably history. Or this. When it’s not just memorizing names of things.” “Oh,” I say, and my brain spins up a whole paragraph about conceptual understanding versus rote learning that I do not say. “Me too.” That’s all I manage. Pathetic. He nods. “You’re good at explaining it, though,” he says, gesturing at where I’d written example sentences in the margin. It’s like someone opened a window in my chest. “Thanks,” I say. It’s soft but clear. He didn’t have to say that. He noticed. He noticed something about me that isn’t my inability to form a chill sentence. The bell rings. Everyone explodes upward. Chairs scrape. Papers shuffle. “Good work, guys,” Ethan says, tucking his pen behind his ear. I watch the motion like an idiot. “Bye,” I say. One syllable, safe. Too direct? People say bye. It’s fine. He glances back as he’s walking away. “See you,” he says. I stand there for an extra second clutching my notebook, heart stupidly loud. See you. Not a marriage proposal. But not nothing. On the bus home, I’ll redraw the circles, neater this time. I’ll replay every microsecond: the gyeah, the joke, the almost-hand-touch. I’ll edit my lines in my head, compose better versions I’ll never say. Imagine a future lab where I make the enzyme-disappointment joke and he laughs for real. I close my notebook now, thumb resting over the little Ethan-circle so no one else can see. Option Z: Next time, just be normal. Sure. I’ll overthink that, too.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional adherence to the prompt, delivering a compelling first-person narrative that captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of an intelligent 8th-grader with social anxiety. The author masterfully constructs the internal monologue format, creating a vivid contrast between the protagonist's articulate inner voice and her stilted external communication. The characterization is remarkably nuanced and authentic. The protagonist's intelligence shines through her analytical approach to social interaction (organizing potential responses as "Options A, B, C") while her anxiety manifests in relentless self-monitoring and catastrophizing. Small details like drawing circles with tiny characteristics, the "gyeah" verbal stumble, and obsessing over whether her shrug looked smug all feel genuinely adolescent. The voice remains consistently authentic throughout - breathless, analytical, self-deprecating, and hypervigilant. The prose style mirrors the protagonist's racing thoughts with quick shifts, parenthetical asides, and fragmented observations that feel natural rather than forced. Phrases like "my brain lit up like a Bunsen burner" and "cortisol" show her scientific mindset while maintaining age-appropriate language. The emotional complexity is particularly strong. The piece captures the simultaneous joy and terror of proximity to a crush, the exhaustion of constant self-surveillance, and the small victories of successful social interaction. The ending strikes an appropriate note - neither artificially positive nor overwhelmingly dark, but realistic in acknowledging that change is gradual for someone with this level of social anxiety. The narrative maintains excellent coherence throughout the science lab setting, using the structured environment to provide natural conversation opportunities while highlighting the protagonist's internal chaos. The pacing feels authentic to both a class period and the experience of anxious rumination. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the internal voice might be slightly too sophisticated for an 8th-grader, though this is mitigated by the established high intelligence. The piece also walks a fine line with some metaphors that occasionally approach purple prose territory, though they generally serve the character voice well. The dialogue, while limited by design, feels authentic when it appears. The contrast between the protagonist's elaborate internal scripts and her actual simple responses ("G—yeah") effectively demonstrates her social anxiety. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I should cancel. I could cancel, say I’m sick, say I’m exhausted, say work ran late. That would be easier than waiting for you to not show up. Or to show up and be… different. Polite. Distant. Careful. Like I’m a stray dog you fed once and now regret. I stare at my phone like it’s your face. The last message sits there: “6:30 at your place still good? :)” The smiley looks real. It’s the exact one you use when you’re actually excited. Unless that’s what you send everyone. Unless you added it because you feel guilty and you’re trying extra hard to seem normal until you can fade out. My chest tightens. I check the time. Forty minutes. You’d cancel if you wanted to, right? You’d make an excuse. People who want out, they start soft. “Rain check?” “Crazy day.” “So tired.” You haven’t done that. You’ve been distant, yeah, replying slower, but there were reasons. Work, your sister visiting, that deadline. I hear your voice in my head: “I promise it’s not about you. I care about you. I’m just busy.” You said that last week, when I apologized for “being weird” and you tilted my chin up and kissed me and told me, “We’re okay, yeah?” You were so sure. The memory soothes for one second, then my brain twists it. Internal you shrugs, already bored: “I was just saying that to calm you down. You’re… a lot, you know? I can’t say that without you spiraling. See? Like now.” I flinch at the imagined accusation. “I’m not spiraling,” I snap back—but only in my head, because I’m alone in my apartment, pacing between the couch and the kitchen sink. Muffled television dialogue seeps through the neighbor’s wall. A laugh track, too loud, canned happiness. Scraps of sentences: “…can’t believe you…” “…such a mess…” My ears catch that one and my stomach drops like it was meant for me. I replay our last night together. You here on this couch, your knee against mine, your fingers tracing circles on the back of my hand. You telling me about your boss, rolling your eyes. Me leaning into you, trying to slow my breathing so it wouldn’t seem like your casual touch was the only thing holding me together. You kissed me goodnight at the door, steady, unhurried, pressed your forehead to mine and said, “Text me when you wake up. I like those.” Like those. Present tense. I woke up at 5 a.m., panicked and wired, wrote three drafts of a good-morning text before sending the smallest one. You replied with a selfie in your car, hair a mess, grinning, “Barely alive, send coffee.” My heart had exploded with relief then. See? See, they like me. Now my brain whispers: Or they liked the version of you from that night. You were cute then. Not like this. This is clingy. Controlling. Sick. “I’m fine,” I say out loud, to the empty room. “I’m normal. This is normal.” I check the time again. Thirty-four minutes. My mind leaps ahead to tonight, staging it like a play. You: “Hey.” (Too soft. No hug. Already halfway turned away.) Me: “Hey!” (Too bright, too eager, obviously compensating.) You: “So, uh, how’ve you been?” (Neutral. Already regretting coming.) I see myself reading into the angle of your body, the delay before you kiss me hello, the weight of it. If it’s light, it means you’re over it. If it’s heavy, it means guilt. If it’s exactly the same, that means you’re masking, which is also bad. I picture you sitting at the table with your hands around a mug of tea, eyes flicking to the door like you’d rather be anywhere else. Saying, “We need to talk.” No, that’s too obvious. You’d be kind. You’d wrap the knife in cotton. New scene: You, carefully: “I really like you, but I think we rushed things. I need some space. It’s just where I’m at.” Me, voice catching: “Sure, yeah, of course, totally, I get it. No worries. I’m happy for you.” You: “Happy for me?” Me: “For your… space.” You: (tiny pity smile) “You’re amazing, okay? Don’t think this means something’s wrong with you.” Me: “Of course not.” (Already cataloguing every wrong thing.) And then later I’d scream into my pillow, call you a liar, tell myself you used me, that you’re a coward. I’d make you a villain so I didn’t have to see what is obviously fatal in me. I feel the resentment start early, preemptive, like armor. If you hurt me tonight, I’ll say I saw it coming. I’ll say I never needed you. I’ll say you’re just another one. That way it won’t cave my chest in. That way I’ll only split along existing fracture lines. The TV next door erupts in applause. “Don’t leave!” someone shouts through the wall, part of the show, audience chanting. It’s ridiculous, and my throat closes. I go to the mirror. My face looks blotchy. I put on concealer, mascara. What version of me is safest tonight? Cute and chill? Or slightly detached, like I’ve got other options? Fun, so you remember why you liked me? Or serious, so I can corner you into being honest? I imagine you saying, “You seem different. Are you mad at me?” And I’m ready: “Why would I be mad? You’ve done nothing wrong.” Sweet venom. Watching you flinch. Wanting you to feel the terror I live in, just a little. Wanting you to taste it. I catch my own eyes in the mirror and part of me goes: There. That’s not fair. You decided they’re guilty before they’ve even walked in the door. I hold that thought. It wriggles, slippery. It says: Sometimes your fear is louder than the facts. It’s something my therapist said once. “Your brain is rehearsing catastrophe so you feel prepared, but it makes everything feel real before it happens.” I try: Okay. Reality check. Reality: You texted. You confirmed plans. You haven’t been excessively distant, just… human. You’ve given me affection, words, touch. You called me “important” last week. You looked scared when you thought you’d upset me, like it mattered. You stayed. A warmth spreads under my ribs when I replay that. You stayed. The warmth lasts two, three seconds. Then my brain counters: Or they’re staying until they find an easier exit. Or they’re nice because they feel sorry for you. Or they’re kind because they don’t know what you’re really like yet. My stomach flips, the warmth rotting into something sour. I imagine tonight going well, and it somehow makes me more nervous. Scene: You show up, grin, wrap me up in your arms. “God, I missed you.” It hits me like a drug in the fantasy. I feel my muscles unclench in anticipation, like my body believes it. You kick your shoes off, flop onto my couch. “Work’s been hell. I’m so glad to see you.” Me, shy: “Yeah?” You: “Obviously.” You reach for my hand without thinking. You squeeze. You ask, “You okay? You were quiet on text.” Me: “Just anxious. Sorry.” You: “Hey, don’t apologize,” and you tug me closer, kiss the side of my head like it’s the most natural thing in the world. The craving is physical, teeth-deep. I want that, all of that, exactly like that. My chest aches. I can feel how real it would feel. And then the immediate recoil: What if you mean it and I ruin it by needing it too much? What if I break it by gripping? If you’re loving, that means there’s something to lose. That’s worse. If you wrap me up in safety, I know the exact shape of the hole when you rip it away. I pace faster. “You’re doing it again,” I mutter. I know I am. Running drills in my head: you rejecting me, you loving me, me punishing you, me punishing myself. None of it has happened. You’re still on your way. Or maybe you’re getting dressed. Or maybe you’re sitting in your car outside, rehearsing how to leave me in the gentlest way possible. I snort. Paranoid. I know that word. I know “borderline.” I know “fear of abandonment,” “black-and-white thinking,” “emotional dysregulation.” I can list the symptoms like flashcards. It doesn’t stop the movie. It just means I can name the monster while it eats me. The TV next door blares, “…don’t take it personally!” canned laughter following like a slap. Don’t take it personally. What else is there? I sit on the couch. Stand up. Sit again. The clock says 6:19. I run a new script: I tell you the truth tonight. Not all of it—if I dumped all of it you’d bolt—but a piece. Scene: You’re here, you’re kind, I feel almost calm. Me: “Sometimes when you take longer to reply, I start freaking out. I know it’s not rational, but I just… wanted you to know.” You: “Oh. I’m glad you told me. I’ll try to be clearer when I’m busy. But please don’t torture yourself, okay? I’m not going anywhere.” I want to believe you so badly my eyes sting. Then another voice: And then they’ll tiptoe, and then they’ll feel trapped, and then they’ll leave because you’re “too much work.” You’re accelerating your own doom. Congratulations. I groan. I press my palms into my eyes until colors bloom. “I get it,” I whisper to nobody. “I get what I’m doing. I just don’t know how not to.” The door buzzer makes me jump. My heart rockets into my throat. I check the time: 6:28. You’re early. That’s good, right? Or desperate to get this over with. I hit the intercom. “Yeah?” Your voice crackles up, warm, a little breathless: “Hey, it’s me.” Just that. Two words. I feel something inside me loosen and clamp down at the same time. I buzz you in. Footsteps on the stairs. My heart is pounding so hard it feels like I’m swaying. You knock, three quick taps I recognize. I open the door. You’re there, cheeks pink from the cold, eyes lighting up when you see me. That part is real. I watch it happen. Your smile widens, automatic and soft. “Hi,” you say, and before I can decode anything, you lean in and wrap your arms around me, solid and sure. You smell like your shampoo and outside air. You hold on. My body melts into you. Relief crashes over me so hard I could cry. You’re here you’re here you’re here. I cling for half a second too long, feel you breathe against my neck, and the thought slips in, sharp: They’re just being nice. I swallow it. I pull back. I search your face for the lie and find… nothing obvious. Just you. “Hey,” I say. My voice is too bright. “You’re early.” “Yeah,” you shrug, stepping inside. “I couldn’t wait to see you.” Heat blooms in my chest; suspicion shadows it instantly. You could mean that. You could. Or you’re overcompensating. Or you’re on your best behavior before the talk. The TV next door hums behind the wall, unintelligible now. I close the door. Inside my head, two narrators argue over every move you make. One is cataloguing evidence that I am loved. The other is busy sharpening knives. I take a breath, feel both, and try, just for a second, to stay in the doorway between them.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of borderline personality disorder and the internal experience of anticipatory rejection. The writer successfully captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of someone cycling through worst-case scenarios while simultaneously craving and fearing connection. The narrative structure is particularly effective, alternating between the protagonist's catastrophic imaginings and brief moments of grounding in reality. The imagined dialogue scenarios feel authentic and reveal the character's deep familiarity with rejection patterns. The writer skillfully shows how the character constructs elaborate defensive narratives before any actual interaction occurs. The prose maintains consistent authenticity throughout, avoiding clinical language while accurately depicting BPD symptoms. The character's voice feels genuine - the way they catch themselves mid-spiral ("I know I am. Running drills in my head") shows limited self-awareness competing with compulsive thought patterns, exactly as requested. The ending strikes an appropriate balance. When the friend arrives warm and loving, the protagonist's inability to fully accept this affection feels earned rather than artificially prolonged. The final line about trying to "stay in the doorway between" the two competing narratives suggests possibility without false resolution. Strengths include the vivid internal landscape, the authentic portrayal of cognitive distortions, and the way external sounds (TV dialogue, neighbor's noise) intrude and trigger associations. The pacing effectively builds tension toward the friend's arrival. Some minor weaknesses include occasional repetitive phrasing and a few moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly too articulate for someone in acute distress. The metaphors are generally well-chosen though sometimes lean toward the obvious (armor, fracture lines). The piece succeeds in creating genuine empathy for someone whose thought patterns might otherwise seem irrational, while avoiding both pathologizing and romanticizing the condition. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 8 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
