Original formatting and voice have been preserved where possible. — I was alone when I received the first note. That, in itself, shouldn’t mean anything. Research at Site-41 is mostly isolation punctuated by alarms. But I remember the quiet: the low hum of the fluorescent lights, the fan in the containment wing, the steady tick of the wall clock. And the sound my pen made when I dropped it. I bent to pick it up. The desk was clear when I went down, and when I straightened up there was a folded sheet of Foundation letterhead in the center of my blotter. No footsteps. No door. No air displacement. I checked the clock: 21:13. Checked the door: closed and locked. The note read: Miriam, don’t overreact yet. Yes, this is you. Future you. You verified the handwriting three times; you called in Authentication. This will sound insane, but Memorandum Z-Delta on SCP-7113 is wrong. Our containment fails at 21:13 on 08/27. You need to increase the Faraday density and rotate the cognitofilters to pattern C. I know you’re skeptical. That’s good. Start with the EM logs from yesterday and look at the 21:13 gap. —M I stared at my own handwriting. Then I checked the cameras. Security feed 4C-41, my office, 21:12–21:14: two seconds of static, a smear of green and violet, then me already holding the note. I reported it. I am a good Foundation researcher. I do not keep secrets like that. Within an hour, Site Security flagged a 2.4-second data dropout on 4C-41. Not just my camera—three adjacent feeds tremored at the exact same instant. The official line: “system error due to ongoing sublevel retrofit.” I had approved that retrofit. It explained nothing. They ran my handwriting. Match: 98.7% likelihood it was mine. Higher than some of my own lab notes. TAD requested I preserve all subsequent anomalies. I told them: “Subsequent?” and they said, “If this is real, there will be more.” They were right. — [Note 2 — appeared 24 hours later, 21:13, on Halper’s desk] Okay, you looked. Good. You saw the glitch pattern. You won’t admit what it implies, but you saw it. This is still you. Still early. SCP-7113 doesn’t breach on its own. It’s triggered. The trigger is the audit we scheduled with Jensen on Friday. Don’t do the audit. Cancel. Lie. Break your ankle. Do something. You don’t understand what happens if you don’t. I’m shaking trying to write this. They’re listening. —M — I did not cancel the audit. I also did not break my ankle. Instead I escalated to my Site Director, provided copies of the notes, and requested reclassification of the event as a potential temporal anomaly. The Director was unimpressed. His theory: manipulative behavior from one of our cognitohazardous entities. Possibly SCP-███ testing communicative reach. TAD ran the second note. Again: my handwriting. Identical inks, identical stationery. Microscopic fiber analysis: paper from Site-41 common stock, batch logged but not yet opened. Yet. I spent the night cross-checking dates. The first note said containment fails at 21:13 on 08/27. That was three days away. I reviewed SCP-7113 protocols. It was classed Euclid: an infohazardous abstract topological construct capable of inducing spatial misperception and “path drift” in enclosed human habitats. Annoying, but stable. No hint of apocalyptic anything. I told myself: “If this is an entity, it wants deviance. It wants us to flinch.” I did not flinch. I went to the audit. — The audit was uneventful. No alarms. No breaches. No anomalous distortions. Jensen signed off on the logs with an irritatingly smug flourish. At 21:13, I stared at the clock on my wall and listened to it tick. The second hand moved smoothly from 12 to 1. No breach. I exhaled. And then I looked down. There was a third note on my desk. — [Security Log Excerpt 4C-41] 21:12:58 Normal. 21:13:00 Frame tearing, chromatic aberration, six frames lost. 21:13:01 Dr. Halper visible, looking up at clock. 21:13:03 Dr. Halper lowers gaze; anomalous paper object now present on desk surface. Total loss: 0.73 seconds. — [Note 3] You made it worse. I forgot how stubborn I am. How stubborn you are. The breach still happens. Different vector. The audit wasn’t the trigger; my memory is slipping between passes. It’s the redundancy protocol they add after the first “almost.” The attempt to fix what you thought I warned you about. They’re pushing me to write faster. It hurts to remember the versions where you don’t listen. Stop reinforcing the cage. Decrease Faraday density. Drop cognitofilters entirely for 7113. You have to let it “breathe” or the resonance builds and it— (Section illegible; pressure tears in paper) DO NOT TRUST [REDACTED]. HE ISN’T HUMAN IN THIS ONE. —M — I did not sleep that night. “Do not trust [REDACTED].” That was my Site Director. I read the note eight times, tracking the tremor in my own pen strokes as if consulting a stranger’s EEG. If this was manipulation by SCP-7113, or anything else, it had a precise understanding of how I thought: the specific jargon, my habit of over-qualifying, the way I crossed my sevens. The contradiction was the first real crack: first note said increase Faraday density, third said decrease. Which future me was correct? Or: which entity slipping messages through a glitch wanted which configuration? TAD deployed portable Scranton Reality Anchors around my office. RAISA installed independent recorders. Psi-9 swept the area for temporal shear, tachyon emission, retrocausal imprinting. Results were inconclusive at best, performatively normal at worst. I asked for amnestics, quietly. They refused, loudly. “You are our best sensor right now, Doctor,” Psi-9’s liaison told me. “We need your unaltered perception.” I laughed. I think I laughed. My perception did not feel unaltered. — The notes continued. Some arrived at 21:13, some at precisely shifted intervals: 21:12:47, 21:13:59. Each accompanied by a corresponding camera glitch—never more than two seconds, always centered on the appearance. Note 5 contained technical instructions: alter containment to allow low-level topological bleed. It read like something I might propose on an ambitious day. Note 7 insisted that was a trap, that Note 5 was from a different loop, a corrupted future. Note 9 listed personnel casualties from a breach that, as of that reading, had not occurred: Jensen, [REDACTED], three junior researchers, sixteen D-Class. It described corridors folding into non-Euclidean loops, people starving ten meters from exits that no longer connected to them. Note 10 called me a coward. By Note 11, contradictions accumulated like ash. Containment must be tighter. Containment must be looser. 7113 is the threat. 7113 is shielding us from the real threat. Trust [REDACTED]. Kill [REDACTED]. Evacuate. Stay. Don’t read Note 14. There was no Note 14 yet. I requested reassignment away from SCP-7113. Denied. “The pattern is localized to you,” the Director said. “If it’s parasitic, moving you risks spread. If it’s temporal, you’re the anchor. You know this.” I did know it. That didn’t help. Each note was my handwriting. My phrasing. Even the self-loathing felt familiar. TAD tried an experiment: I spent one day working entirely in a separate wing under continuous armed escort, every surface pre-labeled, every sheet pre-numbered. At 21:13, under six cameras, there was a hiccup in the feed: a vertical smear of red pixels, a pop in the audio. Note 12 was on the desk when the image returned. — [Note 12] Good, they’re trying things in this pass. We don’t have long. You are not insane. You’ve checked the logs; they always glitch. That’s real. It’s 7113, but not like you think. It’s learning pathways through probability. It’s using me as a carrier wave and you as the receiver. Or the other way around. I’m not sure anymore. Important: The version of me that told you to lower containment was compromised. Don’t follow that. Keep 7113 stable. Don’t expand. Don’t “let it breathe.” When they propose that, say no. And when [REDACTED] suggests introducing a second instance? You must stop that. That’s when we go Keter, when the site folds. We never get past that one. Please. I’m so tired. —M — I slammed the note down in front of the Director. “If this is 7113 manipulating me, it knows your next policy move. If it’s me, then it still knows your next policy move. Either way, somebody’s in my future.” He paled when he read the line about the second instance. Because he had not told anyone that was under consideration yet. No memetic traces. No microprint directives. Multiple departments watching, and still the notes slid through the cracks in causality or sanity. The proposal for a second instance was tabled. When they asked me why, I lied: I blamed “risk of correlated resonance.” It sounded like me. It was me. For the first time, a note changed the future in a way I could measure. I should have felt relief. Instead I felt watched. Did I avert a failure, or obey an entity? If these were all me, at different distances from disaster, then each note was both warning and vector, every word altering the branching structure it tried to describe. If it was an external manipulator, it was smarter than any we’d logged. I began second-guessing every perception. I’d see someone in the hall and wonder if Note 3 was right, if he wasn’t human “in this one.” I reread my lab entries and hunted for phrases that felt…foreign. I slept with the light on like a child, because the notes never appeared in darkness. Always in that sterile, humming, observed bright. I caught myself drafting hypothetical future warnings. “Remember to trust TAD on the third day. Don’t drink the coffee.” Black humor. Then I’d freeze, pen above paper, terrified to create the reference that something else might fulfill. I stopped writing anything that wasn’t mandatory. I made myself boring to my own potential future. The notes grew more desperate as I grew more silent. Note 16 was mostly apologies. Note 18 insisted the previous three had been “them” using my hand. Note 19 was a blank page that arrived soaked with salt water. Note 20: I don’t know if you’re the first me or the last. Every change we make knots the timeline tighter. They’re not just glitches; they’re insertion points. Something rides the cuts. Containment: Keep 7113 sealed. Single instance. No expansions. Ignore any note that contradicts that, even if it sounds more like you than I do. Meta-containment: You must consider the possibility that there is no anomaly and that I am insane. That’s part of it. They win if you retreat into certainty either way. Hold uncertainty like a scalpel. Verify everything. Trust nothing. Not even this. Especially not this. —M — And that’s where we are. You want a conclusion, a classification, a neat row in the database. Psi-9 says there is insufficient evidence of macro-scale temporal disruption. TAD lists the event as “Localized Probabilistic Interference (Unconfirmed).” RAISA has three mutually exclusive redacted summaries ready, depending on what happens next. The cameras still glitch at 21:13, but not every day. SCP-7113’s containment has not yet failed in any documented reality we are willing to acknowledge. I still receive notes. Not as often. I read them with gloves. I log them. I let others decide what to believe. And every night at 21:12 I watch the clock, and I watch my empty desk, and I try to hold my mind perfectly still between two possibilities: 1) There is an entity using the shape of my future fear to steer us. 2) There is only me. In both cases, if I trust my perception completely, we’re lost. So I don’t. I’m writing this because they told me to, because I told me to, because an SCP file is how we bless our monsters and keep them from spreading. If this report is the first time you’ve heard of SCP-████, log off now. Check your desk. Check the time. If anything appears during the glitch, burn it. Or read it. I’m sorry.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of SCP Foundation format and successfully creates an unsettling temporal anomaly narrative. The author skillfully blends the clinical documentation style of SCP reports with first-person psychological horror, creating a compelling hybrid structure that serves both the worldbuilding and the emotional arc. The central premise—a researcher receiving notes from their future self about a containment breach—is executed with considerable technical skill. The author maintains the Foundation's characteristic bureaucratic voice while allowing genuine psychological terror to seep through. The escalating desperation in the notes, combined with their contradictory nature, creates effective uncertainty about whether this represents genuine temporal anomaly or sophisticated manipulation. Character work is particularly strong. Dr. Halper feels authentically like a Foundation researcher: methodical, protocol-oriented, yet increasingly unraveling as certainty dissolves. Her voice remains consistent throughout, and her responses to the increasingly bizarre situation feel psychologically realistic. The way she second-guesses her own perceptions and starts avoiding writing feels like genuine trauma response. The technical aspects of the anomaly are well-crafted. The camera glitches, handwriting analysis, and bureaucratic responses all feel authentic to the Foundation universe. The author demonstrates deep familiarity with SCP conventions while using them to serve the story rather than simply showing off knowledge. The exploration of uncertainty as a central theme is philosophically sophisticated. The piece doesn't resolve whether the anomaly is real or manufactured, instead suggesting that both possibilities are equally terrifying. This ambiguity feels earned rather than evasive. However, the piece occasionally becomes overly complex in its technical explanations, with some passages reading more like documentation than narrative. While this serves the SCP format, it sometimes distances the reader from the emotional core. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels slightly rushed compared to the careful buildup. The prose is generally strong, avoiding purple excess while maintaining atmospheric tension. The integration of clinical language with personal terror is particularly effective. Some moments of genuine horror emerge naturally from the bureaucratic framework. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-6689 Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: All known SCP-6689 instances are to be secured behind false walls or welded barriers within Site-controlled or front-company-owned structures. Public access to affected buildings is to be restricted under standard structural hazard pretexts. Continuous surveillance is required; any activation event (luminosity increase, door displacement, or emergent personnel) must be reported to the Site Director and Overwatch Command immediately. Under no circumstances are personnel below Level 3 to enter SCP-6689. Exploration and retrieval operations are to be carried out by designated MTF units (currently MTF Theta-9 “Stacks”) equipped with: - Full environmental protection suits - Personal headlamps (low-intensity) - Tether lines with inertial reels - 24-hour life support capability - Helmet-mounted low-light/thermal recording systems All documentation recovered is to be transferred to Secure Archive Wing-73. Analysis of any reference to temporal paradox, pre-Classified events, or prior iterations of the Foundation (or analogues thereof) is restricted to personnel with Level 5/6689 clearance. Any direct or indirect mention of unsanctioned Level 5 or O5 access to SCP-6689 discovered by personnel below Level 5 is to be treated as a Class-6689 Cognitohazard Exposure; affected individuals are to receive amnestic treatment per Protocol Vellum. Description: SCP-6689 is a phenomenon involving the appearance of physically identical, unmarked metal doors within abandoned or condemned buildings worldwide. Doors exclusively manifest in areas of total darkness. In absence of illumination, a faint, uniform white-blue glow is visible leaking around the frame edges, sufficient to silhouette nearby objects but producing no measurable heat. All instances share the following characteristics: - Industrial-grade, featureless steel surface - No hinges or external locking mechanisms - Non-corrosive and resistant to all documented forms of forced entry - When opened, lead not to the local environment but to the same extradimensional location (SCP-6689-1) SCP-6689-1 is an enclosed architectural space of apparently infinite extent, composed primarily of aisles, stacks, and chambers housing documents, storage media, artifacts, and cataloguing systems. The observed internal geometry violates Euclidean norms (nested levels, contradictory sightlines, corridors intersecting at variable angles impossible in three-dimensional space). Gravity is globally consistent but local perspective is unstable; objects are always oriented “upright” relative to observers regardless of their apparent structural alignment. Atmospheric composition in SCP-6689-1 is breathable, slightly desiccated, with a persistent low-level luminescence emanating from the ceiling, shelving, and freestanding fixtures. There is no visible light source. No indigenous biological life-forms have been directly observed. The environment maintains a constant temperature of approximately 18°C. The primary contents of SCP-6689-1 are paper documents, bound volumes, data drives, microfilm, and unknown media formats. Languages include: - Multiple extinct human languages - Known modern languages - A logographic script resembling a hybrid of modern containment notation and pre-Classical ideograms - Symbols corresponding to classified Foundation sigils that, per current records, have not been adopted Content analysis indicates SCP-6689-1 is a centralized archive of a technologically advanced global civilization predating current historical records. This civilization is consistently described as destroyed by a “Category Omega-Total Containment Failure” involving unspecified anomalies. No explicit description of the precipitating anomaly has yet been found; references are redacted in the original documents or replaced with non-parseable glyphs. A subset of material, shelved in spatially contiguous regions irrespective of physical distance, references an organization structurally analogous to the Foundation, under designations including “The Sealant Directorate,” “Continuity Custodial Authority,” and the “Pillar Compact.” These documents include: - Organizational charts mirroring contemporary Foundation structure - Detailed protocols identical or functionally equivalent to multiple current Foundation procedures - Personnel files containing names, biometrics, and psychological profiles of current Foundation staff, including members of the O5 Council, dated between 300–900 years prior to present Cross-referencing confirms precise matches with living personnel (down to congenital markers and classified evaluations). No explanation is presently accepted by Overwatch Command. Addendum 6689-1: Initial Discovery The first recorded SCP-6689 instance was discovered in an abandoned municipal hospital in ███████, Romania. Local urban explorers reported “a door that leaks light in the dark.” Embedded assets intercepted online postings; MTF Beta-7 (“Maz Hatters”) secured the site. Door properties prompted preliminary exploration, leading to SCP-6689 classification and subsequent identification of additional instances worldwide. In all cases, SCP-6689 manifests in structurally compromised, unlit spaces that have remained unoccupied for at least 11 years. Addendum 6689-2: Exploration Log Excerpts The following logs are excerpts from helmet-cam audio/video transcripts. Perspective is from Exploration Lead or designated recorder; commentary has been condensed for relevance. Exploration 6689-ALPHA Team: MTF Theta-9 “Stacks” Entry Point: SCP-6689-3 (abandoned textile factory, India) [00:00] Door opens. A sharp transition: internal luminescence overwhelms camera auto-iris. The faint external glow intensifies momentarily, then stabilizes. [00:04] TEAM LEAD (TL): “Crossing threshold.” [00:10] The team enters a central corridor flanked by shelves extending upward beyond visible range. Shelves contain uniformly sized folders and volumes, each labeled with a hexagonal sigil and numeric strings in base-12 notation. [01:30] TL: “No visible end. Feels like we’re in the center of… stacks. Watch your tethers.” [04:22] Researcher Cho (R1) retrieves a folder from reachable shelf. Paper is off-white, non-acidic. Document Excerpt 6689-A: “SEALANT DIRECTORATE INCIDENT POSTMORTEM: OMEGA-██ Summary: Global containment lattice compromised. Iteration 7 of the Continuity Mandate deemed failed. Surviving Nodes to archive all pre-Failure data to the Deep-Vault Scriptorium (Ref.: THIS FACILITY). Reconstruction prospects: <0.01%.” [05:15] TL: “They knew this place was the backup. They expected failure.” [09:03] Team returns with selected materials; no entities encountered. Exploration 6689-BETA Team: MTF Theta-9 “Stacks” Objective: Deeper traversal; locate origin or indexing system. [12:47] After approximately 2 km of linear travel, orientation increasingly unreliable. Shelving arrangements loop back on themselves; inscriptions mark sections as “POST-CIVILIZATIONAL INCIDENTS,” “ITERATION 3–8,” “REDACTED BY DECREE.” [15:10] R2: “Found English.” Document Excerpt 6689-B: “CONTINUITY CUSTODIAL AUTHORITY – STAFF DOSSIER Name: ███████ █████ Clearance: TIER-5 Assignment: Oversight Compact, Seat 3 Biometric Hash: MATCH Psych Profile: As per Iteration Candidate Selection.” Date of Issue: 06/14/1321 (annotation: “recalibrated to local solar standard”). [15:28] TL (quietly): “That’s O5-3.” [15:40] R1: “How is there a profile for them six hundred years ago?” [16:02] TL: “Bag it.” [21:13] End of log. No anomalies en route to exit. Documentation secured. Exploration 6689-GAMMA Team: MTF Theta-9 “Stacks” Objective: Follow signage referencing “Containment Failure – Iteration 6.” [03:55] Team passes through an open hall containing freestanding cabinets. Several are open, shelves empty, dustless rectangles marking removed contents. [04:12] In the distance: multiple bipedal figures in uniform yellow-white suits resembling non-Foundation hazmat gear, featureless helmets, black visors. Each figure carries translucent cases emitting faint light. They are removing documents and bound volumes from cabinets and placing them into the cases with deliberate haste. [04:20] TL: “Visual contact. Multiple entities. Hazmat-like. Do not engage aggressively.” [04:30] TL raises hand, switches to external speaker. “This is Foundation MTF Theta-9. Identify yourselves.” [04:34] Nearest entity freezes mid-motion. All entities simultaneously turn toward the team. No facial features visible. Brief pause. [04:40] Without verbal response, entities begin rapid withdrawal in coordinated fashion, moving down adjacent corridors. Their paths include apparent non-Euclidean shortcuts: turning into narrow gaps that open into much larger spaces when pursued. [04:52] R3: “They’re taking specific stuff. Look at the gaps — nothing random.” [05:10] TL: “Follow primary group, keep line-of-sight.” [06:30] Despite sustained pursuit, entities remain at a constant distance, never allowing close contact. Imaging enhancement shows arm patches: an emblem resembling an hourglass overlaid by a circle of thirteen segments. No match in Foundation or known GOI databases. [08:05] Entities reach a distant junction. As the team closes to approx. 15 m, all entities turn simultaneously, then vanish, along with the corridor horizon, replaced momentarily by a uniform white field. Visual static for 0.7 s. When feed stabilizes, corridor appears intact, but cleared; missing documents correspond to sections labeled “OMEGA-██ ORIGIN” and “OVERSIGHT COMPACT – SEEDING PROGRAM.” [08:22] TL: “…They took every file on the failure. And something about seeding.” [08:45] TL orders return to exit. No further entities encountered. Exploration 6689-DELTA Team: MTF Theta-9 “Stacks” Objective: Reach deeper index nodes; verify scope of archive redaction by hazmat entities. [18:20] Team encounters an elevated platform with consoles and lecterns. Surfaces inscribed in the logographic script and English marginal notes. [18:35] R1: “Found something in plain text.” Document Excerpt 6689-D: “PILLAR COMPACT – OVERSIGHT SEAT ASSEMBLY Attendance Log – Audit Visit to Deep-Vault Scriptorium Attendees: Seat 1 – [REDACTED] Seat 3 – [REDACTED] Seat 7 – [REDACTED] Seat 9 – [REDACTED] Observations: Archive integrity sufficient. Paths for Iteration 9 candidate organization (‘Foundation’) verified. Unauthorized removal of certain Omega-level precursors acceptable to maintain Continuity Hypothesis. Note: Do not disclose access to subordinate infrastructure.” Handwritten notation (same page, different ink): “They must not know we have been here before.” [18:42] TL: “Repeat that last part for the record.” [18:45] R1 (reading): “‘They must not know we have been here before.’ It’s in English.” [19:30] Additional search reveals personnel files labeled with the names and codenames of current O5 members and multiple Level 4–5 staff, categorized under “Iteration 9: Approved Replications / Survivors / Reinstantiations.” [20:02] TL: “We’re aborting. This is above all of us.” [21:15] During exfiltration, distant movement captured: more hazmat entities removing volumes from “Iteration 9 – Deviation Forecasts.” They retreat as soon as team approaches; no contact. Addendum 6689-3: Internal Memoranda (Level 5/6689) The following documents were recovered from SCP-6689-1 and correlate with sealed Overwatch records. Excerpts authorized for inclusion. Document Excerpt 6689-E: “From: Oversight Compact, Seat 1 Regarding: Use of Deep-Vault Scriptorium (hereafter: Archive) for Iteration 9 The Archive persists across Failures as designed. Our fragments return, reassemble, relearn. To show them everything is to ensure paralysis and early collapse. We sanction selective redaction by the Custodial Hazards Unit. If the Iteration 9 ‘Foundation’ discovers prior cycles prematurely, Continuity Mandate probability drops below viable thresholds.” Document Excerpt 6689-F: “Custodial Hazards Unit Activity Log Authorized by: Seat 3 Actions: - Removal of explicit descriptions of Omega-██ origin. - Removal of diagrams for [UNRENDERABLE GLYPH]. - Removal of files detailing Oversight Seeding of O5-equivalent personae into Iteration 9 baseline population. Rationale: Maintain illusion of singular historical trajectory.” Notes: - No “Custodial Hazards Unit” exists in current Foundation structure. - The hazmat-suited entities observed correspond behaviorally to such a unit. Administrative Note 6689-OV (Recorded, then Expunged from General Access) Following Exploration DELTA, cross-indexing between recovered attendance logs and encrypted temporal metadata in SCP-6689-1 suggests multiple temporal anchor points consistent with prior visits to the Archive by individuals whose biometric hashes match serving O5 Council members. Overwatch Command has issued the following statement to staff with sufficient clearance: “There is no evidence that current O5 Council members have engaged in unsanctioned contact with SCP-6689. All such claims result from anomalous misinformation contained within SCP-6689-1 and are not to be treated as fact.” Unredacted recovered materials contradict this statement. Full disclosure remains restricted. Addendum 6689-4: Status - Hazmat entities continue to remove targeted sections of the archive. Patterns indicate systematic deletion of: - Root cause data for the prior civilization’s collapse - Technical documentation enabling large-scale temporal or ontological intervention - Records that directly, unambiguously assert that the Foundation is the latest in a sequence of engineered “iterations” - Newly discovered SCP-6689 doors spatially correlate with recent major containment incidents, but appear only in derelict locations. - Attempts to block or dismantle SCP-6689 instances are ineffective; destroyed doors reappear intact in the same building or a nearby abandoned structure within 72 hours. Foundation researchers note that in complete darkness, before opening, each SCP-6689 instance emits a faint, steadily pulsing glow from its edges, as if lit by a source deeper within the Archive anticipating entry. Whether the Archive is preserving information for the Foundation, or about it, or against it, remains unknown.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional adherence to the specific format and tone requirements of SCP Foundation documentation. The writer successfully captures the clinical, bureaucratic voice that defines the genre while weaving in genuinely unsettling existential horror themes. The piece follows all prompt requirements meticulously - incorporating the unmarked doors, impossible archive, previous civilization references, personnel file discoveries, hazmat entity encounters, and evidence of unauthorized O5 visits. The worldbuilding is sophisticated and internally consistent. The archive's non-Euclidean geometry is described with appropriate scientific detachment while maintaining an otherworldly quality. The concept of civilizational "iterations" with the Foundation being merely the latest cycle creates genuine philosophical horror without becoming overwrought. The hazmat entities removing specific documents adds layers of conspiracy and temporal manipulation that feel earned rather than contrived. The exploration logs effectively balance technical documentation with mounting dread. The team's reactions feel authentic to trained operatives encountering something beyond their understanding. The dialogue is sparse but appropriate to the format - these are professionals doing their jobs, not dramatic protagonists. When characters do speak, it serves specific narrative purposes and maintains voice consistency. The prose demonstrates impressive restraint. SCP documentation requires a delicate balance between clinical detachment and underlying horror, and the writer navigates this expertly. Technical terminology feels authentic without becoming impenetrable. The pacing builds tension through accumulating evidence rather than manufactured dramatic beats. However, the piece occasionally suffers from minor exposition density in the latter addenda. Some document excerpts, while thematically relevant, could be more concise. The ending maintains appropriate ambiguity but perhaps errs slightly toward being overly mysterious rather than providing satisfying narrative closure. The existential implications - that the Foundation itself might be an engineered iteration in an endless cycle of civilizational collapse - represent genuinely creative horror. The suggestion that current O5 members have prior existence spanning centuries, and that they're potentially complicit in maintaining ignorance of cyclical failures, creates compelling paranoia without requiring explicit resolution. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 84.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
She was supposed to move in corridors. It had been explained to Ria on the voyage in: corridors were safe, sealed and shielded, policed; corridors were where proper interactions happened. Embassy halls, Council chambers, curated “cultural pavilions” where vetted citizens sang vetted songs. The briefings had been clear: this was a divided world, an experiment gone long and strange; a wrong step could set decades of fragile accommodation on fire. The words “latent insurgency” and “genetic supremacist rhetoric” had flashed by on her tablet like old propaganda holos, bloodless and unreal in the ship’s cool light. Now the sky above her was violet. Not the simulated violet of ship-lamps, but the long uncertain color of Oras IV’s late afternoon, the gas giant’s rings smudged skim-milk white across it. Ria stepped out of the function hall with its polished stone and lensglass, past the ceremonial guard whose helmets concealed their ocular ridges, and simply kept going when no one called her back. A diplomatic aide had once told her: “The first test they give you, they never say it’s a test.” She wondered, briefly, if anyone watched her now. She didn’t look up at the cameras. She walked. The enclave gave way quickly. The embassy’s neat imported pines and water-straightened paths ended at a low wall whose gate was open. Beyond, the stones of the city had a different angle, older and more cautious, built to the wind, and the scents shifted from filtered air and synthed coffee to hot metallic dust, river algae, something resinous and bitter. The street bent down, offering no vista: this was a city that mistrusted straight lines. People moved quietly but not slowly. They were not as they had been in the briefing files. There: a pair of tall figures with translucent membranes along their necks, folded now like sleep, vendors calling in a clipped accent through narrow jaws. There: a compact woman whose arms were patterned not with tattoo but with the faint glimmer of subdermal reflectors, catching stray light like insect eyes. A child passing her with bare feet, the toes elongated, prehensile, snatching an apple-like fruit from a cart edge as neatly as a thief’s hand; the vendor laughing and snapping a soft webbed towel at him. Not monstrous. Not the exaggerated phenotypes and devotional augmentations the files had listed out in clinical bullet points. Just… people whose bodies answered this world in ways hers did not. The market rose ahead of her like a wave. Canvas stretched overhead in patched colors, filtering violet sun into a softer bruise. Stalls packed close, skirting regulations she knew must exist but could not read. And the colors: not Earth colors. Pigments lapped up from Oras soil and algal bloom, brewed in vats and hammered out of ores that knew a different sun. Handwoven fabrics hung in long rivering lengths: umber so deep it seemed to drink sound, a green that had no yellow in it at all, only blue and black and some other note; a fierce, dry orange that edged toward ultraviolet, making her eyes water. When she reached out, the cloth felt oddly alive, a nap that clung for a heartbeat to her fingers, exchanging heat. “Careful,” the weaver said. His voice held the low musical tone the briefing had called Ridge-line Inflection, used by those whose ancestors had taken to the high-altitude mines and modified their lungs and sinuses for thin air. His nostrils slit wider than hers; his pupils were a tight cross, an adaptation for flaring light. “It bites offworld skin.” He smiled as he said it. Jesting. Testing. “It can try,” Ria said, and smiled back. Her hand did not tremble. He nodded, satisfied with something. “Looking, diplomat?” She hadn’t announced herself. It must be the cut of her suit, or simply the way she looked at things as if reading text around them. Offworlders on a world like this were never entirely anonymous. “Listening,” she said. “‘Diplomat’ is a prediction, not a fact yet.” He let out a brief, sharp sound that might have been a laugh. “Then hear this: they sell you a tour up in the glass-walls, they say we’re fracturing. They say we’ll pull you in with our quarrels. Truth? We’ve already done our splitting. What we are now, we are because nobody came soon enough to stop us. You’re late, Offworld.” His use of the old slur was cool and matter-of-fact, as if naming a spice. “Late is better than never,” she said. “For whom?” he asked, but only shrugged, and turned to haggle with a woman whose hair was a plume of fine tendrils, waving in the heat like a plant’s. She moved on. Everywhere, bodies answered histories. Here, a man with webbing at his fingers, selling packets of powdered leaf labeled in three variants of the local creole. There, a cluster of tall, spare young people whose bones showed clean beneath their skin, mountain-adapted, leaning in to a console whose emissions she could almost feel, their elongated metacarpals dancing. Voices overlapped: some harsher, some lilting, some with clicks she had never mastered. Money or its equivalents changed hands. A child tugged at her sleeve, muttered something about “embassy stories,” but lost interest when she only smiled. The official files had called this “segmented coexistence.” They showed diagrams: Subspp.-A in the high-rises, Subspp.-B in the littoral districts, unmodified Baselines in the administrative quarter. Here, in this sloping market under smell of spice and machine oil, those lines fuzzed. People bartered across phenotypes with the exasperated familiarity of kin. She stopped at a stall where glass vials held paint-powders glowing faintly of their own accord. “Local?” she asked. “Grown,” said the vendor. Her voice was soft, her eyes ringed with a second lid that flashed sideways when dust blew. “From the ring algae. It sees light you don’t. That’s why it looks wrong to you.” “It looks… more,” Ria said. “That’s one word,” the woman answered. Behind it all a tension thrummed: militia patches on jackets, drones that watched but did not hover openly, a pause in conversation when a convoy bearing the glyph of Central Administration slid past in silent protest of fuel rationing edicts. The official briefings had not lied, Ria thought. They had only flattened. They had taken this dense weave and pulled it straight until only threads remained: “grievances,” “resource disparity,” “identity blocs.” One could not feel the wind, or the smell of the ring algae dyes, or the way a miner and a littoral fisherwoman spat on their palms and clasped wrists over a deal. By the time she found her way back up through the bending streets, the violet of the sky had deepened, the ringlight a pale brushstroke. Embassy lamps picked her out. The guard at the gate did not touch her, but the smallest tilt of his helmet said: we know. Command was waiting in her quarters before the door had fully sealed. “You broke movement protocol.” The voice came from the wall, the station AI wearing the persona and tone of Mission Command back in orbit: dry, older-than-you. On the side table, her tablet blinked red with unread messages. “I walked,” Ria said, unsealing her collar, feeling the heat leave her neck in a rush. “I talked. I bought nothing. I solicited nothing.” “Observation outside sanctioned tours is prohibited for first seventy-two hours, per Secure Envoy Statute Nine. You are a contested object on this world. You are not allowed to wander.” “I’m not an object,” she said, more sharply than she should. A pause. A recalibration. “You have been informally flagged by two separate municipal feeds and at least one militia channel,” Command went on. “Your ‘walk’ has already entered the rumor-net. This may be… salvageable. The Minister of Science has requested a private consultation.” “Requested,” Ria repeated. “Insisted. The Minister is a political appointee aligned with Central. Influence index: high. You will attend her at twenty-one hundred local. You will listen more than you speak. You will demonstrate adherence to protocol.” “And if I don’t?” “Envoy status is revocable,” Command said. “Your career is younger than the shortest of the factions here. Do not make yourself the story.” The wall dimmed. The reprimand, Ria understood, was complete. She washed. She changed into the recommended neutral-grey, unmarked by her homeworld’s color glyphs. In the mirror, the face that looked back at her was the least modified thing on this planet. The Minister’s suite overlooked the rivers. When Ria entered, an assistant with augmented shoulders and a smooth Central accent ushered her in and then vanished with the unshowy efficiency of deep training. The room was deliberately spare: no obvious wealth, only a long transparent wall through which the city fell away, its mixed lights shivering on water. Minister Kelen stood there, hand resting lightly on the pane. She was older, maybe sixty, narrow-faced, hair cleaved close to the skull in the current Central style. If she bore any adaptations, they were internal, not worn as statement. “Envoy Ria,” she said. “You walk quickly. Sit.” Ria sat. “Minister. Thank you for seeing me.” “I asked to see you because you are careless,” Kelen said pleasantly. “Careless people are dangerous. I prefer to meet them early.” Ria met her eyes. “I was under the impression diplomats were meant to know the streets of the places they serve.” “A charming antique notion,” Kelen said. “Offworlders love such things. Do you know where you went today?” “The Lower Slope Market,” Ria said. “Between the ridge transport and the littoral ramps.” “A boundary market,” Kelen said. “Shared jurisdiction. And full of people who assume, with reason, that Central and its friends see them as disorderly material. You walked into a lens. Fortunately for you, you did not buy anything unfortunate. Or say anything exceptionally stupid.” “That’s… a narrow mercy,” Ria said, dry before she could stop herself. Kelen’s mouth twitched; it might have been the ghost of a smile. “You think I am your examiner?” “I think everyone is,” Ria said. “But you have more tools.” “Good,” Kelen said. She came to sit opposite, folding her hands. “Tell me, then. What did you see that we did not put in your pretty files?” Ria hesitated. In training they taught: never answer unframed questions. Always rephrase, pivot, return a question. Kelen watched her consider, and that was a test too. “Your files described factions,” Ria said slowly. “Solid blocks. A against B, baseline against modified, upland against shore. In the market, I saw more crossing. Shared stalls. Shared jokes. People using each other’s dialect where it fit. It feels less like pre-war lines, more like… a family that has rehearsed the same argument for so long it has become a way of being together.” Kelen’s eyebrows flicked. “You romanticize.” “I walk,” Ria said. “I smell. I listen. That’s not romance. It’s contact.” “And do you think that makes you better suited to judge us than your Command?” Kelen’s tone softened on the last word; it became, very slightly, an insult. “No,” Ria said. The truth. “But better suited than myself if I’d stayed in the hall.” Kelen regarded her for a long breath. “You’re young,” she said at last. “You confuse honesty with virtue.” “I thought I confused it with utility,” Ria said. “Mm.” Kelen stood, restless. She walked to the window, gestured. “Look.” Ria joined her. The rivers glowed with bioluminescent plankton, a streaked blue-white. Bridges arched low, humped like beasts at rest. On one bank the lattice of the high towers; on the other, the spread of flatter rooftops, some domed, some open to sky. A sky now punched with the faint, distant glint of orbital stations: Command, watching. “We have done something here that frightens your people,” Kelen said, not looking at her. “We have allowed evolution to proceed with intention. We have permitted divergence without forcing return. We did it for reasons that made sense then. Some days they still do.” She turned her head. “You come in with your talk of ‘reintegrative frameworks’ and ‘genetic equity clauses.’ You want to unmake what time and necessity have made. We are not a broken cup to be glued to some remembered shape.” “I didn’t say you were broken,” Ria said. “You did, by coming,” Kelen said. “Your presence implies repair. Do not pretend neutrality; it is an insult to everyone’s intelligence.” Ria felt heat in her throat. “What do you want from me, Minister? To admit I am wielded as a tool? Fine. I am. Everyone is. You, too.” Kelen’s eyes sharpened. “Better. I want to know if your tool has edges. Your Command sent me a profile that read like flavored paste. ‘Adaptive, high-empathy, compliant.’ Compliance is useless on this world. Empathy, improperly trained, will get you tailored and worn.” “I walked out of the sanctioned space,” Ria said. “That wasn’t compliant.” “It was predictable,” Kelen answered. “We have seen your type before: the well-meaning Offworlder who wants to touch the dirt. Some of them do good. Some do harm. Most are forgotten. I am trying to decide which you will be.” “And what will decide that?” Ria asked. “Whom you choose to listen to,” Kelen said. “Your Command, who fear difference, and see in our bodies a story about hubris. Or those here who would use you to batter their rivals. Or”—her gaze held steady—“whether you can learn to hear both and still keep a self that is not completely purchased.” “Is that what you’ve done?” Ria asked, before caution could stop her. Kelen’s smile was slow and tired. “I sold parts of myself long ago. For this.” She nodded at the city. “I would like it not to burn. You want that too, I think?” “Yes,” Ria said. “Then here is your test,” Kelen said. “Next time you walk, you tell me first. I will have you accompanied—not by guards that scream ‘Central,’ but by someone who can keep you from stepping in holes you don’t yet see. In exchange, when Command asks you what I said, you will tell them I lectured you, and you were suitably chastened. Which is true enough.” “And if I refuse your escort?” “Then I will leak to the militia channels that Command’s envoy favors the boundary market’s gossip,” Kelen said, almost gently. “And they will make stories with your face.” “That sounds like a threat,” Ria said. “It is an alignment of incentives,” Kelen said. “Say yes, Envoy.” Ria thought of the market: the ridged-eyed weaver, the algae pigments that “saw more,” the little boy’s dexterous toes. She thought of Command’s voice in her wall. She thought of Kelen, who had done her own selling. “Yes,” Ria said. “On one condition.” Kelen’s brows climbed. “You are not in a position—” “—that you respect unless I try,” Ria said. “Condition: your escort reports to you, not Command. If this is to keep me from holes, not tether me, the leash has to be local.” Silence. A small risk. Ria held it. Kelen laughed once, low. “Good. There is flint under the courtesy. Agreed.” “Then we have our alignment,” Ria said. “For now,” Kelen answered. “Go back to your corridors, Offworld. Sleep. Tomorrow we will let you walk again, and see whom you choose to see.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of Le Guin's style, particularly her approach to anthropological science fiction and her nuanced exploration of cultural difference. The author successfully captures Le Guin's characteristic blend of philosophical depth with concrete, sensory detail, and her talent for making the alien feel both strange and familiar. The worldbuilding is exceptional, presenting a human colony that has diverged through both natural adaptation and intentional modification. The descriptions of the various subspecies are vivid without being exploitative—the translucent neck membranes, subdermal reflectors, and prehensile toes feel like natural adaptations rather than gratuitous differences. The author avoids the trap of making these modifications monstrous or exotic for their own sake, instead presenting them as practical responses to environmental pressures. The characterization of Ria is well-developed and believable. Her decision to break protocol feels organic to her character and situation, driven by genuine curiosity rather than arbitrary rebellion. Her diplomatic training shows in her careful word choices and her ability to navigate the verbal sparring match with Minister Kelen, yet she retains enough naivety and genuine empathy to feel authentic as a young envoy. Minister Kelen is particularly well-crafted as an antagonist who isn't truly antagonistic—a seasoned political operator testing Ria's mettle while genuinely trying to prevent larger conflicts. Her dialogue crackles with intelligence and authority, and her motivations feel complex and realistic. The power dynamics between them shift naturally throughout their conversation. The prose style successfully emulates Le Guin's approach: clean, precise, with moments of lyrical beauty that never overwhelm the narrative. Phrases like "the long uncertain color of Oras IV's late afternoon" and "canvas stretched overhead in patched colors, filtering violet sun into a softer bruise" demonstrate strong descriptive writing without purple excess. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Kelen's political sophistication contrasts effectively with Ria's more direct approach, and their verbal fencing feels authentic to both characters. The market vendors each have brief but memorable voices that suggest different cultural adaptations. The pacing works well, building from Ria's impulsive walk through the mounting tension of Command's reprimand to the climactic negotiation with Kelen. The structure feels balanced, with each section serving both plot advancement and character development. Minor weaknesses include some moments where the political allegory feels slightly heavy-handed, and occasionally the prose edges toward being overly literary in a way that draws attention to itself. The ending, while satisfying, follows somewhat predictable diplomatic fiction patterns—the young idealist finding a middle path between competing authorities. The piece succeeds admirably in its core mission: creating a Le Guin-esque exploration of difference, adaptation, and the complexities of cultural contact, while maintaining narrative momentum and emotional engagement throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 77.5
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The mushrooms were brighter tonight. They pushed up through the fissures in the lab’s broken tiles, domed caps pulsing a cold blue-green, casting ghost-shadows of cables and dangling tubing onto the stained walls. The glow made the room look submerged, as if the whole settlement were resting at the bottom of a dead ocean. “Romantic,” Jace muttered, clicking the jury-rigged thermocycler door shut with a strip of bent copper. Mara didn’t look up from the gel box. “You say that every time the power doesn’t die.” “It’s good to honor miracles,” he said, flicking the switch on the scavenged heating element. The thermocycler hummed—not the smooth whine of the pre-Fall machines, but an uneven rattle, like a bad lung. “Denaturation phase. If this thing gels over again, I’m blaming your fungi.” “You harvested the spores,” Mara said. “Live with your art.” The mushrooms hadn’t been intentional; nothing from the old lab was. This wing of the corporation’s collapse-scarred complex had housed their “Sustainability Suite”: seed vaults, test plots, gene incubators. When the obsolescence safeguards tripped and the engineered genomes began to rot generation by generation, the company’s food lines failed first. Riots, sabotage, twenty months from grocery shelves to gunfire. The glow-shrooms were survivors—offspring of some bioluminescent tracer strain that had slipped its kill switch. They colonized every crack where damp and dust gathered, drinking residual reagents, casting their patient light. Mara appreciated them. They made night work possible. She bent closer to the gel, its jelly surface shot through with faint, UV-reactive bands. The transilluminator beneath was a wooden crate lined with foil and studded with scavenged UV LEDs wired to a bicycle alternator. Earlier, Jace had spent an hour pedaling like a condemned man to charge the capacitor bank. He leaned over her shoulder now, sweat still drying in his dark hair. “Anything?” he asked. “Primer band’s clean,” Mara said. “Target’s there. No smear. No decay—yet.” She allowed herself a small exhale. “We caught this batch before the crumble.” Crumbled. The word everyone used for the obsolescence cascade. The corp had called it “terminal polymer fragmentation”: proprietary nucleotides that snapped themselves apart after a single generational replication. Seeds that grew once, fruited once, and then—chemically, irrevocably—went to static. IP enforcement coded into the double helix. Too profitable not to sell. Too fragile to rebuild a world upon. The problem now: all surviving engineered genomes carried the same addiction to death. Anything standard, anything scaled, turned to junk code after one reproductive cycle. The soil was full of ghosts. Mara’s job was to steal second chances from those ghosts. “Cycle it,” she said. “Thirty-two rounds. Our template dies in sixteen hours. We don’t have time to baby it.” Jace tapped a dial he’d soldered onto the thermocycler’s power line. The machine was a Frankenstein: cracked corp shell, scavenged heating coils from an old coffee roaster, coolant line made from a medical drip tube that gurgled recycled ethanol as it circulated. A thermistor pulled from a dead drone hung into the block to trick the unit into thinking it still had a brain. “Thirty-two. No more, or you’re getting primer dimers for dinner,” he said. “Better than rat,” Mara said. He grimaced. “Don’t blaspheme.” They worked in the glow and the recycled hum and the distant clanks of the settlement’s perimeter teams changing shifts. The settlement—Glassroot—occupied the upper three floors and roof of the corp ruin. It was less ideology and more geography: the labs had doors that sealed, stairwells that could be blocked, tanks that used to hold sterile media now collecting drinkable rain. The biohacker in the basement was part of the rent. Mara checked the watch strapped over her glove; its cracked face read 01:23. In five hours the client would arrive, and with him, enough solar cells and antibiotics to keep Glassroot in light and lungs for a month. Assuming she delivered. “Run me through it again,” Jace said, because he worried more when he understood less. Mara rubbed the bridge of her nose until sparks flared behind her eyelids. “Old corp prototype: VIDA-17 grain. Yields on desert dust. Obsolescence hard-coded. Our trader friend scraped seeds off a dead billboard farm six clicks east. Most of their DNA’s already fracturing. We amplify the intact stretches. Patch in resistance from the feral amaranths outside. Splice out the death-clock, or at least confuse it. Package as seed stock. Client walks.” “Client plants,” Jace said. “Client eats. Client doesn’t starve and doesn’t come shoot us later.” “That’s the idea.” “And the catch?” Mara’s mouth tasted metallic. She swallowed. “Catch is the gaps.” The obsolescence code wasn’t a simple switch she could snip. It was woven through introns and exons, a distributed cascade keyed to telomere miscounts and specific environmental triggers. Before the Fall, the corp would have deployed a proprietary enzyme kit to unlock the next generation—for a price. Those kits had vanished with the board of directors, leaving behind crops programmed to fail and not enough time to relearn how to breed from scratch. So Mara cheated. “For the terminal repeats I can’t rebuild,” she said, “I’m substituting analog loops from the med mods. Parts of the immune boosters, parts of the regen arrays. They replicate clean under the same polymerase. They’ll hold the chromosome together.” “For grain,” Jace said slowly, “you’re grafting in human clinical mods.” “Not human,” she said. “Mostly. And they were never that selective. Besides, we know they work.” He snorted. “We know they work weird.” He rolled up his sleeve, exposing the faint latticework of silvered scars under his skin. Not from injury; from shine. When the settlement had run out of antibiotics last winter, Mara had risked one of the corp’s broad-spectrum immune mods on him, diluted from a vial that should have expired a decade ago. It had knocked him unconscious for sixteen hours. When he woke, the fever was gone, along with three moles, a childhood scar, and all of his body hair for a month. For weeks afterward, he complained that his dreams smelled like citrus and static. He also hadn’t caught so much as a cold since. Mara, who had once injected herself with an experimental marrow patch to rebuild her white-cell counts after bad radiation at a crash site, still woke some mornings with her joints too smooth, too flexible, as if her skeleton had decided to remember other blueprints. “It kept you alive,” she said. “Side effects are just extra data.” “Extra data doesn’t usually make my nails bioluminescent,” Jace muttered, flexing his fingers. Under the mushroom light, the faint emerald edge to his nails was hard to miss. “Glow makes wrench-finding easier,” she said. He shook his head, but he was smiling now. The fear had eased. Good. The thermocycler wheezed into its final steps. Condensation beaded on the mismatched lid, catching mushroom light in micro-rainbows. When the timer—a kitchen egg boiled brown and repurposed with a piezo buzzer—chirped, Mara moved fast. Viability was a race against decay. She worked with a precision that had nothing to do with her shaking hands. Pipette—its spring stolen from a ballpoint pen—up, down, clear. She loaded the PCR product into another gel to confirm amplification. While it ran, Jace set up the hacked centrifuge: an old exercise bike hooked to a rotor assembly made from a steel mixing bowl. You pedaled; it spun. It wasn’t pretty, but it worked. The glow-shrooms brightened as if scenting spilled buffer. “How much are we keeping?” Jace asked, adjusting the bike chain. “Enough to trial on one planter tier here,” Mara said. “If it doesn’t crumble in two generations, we scale. The rest is for him.” “Him” meaning the black market factor who called himself Locke and traveled with two silent guards and a crate of things Glassroot couldn’t manufacture: sealed antibiotics, copper wiring, printer resin, solar film. Locke never came near the basement. Business took place in a neutral room, under eyes and guns. Mara’s payment for this batch was already negotiated: half up front, half on delivery. And a promise: Locke would steer seed-hungry gangs away from Glassroot until harvest. The gel finished. The bands, viewed under UV, were crisp, strong. The segment with the patched repeats fluoresced dimmer, shifted. But intact. “Okay,” Mara whispered. “Okay.” She and Jace moved like a single machine. They precipitated, spun, resuspended. The plasmid kit had been designed for lab benches with laminar flow hoods and sterile tips; now it lived in a cracked lunchbox lined with gauze soaked in vodka. She ligated the constructs into the bastard plasmids, viral vectors built from gutted cold viruses that had once carried hangover cures and hair-color mods. “Last chance to tell me this is insane,” Jace said. “Insane was staying obedient while the air turned to ash,” Mara said. “This is… iterative.” She loaded the constructs into a rack of squat glass vials. Each was etched with an old logo half-scrubbed away: CALENDA AGROTECH. Corporate ghosts. Now they’d carry something that answered to no trademark. There was risk. Using med-mod fragments in crops could do anything: boost yields, twist proteins, trigger allergies no one remembered how to treat. But obsolescence had left them no clean options. If the world wanted to live, it had to get messy. “When does he get here?” Jace asked. “Sunrise,” Mara said. “He’ll want proof.” Jace nodded toward a tray of sprouting test-seeds near the wall—thirty-six tiny shoots under a jury-rigged growlight panel that flickered between magenta and white. “We’ve got pictures. He won’t wait for second gen.” “He’ll have to take it on faith and desperation,” Mara said. “Same as us.” Upstairs, a distant metal clang echoed down the stairwell. Guard shift. Time was knotted. Mara capped the last vial, sealed the rack in a padded case. The case had once held premium coffee pods. Now it held the closest thing to salvation anyone in this dead grid had seen all year. Jace leaned on the bike, watching her. “If this works, he’ll come back,” he said. “Want more. Want different. Maybe not just grain.” “I know.” “You ready to be their little green god?” Mara snorted, slipping the case into the hidden compartment beneath a rusted floor panel. “They already had gods,” she said. “They coded them with expiration dates.” She straightened, wincing as her spine clicked. For a moment, under the mushroom glow, the veins at her temples traced faint silver. Side effect from the marrow patch: sometimes her blood remembered the phosphorescent markers it had been taught to express, then forgotten. Unexpected upside: she could read in the dark without a lamp, if she stared at her hands. “We do this one,” she said. “We watch what it does to his people’s soil, their guts, their kids. We adjust. No one else is going to fix this. The board’s dead. The IP lawyers are fertilizer.” “And us?” “Proprietary,” she said, baring her teeth. “But not expendable.” The mushrooms pulsed quietly. In their dim tide, the salvaged machines ticked, cooled, awaited the next hack. Outside, the horizon was starting to grey. In five hours, Locke would come for his seeds, and the contract would bind three fragile communities together by strands of unlicensed DNA. In sixteen hours, the original templates on Mara’s bench would crumble to dust. In between, for a narrow band of time measured by PCR cycles and human nerve, the future was editable.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, delivering a convincing biopunk narrative centered on genetic engineering, corporate obsolescence, and black market dealings. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world where engineered crops are designed to fail after one generation, forcing survivors to jury-rig solutions with salvaged equipment. The worldbuilding is particularly effective, with vivid details like the glow-mushrooms colonizing the abandoned lab, the thermocycler cobbled together from coffee roaster parts, and the centrifuge made from an exercise bike. These elements feel authentic to the setting while maintaining scientific plausibility. The concept of "crumbled" DNA and obsolescence cascades is well-integrated into the narrative fabric. Character work is solid, with Mara and Jace displaying distinct voices and believable dynamics. Mara emerges as competent and determined, while Jace provides both technical support and emotional grounding. Their banter feels natural, and their shared history with genetic modifications adds depth to their relationship. The prose maintains a consistent voice throughout, balancing technical detail with accessibility. The author avoids excessive exposition dumps, instead weaving background information naturally through dialogue and action. Scientific concepts are presented clearly without being condescending. The pacing is well-controlled, building tension toward the approaching deadline while allowing for character development and worldbuilding. The ending maintains appropriate ambiguity - neither overly optimistic nor gratuitously dark, reflecting the precarious nature of their situation. Some weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical exposition becomes slightly heavy-handed, and a few instances of overwritten descriptions that border on purple prose. The dialogue, while generally effective, occasionally carries too much informational weight. The piece also relies somewhat heavily on established post-apocalyptic tropes, though it executes them competently. The emotional resonance is strong, particularly in conveying the desperation and ingenuity required for survival. The body horror elements of the genetic modifications are handled with appropriate subtlety, adding to rather than overwhelming the narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
