+ Iteration 3 — Avg Score: 82.8
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 72.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The transfer vessel's air filtration system hums with a persistent mechanical drone. Arthur Neegan sat strapped into the narrow acceleration couch, watching the condensation bead and reform along the edge of the overhead duct. The air smelled faintly of machine oil and ironed cloth—prefab sterility, a far cry from the red dust and recycled sweat of his dome. Across from him, three members of the Antares retinue sat in rigid, practiced indifference, their pistols holstered but hardly concealed. Their pale-gray uniforms bore the stylized eight-pointed star of the Antares Diplomatic Corps—a star wrapped in a laurel that was meant to signify concord, but looked more like a noose. Arthur cleared his throat. No one looked up. “So,” he said finally, “do I get to know where we’re going before we get there, or is that above my clearance?” The woman on his left, the one who’d done the talking back at his dome, glanced over. Her features were narrow and exact, as though sculpted with a drafting compass. “Mr. Neegan,” she said, “we are transferring you to a secure diplomatic vessel in Mars synchronous orbit. Your host will brief you. Until then, details are restricted.” “You keep saying ‘host,’” Arthur said. “That’s generous.” The man across from him, heavier-set, with a shaved head and an Antares badge that looked a decade old, smiled faintly. “Could be worse,” he said. “We could have cited Code 11 and left you sedated.” The woman’s glance silenced him. Arthur closed his eyes briefly. He still saw the retinue stepping through his hatch like an equation reaching its inevitable conclusion. The quick scan of his claim registry. The casual verification of his identity. Their polite insistence. “Diplomatic,” he said now. “Interesting label for people who arrive with rifles.” “Expeditionary environments require preparedness,” the woman said. “We prefer consent. You consented.” “I consented the way a pressure hull consents when you open an airlock,” Arthur said. “What does Antares want with a mining engineer from Sector Twelve?” The woman folded her hands. “Mr. Neegan, what we want is for you to remain calm. There are parties who would be far less solicitous. You’ve attracted attention.” “Because of a core sample,” Arthur said. “Because your orbital surveyors missed a vein.” Her eyes flickered. Not denial. Confirmation. “We don’t miss,” she said. “We prioritize. The Azra index from your plot shifted three weeks ago. You logged an anomalous assay, and instead of routing it through one of the recommended channels, you filed it under your own registry and requested an independent verifier from Cydonia University.” “It’s my claim,” Arthur said. “I followed the charter.” “The charter,” the man across from him said, “was drafted before Azra.” The hum of the filters deepened as if in agreement. The vessel shuddered—a course correction, or docking prep. Arthur tightened his fingers around the armrests. “So this is about the vein.” “This,” the woman said, “is about what sits under your name in the planetary ledger. And what other people believe it entitles them to do.” “Other people,” Arthur said. “Plural.” “Off-world interests,” she said. “Corporate blocs. Defense coalitions. Martian charterists. Free Titan. The Minor Jovian League. Some of them use lawyers. Some use other means. We represent one of the more structured factions. You’ll meet our principal shortly.” “And if I decline whatever your principal is selling?” Her answer was delayed by the soft chime of the cabin annunciator. “Approach vector locked,” a neutral voice said. “Stand by for docking.” The woman regarded Arthur steadily. “We’ll cross that bridge in a safer room.” The vibration shifted from a hum to a gentle, rhythmic thrum. Out the small port, Phobos slid past like a sallow stone. Above it, a slate-gray spindle hovered: the diplomatic vessel. It looked less like a ship than like an instrument—something designed to measure, or dissect. Docking was efficient, impersonal. Magnetic clamps engaged with a hollow thud that Arthur felt in his teeth. They unstrapped him and guided him—politely, always politely—through a narrow transfer tube into a corridor lined with muted lighting and acoustic panels. Diplomatic quiet: the sort that stifled raised voices as effectively as security codes. Along one wall, a series of framed glyphs and emblems displayed the “partners” of the Antares Corps: Earth Union, Pacifica Combine, Epsilon Indemnities, and others that Arthur recognized from trade briefs and rumor. The logo of the Interstellar Reactor Commission gleamed like a benediction and a warning. They brought him into a conference compartment with a low ceiling and a wide viewport. Mars hung in it, vast and rust-red, with its polar cap a white wound. Waiting at the table was a man in an immaculate dark tunic, collar high, no visible insignia except a small, metallic Antares star at the throat. His hair was iron-gray, his face unlined in a way that suggested skilled gene-tuning rather than youth. His eyes were not the sharp eyes of a predator; they were clearer and more abstract, like those of a mathematician facing a familiar theorem. “Mr. Neegan,” he said. “Thank you for joining us.” “Invitations with guns,” Arthur said. “You’re very persuasive.” The man’s smile was brief. “My name is Kellan Vard. I’m attached to Antares’ Special Mandate Office.” “Diplomatic?” Arthur asked. “Not habitually,” Vard said. “Please, sit.” The retinue took positions by the door, hands free, weapons dormant but proximate. Arthur sat opposite Vard, Mars looming behind him. “Let’s not waste time,” Arthur said. “You know about the vein.” “We do,” Vard said. “A remarkable deposit. Unusually pure Azra, high lattice stability, anomalously low contamination. Enough, by preliminary estimate, to alter several balance sheets and a few strategic projections.” Arthur swallowed. He’d run the numbers. He hadn’t said them out loud. “It’s just ore,” he said. Vard’s eyes warmed, as if at a child’s endearing error. “Mr. Neegan, Azra is never ‘just ore.’ You’re an engineer; you know what it does.” “I know it accelerates radioactive decay,” Arthur said. “I know if you wrap it around a fusion stack the wrong way you reduce a drive core to slag and prayers. That’s why I requested independent verification, instead of letting one of your affiliated companies ‘lose’ it in a mass survey.” “Prudent,” Vard said. “You also delayed your logging submission by eight hours while you ran a private assay. That, too, was prudent.” “I wanted to be sure,” Arthur said. “I don’t like people crawling into my dome over rumors.” “And yet here we are,” Vard said gently. He tapped a slender pad, and the table between them lit with a crisp projection: a three-dimensional model of Mars, layered with ghostly veins of color. “This is the current official Azra distribution model,” Vard said. His finger flicked; most of the color vanished, leaving a few thin threads. One bright mass pulsed in Sector Twelve. “Your claim,” he said. “Primary anomaly. Deep, dense, clean. Others exist—in the Tharsis uplands, beneath the Borealis Basin—but your vein is… special.” “Because your model is wrong,” Arthur said, frowning. “Your orbital scans undercount. Azra occludes standard geo-spectroscopy at certain densities. You’re missing deeper pockets.” Vard watched him. “How many alternate models did you run?” “Three,” Arthur said. “One using old pre-colonial seismics for baseline. One using variance in thermal dispersion from the southern grid. One… intuitive.” “The third was correct,” Vard said. “Within a useful margin. You see why you’re of interest, Mr. Neegan. It’s not only the ore. It’s you.” Arthur shifted. “I did what any decent engineer would.” “Most engineers,” Vard said, “either sell their assay data to the first bidder or bury it and hope no one notices. You instead selected Cydonia University—nominally neutral, subtly aligned with the Charterists—and you encrypted your transmission with an outdated but nontrivial Earth diplomatic cipher. Where did you learn that?” Arthur stared at him. “Old manuals. My mother had a stack.” “A first-generation settler with legacy codes,” Vard murmured. “Anomalous ore on an anomalous claim. You can see patterns if you wish to.” “I see a lot of people very interested in something that’s under my name,” Arthur said. “You said there are other parties.” “There are,” Vard said. “Some have already tried to spoof the ledger to reassign your claim to shell companies. We corrected that. A different group placed an unregistered drone over your sector. We retrieved that as well. Less than an hour ago, a corporate security team under the Jovian Industrial Bloc requested an extraordinary warrant for your ‘protective custody.’ It will be granted within thirty-six hours.” “And you?” Arthur asked. “What do you want?” Vard leaned back. “To prevent a panic,” he said. “To prevent a war if possible. To prevent certain people from obtaining a monopoly on Azra applications. We are… mediators, when convenient. Strategic saboteurs, when required. In this instance, we propose an arrangement.” “An arrangement,” Arthur repeated. “You retain formal ownership of the claim,” Vard said. “On paper. In exchange, you sign an exclusive operational partnership with an Antares consortium. We handle security, extraction, and distribution. You receive a substantial percentage of net yield. You also accept our protective oversight, effective immediately.” Arthur’s jaw tightened. “Oversight meaning your people at my door. Your guns in my dome.” “Meaning you don’t disappear into an airlock on some procedural technicality,” Vard said. “Meaning the first strike doesn’t go to the most aggressive bidder. Meaning Azra from your vein is tagged, traced, and rationed through a framework we can influence. Not control absolutely—never that—but influence.” “And if I say no?” Vard’s gaze did not waver. “If you decline, the Jovian Bloc will move. Or the Charterists will, in a more righteous tone. Someone will manufacture a prior claim. An audit. A scandal. You’ll be discredited, then detained. The vein will change hands; the panic will not be mitigated. You will have exercised your autonomy in a purely symbolic fashion, and the universe is short on patience for symbols.” “You’re very calm about all this,” Arthur said. “I’ve seen this pattern before,” Vard said mildly. “When superconductor filaments were first spun on Luna. When He-3 extractions shifted from national to corporate control. When the First Belt Syndicate declared independence. Azra is a new variable. The equation is familiar.” Arthur looked past him, out toward Mars. He knew its deserts and buried ice, the hiss of his air recyclers, the way red dust crept into every seal. He’d come here to get away from other people’s equations. “Why not just take it?” he asked. “You had armed people at my hatch. You could fabricate a forfeiture, chalk me up as an accident.” “We could,” Vard said. “Others will, in other quadrants. But it costs less, over time, to enlist willing principals. Stability has its own arithmetic. And I am, by temperament, old-fashioned. I prefer contracts to corpses.” He tapped the pad. Figures appeared: percentages, trust structures, security guarantees, nested jurisdictions. It was not merely an offer; it was architecture. “Antares is not monolithic,” Vard said. “Within our consortium are factions who would prefer a more direct approach. I am offering you my faction’s solution. It buys us time. Time to study Azra’s deeper properties before someone miscalculates and catalyzes an entire reactor grid into accelerated decay. You’ve read those simulations, I trust.” “I’ve run them,” Arthur said quietly. “Then you know the stakes,” Vard said. “This isn’t only about wealth. It’s about whether vessels arrive with intact drives instead of becoming bright, brief additions to the night sky. It’s about whether someone decides that an Azra-shunted warhead is a strategic deterrent or an irresistible temptation.” Silence settled, except for the ship’s orderly drone. Arthur folded his arms. “Suppose I accept. What stops you—from your side—from rewriting this later? Once I’ve signed. Once you’ve ‘protected’ me into a nice, quiet corner?” “A fair question,” Vard said. “Very little. We have power; you have leverage. Our proposal is to formalize that leverage in as many interdependent systems as possible. Multiple signatories. Multi-party escrow. Oversight committees with incompatible agendas. We embed you so thoroughly into the machinery that removing you becomes inefficient.” “You’re saying my safety depends on my nuisance value,” Arthur said. “Yes,” Vard said. “I find nuisances live longer than martyrs.” Arthur almost laughed. “And if I said I don’t want to be either?” “Then you are already in the wrong story,” Vard said softly. “You didn’t choose the vein. You did choose how you handled it. Choices have trajectories.” Arthur stared at the projections. Numbers that could tile half of Mars in green domes—or in radioactive glass. “You said other factions inside Antares disagree with you,” he said. “Why tell me that?” “Because ignorance is flammable,” Vard said. “And because I will shortly ask you to trust me more than is rational. It helps if you know I am, at least, telling you the shape of the trap.” “And the name of the consortium?” Arthur asked. “If I’m selling my soul, I’d like to know the buyer.” Vard hesitated, then keyed a sequence. A name resolved above the table: AZRA STABILITY ACCORD. Beneath it, a ring of sigils—Antares, Earth Union, Reactor Commission, Cydonia University, two others Arthur didn’t recognize. “An Accord,” Arthur said. “You’ve already drafted it.” “Of course,” Vard said. “With or without you, it will exist. With you, it’s stronger. Without you, it’s bloodier.” Arthur watched Mars turn, its red face implacable. “You’re sure I’m that important,” he said finally. “In this narrow window,” Vard said, “yes. Until Azra becomes just another line in a catalog and the universe has adjusted. Right now, you are, regrettably, a fulcrum.” The word hung between them. Arthur exhaled. “I want a Martian seat on whatever board oversees this Accord,” he said. “Not appointed by Earth, not by Antares. Elected by settlers. I want your security in my sector answerable to Martian civil law, not just your mandates.” Vard’s eyes narrowed, appraising. “You negotiate quickly.” “You said I’m a fulcrum,” Arthur said. “Might as well lean.” “Provisional,” Vard said. “We can structure it. The optics may even help. A first-generation settler as guarantor of planetary interest—it plays well.” “So we make each other useful,” Arthur said. “We do,” Vard said. “And in the process, possibly keep the sky from catching fire.” He slid a stylus across the table. “This begins with your consent, Mr. Neegan. Not because we cannot operate without it, but because the story runs better when you sign.” Arthur looked at the stylus. Then at Mars. Then at the armed silhouettes by the hatch. He picked it up. “What,” he asked quietly, “haven’t you told me yet?” Vard’s expression did not change, but something in his gaze sharpened. “That Azra’s behavior at higher densities is not fully understood,” he said. “That your vein may not be a deposit at all, but a convergence. That there are readings… suggestive of non-random distribution.” “You think someone put it there,” Arthur said. “I think,” Vard said, “that the universe rarely offers gifts without terms. We intend, if possible, to read the fine print before someone detonates the contract.” Arthur’s hand hovered over the projected signature band. “Welcome,” Vard said softly, “to the Azra Gambit.” Arthur signed.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and adherence to the Asimovian style requested. The author successfully captures the classic science fiction atmosphere with detailed world-building that operates on both micro and macro levels - from the condensation on air ducts to the broader political implications of Azra mining across the solar system. The retrofuturistic elements are well-integrated, from the diplomatic corps insignia to the technology descriptions. The dialogue carries the narrative effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Vard emerges as particularly well-realized - calculating yet personable, with the kind of measured intelligence Asimov favored in his characters. Arthur's responses feel authentic for someone thrust into circumstances beyond his control, showing appropriate wariness while demonstrating the engineering mindset that got him into this situation. The political intrigue unfolds naturally through conversation, avoiding heavy exposition dumps while still conveying the complex web of competing interests. The Azra Stability Accord and the various factions (Jovian Bloc, Charterists, etc.) feel like natural extensions of current geopolitical tensions projected into a space-faring future. However, the piece occasionally veers toward overly elaborate descriptions that slow the pacing. Some metaphors feel forced ("like an equation reaching its inevitable conclusion") and certain dialogue exchanges become slightly wooden in their precision. The ending, while dramatically appropriate, comes together perhaps too neatly - Arthur's transformation from reluctant participant to someone making demands feels somewhat rushed. The world-building occasionally becomes intrusive, with technical details and faction names that could overwhelm readers not fully invested in the universe. Some dialogue serves primarily expository functions rather than advancing character development or emotional stakes. The piece succeeds in creating genuine tension and establishing meaningful stakes that extend beyond the immediate characters to solar system-wide consequences. The hints about Azra's potentially non-natural origins provide intriguing setup for future developments. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 9 Overwrought: 8 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m the one who kills the lights. I like the way people hesitate right after—the breath before someone hits the red switch. Most of them fumble. I do it like I own the dark. Click. The overhead fluorescents surrender. The room blooms into red. Shadows flatten, edges soften, and everybody looks a little unreal, like we’re all halfway between bodies and negatives, waiting to be fixed. It’s just us in here tonight. Final project crunch. The lab tech left twenty minutes ago with a “Lock up when you’re done, yeah?” tossed in my direction, not Elliot’s. Fair. He’s standing at the enlarger, long black sweater sleeves pushed up, silver ring glinting as he fiddles with the focus. His nails are painted chipped black; there’s a tiny ink smudge at the corner of his mouth. His hair is this black, slightly messy thing that keeps falling into his eyes. He brushes it back with the same carefulness he uses on his prints. Elliot doesn’t so much occupy space as haunt it. Quiet, intentional. Observing. Seemingly allergic to taking up more than his share. “You sure about that exposure?” I ask, coming up beside him. He tilts his head, considering. “Pretty sure.” “Pretty sure is for undergrads,” I tease, bumping his shoulder with mine. “Oh, wait.” He huffs a laugh, soft and startled, like I’ve pulled it right out of him. “Be nice, Dani.” “I’m extremely nice.” “That’s not your reputation.” “Oh?” I lean in, absurdly pleased he even knows I have a reputation. “And what is my reputation, Elliot?” He shifts, eyes flicking up to meet mine in the red wash. They’re greener in this light. “Bossy,” he says, like he’s trying it out. “Intense.” “Hot,” I add. His lips twitch. “I wasn’t going to say it.” “But you thought it,” I say, like it’s fact. I want it to be fact. For months I’ve been clocking his outfits, his notebooks full of dense theory quotes, the way he disappears into himself when he’s thinking. The way I keep wanting to break into that. He clears his throat. “We’re burning time.” “Yeah, yeah. Hit it.” He flips the enlarger light. The frame we picked together—his portrait of me shot in a cracked bathroom mirror, plus my double-exposure of his hands and a city skyline—glows on the easel. Our professor called the pairing “provocative.” I think that’s code for “I don’t know why this works, but it does.” Forty seconds. I count them in my head because he always under-exposes when he’s nervous. He clicks it off and reaches for the paper. I watch his fingers. Long, precise, as he slips the sheet under the enlarger. He doesn’t look at me. He barely ever does for longer than a second. Not like other guys, the ones who stare at me like I’m another assignment to conquer. He hits the switch again. “You’re overthinking,” I say. “I’m thinking exactly the right amount,” he murmurs. “You’ve been quiet all night.” “I’m always quiet.” “Quieter,” I correct. Something passes over his face. A hesitation, coiling tight. “There’s—uh. There’s something I’ve been meaning to tell you,” he says. “If this is a confession that you secretly hate my work, I’ll throw you in the stop bath.” He smiles, quick. Nervous. “Nah,” he says. “I like your work.” It punches a stupid little hole in me. I don’t need his approval. I want it. The timer beeps. He shuts off the light. We move together, automatic, practiced: he lifts the paper; I slide the tray out. Developer sloshes. The darkroom smells like chemicals and metal and some faint ghost of his cologne, something smoky and clean. He lowers the paper in. We lean over, shoulders touching, waiting for the image to surface. “I’ve been thinking about… my work,” he says, like that’s what he planned. But there’s that tension again. “Yeah?” I swirl the tray gently. “Your work is sick. You know that.” “It’s… not just the work.” He swallows. The image starts to appear. My reflection fractured, his hands layered over my throat, the city dissolving into our skin. It’s intense, almost indecent. Vulnerable. “Okay,” I say, softer now. “What is it, then?” He stares at the emerging print like it’s safer than my face. “I’ve been…” His fingers tap the edge of the tray. “I’ve been questioning some stuff. About gender. My gender.” His voice catches on the word like it’s too sharp. A beat. The darkroom hums around us; the ventilation fans, the quiet ticking of the timer, my heart getting way too loud in my ears. “Oh,” I say. My brain goes white for a second. I’m so used to being sure. About what I want, who I want, how I like it. I build my whole thing on that: the girl who knows, the girl who leads. I’ve always liked men who are loud about being men, or women who are loud about not needing them. Defined lines. Sharp edges. And here he is, this soft, deliberate boy in my favorite boots and eyeliner thicker than mine some days, telling me he’s not sure where he lands. I look at him. Really look. His shoulders are tight, like he’s bracing for me to mock him, or worse, get weird. I feel something almost maternal and absolutely not maternal at the same time. Protective. Hungry. Curious. Cautious. “What kind of questioning?” I ask, gentle. Give him room. Don’t decide it for him. Don’t jump in and fix. “I don’t know yet,” he says quickly. “Like. I’m still okay with he/him. For now. I think. But I’ve been trying on other words in my head. Other… shapes.” The way he says it, I see it. Gender as shapes, not ladders. “I’ve always been read as this kind of skinny goth boy,” he continues. “But that never felt… complete. Lately when I look at photos of myself, I feel like there’s someone just off-frame I was supposed to be. And I can’t quite get them into focus.” I stop stirring. The image is full now, floating between us, eerie. “That makes sense,” I say. And it does. It’s weird how much it does. “Do you… want to look different? Be called something different?” “I don’t know,” he repeats, frustrated. “Sometimes I like when people see me as a guy. Sometimes I don’t care. Sometimes I wish I could blur it all out and start over.” He finally looks at me. “Is this weird?” Yes, I think. Because I’ve been constructing this private crush on you as “the soft boy I want to ruin,” and you’re standing here telling me the box I put you in doesn't fit. And instead of putting me off, it’s doing this other thing. This… deeper pull. “No,” I say, steady. “It’s not weird. Or if it’s weird, it’s good weird.” He huffs, some tightness easing. “I haven’t really said it out loud to anyone in the department.” “I’m honored,” I say. I mean it. He lifts the print with tongs and moves it to the stop bath. I grab the next sheet of paper from the stack on the table, my fingers moving on autopilot. The exposed stack. Except I’ve forgotten to close the safe light cover when we were talking, and the red bulb is bleeding right over it. I only realize when I see it: the faint, betraying sheen on the top page. Shit. “Wait—” I say. Too late. I’ve already lifted the lid, already peeled off the next sheet. I freeze. Elliot follows my gaze to the stack. “Oh,” he says. “Oh no.” We both know it at the same time. The safe light’s angle, how long it’s been. The paper’s toast. “Goddammit,” I mutter. He reaches past me, flips the cover down like he can undo the last ten minutes. “Sorry, was that me?” “No, I left it open,” I say immediately. “My fault.” “You were talking to me.” “That’s not an excuse. I know better.” I grab the top sheet and run it through the developer anyway, because sometimes it’s not that bad. The image that appears is just a murky, fogged rectangle. Ruined. I let out a short, helpless laugh. “Well. At least we catastrophically failed together.” “I can buy more paper,” Elliot says quickly. “It was my side, I should’ve—” “Relax.” I put a hand on his wrist. Warm. Thin. He goes very still. “It’s on the school. We’ll steal from the 101 kids.” He smiles a little, but his gaze flicks from my hand to my face. I feel suddenly aware of every point of contact. My brain, the traitor, imagines lacing our fingers. I let go. I don’t want to spook him. Don’t want to be the older student making moves on the confused nineteen-year-old who just entrusted me with his guts. “Thanks for telling me,” I say, backing up, busying my hands with the ruined paper. “About the… shapes.” He leans on the counter, watching me. “I was worried you’d think it made me less…” “Less what?” “Less of what you like,” he says, so quietly I almost miss it. The air between us shifts. My heart trips. “Excuse me?” He flushes, the red light deepening it. “Sorry, that was—fuck. I just. You’re… obvious, Dani.” I stare. “About what?” “You flirt,” he says, like he’s revealing something, not just describing my entire personality. “With me. Sometimes. I thought I was imagining it, but…” My mouth is suddenly dry. This is where I’d usually grin, step forward, pin it down. Say: yeah, and? What are you gonna do about it? Instead I hear myself say, “And if you weren’t imagining it?” He chews his lip. “Then I didn’t want you to feel like you were flirting with the wrong… format.” The choice of word hits me right in the chest. Format. Like he’s a file that might need converting. I take a breath. “Hey,” I say. “There isn’t a wrong format.” He looks skeptical. “You’ve said you’re into… guys. Before. Masculine guys.” I wince internally, remembering drunken critiques, my big mouth. “I’m into confidence,” I say. “Intensity. People who are trying to make themselves on purpose. That’s what I meant.” He looks at me like he’s trying to decide if I’m just being kind. “And you,” I add, feeling reckless and careful at the same time, “are very much my type.” “That’s before you knew I was a gender-questioning disaster,” he says. I step closer. Not all the way. Just close enough that he can step back if he wants. “You’re not a disaster. You’re an experiment,” I say. “I like experiments.” He laughs, a real one this time. “That’s messed up.” “A little,” I agree. “Do you want me to dial it back?” He blinks. “Dial what back?” “The flirting,” I say. The control freak in me hates putting it out there like that, handing it to him. “If you’re feeling weird or… objectified or whatever, I can stop.” He looks at me so long I start to regret being earnest. “No,” he says finally. “Don’t stop.” There’s a tremor in it, but it’s decided. Heat unfurls low in my stomach. My instinct roars: take this, run with it, push him gently against the sink, taste the fixer on his lips. I don’t. “Okay,” I say instead. “Then we take it slow. On your terms. You’re driving.” “I don’t know how to drive,” he protests. “Perfect,” I say. “I’ll just work the pedals.” He snorts. “That’s not how cars work.” “It’s how this one works,” I say, then soften it with, “Seriously. You set the pace. If you want to tell me to chill, you say it. I can take orders, shocking as that is.” He tilts his head, studying me like a new composition. “I want to kiss you,” he says, almost whispered. “But I also don’t know who I’m going to be in six months.” My chest aches. “Good thing we’re not carving it in stone tonight,” I say. “We’re just in the dark, ruining photo paper.” He smiles, small and luminous. “Can I… think about it?” “Yeah,” I say, relieved I’ve managed not to wreck this. “Think as long as you want.” He nods, and there’s this charged quiet between us. Not empty—full. Possibility humming like the safelight. We start over with fresh paper from a different box, more careful now. Our hands brush sometimes. He doesn’t pull away. Neither do I. Under the red glow, our images slowly appear: split selves, blurred lines, bodies overlapping. He watches them form like he’s searching for that off-frame self in every grain. I watch him. For once, I don’t rush the process.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates sophisticated handling of a delicate subject matter with genuine emotional authenticity. The author creates a vivid darkroom setting that serves both as literal workspace and metaphorical space for vulnerability and self-discovery. The red light atmosphere is expertly utilized to create intimacy and otherworldliness that supports the narrative's themes of identity fluidity and uncertain boundaries. The characterization is particularly strong. Dani's voice is consistent throughout - assertive, confident, yet genuinely caring when faced with Elliot's vulnerability. Her internal conflict between her usual take-charge approach and her desire to give Elliot agency feels authentic and well-developed. Elliot's tentative exploration of gender identity is handled with sensitivity and specificity, avoiding both cliche and oversimplification. The dialogue feels natural and age-appropriate, capturing the awkwardness and tentative chemistry between the characters. Lines like "You're not a disaster. You're an experiment" and "Good thing we're not carving it in stone tonight" demonstrate genuine wit while advancing character development and theme. The pacing is well-controlled, building tension through small moments - the ruined photo paper serves as an effective metaphor for imperfection and unexpected outcomes. The author resists rushing toward physical intimacy, instead focusing on emotional connection and consent, which feels mature and appropriate to the characters' situation. The prose generally flows well with strong imagery, particularly in the darkroom descriptions. However, there are occasional moments where the writing becomes slightly overwrought ("It punches a stupid little hole in me") though these are minor compared to the overall quality. The ending achieves genuine emotional resonance without forcing false resolution. The uncertainty about their future relationship mirrors Elliot's gender questioning, and both feel authentic rather than contrived. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 83.7
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The near-collision happened in a blur of chrome and paper. Ben stepped sideways, nose buried in a guidebook paragraph about the Baroque symbolism of the Trevi Fountain, when a horn screamed and hot exhaust whipped his bare calves. The motorcycle skidded, kissed his hip, and a stack of glossy envelopes exploded at his feet. “Cristo—ma sei cieco?” the rider snapped, boots grinding on the cobblestones as she kicked down the stand. Ben stumbled, clutching his guidebook to his chest like a shield. “I—sorry—sorry, I didn’t—” She yanked off her helmet in a single furious motion, curls spilling out, eyes dark and blazing. Her motorcycle was lean and scratched—one particular dent on the side glowed with an almost deliberate streak of color, like someone had attacked it with a paintbrush of turquoise and magenta. “Guarda dove cammini!” she said, voice sharp, breath fast. “I was just reading about the, um, fountain,” Ben said, his accent chewing the vowels. “I didn’t hear—” “Of course you didn’t hear, professorino, you read.” Her gaze raked him quickly—plain t-shirt, sensible shorts, scruffy sneakers, a canvas bag heavy with books. “You British?” He blinked. “Yes. Is it that obvious?” “Like sun on mozzarella,” she muttered, then fired off more Italian, gesturing at the envelopes strewn across the ground. He bent quickly. “I can help you pick these up.” “No no, please, let me risk my deadlines alone,” she shot back, but she scooped papers too, fast and efficient. A glossy tourist map ended up under his shoe; he lifted it, embarrassed. He handed her a stack. Their fingers brushed. A small static shock jumped between them; he jerked, she didn’t. Her mouth twitched. “Tranquillo, non mordo.” I don’t bite. “I caught some of that,” Ben said. “You, um, don’t murder?” “Bite,” she corrected, amused despite herself. “Maybe also murder. Depends.” A reluctant thread of laughter tugged at his chest. “Well. I am very sorry, Ms…?” “Alessandra,” she said. “Courier. Hazard of my job: tourists and pigeons.” “Ben,” he offered. “Visiting researcher. Hazard of my job: footnotes.” He nodded at her bike. “It’s, uh, beautiful. Like a very fast, very angry… horse.” She stared. Then a bright, surprised laugh escaped her. “Madonna. You are so… polite.” “I could try to be less polite,” he said, cheeks pink. “Don’t hurt yourself.” She jammed the envelopes back into her bag with one practiced shove. Then her eyes snagged on his guidebook. “So. You come to Rome to read about fountains in front of the fountains?” “I like context,” he said. “And I’m on sabbatical. Six months.” He regretted the last two words the second they left his mouth; her attention sharpened. “Six months,” she repeated. “Plenty of time to die under a Vespa.” “Motorcycle,” he corrected before he could stop himself. Her brows shot up. “You correct me? I almost kill you and you correct me?” But there was a spark now, not anger—something livelier. He swallowed. “Occupational hazard of academia.” For a second, silence. Rome rushed around them: coins flying into blue water, cameras chirping, someone arguing about gelato flavors. Alessandra’s gaze softened, very slightly. “You have seen anything real today, Professor Ben?” she asked. “I got lost near a Zara and ended up at a Sephora,” he admitted. “Does that count?” This time her laughter was unrestrained, clear and delighted. “No. That is hell, not Rome.” She swung her leg over the motorcycle, hands on the handlebars. The engine rumbled awake beneath her, a growl that seemed to belong to her body as much as the machine. “Wait,” Ben blurted. “I… I am very sorry. Again.” “Mm.” She tilted her head, studying him. “Buy me a coffee.” “What?” “For the near accident,” she said. “You make me late. You fix my mood.” “I—of course,” he said. “I’d be happy to.” She jerked her chin. “Salita di San Nicola. Five minutes. If you find it, you are not hopeless. Se ti perdi, è destino.” He opened his mouth to ask for directions, but she twisted the throttle. The bike shot forward, the colored dent flashing in the sun like an old wound or a badge of honor, and she vanished into the crush of traffic. He looked down at his guidebook, then at the swirling crowd, and exhaled. “Right,” he murmured. “Trial by espresso.” He didn’t see—no one did—the slight, practiced motion as she sped off: Alessandra’s fingers flicking, a glossy tourist postcard disappearing from a nearby stall and sliding up under her jacket. — He found the café in seven. She was leaning against the wall outside: helmet under one arm, cigarette dangling unlit from her lips, scrolling her phone. The motorcycle idled at the curb, vibrating impatiently. “You’re late,” she said, though he wasn’t. “You said five minutes. You didn’t specify Italian minutes.” Her mouth curved: point to him. “Bravo.” She pushed off the wall. “Caffè. And nothing with syrups, or I drive you back to the airport.” Inside, the place was slender and local, full of quick conversations and metal chinks. Ben hovered, alien among the rooted. “What are you having?” he asked. “Caffè.” She looked at his hesitation. “You?” “I, uh, usually have a latte.” “At four in the afternoon?” She grimaced theatrically. “Tourist crime. Due caffè,” she told the barista before he could defend himself. He fumbled for his wallet. She had already paid. “You said I’d buy,” he protested. “Too slow.” She downed the coffee in two swallows. “Consider it an investment.” “In what?” Her eyes lit with mischief. “In your education.” They stepped back into the pale Roman sun. She tucked the cigarette behind her ear without lighting it. “So,” she said. “You study what?” “Classical literature. Translation. I’m working on a… fairly niche Latin poet.” “You come to Rome to sit in library. Tragedia.” She slid her helmet on. “Get on.” He blinked. “Oh. No, no, that’s—” “Inglese,” she said, leaning close so he could hear the smile in her voice, “if I wanted you dead, I would have done it at the fountain.” He hesitated one heartbeat too long. She rolled her eyes, grabbed his wrist, and tugged him toward the bike with surprising strength. “Do you have an extra helmet?” he asked, alarmed. “That is a very cute question,” she said. “Climb on.” “This is… Is this legal?” “In Rome,” she said, “nothing is legal. Only traditional.” He swung his leg over, awkward, trying not to touch too much of her. The bike shifted under their combined weight. “You have to hold,” she said. “I cannot risk losing you in traffic. Paperwork.” He put his hands cautiously on the sides of her jacket. She snorted, reached back, and yanked his arms tighter around her waist. “Oh,” he said, softly. “You good?” she called. “No,” he said. “Yes. Go.” She did. — Rome became a fever dream at thirty-five kilometers an hour. Alessandra wove through lanes as if the city belonged to her, slipping between buses and Fiats, up narrow streets, past laundry-strung balconies and shrines with chipped Madonnas. The colored dent in the tank caught the light, a flash at the edge of his vision. Ben clung on, helmetless, every law-abiding neuron in him screaming. And yet—he was laughing. She could feel it, the way his chest shook against her back. “You trust me?” she shouted over her shoulder. “Absolutely not!” he yelled, grinning. “Perfetto!” They stopped on a hill under the pines, Rome spread beneath them in fading gold. “Gianicolo,” she said, swinging off the bike. “Better than your guidebook?” He slid off, legs jelly. “Significantly fewer footnotes.” She walked to the low wall, looking out at domes and roofs. Without turning, she asked, “Why are you really here, Ben?” He joined her. “Sixteen years of doing exactly what I’m supposed to,” he said slowly. “Teaching the same texts. Writing polite articles. I thought if I came here I’d feel… something I used to feel.” “And? You feel?” He looked at her. Dark curls, leather jacket, the ghost of a cigarette behind her ear. Oil on her fingers where she’d touched the chain. A small paper square peeked from her pocket—the postcard she’d lifted earlier—its corner bright. “Yes,” he said. “Terrified.” She laughed, and for a moment it was soft, almost kind. “Come,” she said. “More.” — Trastevere: chaos in warm alleys, smoke and basil and sweat. Alessandra carved a path through the crowds; Ben trailed behind like a conscientious balloon. She stole moments as they went—a sip from someone’s abandoned spritz, a cherry tomato speared quick from a passing antipasto plate, the lighter off a table (later flicked and returned to a different one with a wink). Ben caught only fragments: her hand lingering on surfaces, a vanished object, her blank-angel expression that never fooled him entirely. At a tiny bar lit in amber, she introduced him to amaro. “It’s like drinking medicinal despair,” he said, coughing. “That’s Fernet. This is poetry,” she said. “Again.” He tried again. It burned less. “You always do this?” he asked. “Pick up strange men you almost run over?” “Only the ones with ridiculous guidebooks,” she said. “And sabbaticals. And death wish in their eyes.” “I do not have a death wish.” “You got on the bike.” Her gaze held his. “You trust easy for a man with rules.” “Maybe I’m tired of rules.” She tilted her head, evaluating him with sudden seriousness. His openness tugged at her; she pushed the feeling away with a smirk. “Careful,” she said. “Rome listens. She gives you what you ask for. Then takes double.” He wanted to ask what she’d lost, what the colorful dent on her bike meant, why her eyes sometimes went distant between jokes. Instead he said, “I’m taking my chances.” She slid off the stool. “Then one more stop.” — Dusk bled into night; they were near Termini now, less postcard, more grit. Ben recognized, on a delay, that this wasn’t quite the Rome his guidebook suggested at sunset. Neon flickered. A street vendor argued with a cop. A guy screamed laughing into his phone. The air smelled of fried dough and exhaust and something sharper. “Alessandra,” he said quietly, “are we, um… meant to be here?” She smiled without looking at him. “You scared?” “A bit,” he admitted. “Good. Means you alive.” She led him into a cramped, fluorescent-lit tabacchi. While Ben tried to pay for a bottle of water and fumbled with the coins, Alessandra slid three cheap plastic keychains from the counter—mini Colosseums—and palmed them. The movement was fluid, unnecessary, thrilling. Outside, she pressed one into his hand. “For you,” she said. He frowned down at it. “Did you… buy this?” Her eyes were all innocence. “Of course.” He watched her for a long moment. She held his gaze, letting him see just enough. Not an admission. Not a denial. “That’s… illegal,” he said softly. “Only a little,” she murmured. “You going to arrest me, professorino?” He swallowed. “No.” “Then you are complice.” Accomplice. The word hung between them, unexpectedly intimate. A siren wailed nearby; he flinched. She didn’t. “Relax,” she said, brushing his arm once, quick. “You are safe with me.” He believed her. That scared him more than the siren. — Later, by the river, Rome hummed low and secretive. They sat on the worn stone embankment, the motorcycle resting above them. The colored dent caught stray streetlight: bruise, halo, story untold. Ben’s shoulders ached pleasantly; his head was light from sun and alcohol and velocity. Alessandra dangled her boots over the edge, watching the black water. “You are quiet finally,” she said. “I’m trying to absorb,” he said. “Today has been… unsanctioned.” “Good word.” She nudged him with her knee. “Tomorrow you go back to your library?” “I’m supposed to.” He hesitated. “What about you? More deliveries?” “Always,” she said. “People need their things. I bring. Sometimes I keep.” He caught that. “You what?” She smirked. “Joke.” “I’m not entirely convinced.” “Keep wondering,” she said. “It looks good on you.” “So this was entertainment for you?” he asked, but there was no accusation, just curiosity. “Picking up a lost academic and tossing him around Rome?” “Maybe,” she said. “You make funny faces. I was bored.” He nodded, gaze dropping to his stolen keychain. “Well. Thank you for alleviating your boredom.” “Prego.” Silence, but charged now. The city’s sounds muffled; time thinned. “You were different on the bike,” she said, more thoughtful. “Less… folded.” “I didn’t have time to overthink,” he said. “You kept nearly killing us.” Her smile was small, approving. “This is good for you.” “And you?” he asked. “What’s good for you, Alessandra?” Her jaw flexed. “Moving,” she said finally. “Not stopping.” He heard the refusal behind it. He let it be. “What happens now?” he asked. “Is this where my wild Roman day concludes and I go back to my safe hotel and read about obelisks?” She considered him, tapping her fingers against the stone. He held her gaze but didn’t push. At last, she stood. “You remember where you stay?” “Near Piazza Navona.” “Tourist central, certo.” She jerked her head toward the bike. “I take you.” He rose, a little too quickly. “I could walk.” “Boring,” she said. “One more illegal ride. Last gift.” “Complice,” he said under his breath. She heard. Smiled. — The ride back was slower. Night wrapped them in warm air and scooter lights. Ben rested against her more naturally now, no apologetic stiffness, his chin close to her shoulder. The city blurred to strokes of gold and shadow. At his street, she stopped. Engine idling. They didn’t move. “Thank you,” he said, reluctant. “For today.” “Don’t thank me too much,” she said. “You survive, that is already miracle.” “I meant it,” he insisted. She turned slightly, enough that he could see the gleam in her eyes. “Careful, professorino. Rome is dangerous.” “I’m starting to hope so.” That surprised her. It flickered across her face: a crack in the game. She reached up, and for a second he thought she might touch his cheek. Instead she hooked a finger in the collar of his shirt and tugged him a fraction closer. “You want more dangerous,” she murmured, “come back to Trevi tomorrow. Eleven.” He exhaled. “Is that… an invitation?” “It’s a possibility,” she said. “I like possibilities.” She let him go. “Or you go to your library. Very safe. Very… folded.” “And if I come?” She smiled slow, unreadable. “Then we see how much trouble you can be.” He stood there as she pulled away, colored dent flashing once under the streetlights. No postcard farewell, no dramatic promise. Just exhaust and the echo of her laughter. Ben looked down at the cheap plastic Colosseum in his hand and realized his heart was beating too fast. “Right,” he murmured to the Roman night. “Trial by espresso, part two.” He did not open his guidebook that evening.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong craft in executing a contemporary romance premise through interconnected scenes across a single day in Rome. The writer successfully captures the cultural clash between Alessandra, the fiery Roman motorcycle courier, and Ben, the reserved British academic, while building genuine chemistry through their contrasting personalities. The characterization is particularly effective. Alessandra emerges as authentically complex - her kleptomania is woven subtly throughout rather than stated outright, manifesting in deft moments like stealing the postcard, cherry tomato, and keychains. Ben's transformation from bumbling academic to someone willing to embrace risk feels organic, driven by genuine attraction to Alessandra's freedom rather than forced plot mechanics. The dialogue crackles with authenticity, capturing Ben's awkward politeness ("I could try to be less polite") against Alessandra's sharp wit ("Like sun on mozzarella"). The prose quality is consistently high, with vivid sensory details that immerse the reader in Rome without becoming overwrought. Phrases like "the near-collision happened in a blur of chrome and paper" and "Rome became a fever dream at thirty-five kilometers an hour" efficiently establish mood and movement. The writer shows impressive restraint, allowing tension to build through action and subtext rather than excessive exposition. The structure works well, moving through distinct scenes that each serve character development while maintaining narrative momentum. The motorcycle rides provide natural opportunities for physical intimacy and metaphorical liberation. The pacing feels natural, building from initial antagonism through growing attraction to a satisfying but open ending. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the "uptight academic loosened up by free spirit" dynamic is well-worn territory, though executed skillfully here. The Rome setting, while evocatively rendered, occasionally borders on tourist-brochure territory with its fountain/hills/Trastevere progression. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - romantic tension is established without rushing into unrealistic declarations, and Ben's transformation feels earned through the day's experiences rather than artificially imposed. The final image of him holding the stolen keychain effectively symbolizes his willing complicity in Alessandra's world. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.5
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The stranger’s tentacles drip asteroid dust onto my bar. “Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double.” Voice low, roughened, like they’ve been breathing unfiltered freon. “I can do that,” I say. “And I can do it without the dust garnish, if you like.” They blink; lidless, translucent membranes slide sideways over pale green eyes. Four thick head-tentacles twitch, slowly unkinking from panic into something like embarrassment. “Yeah. No dust,” they murmur. “Please.” Polite. That’s one point in their favor. I reach for the Vega, third shelf up: squat cobalt bottle with a chip in the neck. As I pour, I clock the stranger’s clothes—black flight leathers, pressure-suit lining visible at the wrist, one sleeve scorched. Their left glove is missing. Burn marks kiss the bare skin. The faint smell of ionized metal clings to them like a second atmosphere. “You look like you got in a fight with an engine,” I say. They try on a smile. It doesn’t fit. “Engine won.” “Condolences,” I say, and slide the double over. Their fingers—three long, jointed, faintly luminous—wrap around the glass. They knock back half in a swallow, hiss softly, then exhale. The tentacles slump. The Last Outpost hums around us, lazy and familiar. Low asteroid gravity gives everyone an extra sway. Miners in dust-streaked fatigues crowd the left rail, arguing about claim markers in three languages. A cluster of merchants occupies the lounge alcove, screens floating above the table as they haggle over refinery rates. In the back booth, the two resident gamblers, Jex and Orla, flip cards with magnetic edges that cling and snap. The constant deep thrum of the station’s spin coupling pulses under my boots like a comfortable heartbeat. Someone laughs too loud near the holo-darts. Someone curses at the jukebox panel. And at the far end of the bar— The sharp, unmistakable sound of shattering glass cuts through everything. I don’t flinch. My shoulders go tight, sure, but I keep my face neutral. “Rook,” I call, without looking. “You break it, you buy it.” “It slipped!” Rook protests. He’s nineteen, maybe twenty today, all elbows and optimism, halfway into a mining rig still tagged from his last shift. “The gravity hiccupped.” “The gravity didn’t hiccup,” I say. “You did. Inventory’s on your tab.” Grumbling. A broom starts its lazy, grating scrape. The stranger watches all this with a tired kind of alertness. Cataloguing exits, counting heads. Classic signs. I’ve done that scan myself a thousand times. “You new to the Belt?” I ask. They study me over what’s left of the Vega. “Just passing through.” “Everybody’s just passing through,” I reply. “Until they’re not.” That gets the ghost of a real smile. “Nets, right?” My fingers tense around the bar rag. “Who’s asking?” “Nobody important,” they say quickly, raising their free hand. “Just… word gets around. Bartender at the Last Outpost. Good with people. Better with secrets.” My pulse stutters. I do a smooth pivot to the tap, start pulling a pint for Ledo down the way just to keep my hands busy. “Word should mind its own business,” I say lightly. “Sometimes word needs help,” the stranger says. “Name’s Kesh.” No surname. Of course. “Alright, Nobody Important Kesh,” I say. “Second round?” “I shouldn’t,” they say. “But yes.” I pour, slower this time. “So. You need help, or is this just a fan visit? I don’t sign autographs.” They hesitate. There. The micro-flinch. “I—look,” Kesh says. “I’m not trying to cause trouble.” “Everyone who says that is absolutely about to cause trouble,” I say. They breathe out through their teeth. “Okay. I might be… adjacent to trouble. But I’m here to avoid it, swear on my ship’s rotting hull.” Behind them, the holo-screen above the back bar cycles from soft nebula views to traffic bulletins. Green icons pulse in the corridor map. Docking clamps, comm pings, inbound manifests. All normal. “You got a ship,” I say. “Had,” Kesh mutters. “Condolences, again.” I rest my elbows on the bar. The rag hangs off my hand like a truce flag. “Talk.” Their eyes flick to the nearest miners—Gerva’s crew, exhausted and half-drunk—and back. “Can we not broadcast this?” Kesh asks, lowering their voice. “This?” I echo, and turn up the music half a notch with a heel-tap to the control pad under the bar. The jukebox obliges with an old Andromedan ballad. “Congratulations, we’re private. For certain values of private.” They down half the second drink in a swallow. Those tentacles curl tight at the base, then slowly relax. “I was running a courier job,” Kesh says. “Outer ring to the rim. Standard no-questions crate. Thought it was corp contraband, worst case. Smuggling mining processors, maybe. Boring things that justify a bonus.” “And?” “And then I get flagged on approach,” they say. “Not by station control. By a cruiser with its transponder scrambled to hell. They ordered me to shut down engines and prepare to be boarded.” “Pirates?” I ask. “If they’re pirates, they’ve got military-grade stuff,” Kesh says. “They knew my cargo tag. They knew my route. Somebody paid serious credits to find me.” The hair on my arms rises. “And you came here.” “It was the closest rock with a bar,” Kesh says, managing a small shrug. “I dumped the crate in an ice cluster and burned hard. They followed for a while, then peeled off. If they pick up the crate, they’ll know I ditched it. If they track my trail, they’ll clock your station.” “Comforting,” I mutter. “I just need a few hours,” Kesh says. “To arrange a ride out, send a dead-drop, vanish. I figured big busy hub, easy to blend.” “This is the Last Outpost,” I say. “We’re about as big as a generous cupboard. And I don’t like people bringing their heat into my cupboard.” “I didn’t have anywhere else to go,” they say quietly. I look at them. Really look. The scorched sleeve. The bare hand. The sagging lines of someone running on fumes and fear. “What was in the crate, Kesh?” I ask. They look away. “No-questions courier,” I remind them. “But that ship didn’t look like a ‘we misfiled your kitchen appliances’ retrieval team.” Kesh’s voice drops. “Bio-something. Small. Shielded. I tried to scan it, it scrambled my boards. The pickup code wasn’t corp, wasn’t guild. Felt… wrong. So I skimmed the bonus, planned to ditch the job.” “Word gets around,” I say, echoing their earlier line. “Yeah.” Their mouth twists. “Guess it does.” The holo-screen above us flickers. A subtle glitch, one frame of static in a sea of smooth ads. My gut twists. Behind me, the station’s low hum stutters, like a held breath. It resumes so quickly most people won’t even register it. I do. “Nets?” Rook calls nervously from down the bar. “Did you feel—” “Probably you dropping another glass in spirit,” I say. “Keep sweeping.” He grins, reassured. I am not reassured. “Listen,” Kesh says. “I know you don’t owe me anything. But if those people track me here and think I know where their toy is, I’m a corpse. And if they think anyone here helped me—” “They won’t like you either,” I finish. “They really won’t,” Kesh says. I pour myself a finger of Vega. I don’t drink on shift. Not anymore. I take a sip anyway. It burns a clean line from tongue to gut. “So your plan is to sit at my bar and hope your ghost cruiser loses interest,” I say. “My plan was to call in a favor with a freighter captain named Torv,” they say. “He runs ore loads out past the rim. Owes me two lifetimes.” “Torv’s in dock three, refueling,” I say automatically, then hate that I’ve admitted I know ship rosters that well. Kesh’s eyes sharpen. “So you’ll let me talk to him.” “I didn’t say that.” “You didn’t say no,” they counter. “Yet.” We hold each other’s gaze. The jukebox croons. Rook’s broom scrapes. Someone whoops at a winning hand. Life at the Outpost breathing in and out. The holo-screen glitches again. This time it’s obvious: the traffic map blinks, icons reconfiguring. A new red wedge appears at the edge. An unscheduled inbound. Transponder: scrambled. I swallow. Kesh sees my eyes move, turns slowly to look. Color drains from their face. “That’s them,” they whisper. “Could be anyone,” I say. The red wedge pings a handshake at the station. The comm text scrolls at the bottom of the holo in crisp, impersonal glyphs that translate themselves for anyone paying attention: PRIORITY DOCK REQUEST. ENFORCEMENT MATTERS. COMPLIANCE REQUIRED. “Enforcement,” I say. “They’re claiming to be legal.” “They’re not,” Kesh says. “I know their drive signature.” “Of course you do,” I murmur. My boss, Jaila, appears in the archway from the corridor. All sharp angles and silver hair, her expression unreadable as she takes in the holo, the bar, me, Kesh. “Nettle,” she says. It’s never Nets with her. “We have incoming officials with questions.” “Do we?” I ask. “Lucky us.” Her gaze flicks to Kesh, lingers on the scorched sleeve, then returns to me. “Handle your end,” she says softly. “Don’t make me regret my hospitality.” She disappears back into the flow of people. Kesh is breathing too fast. “If they scan, they’ll see trace from my engines. If they ask around—” “They’ll hear you ordered a double Vega and tipped poorly,” I say. They blink. “I haven’t tipped yet.” “I noticed,” I say. A corner of their mouth twitches despite everything. I lean closer, voice dropping. “You brought this down on my bar, Kesh. On my people. You lied about the size of the target on your back.” “I didn’t know they’d follow this far in,” they say. “I thought dumping the crate would—” “People don’t throw away expensive toys,” I cut in. “They chase.” On the holo, the red wedge locks to Dock Two. The station hum shifts as clamps extend. In the corner, Rook abandons the broom to stare at the screen. “Hey, Nets,” he calls. “We expecting Enforcement?” “No,” I say, a beat too late. The air changes. It’s subtle, but I’ve lived in dens like this my whole life. Conversations stutter, then fragment. Miners glance at doors. Merchants close tabs. The Last Outpost, lazy heartbeat, holds for a second, listening. I reach under the bar, fingers brushing the small, illegal jammer I swore I’d never use again. “Kesh,” I say. “You finish that drink. You go have your chat with Torv. You do not talk to anyone in a uniform, fake or otherwise.” “And if they ask for me?” Kesh whispers. “I haven’t decided yet,” I say. Their eyes search my face. “Decide fast.” I look around my bar. My cupboard. My almost-home. The holo over us flashes a final time, resolving into a live feed from Dock Two: an angular black ship kissing the station’s hull, markings scrubbed, guns not quite hidden. The clamps engage with a heavy, echoing thud. The station shivers. I take another sip of Vega and set the glass down very, very carefully. “Rook,” I say, not looking away from the holo. “Mop up that broken glass. We’re about to have company.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt requirements, delivering a compelling opening chapter in first-person present tense with approximately 60% dialogue as requested. The author successfully establishes the cozy sci-fi atmosphere of The Last Outpost while introducing meaningful conflict without resolution. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Nets emerges as a fully realized protagonist with a clear voice - competent, wary, protective of her adopted home, with hints of a troubled past. Her dialogue feels natural and reveals character efficiently. Kesh is effectively portrayed as desperate but not helpless, with believable alien physical characteristics that enhance rather than overshadow the human drama. The worldbuilding strikes an excellent balance between specificity and restraint. Details like "magnetic edges that cling and snap" for cards, the "spin coupling" heartbeat of the station, and the casual multi-species environment create immersion without overwhelming exposition. The author demonstrates strong craft in weaving background details naturally into the narrative flow. Dialogue carries much of the story's weight effectively, revealing character relationships, advancing plot, and building tension. The banter between Nets and her patrons, particularly with Rook, establishes the cozy atmosphere while her exchanges with Kesh build suspense. The conversations feel authentic to the space-bar setting. The escalating tension is well-constructed, moving from Kesh's initial appearance through revelations about the mysterious cargo to the arrival of the pursuing ship. The author maintains mystery about both Nets' past and the true nature of the threat, creating multiple layers of intrigue. The prose is generally clean and effective, though occasionally ventures into slightly overwrought territory with phrases like "burns a clean line from tongue to gut." However, these instances are rare and don't significantly detract from the overall quality. Minor weaknesses include some predictable story beats (mysterious stranger brings trouble to sanctuary) and a few moments where the pacing slightly slows. The piece also relies somewhat heavily on familiar sci-fi bar tropes, though it executes them competently. The ending effectively sets up future conflict while maintaining the chapter structure requested. The atmosphere remains cozy despite mounting tension, successfully balancing the genre requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16

+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 85.7
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The guy who dumped me out of his truck has one of those sunburned necks that looks like it smells like gasoline and chewing tobacco. It’s not fair to stereotype people’s necks, but here we are. I hit the pavement with a grunt and my backpack thuds beside me. The heat slaps me a second later—humid, aggressive, like Tennessee August but with better food smells. Everything is loud: car horns, people yelling, some drunk guy laughing, and over all of it, this saxophone—low and sultry, weaving in and out like it’s narrating my bad decisions. “New Orleans,” the driver grunts. “Last stop, kid. Out.” “I have a name,” I say, already out. He’s not worth correcting, but I do it anyway. “It’s Taylor.” He shrugs; the truck door slams. He’s gone before the light changes. I stand there, hugging my backpack straps, pretending like this—getting dropped in a random city two states away with sixty-three dollars and a half-dead phone—is exactly what I planned. It’s not the stupidest thing I’ve ever done, but it’s definitely top three. The street’s crowded. Tourists, locals, bachelorette parties with matching pink shirts. The buildings are all old and crumbly-beautiful, iron balconies sagging under flowers and beads. The air smells like sugar, beer, cigarettes, and something frying in butter. The saxophone comes from the corner. The musician is this older Black guy in a white shirt and suspenders, eyes closed, cheeks puffed as he plays. His case is open in front of him, seeded with ones and fives. People actually stop to listen. A little girl stares at him like he’s magic. The music curls around me, warm and complicated. It makes me feel like I’ve arrived somewhere real. Or like I’ve stepped into a movie where I’m the kid who’s run away from home and is about to learn Important Lessons. I hate that thought so much I almost laugh. I should be freaking out right now. Mom’s face when I said “I’m your daughter” flashes in my brain. That weird frozen smile, like the good Christian lady mask cracking but holding. My stepdad, arms crossed, jaw working like he’s chewing on my existence. The words “You’re confused” and “this is a phase” and the worst one, “You’re not doing this in my house.” I walked out with a backpack, three pairs of jeans, two shirts, my binder, hormone info printout (not that I’ve gotten that far), and sixty-three dollars I’d been saving for a guitar. They didn’t stop me. So that’s an answer, right? The saxophone hits a high, aching note that feels too on-the-nose. “Watch your pockets,” a voice beside me says. I flinch. It’s a kid around my age—maybe seventeen, maybe eighteen, sharp shoulders under a faded denim jacket with hand-stitched patches. They’re slim, messy dark hair shoving into their eyes, a silver ring hooked through one eyebrow. They’re holding a giant plastic cup of something bright red and entirely illegal-looking if they’re underage. There’s a backpack slung over one shoulder, straps fraying. Their boots are unlaced. They nod towards the crowd. “Tourist central. Easy pickings. Not all of ’em friendly.” “I’m not a tourist,” I say. Their eyes flick over me. Jeans, flannel, too-big sneakers, backpack, anxiety aura. They raise an eyebrow ring. “Okay, Tennessee.” My heart stutters. “How did you—?” “Accent,” they say. “And the trucker cologne. I’m Avery.” Avery. Gender vibe: yes. Also: trouble. I tell myself to walk away. Mom’s voice in my head: You attract weirdos, Taylor. Then I remind myself Mom’s opinion is now officially in the dumpster fire category. “Taylor,” I say. “Local?” Avery asks, lips quirking, like they already know the answer. “Got here five minutes ago.” “Damn. Fresh off the truck.” They say it like I’m produce. “You got a place?” I hesitate. Rule one of not getting murdered: don’t tell strangers you’re homeless. “Yeah,” I lie. “I’m good.” They clock the lie so hard it might as well be on a billboard. “Sure,” they say easily. “Cool. Enjoy the Quarter, Taylor.” They melt into the crowd, shoulders loose, cup swinging. That should be the end of it. Stranger warns me about pickpockets, calls me out, leaves. Fine. Good. I last maybe twenty seconds before moving. “Wait,” I call, pushing through a trio of sunburnt men in football jerseys. Avery half-turns, walking backward now. “Yeah?” I hate asking for help. It feels like offering your throat to someone and hoping they’re not hungry. “I, uh… don’t really have a plan,” I blurt. “I have some money. Just. If there’s somewhere that’s… not a total rip-off, that’d be cool.” Avery grins, slow and wolfish. “There it is.” “Is this where you mug me?” I ask. “If I was gonna rob you, I’d have done it already,” they say. “Come on. I’ll show you where you can breathe without paying fifteen bucks for watered-down Coke.” I follow. Because I’m an idiot. Or because I’m tired of my own fear. We slip off the main drag, away from the loud bars and souvenir shops. The saxophone fades, replaced by distant drumlines, someone blasting Beyonce out of a car, a couple arguing in fast French-accented English. “You really from Tennessee?” Avery asks. “Yeah.” “What part?” “Small town nobody’s heard of. I promise you.” “Cool.” They nod, like that explains everything. “I’m from here.-ish.” “Here-ish?” They laughs once. “Been… around. But I know the city. I know where they’ll call the cops on you for existing and where they don’t give a shit.” We cut down a narrow street strung with laundry and Christmas lights that no one took down. My brain is still buzzing: You are following a stranger. This is how people disappear. “You can bail any time,” Avery says suddenly, like they heard it. “I’m not, like, recruiting you for a cult. Unless you like, really love ska bands, then we can talk.” “Ska is not a cult,” I say automatically. “Spoken like a cult member,” they shoot back. I snort. It feels weirdly good. My chest’s been tight since I left, like my ribs have been vacuum-sealed. One dumb joke and something loosens. Avery steers us into a courtyard kind of space between buildings, half-hidden behind a leaning wooden gate. There’s a chipped fountain with no water, just cigarette butts. Two kids about our age are sitting against the wall sharing a bag of chips, and there’s a guy on milk crates tuning a beat-up guitar. It smells like weed, sweat, and gumbo from somewhere nearby. “This is…?” I say. “A place,” Avery says. “We float. Cops come through sometimes but less than up there. Sit. You look like you’re about to vibrate into thin air.” I drop onto a step. My legs ache with the sudden permission to stop. Avery flops down beside me, knees knocking mine. “So.
