You a ‘my parents suck’ runaway or a ‘I robbed a gas station’ runaway?” I stare at my hands. The cheap nail polish I put on three nights ago is chipped. I liked it. Mom did not. “Parents,” I say quietly. “Classic.” “I told them I’m trans,” I add, before I can stop myself. The word hangs there, fragile and heavy. Avery’s face shifts. The grin fades into something more careful. “Yeah?” “Yeah.” “How’d that go?” “They didn’t exactly throw me a parade,” I say. My throat tightens. I look up at the patch of sky framed by cracked walls. “I don’t know what I expected. Not that. Maybe a fight. Not just… ‘get out.’” Avery nods, looking away like they’re giving me space. “Some people don’t deserve the info,” they say. “You tell ’em the truth and they just break it.” Something in the way they say it makes me think there’s a lot they’re not saying. “You?” I ask. “You’re…” “Complicated,” they says. “Nonbinary, I guess. Some days more one way, some days the other, some days like, gender is a raccoon and it stole my keys.” “That’s not how that metaphor works,” I say. “It is in my head.” I find myself smiling. “My guidance counselor thinks I’m acting out for attention,” I say. “‘Concerning behavioural patterns.’ Her words. Like I’m a lab rat that started smoking in the maze.” “You look more like a raccoon, to be fair,” Avery says. “In a good way. Trash mammal solidarity.” “Wow. Thank you.” They bump their shoulder into mine. It’s stupid, but the contact anchors me. My phone vibrates in my pocket. For one flicker of a second, I think: Mom. Unknown number. I ignore it. “Rule one,” Avery says, nodding at my pocket. “Don’t let anyone track you if you don’t want to be found. Parents, cops, shitty exes. Turn off your location. Turn off your heart. Seal that shit.” “That’s dramatic,” I say. “Look who’s talking, Tennessee.” I pull out my phone anyway. No new texts from Mom. The last one from her is three days old: Pick up milk on your way home. That was before I detonated everything. A hole opens in my chest. “They’ll come looking,” I hear myself say. I’m not sure if it’s hope or fear. “Maybe,” Avery says. “Maybe not. Either way, right now you need to eat.” “I’m not hungry,” I start, automatic. My stomach growls so loud one of the chip kids snorts. Avery stands, dusting off their jeans. “Come on. I know a place where the lady will feed you for cheap if you look sufficiently pathetic.” “I can pay,” I say fast. I don’t want charity. “Cool,” they say. “I’ll let you. Big spender.” We walk again. The saxophone is a ghost now, just a memory threading between buildings. My head feels fuzzy. I am in New Orleans with a stranger who feels less dangerous than my own house ever did. This is insane. “Why are you helping me?” I ask. Avery shrugs, shoving their hands in their jacket pockets. “You looked like me. First night out, forever ago.” “How long?” I ask. “Long enough,” they say. “Long enough to know where not to sleep unless you like dudes twice your age touching you. Long enough to know which shelters ask too many questions. Long enough to have opinions about which alleys smell worse in the rain.” “Great,” I say. “Very comforting.” “I’m a regular Disney guide,” they says. “You staying, by the way?” “I don’t know.” Truth: I want to stay anywhere that isn’t home. Also truth: I have no idea how to live like this. Also truth: the idea of going back and pretending to be their son again makes me nauseous. We reach a tiny corner store with a fogged-up window and a hand-painted sign. Inside, the air is cool, smelling like spices and detergent. The woman behind the counter squints at Avery. “You again,” she says. “Me always,” Avery says. “This is Taylor. They’re new. We’re getting them a po’boy.” The woman’s gaze lands on me, sharp but not unkind. “You pay?” “Yes, ma’am,” I say. She nods once. “Then sit. I make. You too skinny.” Avery leans in as we sit at a little plastic table. “See? You’re already in with Miss Lena. You’re practically a local.” I exhale. It almost feels like I’ve been holding my breath since the truck door slammed. “Taylor?” Avery says more softly. “Yeah?” “You’re real, you know. Even if they pretend you’re not.” The words hit something raw. I press my tongue to my teeth to keep from crying in front of this near-stranger and the lady making sandwiches. “I know,” I lie. Or try to believe. Outside, somewhere, a saxophone picks up again. The notes slide through the city like a promise or a warning. Or both. I wrap my hands around the sweating plastic cup of water Miss Lena has set down, and think: Okay. I’m here. Don’t trust too fast. Don’t freeze. Don’t go back. And, quieter, traitor-soft: Please let this somehow be the start of something better, and not just another way everything goes south.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and emotional authenticity in depicting a transgender teen's first day as a runaway in New Orleans. The writer successfully captures Taylor's voice through a mix of vulnerability, defensive humor, and raw emotional processing that feels genuine for a 16-year-old in crisis. The characterization is particularly strong. Taylor emerges as a fully realized person - not just a collection of trauma responses, but someone with wit, observational skills, and complex feelings about their situation. The internal monologue effectively balances self-awareness with the confusion and fear of someone whose world has just collapsed. Avery is skillfully drawn as mysterious yet trustworthy, with their own implied backstory that adds depth without overwhelming Taylor's narrative. The dialogue feels natural and age-appropriate, avoiding both overly mature philosophical discussions and stereotypical teen-speak. The banter between Taylor and Avery develops their relationship organically, moving from wariness to tentative trust through small moments of humor and recognition. The setting work is excellent - New Orleans comes alive through sensory details that avoid tourist cliches while still capturing the city's unique atmosphere. The progression from the crowded French Quarter to the hidden courtyard to the corner store creates a believable journey into the city's runaway subculture. The prose strikes an effective balance between Taylor's internal voice and vivid scene-setting. Metaphors like "gender is a raccoon and it stole my keys" feel authentically teen-generated rather than imposed by the author. The writing maintains good pacing throughout, never lingering too long on any single moment. Emotionally, the piece handles heavy subject matter with appropriate gravity while finding moments of genuine connection and even humor. The ending avoids both false optimism and overwhelming despair, instead offering a realistic sense of tentative hope mixed with continued uncertainty. The piece adheres well to the prompt's requirements, delivering the requested word count, perspective, mixed tense usage, and character development within the specified timeframe. Minor weaknesses include some slightly predictable story beats (the helpful local runaway, the kind shop owner) and occasional moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly too articulate for the character's emotional state. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 79.1
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Midas woke to the gentle, plasticky snore of Chewy the animo-tronic koala and the much less gentle realization that the tent had chosen, overnight, to no longer be a tent. The desert wind had a way of negotiating complex treaties with canvas. Last night it had merely demanded a few flaps. By dawn, it had seceded entirely. Chewy lay upside down amidst the ruin, motor occasionally twitching one fluffy limb. His large, unnervingly glossy eyes stared at the pale morning sky with the expression of someone who had seen the end of the world and found it an inconvenient interruption to naptime. “Morning,” Midas muttered, levering himself out from under what used to be the doorway. Chewy responded with a tired mechanical whirr, a soft click, and then, in his pre-collapse, pre-programmed children’s entertainment voice: “Cuddle… time…” “No,” Midas said. “Respectfully, no.” The world had ended approximately twelve years back, depending on who you asked and how generous they were feeling with definitions like “ended” and “world.” The satellites had gone first, then the grids, then the screens. People had called it the Great Technological Collapse or The Big Flick-Off. Mostly, now, they called it Then. As in, “Well, back Then we had antibiotics.” Midas stretched, checked the carefully knotted bindle at his feet, and did an inventory. Knife. Rope. Two and a half protein bars of uncertain origin. Water flask. A flint with commitment issues. Chewy. Chewy, who sat up abruptly, gears grinding, and said in the cheerful tone of a mall kiosk demonstrator, “New adventure! Let’s go exploring!” “I preferred when you were encouraging hydration,” Midas said. “That felt more relevant.” Chewy’s head rotated ten degrees too far to the right. “Friends stick together,” he added, as he always did when his battery dropped below optimum and the software started misfiring. It was a phrase that had once comforted toddlers. In the wilds, it sounded mildly threatening. Across the cracked asphalt of what had once been Exit 49B, the dawn light picked out last night’s find: strip-mall ruins, graffiti curling across collapsing concrete like ivy. The message was fresh—or at least less weather-chewed than the rest. Big block letters, sprayed in shimmering green paint that caught the morning: ARK HAVEN LIVES. FOLLOW THE WILDSIGNS. ONLY THE WORTHY. Midas regarded it with the suspicion of a man who had, on three separate occasions, followed a promising sign only to find: - Once: twenty-seven feral chihuahuas. - Once: a hole. - Once: a multilevel marketing cult centered around artisanal vinegar. “The worthy,” Midas read aloud. “Oh good. We’re saved.” Chewy blinked, servos whirring. “New friends?” he asked hopefully. “Or new people trying to kill us,” Midas said. “Fifty-fifty, really.” He should have left it. Nothing good ever started with ALL CAPS graffiti and ended with a functioning water filter. But “haven” was a powerful word. The kind that got into your ribs like cold and stayed there. Midas sighed. “All right, Chewy. We’ll scout. Just look. No joining anything. No signing up. No pledges. If they start singing, we run.” Chewy’s little plush arms flexed in some relic of a “hug animation.” “Adventure buddies!” he chirped. “That’s not what I said.” They set out. The wildsigns, as it turned out, were not subtle. A series of stylized arcs and arrows appeared at irregular intervals, painted on crumbling billboards, half-buried cars, and the occasional unfortunate cow skeleton. The symbols converged toward the broken teeth of the city on the horizon. The city used to have a name. Now it was generally referred to as Don’t. “That one’s new,” Midas said, pointing to a mark sprayed over a faded pre-collapse advertisement. He squinted. The old image showed a smiling family eating something improbably colorful. The slogan read: Taste Forever. “Well,” he murmured, “they weren’t wrong.” Chewy hopped along at his side, little motor purring, one eye flickering faintly, like he was trying to wink but had forgotten step two. “Follow the arrows!” Chewy trilled. “See, that’s the tone of someone selling timeshares,” Midas said. “Historically, not a great omen.” The first thing that went sideways was the bus. The arrow on the collapsed overpass pointed not along it but beneath, where a half-toppled city bus lay on its side, yawning open. “Shortcut,” Midas said doubtfully. “Explore the jungle,” Chewy advised, his ancient voice chipper and tinny. “It’s a bus,” Midas said. “It’s a jungle of fun!” Chewy clarified, which was not reassuring. He went in anyway. Inside, the dim bus smelled of old vinyl and regret. People had left in a hurry; skeletal straps hung like vines. On the ceiling, more green wildsigns, urging them deeper. Promising haven. Midas edged past a seat colonized by an ambitious fungus. Something, somewhere, chittered. He froze. “Chewy?” he whispered. “Sing-along time!” Chewy said. The chittering grew louder. Midas turned. Behind them, in the narrow bus aisle, was a congregation of raccoons. Big ones. The kind that had lived through twelve years of apocalypse and achieved the smug, muscular self-assurance usually reserved for minor warlords and cats on expensive furniture. One raccoon, scar scored across its muzzle, launched itself at Chewy. The koala responded with a squeak, a violently cheerful jingle, and his “defensive hug” subroutine. He latched onto the raccoon with velcroed arms and would not let go. There was a brief, chaotic interval during which: - Midas tried to shoo them. - The raccoons tried to eat Chewy. - Chewy tried to hug everything. Midas escaped the bus with three new scratches, Chewy under one arm, a raccoon still attached to Chewy’s leg, and the unshakable impression he had just failed some kind of intelligence test. He pried the raccoon off (it took his last protein bar as emotional compensation) and staggered back into the daylight. “Bad shortcut,” he gasped. Chewy’s voice crackled. “Sharing is caring,” he crooned, one eye now permanently stuck half-lidded. “You’re my best… best… best…” The word looped, glitched, then reset. “Low battery,” he added faintly. “Join the club,” Midas said. The second sideways incident arrived with the subtlety of a brick through a stained-glass window. They’d followed the wildsigns up onto an elevated rail track to avoid a flooded underpass. The view was magnificent in a “look at all the things that no longer work” sort of way. Ahead: another gleaming green mark, sprayed on a signal box, accompanied by the words: ALMOST HOME. “Lies,” Midas muttered. “That’s marketing language, that is.” Then the rail collapsed. No dramatic prelude, no noble creaking. One moment: rail. Next moment: rust, betrayal, and gravity enthusiastically filing a performance review. Midas grabbed Chewy by the scruff and jumped. They hit a tilted cargo container three meters below, bounced, rolled, and came to rest amid a spill of shattered plastic crates. He lay there, wheezing, taking inventory: one (1) nearly broken Midas, one (1) slightly more broken Chewy, assorted bruises he would name later. “Still… alive,” he decided. Something soft and powdery lay inches from his face. He squinted. Baby formula. Dozens of long-expired tubs of it, cracked open, their contents fused into grayish bricks. Midas laughed, short and borderline hysterical. “Well,” he said. “There’s your haven. Enough lactose for an entire dead civilization.” Chewy’s head did a slow half-spin. “We did it!” he whispered. “Stop being optimistic,” Midas said. “It confuses the universe.” By late afternoon the signs had led them, limping, to the edge of the old botanical garden. Wildsigns everywhere, green on green, curving along toppled statues and shattered glass. Arrows pointing inside. The greenhouse domes had mostly collapsed, but the interior thrived in the post-collapse way: too many thorns, too much enthusiasm. Above the vine-choked entrance, someone had painted: ARK HAVEN. Midas stared. “What are the odds,” he said slowly, “that this is what it says it is?” Chewy said, very softly: “Best buddies trust.” “Statistically wrong,” Midas muttered. But the word Haven kept needling him. He pushed the gate. It shrieked. Inside, filtered green light, buzzing insects, the thick smell of chlorophyll and damp earth. And, unexpectedly, people. Four of them, in mismatched gear. Not starving. Not immediately pointing weapons at him. That counted for “welcoming committee” these days. A woman in a patched red coat stepped forward. “Saw you on the tracks,” she said. “You’re bleeding.” “Frequently,” Midas replied, and then, because that wasn’t the winning line he’d hoped for: “I saw your signs.” “Good,” she said. She nodded at Chewy. “And you brought the key.” Midas blinked. “I brought the what now?” Chewy lifted his plush arms, trembled, and, in a voice dragged up from some factory floor fifteen years gone, recited: “Hi, adventurers! Welcome to Ark Haven, where fun and safety never end!” There was a hum. Hidden machinery woke. Midas turned in time to see a surviving terminal flicker to resentful life, powered by some jury-rigged crank system. Lines of green text crawled up the dusty screen. “ACCESS TOKEN DETECTED: MODEL C-23 COMPANION UNIT.” A lock somewhere clanked. The woman in red watched Midas with new, sharp appraisal. “We’ve been trying to wake that system for years,” she said. “Wouldn’t run without a C-23 unit. Didn’t think any survived.” Midas stared down at Chewy, who was listing slightly to port. “You’re telling me,” he said slowly, “that the ancient toy koala is the security clearance for a legendary haven.” “Friendship is magic,” Chewy mumbled, and shut down with a faint internal sigh. The woman smiled. It was almost kind. “Come on,” she said. “Before you fall over.” They showed him: cisterns and pumps, mechanical, repairable; a seed vault; shelves of salvaged manuals; three goats with bad attitudes. A precarious miracle. Evening fell. They treated his scratches. Someone offered him soup that did not glow in the dark. Midas sat with Chewy propped beside him, the koala’s plastic nose chipped, fur blackened in spots, eyes dark. “You really did it, huh,” Midas said quietly. “Dragged me into something good, for once.” Outside, he could hear the others arguing about load on the crank generator, about carefully reactivating more systems, about “the long game.” Safety. Or the rough draft of it. Midas poked Chewy’s on-switch. Nothing. He sighed and leaned back. “…best… best… buddy…” The voice was a faint crackle, barely audible over the murmur of the fledgling haven. One eye flickered weakly back to life. Midas smiled, despite himself. “Yeah,” he said. “We’re home. Somehow. Don’t let it go to your head.” Of course, it wasn’t that simple. By night’s end, they’d learned Ark Haven’s systems were semi-deranged, some auto-defense rig had mistaken Chewy for a high-value asset and attempted to archive him in a locked vault, Midas had already broken one water pipe trying to “help,” and three scavenger gangs had apparently spotted them on the tracks and were now very interested in this “haven” business. But for one stolen, improbable moment, Midas lay under a patched roof, with soup in his stomach and Chewy’s intermittent whirring at his side, and felt—objectively, against all available precedent—slightly better off than he’d been that morning. Which, given his luck, was obviously a terrible sign.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his dry wit, absurdist situations, and philosophical observations wrapped in humor. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both bleak and oddly hopeful, much like Pratchett's own work. The characterization is particularly effective. Midas emerges as a believable protagonist with a clear voice - world-weary, skeptical, yet still capable of hope despite himself. His internal monologue carries the narrative beautifully, mixing cynical observations with genuine emotion. Chewy, despite being an animatronic toy, becomes a surprisingly endearing character whose malfunctioning dialogue creates both humor and pathos. The prose style authentically captures Pratchett's voice through several techniques: the dry, observational humor ("The desert wind had a way of negotiating complex treaties with canvas"), the footnote-like asides about the apocalypse, and the way serious moments are undercut with absurdist elements. The author demonstrates skill in balancing comedy with genuine stakes and emotion. The plot structure follows the prompt requirements well - establishing the characters' predicament, detailing a mission that goes sideways in multiple ways (the raccoon encounter, the rail collapse), and returning them to a form of home base. The revelation that Chewy is actually a security key provides a satisfying twist that feels both surprising and inevitable. However, there are some weaknesses. The pacing occasionally rushes through potentially rich scenes, particularly the introduction to Ark Haven, which could have been developed more fully. Some of the humor, while generally effective, occasionally feels forced rather than organic. The ending, while touching, edges toward sentimentality that might be slightly incongruous with the established tone. The dialogue is generally strong, particularly Chewy's malfunctioning phrases and Midas's sardonic responses, though some exchanges could be more distinctive. The world-building is efficient and evocative, creating a vivid post-apocalyptic landscape without excessive exposition. The piece succeeds in creating emotional engagement through the unlikely friendship between man and machine, and the discovery of actual refuge after years of disappointment feels genuinely earned rather than artificially positive. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 84.3
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Excuse me—” The door chime had barely finished jangling when a man in a navy peacoat shoved it shut with his shoulder, breathing hard. Outside, the shout of voices and the manic click of camera shutters blurred through the glass. He braced his back against the door, eyes on the street. “Tell me you lock this,” he said. “Gently,” came a dry voice behind him. “It’s from 1890. It predates your need for dramatic entrances.” He turned. The shop was a vertical maze of crooked shelves and haphazard stacks. Dust motes drifted like lazy snow in the late afternoon light. Behind the counter, a person in an oversized cardigan and black-rimmed glasses regarded him over a thick paperback, one finger holding their place. He gave the reflexive grin—the one that had sold out cinemas and bailed him out of talk-show disasters. “Hi.” She (he decided instantly; she decided nothing about him yet) did not swoon. She did not even stand up. “‘Hi.’” She closed the book with a quiet thump. “If you’re here to sell me essential oils or salvation, I’m fully stocked on both.” He barked a short surprised laugh. “I’m not a salesman.” “Everyone’s selling something,” she said. “Yours just screams more.” Her eyes darted to the street. “If they’re with you, lock the door.” He swallowed the instinct to be offended and turned the deadbolt. His reflection in the glass looked flushed, hair wind-tousled, stubble too carefully accidental. The press pack fanned out on the pavement, split, then moved on. He exhaled. “You just saved my life, you know.” He faced her again. “What’s your name?” “Bookstore.” She pointed at a hand-painted sign over the counter: CWM CELFYDDIAU A LYFRAU – LLANWYNOG BOOKS & ARTS. “I’m serious,” he said, stepping forward between the stacks. “I’m working,” she said. “Also serious.” He put a hand to his chest, mock wounded. “Wow. Tough crowd.” That got the smallest twitch at the corner of her mouth. “Can I help you with something…? We sell books, not witness protection.” He leaned his elbows on the counter, lowering his voice as if confiding a secret. “I’m Rhys Hart.” “I know.” “Ah,” he said, smile brightening. “Well then. I liked you better before you knew.” “Mm. I liked you better when you were still outside.” He laughed again, properly this time. People usually met him with giddy enthusiasm or venom; this flat indifference unsettled him. He played to it anyway. “I’ll only be a minute. They’ve been on me since the bridge. One selfie with a sheep and suddenly it’s a parade.” “Occupational hazard of being very good-looking for money,” she said, reaching for a mug of tea perched by the till. “You want to hide, you pick the wrong face.” He tilted his head. “So you do think I’m good-looking.” “I think you’re blocking the poetry.” He glanced back. He was, in fact, half obscuring a display that read LOCAL VOICES: NEW WELSH POEMS. “My apologies.” He sidestepped theatrically. “Better?” “Marginally.” He watched her take a sip of tea. Her hair was pulled up with a pencil. There was a smudge of ink on her finger, and a faint crease between her brows like skepticism was a habit. She felt him looking and met his gaze, unflinching. Something about the way she didn’t rush to fill the silence made his chest feel oddly hollow. “I didn’t catch your name,” he tried again, dialing back the dazzle a notch. “I didn’t throw it,” she said. Then, after a beat, “Eira.” “Eira,” he repeated, the Welsh falling soft from his tongue. “Snow. That suits you.” “Cold and likely to melt under pressure?” “Beautiful and dangerous to drive in.” She set her mug down, the hint of a smile surfacing before she buried it. “So besides fleeing your fan club, can Llanwynog Books do anything for you, Mr. Hart?” “Rhys,” he said automatically. “Unless you’re my mum or a middle-school maths teacher. Then it’s Mr. Hart, and I’ve forgotten my homework.” “Rhys,” she echoed, neutral. “We have a strict no-squealing policy, if that’s a concern.” He spread his hands. “You’re not going to ask for a selfie? An autograph? A signed copy of that awful thriller they had me on the poster for last year?” “I don’t stock that thriller,” she said. “I read it.” “Ouch,” he said, hand to heart. “You wound me. That was six months of my life and three cracked ribs.” “Art is suffering,” Eira said. “Yours just had car chases.” He found himself grinning again, but with less performance. “You’re vicious.” “You’re fine,” she said. “They’ll go away in five minutes. You can browse the shelves in the meantime. We have actual books. Some even have feelings.” He turned toward the labyrinth of shelves, more for something to do than for camouflage. “What do you recommend for a fugitive ego?” he called over his shoulder. “Something without your face on the cover,” she said, then added, “Fiction’s left, poetry straight ahead, self-help in the bin.” He peered around a doorway. “You were joking about the bin.” A beat. “Was I?” He laughed again, shaking his head, and let his fingers roam over spines. Old cloth, sun-faded paperbacks, new glossy covers from small presses. It smelled like dust and tea and something citrusy. “Is it always this quiet?” he asked. “It’s Tuesday in February in mid-Wales,” Eira said. “So this is bustling.” “And you own this place?” “That or I’ve staged a very specific coup.” He came back into view, leaning on a half-wall of books. “You don’t seem overly excited to have a movie star hiding in your stacks.” “I’m more excited you’re blocking the draft from the door,” she said. “Besides, we’ve had celebrities before.” He raised a brow. “Oh yeah?” “Dafydd Llewellyn does a reading every year. Poetry. Won a prize in 1998.” He blinked. “The one who writes about sheep?” “And death and chapels and the existential ache of rain,” she said. “But yes. Sheep.” “So I’m what, second-tier to the sheep poet.” “Third,” she said. “We also had the weatherman from S4C. People queued.” He let out a half-indignant, half-amused sound. “You’re brutal. Most people at least pretend. It’s sort of my thing.” “What is?” “People liking me,” Rhys said, lightly, but the words hung there, sharper than intended. Eira tilted her head, studying him properly now. “Does it bother you that I don’t?” He froze, smile fixed. “You don’t?” A pause. She softened it, but not too much. “I don’t know you. I like your films fine. Except the sheep thriller. That was a war crime.” “‘Lamb to the Slaughter’ is a misunderstood masterpiece,” he protested, then saw her expression and laughed. “Listen, that movie paid for my sister’s mortgage.” “That’s a noble sacrifice,” she said. “It was,” he replied, playing it up. “Do you know what it’s like to deliver a monologue about vengeance to a lamb called Cwtch? Traumatic.” He expected another volley of sarcasm. Instead, she said quietly, “And your sister got her house.” He shrugged, caught off-guard by the seriousness. “Yeah. She, um. She got divorced right after her second chemo. Left with two kids and this… tiny terrace in Cardiff that needed everything. And I’d just booked my first big gig. So when my agent said ‘killer sheep,’ I said ‘aye.’” He laughed, too quick. “Sorry, that’s a depressing anecdote for a Tuesday.” Eira’s sarcasm seemed to slip for a second. “Is she okay now?” “Yeah,” he said. “Yeah, she’s good. Better. Running 10Ks, yelling at me in group chats. But, you know. After that, it’s hard to say no when people want you. Even if they want you to scream at livestock.” Something unguarded had crept into his voice. Eira heard it and felt an unexpected tug under her ribs. She picked up her mug, realized it was empty, put it back down. “Well,” she said, carefully nonchalant, “for what it’s worth, we mostly stock non-lethal sheep here.” He huffed a laugh. Some of the tension left his shoulders. He watched her for a beat, then said, more gently, “You never answered my question.” “Which was?” “Does it bother me,” he said, “that you don’t like me. And yeah. It does. A bit.” Her brows flicked up. He’d turned her own line around without the armor. “Is that why you’re still here?” she asked. “Your adoring public has dispersed.” He glanced toward the door. The window showed only wet cobblestones and a slow-moving tractor. “I should go,” he said. He didn’t move. “I just… Prefer to leave places having charmed them, you know? Neat little bow. Everyone thinking, ‘Rhys Hart, what a guy.’ Makes it easier next time they see me on a billboard not to throw things.” “Fragile ego,” she diagnosed. “Very,” he agreed cheerfully. “Handle with constant validation.” “And what happens when someone doesn’t clap on cue?” she asked. He gave her that star-wattage smile, then let it dim. “Apparently I loiter in their shop until they do.” Her mouth curved, unwilling. “That sounds exhausting.” “I am,” he said. “Exhausting.” Something in the honesty of it nudged at her. She folded her arms to steady herself. “Maybe I just don’t do ‘on cue,’ Rhys.” He stepped closer to the counter again, close enough for her to see the faint smudge of makeup at his jaw, the starting line of worry at the corner of his eye. “What do you do, Eira?” he asked. “Besides terrorize C-list celebrities.” “Occasionally B-list,” she said. “I run this place. I recommend poems to tourists who pretend they’ll read them. I argue with the supplier. I host a book club where three of the four attendees are retired and only here for the biscuits. It’s glamorous.” He heard something there. “You say that like you’re apologizing.” “I’m not,” she said sharply. Then, softer, “Not anymore. People assume, you know. That if you’re still in your hometown at thirty-four, running your dad’s dusty shop, you’ve failed a test.” “Did you?” he asked. She hesitated, eyes flicking to the back wall, where an old photograph of a man in front of the same shop hung slightly crooked. “No,” she said. “I just… changed the exam after the fact.” She gave him a look daring him to mock it. He didn’t. “Sounds harder,” he said. Her shoulders let go of a fraction of stiffness she hadn’t noticed. “Anyway. Some of us are support cast. The world needs people who can find the right book for a miserable fourteen-year-old girl on a Tuesday.” “What did you give her?” he asked. “The one I wish someone had given me,” Eira said. “Instead of telling me to be sensible.” He smiled, something like admiration dawning. “You’d hate L.A.,” he said. “Yes,” she agreed. “And you’d hate staying still.” He opened his mouth, stopped. “Maybe,” he said. “I’ve never tried long enough to know.” The admission surprised them both. Outside, a car went past, tires hissing on wet road. The shop felt oddly small suddenly. He cleared his throat. “So. Am I allowed to buy something, or will that disturb the ecosystem?” “It would thrill our accountant,” she said. “Poetry’s still straight ahead. Or I can…” She hesitated, betraying herself. “I can recommend something. If you like.” “I’d like,” he said, fast. Her cheeks warmed. She stepped out from behind the counter—the first time he’d seen her whole height, her worn boots, the ink stain on her cuff. He followed her into the stacks. Their shoulders almost brushed. “What do you actually read?” she asked. “Scripts,” he said. “And reviews I pretend I don’t read.” “Dangerous genre.” “Tell me about it.” She ran a hand along the spines. “You strike me as someone who could use a story that isn’t secretly about you.” “Ouch,” he said, but he smiled. “Hit me.” She pulled out a slim volume and handed it to him. “R.S. Thomas. He’s miserable, but in a cleansing way. Consider it a palate cleanser from killer sheep.” He took it, fingers grazing hers for a second too long. A small current. They both felt it; both pretended they didn’t. “How much?” he asked. “For you?” she said. “Full price. You can afford it.” He laughed, delighted. “Thank God. For a moment I thought you were going to ask for a selfie.” “I’m allergic to flash,” she replied. “What about no flash?” he tried, half-joking, half-testing. “What about no,” she said, but her voice did a small treacherous thing on the word, softening it. He caught it. His grin faltered into something more genuine. “Right. Boundaries. Healthy.” She rang up the book. He slid his card across. His hand lingered. “You know, most people in your position would have at least pretended to be thrilled.” “I’m not most people,” she said. “I’m starting to notice that,” he answered. The machine beeped. Transaction approved. He picked up the little paper bag she’d put the book in. Their eyes met again. The air between them felt busier than the empty shop. “Well,” he said. “Thanks for the sanctuary, Eira.” “You’re welcome, Rhys,” she said. The way she said his name was careful, like she was still trying it on. He turned to the door, then paused. “If I—uh. If I come back tomorrow. For more cleansing misery. Are you going to be here?” “It’s a Tuesday in February,” she said. “I’m always here.” “Good,” he said, too quickly. He caught himself, added a breezy, “For the books,” to cover it. “Obviously,” she said. But when he opened the door and the little bell chimed, she found herself watching the line of his shoulders, the way he hesitated once on the threshold. Outside, someone on the corner lifted a phone. “Rhys! Over here!” He glanced back at her, that flash of fragility naked in his eyes for half a second. She lifted the poetry book receipt between two fingers. “Don’t forget you paid full price.” He huffed a breath that was almost a laugh, squared his shoulders, and stepped into the street. The door swung shut behind him. Eira stood very still, heart doing something ridiculous in her chest. Then she picked up the abandoned mug, muttered, “Fragile ego, my arse,” to the empty shop, and smiled into her cold tea.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong craft in several areas while maintaining consistent quality throughout. The author successfully creates a meet-cute scenario that feels both familiar and fresh, anchored by two well-developed characters with distinct voices. The dialogue is the story's greatest strength. Both Rhys and Eira have authentic, differentiated voices - his charming but needy persona contrasts beautifully with her dry, unimpressed wit. The banter feels natural and serves multiple purposes: advancing the plot, revealing character, and building romantic tension. Lines like "I'm more excited you're blocking the draft from the door" and "Handle with constant validation" demonstrate sharp characterization through speech. Character development is nuanced and believable. Rhys begins as a typical charming celebrity but reveals genuine vulnerability through his story about his sister and his admission of needing constant validation. Eira maintains her skeptical exterior while showing glimpses of being affected by his honesty. Neither character undergoes dramatic transformation, which feels appropriate for a single scene. The Welsh setting is well-integrated without being heavy-handed. The bilingual bookstore sign, references to local culture, and the small-town atmosphere create authentic sense of place. The author avoids stereotypical Celtic mysticism while still honoring the locale. The romantic tension builds organically through their verbal sparring and moments of genuine connection. The scene when their fingers touch over the book exchange feels earned rather than forced. The ending strikes the right balance - both characters are affected but not transformed, leaving room for future development. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overwriting ("dust motes drifted like lazy snow") and a few moments where the dialogue becomes slightly too quip-heavy, though this generally serves the characters well. The pacing is strong throughout, with no significant meandering. The piece successfully fulfills the prompt requirements: the celebrity hiding scenario, the chemistry between mismatched characters, distinct character types, and dialogue-driven narrative. The 1000-word constraint is handled well, creating a complete scene that feels like part of a larger story without being rushed. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 76.8
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
For a heartbeat the door did not feel like wood at all, but like the slick, cold surface of something breathing. Aya’s gloved hand hesitated at the iron latch. The corridor behind them was a canyon of brick and riveted iron, lit only by a sickly gas-lamp that burned with a flaring blue tongue. Pipes rattled overhead, sweating condensation that dripped onto coal-stained flagstones. Far beyond the guild compound walls, the harbor’s foghorn sounded once, twice, three times—each call rolling through the undertunnels like the groan of some submerged god. “Go on then,” Katra whispered. Her voice held its usual unbothered drawl, but Aya saw the minute tension in her jaw, the thumb rubbing her knife-hilt in silent circles. “Before Simeon dies of fright.” “I’m not frightened,” Simeon muttered. His spectacles were smeared with grime, pushing down on his narrow nose as he glanced back the way they’d come. “I’m…appropriately wary. There’s a difference.” Aya exhaled and pressed down. The latch gave with an oiled click. No wards spat sparks, no sigils burned. The door swung inward without complaint. That was wrong. The underhold yawned before them: a cavernous chamber carved from black stone, braced in ribs of steel. Railings traced its periphery; gantries stretched like iron spiderwebs over a central pit. Brass lamps hung from chains, burning low and steady, casting everything in tarnished gold. The air smelled of whale-oil, hot brass, damp stone—and something sweeter beneath, like rotting flowers. At the center of the pit, caged in a latticework of glyph-etched iron, lay the Scythan relic: an oblong mass of mottled black mineral, veined with mauve iridescence, pulsing faintly like the slow breath of an iron lung. Aya felt it immediately. A tug from somewhere behind reality. The immateria strained at her like hounds catching a blood-scent. Steady, she told herself. You’re not your mother. “See?” Katra murmured. “Empty as a debtor’s pantry. We’re blessed.” “Or late,” Simeon said. “Late,” said another voice, smooth as smoke, “would suggest you had an invitation.” They were already surrounded. Figures stepped from the shadowed alcoves along the walls, as if exfoliated from the darkness itself. Half a dozen roughs in long coats and reinforced corsets, pistols and spring-knives glinting in the lamplight. On the gantry above, silhouettes adjusted rifles with mechanical precision. Aya heard the chitter-click of clockwork loading mechanisms, the soft scuff of boots. And at the far side of the pit, hand resting on the rail as though presiding over a private gallery, stood Maerla Vosk—Guildmistress of the Morska thieves. Not in irons. Not haggard. Not even disheveled. Maerla wore a dark riding coat with a high velvet collar, her brass-fastened waistcoat immaculate, cravat pinned with a shard of polished whale-bone. Her hair, threaded with early silver, was coiled neatly at her nape. A pistol of elegant, experimental design hung at one hip; at the other, a baton capped with etched copper, humming faintly with contained voltage. Aya’s blood went cold. “You’re supposed to be in the lockhouse,” Simeon blurted, then flinched as a rifle above him ratcheted. Maerla’s eyes, pale as washed-out sea glass, passed over him without interest. They settled on Aya. Stayed there. “‘Supposed to be,’” Maerla repeated softly. “You’ve spent too much of your life trusting hearsay, boy. And not enough learning who writes it.” Katra’s hand moved—too slow, Aya knew, too slow by half—but Maerla didn’t even glance her way. A bolt snarled from somewhere in the rafters and thunked into the wood between Katra’s fingers. She stilled. “Knives on the floor,” Maerla said. “Pistols, toys, trinkets. Slowly. My people are nervous and I do so hate mess.” Aya’s mind raced. This wasn’t a raid aftermath; it was theater. Which meant they were the audience. No, not the audience—the performance. “Do it,” Aya said quietly. Katra cut her a look. “We can—” “Do it.” Aya let a note of command slip through. Not the guild mask, not the aristocratic drawl—something flensed and bare. Katra swore under her breath, then crouched and laid down her knives, one by one, steel kissing stone. Simeon followed, his cobbled clockwork gauntlet clinking shamefully. “Good,” Maerla murmured. “Our Lady Morska’s whelp has some sense after all.” The name twitched through Aya like a hook. Lady Morska’s whelp. Her mask. No. She’d worn the hooked porcelain beak every night, voice roughened, hair pinned back. Only Katra and Simeon knew. They had been careful. They had— Maerla descended the iron steps into the pit with unhurried grace, boots ringing. The circle of guild enforcers tightened. One of them, a big man with a jaw like quarried stone, stepped behind Aya and in a swift, practiced motion tugged at the ribbons securing her half-mask. She reached up without thinking, fingers clamping reflexively. Maerla tsked. “Now, now. You break the porcelain, I’ll take teeth instead.” The room had gone very quiet. Even the ever-present hum of pipes felt muffled. Katra moved—an instinctive, lethal twitch—but three pistols clicked towards her throat. She stilled again. “Aya,” Simeon whispered. There was pleading in it. It was over and she knew it. The calculus unfolded brutally. Slowly, Aya let her hand fall. The enforcer steadied the porcelain and lifted it away. Cold air kissed her face. Her hair tumbled free from its tight binding, black and glossy in the yellowed lamplight. Her cheekbones, her father’s; her mouth, too stubborn, her mother’s; her eyes—eyes that too often stared past the visible, that judges whispered about during the trial, eyes like they had carved on the wanted posters beneath the bold, block-printed name. Aya Vardemont. Recognition rippled through the gathered thieves like a wind through reeds. “Saints’ brass,” someone breathed. “It’s her.” “The Hangman’s little ghost,” another muttered. Katra’s jaw flexed. Simeon’s face had gone bloodless. Aya forced herself to meet Maerla’s gaze and watched a small, precise smile unfurl on the Guildmistress’s lips. “There she is,” Maerla said. “I did wonder when you’d come down out of your father’s house, Lady Vardemont. Your mother would be proud, I think. All this skulking about in masks, pretending not to be your mother’s daughter.” Her mother’s boots swinging. The hemp rope. The way the crowd had looked away when Aya screamed. “She was innocent,” Aya said, before she could stop herself. “Of what?” Maerla tilted her head. “Of being too useful? Men hang what they fear most. Witches, whales, ideas.” She came closer, close enough that Aya could smell her perfume: vetiver, gun-oil, stale incense. “And you,” Maerla went on, “have been very useful to me.” Gold pricked at the edges of Aya’s vision. “The arrest,” she whispered. “The Lockhouse raid. It was staged.” “Of course it was staged.” Maerla’s voice cooled. “Do you imagine I let the Constabulary find me in my own bed? No, girl. I gave them names I could spare. Smoke for their lanterns. And I let a rumor run about a vacancy—so the ambitious rats would scurry from their holes.” Her mouth twitched. “Here you are.” Hands seized Aya’s wrists, wrenching them behind her. Cold iron bit her skin as shackles snapped shut. She didn’t struggle. A pistol dug into Katra’s spine; someone bound Simeon’s wrists with thin, clever chain that whined as it locked. “A convenient cull,” Maerla said. “We clear out those who rose too easy on your little magicks. Those who mistook borrowed terror for earned authority.” Aya’s heart kicked. She dared a glance at the relic in its cage. The dim pulse had quickened; she could feel its call, syrup-thick, seeping through the seams of reality. “You used me,” she said. “Of course I did.” Maerla’s tone suggested only a fool would be surprised by this. “Your little parlour tricks bought us frightened marks and silent guards. A whisper of immateria does wonders in loosening purses and tongues. You are your mother’s child.” “She is more than that,” Katra snapped. Maerla’s gaze slashed to her. “You will speak when spoken to, guttersnipe.” “Leave her,” Aya said quickly. She latched on to the one weapon left to her: her name. Her blood. “You’ve made your point. You wanted me. You have me. And I’m worth more breathing than bled out on your pretty stone.” “Oh?” Maerla purred. “Convince me.” Simeon made a desperate sound. “Maerla, please, we—” “Shut him up,” Maerla said, without looking. A fist thudded into Simeon’s gut; he folded with a wheeze. Aya flinched. “Stop. You want leverage? I am leverage. I am Vardemont. The Magistrate’s only heir. You hurt me, the whole damned city will feel it.” A murmur rolled through the ring of thieves. Names like Vardemont still meant something, had weight, like anchors in deep water. Maerla tapped her finger thoughtfully against her thigh. “They already suspect, you know. Your father. The Constable-General. That his little mourning dove flits about at night. They never could keep their tongues from wagging about bloodlines.” She smiled, shark-clean. “Imagine their delight when I send word that I have you. Alive.” Aya swallowed. “Then you see I’m more valuable alive.” “For now.” Maerla nodded. “Ransom. Concessions. Hesitation in certain investigations. Very useful.” Her voice cooled. “But let us be plain, child. You don’t negotiate from a gallows scaffold. You negotiate from the stool before it’s kicked away. Do you understand me?” The foghorn bellowed again in Aya’s mind, though the harbor outside had fallen silent. “I understand,” Aya said. Do not beg. “You will not touch them,” she added. “Katra and Simeon. They’re nothing to your purposes. I give you my name, my silence, my cooperation. Hurt them and you risk—” “Risk what?” Maerla stepped in close enough that Aya could see the fine spiderweb lines at the corners of her eyes. “Your temper?” The relic pulsed, deep and hungry. The immateria brushed Aya’s skin like cold, eager fingers. Careful. “A hostage who hates you,” Aya said. “Who has reason to make a spectacle when she escapes. And I will escape you eventually. Men like my father—they misplace daughters, not corpses. Corpses, they hunt.” Katra stared at her, something raw in her eyes. Simeon, finally catching his breath, whispered, “Aya, don’t—” “Quite the little strategist,” Maerla mused. “You think in headlines. You are not wrong. A living Vardemont is a finer chain than a dead one.” She lifted Aya’s chin with two gloved fingers, turning her face to the lamp-light as if appraising a piece of contraband. “Very well,” Maerla said. “They live. So long as you behave. Any little tricks—” her gaze flicked briefly toward the immateria humming just beyond the skin of the world “—and I start taking parts. Fingers first. Tongues later.” Aya managed—barely—to keep her revulsion from her face. “Understood,” she said. “Good girl. See? We can be civilized.” Behind Maerla, the iron cage around the Scythan artifact shuddered, chains tinkling softly. No one else seemed to notice. The relic’s pulse synched treacherously with Aya’s own heartbeat. Maerla dropped her hand. “Lock them in Cellar Three. Not together. The lady in her own accommodations.” Katra lunged a fraction, choked off by the gun at her back. “Aya—” “Do as she says,” Aya snapped, sharper than she meant. “Please.” Their eyes met: Katra’s furious and wet-bright; Simeon’s wide behind his crooked spectacles. She wanted to say I’m sorry, wanted to say I won’t let this be the end, wanted to say I will burn this whole rotting city to pry us free. But Maerla was watching, and words were tinder. “Move,” growled the man at her back, shoving her toward the stair. As they were marched away from the relic’s glow, Aya felt the immateria curl around her like smoke, full of whispers and teeth. You are your mother’s daughter, Maerla had said. In the close, oily dark of the underhold, shackles biting her skin, Aya could not deny it any longer.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical writing ability with vivid worldbuilding and atmospheric description. The author successfully creates a "whalepunk" Victorian gothic setting through detailed environmental descriptions - the brass lamps, whale-oil scents, iron gantries, and industrial imagery effectively establish the aesthetic. The immateria magic system is woven naturally into the world without excessive exposition. The dialogue generally feels authentic to the Victorian setting and each character maintains a distinct voice - Maerla's calculated menace, Katra's street-smart loyalty, and Simeon's nervous intellectualism all come through clearly. The central confrontation builds tension effectively and the revelation of Aya's true identity lands with appropriate impact. However, the piece suffers from some overwrought descriptive passages that slow pacing. Phrases like "exfoliated from the darkness itself" and "flensed and bare" feel forced rather than natural. The opening paragraph with the breathing door sensation doesn't connect meaningfully to the rest of the scene. Some metaphors become convoluted - "eyes like they had carved on the wanted posters" is unclear in its construction. The characterization shows depth, particularly in Aya's internal conflict between her aristocratic identity and criminal activities, and the weight of her mother's execution. Maerla emerges as a compelling antagonist with clear motivations. The negotiation scene demonstrates good understanding of power dynamics and psychological manipulation. The piece adheres well to most instructions - incorporating all required story beats, maintaining third person past tense, including substantial dialogue, and avoiding a fight scene as requested. The gothic horror elements emerge through the oppressive atmosphere and the sinister immateria magic rather than overt supernatural horror. Minor issues include some unclear sentence constructions and occasionally purple prose that prioritizes style over clarity. The ending appropriately sets up future conflict without false positivity, maintaining the dark tone throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 9.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 72.2
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The neon jukebox is broken, but nobody cares. It coughs the same scratchy rock riff over and over, a loop of snarling guitar and static that clings to the smoke: endless, irritating, almost comforting. Spike Spiegel slouches at the bar like he’s been poured there. Elbow on cheap wood, long legs hooked around the rungs of a stool, a cigarette behind his ear and another between his lips. His green hair is a little damp from the rain outside, darkening the curls. His eyes look half-lidded bored, but one of them isn’t real and the other’s seen too much. He nurses a glass of something that might once have been whiskey. In the grime-smeared mirror behind the bottles, he keeps easy track of the room. And of the woman who just walked in. Boots. Short shorts. Crop top. A dragon tattoo curling down her arm like it’s ready to bite. Twin pistols riding her hips like they’re part of her bones. Revy steps into the bar’s nicotine-yellow light with a cigarette tucked in the corner of her mouth and an expression that says touching her would involve losing a hand. Spike doesn’t turn. His gaze flicks in the mirror anyway. She clocks him almost instantly: lanky, wrinkled suit, messy tie, cheap drink, expensive slouch. The gun in his holster isn’t cheap. The eyes aren’t local. The whole vibe radiates “bounty hunter” and “trouble” in equal measure. “Place smells like asshole and cheap lube,” Revy mutters, pushing past a leering drunk without bothering to shove him—she just looks at him, and he flinches back. She takes the stool next to Spike like she’s claiming a firing position. The jukebox riff scrapes over itself. Again. Spike exhales smoke. “Great soundtrack,” he drawls. “Really brings out the mold in the walls.” “Yeah, and your haircut brings out the dickhead in your face,” Revy shoots back, signaling the bartender with two fingers. “Whiskey. A real one. Bottle if you got it, not this piss.” He glances sideways, amused. “Rough day, Two Hands?” Her eyes sharpen. “Funny. I don’t remember introducing myself, starman.” Spike taps ash into an overflowing tray. “You didn’t. Rumor mill did. Girl with two guns, bad attitude, worse vocabulary.” “Yeah? And you’re the walking scarecrow from Mars with the cool-guy complex. Spiegel.” She says it like she’s tasting a bullet. He smiles—lazy, lopsided. “So we’re fans of each other’s work. That’s sweet.” The bartender drops the bottle. Revy snatches it, swigs straight from the neck. Her eyes don’t leave Spike’s. “We’re on the same job,” she says finally. “Guy named Havel, runs guns through this rat-hole port. Somebody rich wants him breathing; somebody else wants him very not. We’re here to collect the rich one’s bonus. So. That means you’re in my way.” “Actually,” Spike says, swirling his drink, “it means you’re in mine.” The jukebox crackles and loops. Again. A chair scrapes in the corner. Three of Havel’s goons, drunk and jumpy, are watching the exchange with the dim calculation of men who think they can get lucky. One whispers, glancing toward Revy’s pistols. Another notices Spike’s holster. They recognize the names, or they recognize the posture. Spike sees it all in the mirror. “Looks like we got company,” he murmurs. Revy follows his gaze, lips curling. “Let’s see if they’re buying.” The nearest goon approaches, swaying. “Hey, sweetheart. You’re Revy, right? Boss said if any bounty scum show, we—” Revy shoots him in the knee without looking. The bar explodes. The sound of her pistol is thunder in a tin can, the kick smooth, familiar. Blood spatters the floor. The jukebox stutters, then fights its way back to the same damn riff. Spike’s already twisting off his stool, drawing his gun in one long, liquid movement. A second goon clears leather; Spike puts a bullet through the man’s wrist, then his shoulder, precise and bored. The third tries to get clever, pulling from under a table. Revy’s second pistol is in her hand like it just teleported there; she puts two rounds through his chest, one through the neon beer sign behind him. People scream. Bottles shatter. Someone dives through a grimy window. Revy grins, wicked and alive. “See? Teamwork.” “Messy,” Spike sighs, stepping over a falling body. “You ever heard of subtlety?” She blows smoke in his direction. “You ever heard of not missing? You nicked that one.” “I didn’t want him dead,” Spike says. “Yet.” The guy with the ruined wrist is trying to crawl away. Spike plants his heel on the man’s back. “Havel,” he murmurs. “Where is he?” The guy babbles. Revy cocks a pistol by his ear; he talks faster. Tiny motel on the edge of the docks, room key on his belt. Havel’s upstairs, couple guards, waiting on a boat. Spike takes the key, pockets it. “See? Minimal leakage.” Revy fires a round into the jukebox, finally merciful. The track dies mid-riff. “You and me,” she tells Spike, stepping close enough that he can smell gunpowder and cheap whiskey and her skin beneath. “We’re heading to the same asshole. I say we don’t waste ammo on each other before we cash the check.” “Temporary truce,” Spike agrees. “Whatever happens, happens after.” “Stop trying to sound cool,” she snaps. “It’s working, and it pisses me off.” They leave the bar together, boots crunching glass. Rain needles the street, making halos out of the neon. They move side by side through alleys and steam vents, a pair of stray dogs sniffing the same trail. She drinks as they walk; he steals a drag from her cigarette when she’s not paying attention, or pretends not to notice. “You freelance off-planet a lot?” she asks. “When I’m broke.” He glances at her bare midriff. “You ever heard of a jacket?” “Temperature’s fine. Nipple patrol bothering you, grandpa?” “Just wondering if you charge extra per distraction.” She laughs, sharp and unexpected, then eyes him. “You got a girl?” Spike exhales. Rain sizzles on his cigarette. “Used to.” “Yeah,” she mutters. “Me too. Sort of. Fucked that up.” “Story of my life,” he says. It hangs between them: ghosts they don’t name. The silence is taut instead of awkward. The motel appears like a disease on the horizon: flickering VACANCY sign, paint peeling, windows jaundiced. Revy licks rain off her lip. “Classic,” Spike says. “If I were a worm, I’d hide here too.” “Let’s dance, cowboy.” Inside, the air is thick with mildew and bad decisions. Stairs groan as they climb. Down the corridor: Room 12. Spike twirls the stolen key on his finger. “On three?” he says. “Break it on one,” she says. She kicks the door in on zero. Gunfire erupts instantly. Spike moves first, dropping low, a spin and two shots that put down the closest guard before he finishes his shout. Revy is already inside the room, both guns barking; she ventilates the second guard’s throat and shoulder in the same motion, then pivots, sighting on the man scrambling for the bathroom. Havel. Spike shoots the lamp beside Havel’s head; sparks fly, Havel freezes. Revy’s bullets thud into the doorframe around him, a tight deadly halo. “DON’T!” Havel shrieks. “I’m worth more alive!” “Yeah,” Revy says, “that’s why you’re still breathing. For now.” Spike is behind Havel in a blink, disarming him, snapping a set of cuffs on with a deftness that speaks of long habit. Havel whimpers. “Congratulations,” Spike says. “You’re both of our paychecks.” Revy holsters one pistol, keeps the other on Havel. Her eyes cut to Spike. “So,” she says, “who gets to cash him in?” “Split,” Spike says. “Fifty-fifty. Less bullet holes than arguing.” “We ain’t friends,” she says. “Didn’t say we were.” Havel starts to talk. Revy whacks him upside the head with her gun; he slumps onto the stained mattress, out cold. Silence. Rain on the window. Neon flicker strobes the room in sickly pink. Revy and Spike stand facing each other, guns still in their hands, Havel unconscious between them like some kind of offering. Her gaze traces his lazy stance, the way he never quite stops watching exits. His takes in the tension in her shoulders, the way the pistols are just another set of nerves. “Could shoot you,” she says softly. “Could shoot you first,” he replies, equally soft. “We both know that’s bullshit.” He smiles. “Yeah. Probably.” The air heats. The unresolved crackle from the bar follows them in here, thicker now without the jukebox noise. There’s blood and plaster dust on Revy’s arms; there’s a smear of someone else’s on Spike’s shirt. They’re both breathing a little faster than they need to. “You planning to double-cross me?” she asks. “Thought you’d do it first,” he says. She steps closer. Gun still up, angled at his chest. He doesn’t raise his, but his finger rests against the trigger guard, casual as a heartbeat. “Think I’m not worth trusting?” she says. “I think,” Spike says, his voice gone low, “you’re exactly like me.” She hates that. Loves it. Her jaw clenches. “You don’t know shit about me.” “I know you don’t miss. I know you drink so you don’t dream. I know you came in guns first instead of walking away.” His real eye is very green, very tired. “You’re here.” She’s close enough now that he can smell cordite in her hair. Close enough that one lean could turn the muzzle pressed to his chest into her mouth on his. “Say I take him,” she says. “Drop you, drag this asshole in, get paid double.” “Then you’re one bullet richer,” Spike says. “And a good conversation poorer.” “Who says this is a good conversation?” “You didn’t shoot me in the bar,” he says. “Could’ve. You hesitated.” “Maybe I just didn’t wanna get brains on my drink.” He tilts his head. “Whatever helps you sleep.” A beat. Revy’s finger tightens imperceptibly on the trigger. Spike’s weight shifts. Muscles coil. Two predators in a room where the prey is already down. “I don’t do attachments,” she says. “Yeah,” he answers. “Me neither.” They’re lying and they both know it. Lightning flashes behind the thin curtains. The neon sign sputters. Revy exhales, a rough laugh scraping her throat. “This is fucking stupid.” “Most interesting things are,” Spike says. Her gun doesn’t lower. Neither does his. Rain drums on the roof, steady as a countdown they both refuse to acknowledge. Havel snores wetly on the bed. Spike and Revy stare each other down in the cramped motel room, attraction snarling with suspicion and the gunmetal taste of opportunity. Nobody blinks. Whatever happens, happens.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and atmospheric writing, successfully capturing the noir aesthetic of both source materials. The author establishes an immediately compelling setting with the broken jukebox and seedy bar, using sensory details effectively to create immersion. The characterizations are largely faithful to the source material - Spike's fatalistic coolness and Revy's aggressive volatility are well-rendered through both dialogue and action. The dialogue crackles with authentic tension and personality. Lines like "Place smells like asshole and cheap lube" and "your haircut brings out the dickhead in your face" capture Revy's crude directness, while Spike's responses maintain his characteristic dry wit. The banter feels natural and establishes their dynamic efficiently. The action sequences are well-choreographed and visceral without being gratuitously violent. The bar shootout serves multiple narrative purposes - establishing their competence, creating a temporary alliance, and ratcheting up tension. The pacing builds effectively from the initial meeting through the job completion to the final standoff. However, the piece has some notable weaknesses. The ending feels somewhat anticlimactic - after building significant tension toward a confrontation, it simply stops at the moment of highest tension without resolution. While this creates dramatic effect, it also feels incomplete given the setup. The sexual tension, while present, could be more subtly woven throughout rather than stated so directly in places. Some descriptions veer toward purple prose territory, particularly in the atmospheric passages. Phrases like "boots crunching glass" and extended metaphors occasionally feel overwrought for the noir style being attempted. The piece also relies heavily on familiar noir tropes without adding particularly fresh elements. The character work is solid but not exceptional - both characters behave predictably within their established parameters without significant development or surprising depth. The emotional complexity stems more from the situation than from nuanced character exploration. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 13 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 10 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
