+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 85.7
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Lucifer woke up to the sound of screaming. He lay there a moment, staring at the canopy of black obsidian above his bed, counting the shrieks. The cadence told him someone on Level Nine had discovered the new “eternal paperwork” initiative. Good. That would keep things interesting for at least a century. Beside him, the sheets were cold. That part was less good. Lucifer slid out of bed, tugged a shirt over his shoulders, and immediately trod on something sharp. He hissed, looked down. A bone. Again. “Hound,” Lucifer said. A large hellhound’s head emerged from under the bed: ember eyes, magma drool, a ribcage that contained unlikely shadows. The dog looked as guilty as something that had never regretted anything in its existence could manage. “This is the third femur this week,” Lucifer said. “We’ve talked about sourcing.” The hound wagged its barbed tail and trotted off, dragging a chain and a piece of someone. Lucifer sighed. “Requisition,” he muttered. “Remind me to speak with Requisition.” Nobody reminded him. That was the difficulty, in Hell. Infinite minions. Not a single decent PA. He padded barefoot through the fortress: vaulted ceilings, rivers of molten rock flowing through open channels in the floor, screaming souls embedded decoratively into the walls. He turned down the volume on the screaming—there was a dial—and flicked on a lamp in the kitchen. The fridge contained: - Three bottles of souls (artisanal, Scandinavian). - One half-eaten apocalypse. - Lilith’s jam. Blackcurrant. He closed the door a little too gently. At the obsidian kitchen island sat a demon in a suit, reading a clipboard that smoked faintly. “Morning, sire,” the demon said. “Belial. Why are you in my kitchen.” “Strategic briefing,” Belial said. “And someone ate Human Resources.” Lucifer leaned against the counter. “Define ‘ate.’” “Literally. Consumed. With relish. Apparently it was a metaphor gone too far. We’ll need to hire a new one. Also, we’re over capacity in Circle Four. The greedy have started double-bunking.” “If they share, they won’t be greedy,” Lucifer said. “That’s rehabilitation. Absolutely not.” Belial made a note. Something screamed from the clipboard. “The unions are complaining about spontaneous flaying,” Belial added. “They’re saying—” Lucifer held up a hand. “Belial, I haven’t had coffee yet.” “We don’t have coffee in Hell,” Belial said. “You banned it on account of—” Lucifer snapped his fingers. A steaming mug appeared in his hand, smelling of despair and arabica. “I changed my mind,” he said, and took a sip. Better. The mug read: WORLD’S WORST BOSS in dripping letters. Belial waited politely, only mildly on fire. “We also have a… visitor,” Belial said carefully. Lucifer’s hand stilled on the mug. “Lilith,” Belial said. “She’s in the throne room.” “I see.” Lucifer inspected his reflection in a knife. “Do I look… tyrannical?” “Yes, sire.” He nodded. “Good.” He did not fix his hair before leaving the kitchen. He told himself this. In the throne room, the iron throne hunched like something growing naturally out of the basalt dais. It screamed quietly, but only when you sat in it. Beside one of its massive front legs, the hellhound was gnawing industriously, sending up sparks and unhappy metal shrieks. “Off,” Lucifer called. The hound ignored him, grinding down iron with the slow, squeaky persistence of a rubber toy in a suburban living room. Lilith stood at the window slit, back to him, looking out over the infinite charnel metropolis of Pandemonium. At this hour, the river of fire was particularly picturesque, reflecting the burning rain. She wore black, of course, but it wasn’t the black of mourning; it was the black you chose when you intended to be seen. Dark hair, bare feet, a chipped black nail polish on one toe that bothered him irrationally. “You changed the clouds,” she said, without turning. “Less screaming faces. More traditional storm aesthetic. I approve.” “The faces said it was ‘exploitative,’” Lucifer said. “We’re trying a classic look. Retro torment.” She turned, finally. Her smile was there, but so were the walls. “Morningstar,” she said. “Lilith,” he replied. It came out softer than he liked. They regarded each other in a comfortable, agonizing silence. The hellhound’s chewing filled the room. Iron grated. A screw pinged free and rolled across the floor, clinking. Lucifer winced. “We need to talk,” Lilith said. “Oh good,” Lucifer said. “I love that phrase.” She lifted a brow. “Don’t be petulant. It clashes with the wings and the omniscience.” “You keep saying ‘omniscience’ like it’s not mostly memos and complaints about the temperature,” Lucifer said. “What do we need to talk about?” “Your hound,” she said, pointing. The hellhound looked up, muzzle gray with iron filings. “That’s Cerberus,” Lucifer said. “It is very obviously not Cerberus,” Lilith said. “Cerberus is at the gates. This is a smaller, disobedient one with attachment issues.” “She doesn’t have—” The hound trotted over and rested its monstrous head against Lucifer’s leg, whimpering. “Yes, well,” Lucifer conceded. “She’s… sensitive.” “The throne is listing,” Lilith said. “Your symbol of absolute dominion is about to fall over because you won’t discipline your dog.” There it was: the day’s first small humiliation. “I’ve had a century,” Lucifer said, “and this is what you want to talk about?” She stepped closer. Not close enough to touch. Close enough. “I am, believe it or not, trying to be constructive,” she said. “You’re distracted. You’re sulking. Hell is leaking.” “Hell is not leaking.” “In Sector Seven, the lava’s running lukewarm. Souls are complaining. Some are… regretting less. You’ve got bureaucrats eating bureaucrats. There’s a suggestion box in Circle Two.” Lucifer stared. “Who authorized a suggestion box?” “I think the box authorized itself,” Lilith said. “My point is: you’re off your game.” He summoned his wings without meaning to: great white things with an oil-spill sheen, half memory, half threat. They made the throne room look smaller. “You left,” he said. “Forgive me if the ambiance is suffering.” She did not flinch. They had decades of this. “I left,” she said, “because last time I proposed restructuring the Punishment Department, you told me, quote, ‘I am literally the Prince of Lies, I think I understand feedback loops.’ End quote.” “It was a good line,” Lucifer said. “It was,” she admitted. “It was also you being an ass.” The hellhound resumed chewing the throne. The iron gave a long, desolate creak, like an empire trying yoga for the first time. “I can fix that,” Lucifer said quickly. “The throne or your personality?” Lilith said. “Both. One will obviously be easier.” He snapped his fingers. The throne’s leg mended itself, regenerating new, vicious-looking barbs. The hellhound yelped as the metal pulled away from its teeth. “Bed,” Lucifer said. The dog slunk under the throne, whining. “That never works for you,” Lilith said. “I’m trying consistency,” Lucifer said. “Parenting blogs swear by it.” “You read parenting blogs.” “I have billions of unruly souls. They count.” She watched him, and there it was: a flicker, quickly extinguished. Fondness, or something more dangerous. “I didn’t come here to fight,” Lilith said. “Then why?” He hated the way the question sounded. Too open. Vulnerable. Not very Devil. “To return your things,” she said, and snapped her fingers. A small obsidian suitcase appeared between them. He recognized it. Of course he did. “I see,” Lucifer said. “How symbolic.” “I know you like symbols,” she said. He kicked the suitcase lightly. It spilled open: a few shirts, a knife capable of killing conceptual entities, one of his records, an old photograph of the two of them on the balcony of Pandemonium, laughing at something the camera hadn’t caught. Notably: Lilith’s jam, from his fridge, now sitting neatly atop the pile. “You stole my jam,” he said. “You don’t eat,” she said. “You brood. It was getting lonely in your fridge.” He almost laughed. It came out as an exhale. “Are you…” he started. “Staying? Or is this another drive-by catharsis?” She tilted her head. “Depends.” “On?” “On whether you’re going to keep wallowing. On whether you’re going to let Hell run itself into the ground because you’re heartbroken like some mortal poet with a trust fund. On whether you want a partner or just someone to admire the angle of your cheekbones while you monologue.” “That’s…” He blinked. “Quite a list for this early in the millennia.” “I’ve had time to draft it,” she said. “Also your hound ate my left boot last time. That’s on there.” The throne gave another uneasy creak. “Fine,” he said. “Let’s be… practical. You think Hell’s untidy.” “I think Hell reflects you,” she said. “And you, right now, are a mess.” “You’re proposing… what,” he said. “Joint management? Again?” “Perhaps with fewer power struggles,” she said. “And more calendars.” “I hate calendars.” “I know. That’s why they work.” He hesitated. In the distance, someone invented a new kind of scream. It spiraled beautifully upward. Art. Life went on. “Belial!” Lucifer called. The suited demon appeared in a burst of geopolitics. “Yes, sire.” “Lilith is reinstated as… co-regent. Effective immediately.” Belial’s eyes widened. “The last memorandum—” “Burn it.” “It is already on fire, sire.” “Excellent,” Lilith said. “First directive: no more suggestion boxes. Second: implement performance reviews. Third: get someone to walk the dog.” The hellhound poked its head out, tail thumping, chewing on what was definitely a piece of someone important. “I’ll walk her,” Lucifer said quickly. Lilith’s mouth twitched. “Look at that. Growth.” Belial bowed and vanished. Lucifer looked at Lilith. “We’re not… resolving anything,” he said. “We never do,” she said. “We simply continue. That’s our charm.” “And tonight?” he asked, lightly, carelessly. “Tonight,” she said, “we will audit Circle Four, redesign the torment protocols to remove all accidental rehabilitation, and decide where your dog sleeps. Nothing more.” “Of course,” he said. “Of course,” she echoed. They stood side by side, watching their kingdom. The burning skies. The black towers. The endless movement of souls and demons and petty eternities, all needing sign-offs and signatures. The hellhound, sensing a fragile equilibrium, came to sit between them, leaning its weight against Lucifer’s leg, its nose nudging Lilith’s hand. Absentmindedly, she scratched behind its horn. The dog sighed, sparks drifting from its muzzle, content. Below, Hell screamed and shuffled and got on with its day. Above, the two of them did the same.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style while delivering a compelling "day in the life" narrative that merges infernal bureaucracy with relationship drama. The author demonstrates strong command of understated irony and absurdity throughout, particularly in details like the screaming volume dial, the "World's Worst Boss" mug, and the hellhound's domestic dog behavior despite its monstrous nature. The characterizations are nuanced and believable. Lucifer emerges as simultaneously powerful and petulant, dealing with administrative headaches while nursing romantic wounds. His vulnerability beneath the princely facade feels authentic. Lilith is equally well-drawn - sharp, pragmatic, and clearly the more emotionally mature partner, yet still invested in their relationship. Their dynamic crackles with history and unresolved tension. The prose maintains an elegant balance between the grandiose (obsidian thrones, rivers of molten rock) and the mundane (coffee needs, parenting blogs, performance reviews). The voice remains consistent throughout - wry, observational, with perfect comedic timing. Lines like "I am literally the Prince of Lies, I think I understand feedback loops" demonstrate the author's skill with dialogue that reveals character. The story adheres excellently to instructions, delivering dark comedy through the juxtaposition of cosmic evil with relationship counseling. The fantasy elements feel lived-in rather than decorative, and the domestic drama drives the narrative meaningfully forward. However, there are minor weaknesses. Some transitions feel slightly abrupt, and occasionally the prose edges toward being overly clever, though never crossing into true purple territory. The resolution, while emotionally satisfying, perhaps comes together a bit too neatly for the complexity established earlier. The imagery is vivid and purposeful, creating a Hell that feels both terrifying and bureaucratically mundane. The hellhound serves as an excellent metaphor for their relationship - destructive but beloved, requiring boundaries neither wants to fully enforce. The ending achieves genuine emotional resonance without betraying the story's darker undertones. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17

+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 77.0
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first sting of the day was always the vinegar. I woke to it soaking my nose and throat, sharp as a whip-crack, as one of the lanista’s boys sloshed it over the stone floor to rinse away yesterday’s blood and sweat. The dormitory of the ludus was a box of dim light and long shadows, thirty men on thirty pallets. Bodies shifted and grunted as the cold crept under thin blankets. Someone coughed wetly. Someone muttered a curse in Thracian. Outside, a gull cried, thin and hungry above Capua’s roofs. I lay still a moment longer, feeling my ribs rise and fall, counting breaths. Alive. Always a quiet surprise. That day, like all days, began with the small, stubborn fact that my heart still beat in my chest. The iron ring around my ankle tugged when I sat up. I wore the chain only at night now, a privilege, my lanista’s acknowledgement that I had nowhere to run. Freedom was a story for other men. “Up, Gaius,” Rufus growled from the pallet beside mine. His broken nose bent permanently left. “Or Festus’ll have your hide for breakfast.” “He eats worse things,” I said, voice dry as dust. He grinned, a gap where his front tooth had been. “True. He eats us.” We dressed in the half-light: wool tunics stiff with old sweat, belts, sandals patched and re-patched. My left sandal rubbed the scar on my heel, a line where a German’s blade had tried and failed to send me to Orcus. The scar prickled when I stood. I rubbed it once for luck, as I always did, and whispered—too softly for anyone to hear—“Mithras, hold my path.” I was Roman born, but it was Mithras who had taken me in his cloak the night I should have died. I remembered the cold, the mud, the roar of the crowd rolling like the sea, and above me a fragment of sky where the sun pierced the awning—the god’s spear of light straight into my eyes. I lived. After that, I owed him. We filed out into the courtyard, thirty men becoming soldiers of routine. Dawn dragged pale gray across the sky. The ludus loomed around us, high walls crusted with dust and the ghosts of old graffiti. I caught a glimpse of my own name among them, scratched by some admirer’s hand: GAIUS VICTOR. Below it, a crude figure with raised sword. Next to that, a different hand had carved: PANEM ET CIRCENSES. Bread and circuses. The promise that kept the city from tearing its own throat out. The air in the yard was a paste of smells: sweat ground into sand, oil lamps just extinguished, the sour tang of yesterday’s stew, a latrine somewhere too full, and, cutting through, the faint sweetness of baking bread from beyond the walls. That sweetness didn’t belong to us. It drifted from the city, from ovens in houses where no one woke to a chain on their ankle. Festus, our trainer, waited by the equipment racks, his shoulders bowed with old injuries and the weight of other men’s futures. His Greek accent thickened when he shouted. “Run,” he said. “Five laps, no talking. Move, animals.” Sand scrambled under my feet. Breath burned in my throat as we circled the yard, again and again, until the cold in my bones turned to heat. The slap of sandals, the rasp of lungs, the jingle of a chain not yet removed—this was our morning hymn. On the third lap, I glimpsed over the wall, at a gap where plaster had crumbled. A sliver of Capua: a woman balancing baskets of figs, a boy chasing a dog, a cart rattling by piled with amphorae. The distant murmur of the forum, where men with clean hands haggled over wheat and slaves and whispered about Emperors. About decrees and governors and legions in far provinces. We ran, and beyond the wall Rome argued with itself. After running came drills. Wooden swords, wooden shields, the false weight that trained us for the real. Festus prowled among us, his vine staff always ready. The crack of it on flesh punctuated his words. “Guard high, Gaius.” I brought my shield up. The staff smacked wood instead of my ear. “You think they love you,” Festus said, low enough only I heard. “They love how you bleed. Remember that.” “I remember,” I said. I remembered the last games. The Emperor himself had not come, but his statue had been paraded into the amphitheater with trumpets and incense, as though marble could taste glory. The magistrates smiled and threw more games to please the shouting mob, to prove their loyalty to a distant ruler who devoured loyalty by the legion. Every drop of our blood was a coin spent to buy the people’s silence. My shoulders ached. Sweat crawled down my spine. The sun hauled itself higher, turning the tiles of the ludus roof to dull gold. Between drills, while we waited for new orders, a new boy stared at me. Thin, with the raw look of someone not yet turned from man to beast. Fresh brand on his neck. “You’re Gaius,” he said. “I saw you in the arena. Against the two Samnites. They spared you. The crowd…” His voice went soft. “They roared for you.” “They roared for themselves,” I said. “Grow stronger. Or they will roar when you fall.” His mouth tightened. A spark. Good. Better anger than fear. Festus made us practice falls next, throwing ourselves into the sand until my hip throbbed and my right elbow hummed with pain. Learning how to kiss the ground without breaking. The sand smelled of iron and old days. Tiny teeth of grit worked into my skin. By midmorning, he relented. “Water. Then food. Don’t be greedy.” We shuffled to the cistern, cupping our hands. The water was lukewarm, tasting of stone and metal, but it slid through my dust-dry throat like a blessing. I watched one of the Gauls splash his face, his blue tattoos pale with soap residue. We reduced differences to scars and skill here, but I remembered how the crowd shouted louder for certain names: Greek, Gaul, Moor, Thracian. Conquered peoples thrown into the sand so that Roman citizens could watch victory replayed in miniature while the real Empire strained at its edges. In the refectory, we sat on benches worn smooth by restless men. Bowls of barley porridge, beans, a few strips of salted pork for those favored. I was favored. My bowl was heavier. Rufus bumped my shoulder. “Fame has weight,” he said, eyeing my pork. “Fame has teeth, too,” I said, pushing one strip into his bowl. A slave girl passed, jug of watered wine in her skinny arms. Her eyes flicked to my face, then away. Respect or fear—I wasn’t sure. We were dangerous animals, but dressed in glory for the arena, some of us passed for heroes in the streets. Children imitated our stances with sticks. Old women crossed themselves and whispered prayers when we rode by in procession, as if the gods listened more closely to men who dined so near death. “Did you hear?” Rufus said, mouth full. “More games next month. A gift from Rome. Grain shipments delayed, so they send us instead.” “Better for them if we were grain,” I said. He laughed, but there was no humor in it. We all knew. The Empire held together with ships of wheat from Egypt, taxes from Gaul, silver from Spain, blood from men like us. When the grain ran late, tempers sharpened. So the magistrates opened the amphitheater, a vein for the city’s anger. Let them scream for death instead of bread. Festus entered, nodded to the overseer. The room buzzed lower. “Listen,” Festus said. “Imperial party comes today to inspect stock. Some senator’s nephew, some priest of this or that. Look strong, look loyal, look like men worth wagering on. Especially you, Gaius. Our golden cock.” “A cock?” I murmured to Rufus. “I prefer bull.” He snorted barley. After we ate, they gave us a brief hour. Some slept, sprawled boneless on their pallets. Some whispered wagers over knucklebones. A Nubian named Tiro knelt in the yard, marking strange signs in the dirt, praying to a god older than our city. I took my wooden sword and climbed to the shade near the wall, where a cracked fresco showed Mars in chipped red, spear raised, cloak flying. I sat beneath him and took out the small painted tile I kept hidden in my tunic. Mithras, slaying the cosmic bull, his cloak curving like the night sky. My thumb traced the god’s calm face. “You spared me once,” I whispered. “You know I am your bull, too.” I thought of the games ahead. Of the Emperor in his palace, miles away, deciding on war or peace, tax or clemency, never seeing the faces in the sand who died to polish his image. I thought of the crowd: merchants, beggars, freedmen, patricians. All equal for a little while, their voices joined in one monstrous throat. Thumbs rising or falling like the judgments of Jupiter. When the imperial visitors came, we were lined up in the yard, oiled and bare-chested, muscles shining in the noon glare. They liked us shining. Made it easier to believe we were not like other men. The senator’s nephew walked past, perfumed like a garden. He was no older than I. Soft hands, soft jaw. His eyes lingered on scars as if they were curiosities in a market. “This one,” he said, stopping before me. “I’ve heard his name.” “Gaius Victor,” the lanista said smoothly. “Crowd favorite. Swift. Precise. Obedient.” The boy looked into my eyes, searching for something. I gave him nothing. His lips curled. “And loyal to Rome, I hope,” he said, projecting his voice so his retinue would hear his patriotism. “I am loyal,” I said. To Mithras, who had spared me. To Rufus, who shared my bread. To the precise angle of my shield that might let me live another day. “To Rome,” I added. He nodded, satisfied with the lie he’d purchased. They moved on, discussing odds, expenses, the importance of keeping the plebs entertained while the Senate untangled some trouble in Judaea, or Dacia, or wherever the legions bled that season. The sun pressed down. Sweat itched between my shoulder blades. A fly crawled along my collarbone. I watched the Romans who owned our lives, their togas glowing white as ivory teeth. Once, I believed being a citizen meant something solid. Now, branded property, I saw the truth: Rome devoured Romans too, when it was hungry enough. Later, when the visitors were gone and the yard had emptied, I lingered by the wall. Beyond it, the city rumbled: hucksters calling prices, a donkey braying, a burst of laughter from a tavern. Above, the sky stretched huge and indifferent, bright as Mithras’s gaze. I pressed my palm to the warm stone. “Another day,” I told the god. “I’ll take another day.” The chain at my ankle was gone for the afternoon, but its memory lay cool on my skin. I flexed my toes in the sand, feeling the tiny grains, each one a moment, a breath. Somewhere, a herald shouted news of fresh laws, fresh taxes, fresh victories. In here, Festus’s voice rose again, calling us back to drill. I turned from the wall and went.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and a deep understanding of historical fiction requirements. The writer successfully creates an immersive Roman setting through careful attention to sensory details - the vinegar sting opening, the paste of smells in the courtyard, the taste of stone-flavored water. The historical context feels authentic, incorporating specific details like the ludus structure, gladiator training routines, and social dynamics of the Empire. The first-person narration maintains a consistent voice throughout, balancing the protagonist's philosophical reflections with practical observations. Gaius emerges as a nuanced character - neither purely heroic nor bitter, but pragmatically resigned while maintaining inner dignity and religious faith. His relationship with Mithras provides spiritual depth without feeling forced, and his interactions with fellow gladiators feel genuine. The prose quality is generally high, with evocative imagery and well-constructed sentences. Phrases like "freedom was a story for other men" and "we reduced differences to scars and skill here" demonstrate literary sophistication. The writer effectively weaves larger political themes into personal moments, showing how imperial politics trickle down to affect individual lives. However, the piece suffers from some structural weaknesses. The pacing feels uneven, with certain sections dragging through routine activities without sufficient narrative tension. While the slice-of-life approach is appropriate, some episodes feel more like historical exposition than meaningful story moments. The philosophical reflections, while thoughtful, occasionally border on overwrought, particularly in passages about Rome devouring its own citizens. The dialogue, though limited, feels authentic to the characters and setting. The interactions with Rufus provide moments of humanity and lightness that balance the heavier themes effectively. The visiting Roman officials scene works well to highlight class differences and the protagonist's internal conflict. The ending maintains appropriate tonal consistency - neither falsely optimistic nor melodramatically dark. Gaius's quiet acceptance and determination to endure feels earned based on his established character. The piece successfully feels like an excerpt from a larger work rather than a complete story, which fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 12 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 12.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 9.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 87.0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
16 February 1972 Mither, Made it in one piece. The boat left me and my crate on the slip like a sack of tatties and vanished before I could wave. Can’t say I blame them. Bell Rock sits mean in the water. Just rock, spray, wind. Lighthouse rising straight up like someone hammered a white nail into the sea. Principal Keeper is Fraser. Thin as a mast, watches every move. Says, “You’re probationary, McKay. The light’s not a romance novel.” Like I’d written him one. I’ve a bunk under the lantern room stairs. The stone sweats. Everything smells of paraffin and boiled cabbage. It’s loud, Mither. The sea never shuts up. Maybe that’ll be a comfort once I’m used to it. Tell wee Isla I’ve got a view of the whole world. Love, Rob 3 March 1972 Son, Your letter came with Mrs. Coyle’s Mary from the post office. She read the address aloud in front of the whole queue as if I was illiterate. Everyone says, “A lighthouse! Fancy!” I said, “He’s there to work, no’ pose.” I don’t like the sound of you sleeping in the stair. Are there no proper rooms? Is there no union? Isla says the light blinked different last night and was that you. I told her it’s all cogs and rules, not your daft notions. Eat properly. Don’t go quiet in your own head. Love, Mum 27 March 1972 Mither, Fraser lets nothing go. He ran his finger along the brass rail and said, “Carnoustie could see their faces in this once.” I polished till my hands shook. There’s one other assistant: McEwan, from Leven. Talks football like it’s scripture, snores like a trawler. He’s been at sea since he was fifteen, says this is “a softer billet.” I’m still waiting on the soft. The were saying in the manual, Bell Rock’s the oldest sea-washed lighthouse. I pretended I knew that. Can’t have the Fifer thinking the Dundee lad’s ignorant. Last night on watch I saw the dark where the land should be. Just the loom of Arbroath and then nothing. Like a tooth missing. I’m fine. My hands won’t stop smelling of paraffin. It gets into your food. Into your dreams. Give Isla a clip round the ear if she tells her pals I’m “fancy”. Love, Rob 10 April 1972 Son, You sound like your father when he started with the trawlers. Sea this, sea that. He came back wrecked in the joints and quiet. You’re no’ to go the same road. We’re fine. The factory still wants me weaving faster. My thumbs click now like castanets. Isla sent you a drawing of a lighthouse with the moon smiling. I said the moon’s too old to be smiling at anything. Write more. Don’t show off with your “sea-washed” and your manuals. Tell me if your boots are dry, and if anyone there’s a drunk. Love, Mum 26 May 1972 Mither, Boots are dry. Nobody’s a drunk. Rules say no drinking “to excess.” McEwan says that means you drink just under. It’s calmer now. Gannets plunge like thrown knives, and seals lie on Bell Rock like fat old uncles. The light’s a living thing. Everything has a schedule. Hourly readings, wick trimming, fog signal. You’d like the routine. No foreman shouting, just Fraser quietly disappointed. Sometimes on clear days you can see the cliffs at Auchmithie sharp as if you could touch them. Then the haar comes and it’s like the world never existed. I miss your mince-and-tatties more than I thought possible. Love, Rob 5 June 1972 Son, Your sister has taken to pointing at any seagull and saying, “Is that Rob’s?” This is your fault for telling her they report back. I can see Bell Rock some evenings from the quay. A wee blink, that’s all. I tell folk, “That’s my laddie.” Then they go, “I thought he’d stick to the jute.” I say, “He’s got more sense.” I like the idea of you with your routines. Better than drifting into the pub like some. Don’t fall off any ladders. It’s a daft way to go. Love, Mum 18 August 1972 Mither, Storm blew up fast last night. Fraser had me on the lantern room from midnight. Rain horizontal. You’d have near enjoyed it from inside, I think. At two, we picked up a fishing boat too far east. No radio. Just a shape where no shape should be. Fraser swung the sector light, flashed danger. McEwan laid on the fog signal of his own notion. Boat showed us her red, corrected, slid off into the black. After, Fraser says, like he’d asked for more tea, “That’s why we keep it perfect.” I pretended not to care. But my hands wouldn’t stop shaking. Tell Isla yes, that one was my gull. Love, Rob 1 September 1972 Son, You wait till I tell the girls at the mill my boy saved a boat. You’ll never hear the end of it. This is the first time you’ve written like you’re proud. It suits you. Keep that Fraser sweet. Even the quiet bastards have ears. Love, Mum 14 November 1972 Mither, Days are black as your kettle. Wind works its way through the stone and into your bones. I’ve started talking to the lamp. Daft, I know. But it’s the only thing that answers regular. McEwan went ashore rota last week. Weather’s kept the boat from bringing his replacement. So it’s just me and Fraser. He’s not unkind; he’s just shrunk himself to fit the rules. Sometimes I go three days without hearing my name. I’m fine. Just tired. If the lamp’s lit, I’m still here. Love, Rob 20 November 1972 Son, Three days with no one saying your name is three too many. I had a word with Mrs. Coyle. She says post can still get through when the boats can’t, so no excuses. I expect words from you, even if it’s “still alive, still damp.” I know loneliness. Don’t be proud with it. It’s not a medal. You’ll be home at New Year. That’s not far. Love, Mum 5 January 1973 Mither, I’m sorry I missed New Year. You know I didn’t choose the weather. The boat tried. Could see Arbroath Harbour plain from the lantern, fireworks spitting. Could hear faint cheering carry over. Could have sworn I heard you shout my name on the wind. Stupid. Fraser brought out a bottle from somewhere. We had one nip, exactly. “For the King of the Bell,” he said. Meant the rock, no’ me. I’m starting to think clearer. The routine holds. Your last parcel with the Dundee Cake saved us all from murder. Stroke Isla’s daft hair for me. Love, Rob 9 January 1973 Son, We toasted you with flat ginger wine. Isla cried for three minutes, then asked if she could have your piece. I did shout your name, as it happens. Shows what good all that common sense has done me. When it gets heavy in your head, count things. Windows. Steps. Tins. That’s what I did when your father took the boat out in bad weather. And don’t apologise for weather. You’re no’ Neptune. Love, Mum 22 April 1973 Mither, I signed another year. Before you start, I know what you’ll say. “One becomes two becomes a life.” But it’s work I can see the point of. Lights on, ships clear the reef, men go home. That’s cleaner than feeding jute to fat men in suits. Fraser nodded like he’d expected it. McEwan said, “You’re one of us now.” Must be true; I caught myself telling the new lad, Rogers, to polish “like Carnoustie wants to see its face.” Sometimes I hate how proud I am of this tower. Love, Rob 30 April 1973 Son, Ah, Robbie. A whole extra year of worrying for your auld mother. I’m proud, you daft article. Don’t tell the women at the mill I said “proud,” I’ve a reputation. But I don’t like the thought of you stuck on a rock while the world moves on. Find out if there’s any postings closer in. There’s that wee light at Fife Ness. At least then if you drowned, you’d wash up within bus distance. Love, Mum 3 November 1974 Mither, They’re talking automation. Bloke from the Northern Lighthouse Board came out with a clipboard. Measured things that don’t need measuring. Says in “five to ten years” Bell Rock could run by itself. Think they like the idea of no wages spoiling their books. Fraser watched him like a man measuring his own gravestone. Funny to think they could leave this place hollow. Light going on with no one listening to the sea. Don’t worry. “Five to ten years” in their mouths means “after we’re all dust.” Love, Rob 9 November 1974 Son, They’d automate their own mothers if you could run them on batteries. If it comes to it, a clever lad like you can work anywhere. Don’t marry the stone. Isla’s started seeing a lad from Broughty Ferry who thinks he’s better than us. She says to tell you he wears cologne. I said, “So do drunk uncles.” Love, Mum 17 February 1977 Mither, Fraser’s dead. Heart, in his bunk. Went without fuss. We laid him out proper until the boat could come. House feels wrong without his slow steps. The Board sent a letter about “valued service.” Man gave thirty years to this rock and gets a form letter. They offered me Acting Principal Keeper. Acting. Like it’s a pantomime. I took it. Somebody has to care properly. Else the place will notice. Love, Rob 22 February 1977 Son, I’m sorry about Fraser. I know you liked him, though you’d not admit it. “Acting Principal Keeper” is just their way of seeing if you’ll do two jobs for one wage. Tell them your mother says no. I brought your news to the pub and they all said, “Oh, the wee bugger’s done well.” You’re 25 now. That’s too young to be haunted by lights. Love, Mum 8 July 1980 Mither, It’s decided. Full automation by ‘88. They had the decency to send a man to say it to my face. Same clipboard, older. They’re converting Bell Rock to automatic, monitored from shore. No keepers. Not here, not Fife Ness, not anywhere, soon enough. He said, “You’ll be redeployed.” Like I’m a crate. I’ve another eight years with the tower, give or take. Feels like sitting with someone on a waiting list. Don’t fuss. A job’s a job. I’ll stick till they shift me. Love, Rob 15 July 1980 Son, I’ll fuss if I like. They’re daft if they think a machine’s better than you watching. Still, eight years is eight years of a wage and sea air. Then you come back to us and complain about the smell of the town. I’m getting older. Don’t make a face. My knees click now. But I can still clip you round the ear if needed. Love, Mum 3 January 1985 Mither, Bad blow this Hogmanay. Worse than ‘72. We took a wave over the lantern. Whole place shuddered like it might finally give in. Rogers, now my assistant, turned green, which would’ve made you laugh. After, when it calmed, there was a yacht mast snagged against the rock. No hull. No people. We phoned it in. Lifeboats combed about. Found nothing but a fender. Kept the light pattern steady through it all. Felt useless and essential at the same time. I know what you’ll say—count the tins, breathe, you’re not a god. I’m trying. Love, Rob 9 January 1985 Son, I wasn’t going to call you a god. You’d only get ideas. You did what you could. That’s all there is. If you start carrying every lost boat, you’ll sink. I saw the report in the Courier. Didn’t like reading “Bell Rock” and “wreckage” in the same column. Felt like someone talking about you bleeding. Isla’s got two bairns now. They think “Uncle Rob” is a story. Don’t leave it so long between letters. Love, Mum 11 March 1988 Mither, It’s my last month on Bell Rock. They’ve put the new gear in. Sensors, batteries, remote monitors. Rogers left last year for some office. Says he “misses the view, no’ the damp.” I’ve a lad from Leith covering the end with me; he plays tapes of noisy English bands I pretend to hate. The Board’s letter says “your experience is valued” and offers me a shore job at the depot. Regular hours. Back to scraping barnacles off other men’s lights. I signed. Don’t have the fight left to start again. I climbed to the lantern alone last night. Switched from manual to auto. Wee red light came on to say the system’s live. I put my hand on the glass. It felt like saying sorry to a dog you’re leaving. Boat comes Thursday. Love, Rob 15 March 1988 Son, I cried, you bugger. Not for the rock. For you. You did what folk don’t manage in a lifetime: kept something burning, and left before it took everything. I’m glad you took the depot job. Selfish of me, maybe. I want you where I can feed you soup now and then. When you step off that boat, I’ll be there. Don’t think you can sneak in. Love, Mum 24 March 1988 Mither, First letter from land. The depot’s fine. Smells of oil and paper instead of sea and ghosts. I drive out to check lights in a van, if you can believe that. I check dials where brains used to be. Sometimes, at dusk, I look east and wait for Bell Rock’s flash. It comes on, right on cue. Bit too clean. But it’s there. Came round last Sunday, you weren’t in. Isla says you’ve joined a “club.” She means bingo; she’s trying to make you sound glamorous. I’m trying to get used to streets that stand still. To people saying my name without shouting up a tower. I’m lonely in a different shape now. But I can get on a bus and land at your door inside an hour. That’s something. We’ll call the next Sunday dinner a “handing-over ceremony,” you and me. You hand me a plate, I hand you all the stories I never wrote down because I didn’t want to worry you. You were right. Loneliness isn’t a medal. See you soon. Love, Rob
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully creates an authentic Scottish working-class voice through Rob's correspondence with his mother over sixteen years as a lighthouse keeper. The piece demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, spanning from 1972 to 1988 and chronicling Rob's journey from isolation through acceptance to automation-driven departure. The characterization is particularly strong. Rob's voice evolves naturally from the terse, defensive young man ("Made it in one piece") to someone more reflective and emotionally aware ("I'm lonely in a different shape now"). His mother's voice is equally distinct - practical, loving but unsentimental, with authentic Scottish vernacular ("you daft article," "I'll fuss if I like"). The relationship between them feels genuine, built on understated affection and mutual concern. The gradual revelation of plot through correspondence works effectively. Key moments - Fraser's death, the storm rescue, the automation announcement - are revealed naturally through letters rather than forced exposition. The technical details of lighthouse keeping feel researched and authentic, grounding the story in believable reality. The prose quality is consistently high, with economical but evocative descriptions ("Bell Rock sits mean in the water," "the haar comes and it's like the world never existed"). The writing avoids purple prose while maintaining poetic moments that serve the story's emotional arc. The emotional progression feels earned rather than manipulated. Rob's initial struggle with isolation, his growing pride in the work, his grief over Fraser, and his final acceptance of change all develop organically. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - melancholic about loss but hopeful about renewed human connection, avoiding unearned positivity. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the dialect feels slightly forced, and a few letters that serve primarily as plot advancement rather than character development. However, these are minimal compared to the story's overall strength. The piece successfully builds to its emotional climax with the automation announcement and Rob's final night manually operating the light. The resolution through his return to land and reconciliation with a different kind of loneliness feels psychologically authentic. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 85.9
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
She’s laughing. I haven’t heard that sound in a restaurant in years without immediately wondering if it’s staged, if it’s a distraction, if somewhere behind me someone’s swapping plates or skimming cards or shoulder-surfing PINs. But no, she’s just laughing at my story about bricking the CEO’s laptop in front of the board. “Well,” I’d said, “if you patch in production during the presentation, you get what you get.” She got it. Actually got it. That was my first surprise. The second is the Magic: The Gathering deck box peeking out of her tote when she leans down to set her phone to silent. Black Ultra Pro. Small scuff on the bottom edge. Not new, not precious enough to keep pristine. Used. “Is that—” I start. She follows my eyes, grins like she’s been waiting for me to notice. “You play?” I’ve known her for forty minutes. I’ve already categorized her as “probably out of my league” in two separate dimensions: looks and emotional normalcy. The fact that she might also be a nerd is cheating. “Since Fallen Empires,” I say. Her eyes flare. “No way. Casual or…?” “Competitive. Used to travel for PTQs. Blue-white control, long games, making people hate me.” She claps once, soft. “I knew you had that energy.” That energy. I wish I didn’t know exactly what she means: the meticulous, patience-of-a-saint, I-will-outlast-you energy. The waiter appears, and I see everything at once because that’s what my brain does. Square terminal with an unpatched Android skin. The NFC disabled sticker half-peeled. POS connected over visible Wi-Fi; SSID: “CasaLuna-Staff.” Open. Cute. On the host stand: laptop with the lid just a bit ajar, clear line of sight from the entryway camera. The camera itself: cheap, slightly tilted, LED on, default credentials practically echoing in my mind (admin/admin, admin/password, take your cursed pick). Deep breath. Don’t threat model the date. She orders the mushroom risotto. Voice steady, eye contact easy. I watch the way she moves her hands, the way she pauses, giving me room to jump in. Attentive. Nested if-elses in human form. Compatible with my runtime, maybe. We talk about work. I do the sanitized version: “application security consultant,” “help companies not get breached,” “yeah, I used to be on the wrong side, long time ago, all very dumb and edgy, now I fix instead of break.” She doesn’t flinch at that. Doesn’t lean in like it’s sexy danger, doesn’t lean back like I’m contagious. Just nods. “I’m glad you’re on my team now,” she says, and flicks her napkin over her lap. On your team. I put that in /hope. She starts on Magic again, tells me about her cube, her commander group, the salty guy who rage-quit after she combo’d off in response to a board wipe. She names cards correctly. Doesn’t call it “Manic Drain.” Says “stack” without apology. She mentions she has two younger brothers. Names them. She mentions her dog’s name. Her favorite teacher in high school. The street she grew up on. Her college mascot. Favorite band. The first concert she went to. She’s just chatting, open, trusting. My brain calmly highlights each detail: Security question. Security question. Potential password seed. Default mother’s maiden name vector. Social engineering gold. I want to turn it off. Instead I catalog. Years of training. Years of being paid to notice all the dumb things people do that make it trivial to break their lives. She’s funny, too. Uses sarcasm like punctuation. Eyes bright, but there’s a carefulness when she asks about my “old life.” “Anything… bad-bad?” she says. “That depends on your definition,” I answer. “Never hurt anyone directly. Never went after individuals. Never touch hospitals, never touch civic infra. Some corporate crime, some righteous hacktivism that wasn’t as righteous as I thought it was at twenty-one. Then lawyers. Then plea. Then… this.” I gesture vaguely at the present: my job, my parole completed, my boring, careful life. “You’re trying,” she says, like it’s a verdict. “I like people who try.” I log that, too, but in a nicer way. The food comes. Smells amazing. I watch the waiter’s hand as he sets down my plate; he almost nudges her phone. The case is translucent, glittery. Her wallpaper, when it flares for a second, is a planeswalker. Liliana. “That tracks,” I say, vague. She smirks. Midway through her risotto, her screen lights again and buzzes on the table. She glances down. “I’m just gonna mute this,” she says. “Group chat is drafting without me.” And then she does it. She picks up the phone and, in full clear view, draws her unlock pattern. I don’t want to see it. But I do. Top-left to bottom-right diagonal. Then a little right, a little up. Six points total. It’s not even bad in a creative way; it’s the kind of thing you could guess in four tries if you’d ever worked a help desk, if you’d ever shoulder-surfed in a coffee shop, if you’d ever, say, been arrested for exactly that. She locks the phone, sets it back down. In my head, alarms. Pattern reuse probability: high; gesture confidence suggests muscle memory. Path shape: iconic, symmetric, likely used across devices. Combined with her info breadcrumbs, you could— “Your pattern’s really weak,” I say. It’s out of my mouth before I can catch it. Like breathing. Like SQL injection. She blinks, hand hovering over her fork. “My… what?” I close my eyes for half a second. Damage assessment. “Your unlock pattern,” I say. Might as well own it. “I, uh, saw it. It’s super guessable. Top-left to bottom-right is—” I stop. This is not a client call. She is not a quarterly report. Her face does this quick contraction, like something inside pinched. Embarrassment? Irritation? “Wow,” she says. “Okay. Creepy.” Good job, hero. I put my hands up, palms out, elbows on the table. Open posture. No sudden movements. “I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to be creepy. It’s… occupational hazard. I see patterns. And patterns that get people hacked.” She stares at me for a beat too long. The sound in the restaurant recedes: silverware, low music, espresso machine. All background. Foreground: her eyes, measuring. “You were watching my screen,” she says. “Yes,” I say, because lying is worse, and also pointless. “But not like— I watch everybody’s screens. Doors. Cameras. Card readers. It’s automatic. I spend all day thinking how someone could break things. It doesn’t completely shut off. I’m working on that.” She takes a breath, sets her fork down. Doesn’t look away. “You could’ve just… not said anything.” “Yep,” I say. “Should’ve. I’m sorry.” The version of me from eight years ago would weaponize this. Lean into it. Build dependence: I’m the only one who can keep you safe, look how fragile you are. That sick little power rush. I remember it like a smell. I hate that I remember liking it. Current me: I stare at the water glass and consider if I should offer her an out. “If that felt like a boundary cross,” I say carefully, “you’re absolutely allowed to be annoyed. Or to bail. I won’t follow you or try anything weird. I’ll pay for dinner. And I’ll go home and lecture my ceiling instead.” A corner of her mouth betrays amusement before she smothers it. “You have a ceiling lecture prepared already?” “Several,” I say. “One specifically titled ‘Stop Being a Walking Nmap Scan on Dates.’” Another half-smile. Not full forgiveness, but not a hard no. She leans back, crosses her arms—not closed off, more evaluating. “So what, you’re constantly threat modeling me?” Yes. “No,” I say, then correct, “Okay, yes. But not because it’s you. Because it’s everyone. I’ve seen too many worst-case scenarios. It’s like if a firefighter sees all your extension cords, they’re going to notice which ones are frayed.” “Do firefighters also narrate it out loud over appetizers?” “Only the really awkward ones.” She exhales. That tiny laugh again. Good sign. “I get the instinct,” she says. “I work in data science. Once you know how models can be poisoned, every survey link feels like a trap. But I don’t tell people their taste in music makes them predictable to an ad server.” “Yet,” I say. She points with her fork. “Yet.” That breaks a bit of the tension. I decide to do the one thing Past Me never did: give up the advantage. “For what it’s worth,” I say, “if I had stayed quiet, someone else with less ethics could’ve watched that pattern and used all the personal details you’ve casually dropped—dog’s name, high school, brothers, everything—to guess your passwords, reset your accounts, own your life. You’re very… open.” She frowns. “So now I’m too trusting.” “Yes,” I say. “But that’s not a flaw. That’s something I don’t want broken.” It comes out rawer than intended. True in a way that startles both of us. She studies me again. That sharp, analytical glint I liked when she was talking about sideboards is back, pointed at me. “You don’t actually enjoy seeing this stuff, do you,” she says. It’s not a question. “I used to,” I admit. “Now I just can’t unsee it. The difference is I’d rather use it to protect than exploit. And I’m trying to learn when shutting up is the protective move, too. I messed that up just now. I’m sorry.” She picks her phone up, looks at it, then back at me. “What should I change it to?” she asks. Tiny relief spike. Okay. Not dead in the water. “I am absolutely not telling you that on a first date,” I say. “I don’t want your secrets. Use a long PIN. Different from your others. And, uh, maybe don’t reuse your dog’s name plus birth year for everything.” Her eyebrows shoot up. “I never said—” “You absolutely did,” I say gently. “You said you’re bad at coming up with unique names so you reuse the ones you love. Then you told me your dog’s name, your favorite number, your grad year. That’s a four-field dictionary attack with training wheels.” She groans and covers her face for a second. “I hate you.” “I know,” I say. “I’m terrible.” She peeks at me between her fingers. “You’re not, actually. You’re just… intense.” “I can live with intense,” I say. “I’m aiming for ‘intense but safe to be around.’” She lowers her hands. Really looks at me. “If we keep seeing each other, are you going to audit my entire life?” “That depends,” I say. “Do you want me to?” She thinks. “Maybe a little. Quietly. With consent. On a schedule. Not… during dessert.” “That is an extremely reasonable boundary,” I say. “I accept your terms.” She shakes her head, smiling for real now. “Okay. So. No more unsolicited security feedback tonight.” “I solemnly swear,” I say. “Unless you start your banking password out loud.” She raises her glass. “To not starting my banking password out loud.” We clink. She changes her pattern under the table, screen angled away from me this time. Good. Very good. I don’t try to peek. That’s my penance: living with curiosity and choosing not to satisfy it. The conversation picks back up, a little dented but serviceable. We argue about whether Force of Will is healthy for Legacy. We rank Kamigawa block art. She trash-talks my love of control decks; I explain the joy of having an answer to everything. “Of course you like having an answer to everything,” she says, smirking. “You’re literally trying to pre-empt all possible threats. You’re a walking counterspell.” “I prefer ‘protective ward,’” I say. “Mm. We’ll see.” When the bill comes, the waiter sets down the tablet between us. I feel the muscles in my shoulders tighten automatically, scanning: device ID, connection indicator, no tip preselected (bless), the faint hairline crack in the glass like a stress fracture. “Split?” I ask. “Yeah,” she says. She taps first. I pointedly stare at the salt shaker while she enters her card details and PIN. It’s harder than any technical discipline I’ve ever learned. When it’s my turn, I pay, tip well, sign. Outside, the air is cool, the streetlights humming softly. We stand there in the sodium glow, that awkward first-date-outro moment loading like a slow page. “I had a good time,” she says. Genuine. “Me too,” I answer. Also genuine. A beat. “And I’ll, uh, think about the password stuff,” she adds. “I will think about the not blurting stuff,” I say. “Maybe we meet in the middle.” She nods. “Maybe.” We hover. She steps in, quick, brushes a light kiss against my cheek. My brain, miracle of miracles, does not inventory proximity-based attack vectors. It just… notes warmth. “Don’t hack me,” she says, half playful, half warning. “Don’t make it easy,” I say, and instantly regret it. But she laughs. Then, over her shoulder as she walks away: “Text me your favorite commander list. That’s your homework. White hat only.” “Yes, ma’am,” I say, too soft for her to hear. On the way home, every person on the train is another open port, another leaked data point, another flawed lock. The world is one big screaming vulnerability. But somewhere in it is a person who heard what I was and still handed me a small piece of trust—and asked me not to break it. That’s one vector I can choose not to exploit.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional adherence to the prompt's complex requirements. The first-person narrative authentically captures a reformed hacker's mindset through rich internal monologue, successfully balancing technical expertise with human vulnerability. The protagonist's compulsive pattern recognition feels genuine and well-researched, from cataloging restaurant security flaws to automatically profiling the date's digital habits. The characterization is particularly strong. The protagonist emerges as a fully realized person - someone genuinely trying to reform while battling ingrained habits. Their awareness of their own problematic tendencies ("The version of me from eight years ago would weaponize this") creates compelling internal conflict. The date character avoids the trap of being a mere plot device, displaying her own agency, intelligence, and reasonable reactions to boundary violations. The Magic: The Gathering shared interest serves as an effective bonding mechanism that feels organic rather than forced. The technical details throughout are accurate and specific, lending authenticity to the hacker perspective. The restaurant setting is well-utilized, providing numerous opportunities for the protagonist's security observations without feeling contrived. The crisis point - the protagonist commenting on the weak unlock pattern - feels inevitable given the character's established compulsions, and the subsequent negotiation of this social misstep is handled with nuance. Both characters respond believably: she's appropriately uncomfortable but not unreasonably so, and he shows genuine remorse while explaining his perspective. The prose maintains consistent voice throughout, with the internal monologue feeling natural and unforced. Technical terminology is integrated smoothly without overwhelming non-technical readers. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - cautiously optimistic without being unrealistic, acknowledging ongoing challenges while suggesting possibility for growth. Minor weaknesses include occasional over-explanation of technical concepts and some predictable story beats, but these don't significantly detract from an otherwise sophisticated piece that successfully balances multiple complex elements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 86.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Projector squeak. Pause. Squeak. Pause. I think if someone hooked my brain up to it, it would make the same sound. Okay. Okay. Calm down. It’s just a group project. It’s just science. It’s just a living, breathing human sitting three feet away from you with an unfairly nice profile and a T-shirt that proves he knows what mitochondria are. It’s fine. I can’t feel my hands. “Remember,” Ms. Lewis says, click-squeak of the projector as the slide jumps, “this should be collaborative.” Collaborative. Group work. Social horror disguised as education. I sneak a look at him. Jonah. He’s drumming his fingers on the table, the way he does when he’s thinking or bored or, possibly, contemplating his escape from this fluorescent-lit prison. He doesn’t look miserable to be paired with me. That’s something. His hair falls over one eye in a way that would be annoying on anyone else, but somehow on him it looks accidental and perfect, like gravity is in love with his head. “Okay, partners,” Ms. Lewis says. “Start planning. You’ll present Monday.” The room blooms into talking. Chairs drag. Paper rustles. The projector squeaks again, like it’s protesting. I stare at my notebook. Now I have to actually be a person. Say something. “Hey,” Jonah says first, turning slightly toward me. His voice is softer than I expect. “So, um. Ecosystems.” Words. I know words. I read at a twelfth-grade level and once used “ephemeral” correctly in a sentence. Any second now one of those words will come out of my actual mouth. I look up too fast. Eye contact. Abort. I drop my gaze to his shirt: a cartoon planet with sunglasses. That’s safer. No, that’s staring at his chest, that’s weird. Look at the table. Perfect. I’m a normal person looking at a normal table. “Hey,” I manage. It sounds thin and squeaky. I hate my voice. You should smile. I try. My cheeks twitch like I’m smelling something suspicious. Stop. Reset. You practiced this. Script #3: “I’m really glad we’re partners. You’re good at this stuff.” Casual compliment, not too much, shows I’m confident but also not arrogant. Yes. Go. “I’m—” I start. “I was thinking,” he says at the exact same time, and we both stop. He laughs a little. “Sorry. You go.” Panic. Abort compliment. If I say “I’m glad we’re partners” now, it sounds huge, like some kind of confession. Like I’ve thought about it. Which I have. Obviously. But he doesn’t need to know that my brain ran a twenty-minute simulation last night of all the ways this could go. “I was just gonna say…” I can feel the words evaporating. “…um… no, you go.” Brilliant. So eloquent. Truly, a mastermind. He shrugs, still smiling. Is it a polite smile? Pity? No. Not analyzing that. Except I am. Obviously. “I thought we could do something with, like, food chains,” he says. “Since it’s easy to make visuals. And Ms. Lewis literally drools over visuals.” I snort. Out loud. An actual snort. Great. “I mean, not literally,” he says, and laughs. “Yeah, that’d be unhygienic,” I blurt, too quickly. He grins. “Exactly.” Okay. All right. That was almost banter. Breathe. Script #2: “We could build a model with string and pictures. Like, producer, primary consumer, secondary, etc.” Good. Efficient. Not weird. I can do this. “We could,” I say, “um, do a model? With, like… string. For the, you know, trophic levels.” Trophic levels? Why would you say trophic levels out loud? You’re trying to impress him. He’s going to think you’re a try-hard. But he nods. “Yeah, like a big web. That’d look cool.” His pencil starts tapping again. It’s kind of rhythmic. I wonder if he knows he does that. I wonder if it annoys other people. I find it weirdly soothing, which is probably another thing I should not say out loud. “Your fidgeting relaxes me” is not on any of my scripts. I am hyper-aware of my limbs. Where do arms go? I fold mine, then uncross them, then realize that looked weird, so I pretend I was reaching for my notebook. Smooth. “Okay,” he says, “what ecosystem do you want to do?” He looks at me, waiting, like my opinion matters. My heart punches my ribs. Say something normal. “Um. Maybe…” Forest? Ocean? Urban? You’ve thought about this. You literally made a ranked list this morning. Pick one. “Maybe tide pools?” I say. Too specific. Now he’ll know you overprepared. His eyebrows go up a little. “Oh. That’s actually cool.” He scribbles “tide pools??” on the paper. Two question marks. What does that mean? Is he unsure? Am I supposed to justify my choice? You should justify. But not too much. Not a TED Talk. “They’ve just, um,” I start, “they’re like… compact ecosystems. A lot of interactions in a small area. So it’s… neat. For diagrams.” That was… coherent. “Nice,” he says. “Yeah, we can do that.” I feel a stupid flare of pride, like I’ve won something. He liked my idea. Or at least did not reject it outright. Low bar, but still. Projector squeak. I glance up at the screen just to give my eyes somewhere to go. “Food Webs in Ecosystems” blares across the slide like a headline about my internal organs. “Want to split it up?” he asks. “I can do research if you want to, like, design the poster or whatever. You’re good at art, right?” My brain short-circuits. He noticed that? I haven’t drawn in class since October because I didn’t want people to look over my shoulder. He noticed. Careful. Do not beam. Micro-smile only. “Um, I can do the layout,” I say. The word “layout” makes me sound competent. “And some research too. If—if you want.” He leans his elbows on the desk, closer to me. My pulse skyrockets. “Cool. So, like, we need producers, herbivores, carnivores, maybe some decomposers. Starfish eat mussels, right? Or is that wrong?” I know this. I know fifteen facts about tide pool predation. Say one. Just one. “Yeah,” I say. “Pisaster ochraceus. The, um, sea star. It’s a keystone species.” Why. Why did you say the Latin name. Why. But instead of giving me The Look (the one people give when I use my Real Vocabulary), he goes, “Keystone species. That’s the thing where if you take it out, everything collapses, right?” “Yes,” I say, too fast. “Exactly.” Okay. You’re allowed one Latin name. No more. “That’s sick,” he says. “Like Jenga, but with animals.” I laugh. This time it’s a controlled, soft laugh that sounds almost intentional. My shoulders untighten by a millimeter. Say something. Keep it going. You can do small talk. You literally watched a video about it. Script #5: “I like how you explained that.” No, that’s weird. Script #7: Ask about his soccer game this weekend. But what if he thinks it’s creepy you know his schedule? Because you overheard. Twice. Stick to the project. “We could show that,” I say. “On the poster. How if you remove the sea star, the mussels take over and you lose biodiversity. Like, a before and after.” He’s writing as I speak. “That’s awesome.” Awesome. He thinks my idea is awesome. Catalog this moment, file under: Reasons Today Did Not Completely Suck. Projector squeak. Someone in the back laughs too loudly. I flinch. I hope he doesn’t notice. “You okay?” Jonah asks. Too late. “Yeah,” I say. I tuck my hair behind my ear, then immediately wish I hadn’t because now he’s definitely looking at my ear. Ears are weird. Why do we have ears. “I just, um. The squeak.” I gesture vaguely toward the front. “Brain doesn’t like it.” He huffs a tiny laugh. “It is pretty terrible. Like a dying mouse.” “Yes,” I say, maybe too eagerly. “A very repetitive dying mouse.” Stop. That was strange. But he nods. “I’m gonna hear it in my nightmares now. Thanks.” He’s joking. Smile. You know how this works. I smile. This time it’s easier. Something loosens in my chest. “Okay, so,” he says, “you draw. I’ll find stuff about the species. We can print pictures too, glue them on. Maybe do strings connecting everything. Like one of those conspiracy boards.” He mimes connecting dots with imaginary yarn. Say something funny. Say “ecosystem conspiracy.” Say “Keystone Gate.” Say anything. “Like, uh, ‘Who killed the biodiversity?’” I say. What. But he laughs. “Exactly. And it’s just like, some purple starfish in a trenchcoat.” I grin. I did that. Partial credit. I’m suddenly hyper-aware of how close our hands are on the table. Four inches? Three? If I move mine, will it look like I’m avoiding him? If I don’t move it, is that weird? My palm is getting sweaty. Sweat is gross. Move it. No, don’t jerk it. Just… casual reposition. I pretend I need to erase something that isn’t there and slide my hand back. Nailed it. Probably. “You want to, uh,” he says, “maybe work on it together at lunch tomorrow? So we’re not cramming on Sunday?” Lunch. Together. My brain throws up thirty red flags at once. The cafeteria is loud and chaotic and smells like ketchup. If I say no, I’m antisocial. If I say yes, I have to navigate the whole “where do we sit” and “do we talk the whole time” thing, and what if he regrets asking? Script emergency. “Sure,” I hear myself say. Too fast. That sounded desperate. “Cool,” he says. No visible regret. “We can grab one of those tables by the windows?” He picked a quiet spot. Thoughtfulness? Coincidence? Don’t overinterpret. You always overinterpret. Just nod. “Yeah,” I say. “That’s good.” The projector squeaks again, and Ms. Lewis says, “Five more minutes, guys!” Time is fake. I feel like I’ve lived an entire life in the last ten. I should say something normal. Something that isn’t about sea stars or string. Ask a question. People love questions. “So,” I start, then freeze. No script ready. Raw social interaction. Horrifying. He looks at me, waiting. Abort? No. Commit. “How’s… soccer?” I ask. Immediate regret. Too vague. Too obviously eavesdropped. Everyone knows he plays soccer. No they don’t, you know because you listen. Ugh. But he just brightens. “Pretty good. We’ve got a tournament Saturday. I’m kinda nervous.” He’s nervous. That’s… human. “You’ll do great,” I say, before I can overthink it. It comes out firm. Certain. He blinks, like I surprised him. “Thanks,” he says. His smile this time is smaller, realer. “I hope so.” Heat creeps up my neck. Did that sound flirty? It wasn’t flirty. It was supportive. Is supportive flirty? My brain needs a manual. “Okay,” I mumble, looking down. “So… tide pool conspiracy board at lunch.” “Yep,” he says. “With the dying mouse soundtrack.” He nods toward the projector, which squeaks right on cue. I let out a real laugh. Dangerous. People might notice I’m enjoying myself. The bell rings. Chaos detonates. Chairs scrape, backpacks zip. Jonah stands, slinging his bag over one shoulder. “I’ll bring the string,” he says. “I’ll bring the sea stars,” I say. What? No. No, that’s not— But he grins. “Cool. See you tomorrow.” He walks away. I exhale so hard I almost deflate. My heart is doing gymnastics. My brain replays every second in a highlight reel of potential humiliation. You snorted. You said Latin. You invented a dead mouse soundtrack. You’re ridiculous. He smiled. He laughed. He asked to work with you. He said cool like twelve times. I pack my notebook carefully, like it contains evidence that I can, occasionally, function. Tomorrow, window table. Tide pools. String. Jonah. Projector squeak. My brain squeak. Maybe I’ll survive.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of the assigned task, delivering an authentic portrayal of an anxious 8th-grade girl's internal experience. The narrative successfully captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of social anxiety through almost entirely internal monologue, as requested. The character voice is remarkably consistent and believable. The protagonist's internal commentary feels genuinely adolescent - intelligent but self-sabotaging, articulate in thought but stumbling in speech. The gap between her sophisticated internal vocabulary ("trophic levels," "Pisaster ochraceus") and her awkward verbal fumbling is well-executed and creates natural tension. The writing excels at showing rather than telling emotional states. Instead of stating "she was nervous," we get physical manifestations: "I can't feel my hands," sweaty palms, heart "punching" ribs. The recurring projector squeak serves as both atmospheric detail and metaphor for her mental state, creating coherent imagery throughout. The dialogue, though minimal, feels natural and age-appropriate. Jonah's casual speech patterns ("That's sick," "Like Jenga, but with animals") contrast effectively with the protagonist's more formal internal voice. Their interaction builds believably from awkward starts to tentative connection. However, the piece has some weaknesses. Certain phrases edge toward overwrought territory ("my heart punches my ribs," "chaos detonates"), though they generally stay within the heightened emotional register appropriate for an anxious teenager. Some moments risk being slightly precious in their self-awareness, particularly the meta-commentary about social scripts. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - the protagonist doesn't undergo a dramatic transformation but experiences a small, earned victory. The final optimism feels genuine rather than forced, emerging naturally from the successful interaction rather than being imposed. The prose flows well overall, with effective use of sentence fragments and interrupted thoughts that mirror anxious thinking patterns. The piece maintains strong reader engagement through relatable emotional authenticity and specific, vivid details that ground the abstract experience of social anxiety in concrete moments. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
