+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming convened in its indifferent splendor. Thrones and pews shifted subtly as witnesses arrived, rearranging themselves to suit each new presence. The ceiling was a high, dim arch that suggested stars without committing to any. Banners of other people’s half-remembered nightmares drifted overhead like lazy storm fronts. In the center: the obsidian bench of Dream of the Endless, where he sat, draped in the definition of sleeplessness. His eyes, two remote night skies, regarded the case file before him. “Next matter,” intoned a clerk who was also, apparently, every school intercom speaker ever used to say someone’s name wrong. “Case of First Love vs. Mora, re: Territorial Interference, Codex of Recurring Innocent Dreamscapes, subsection—” “That is sufficient,” Dream said, voice low, edged with bored thunder. He didn’t slam a gavel. Time hiccuped instead. Everyone understood that to mean “Come to order.” First Love stepped forward. He was perpetually mid-blush: curls a little damp with nerves, cardigan slightly too big, smelling faintly of pencil shavings and cheap perfume samples. He clutched a folio embossed with shy hearts. His eyes shone with wounded sincerity. At the opposing table lounged Mora. She was long-limbed and lightless, hair hanging like drowned weeds, skin the color of old milk and fingernails vaguely too sharp to be incidental. Her dress looked like it had been stolen from a peasant’s funeral and never washed. Yellow eyes hooded, she reclined with a lazy predatory ease, one knee over the other, as if the bench beneath her were someone’s ribcage. Faint cackles slipped from her now and then: thin and rasping, stretching up into the vaulted darkness like someone testing the acoustics inside a coffin. The sound made a couple of lesser nightmares in the gallery unconsciously fasten their collars. Dream surveyed them with palpable reluctance. “This is a territorial dispute,” he said. “Concerning the recurring dreamscape of one mortal, Max Aronson, aged fifteen years, eight months, and three days. Initial petitioner: First Love. Respondent: Mora. I will hear argument.” First Love cleared his throat. A small, hopeful violin note tried to play somewhere and thought better of it. “My lord Dream,” he began, “for the past three months I have been carefully curating an age-appropriate, emotionally constructive romantic fantasy for the subject. It is calibrated. Gentle. Organic. We have wildflowers, adolescent banter, shared earbuds, hand-on-hand brush, nearly-kissing, mutual blushing—textbook stuff. I cite Precedent: The Fair and Glorious Crush of Eliana Reed, 2003, and the Bench’s own commentary in The Matter of Softly Lit Lockers vs. Gratuitous Heavy Petting.” “That was mischaracterized in the headnotes,” Dream muttered. “Continue.” First Love flicked his folio open; out fluttered a projection of the dream: a summer field, golden, girl laughing, boy stammering before she leans in, their noses nearly touching. “It was functioning within ideal parameters,” First Love said. “Heart rate elevated, no panic. Hormones stirred, not stampeded. He wakes with a warm confusion and a fresh respect for the inscrutable majesty of girls. Then—” He jabbed a finger. The girl in the projection straddled Max’s chest, smile stretching too wide, eyes hollowing. Her hair spooled into darkness, hands elongating, bloom of shadowy weight pinning him. Mora’s silhouette unfolded from within the sweet shape. The gallery murmured. A bureaucrat made of index cards took notes. Max’s projected eyes bulged. No scream emerged. Mora’s projected self leered. “Hush now,” echoing in three languages at once. The image dissipated. First Love swallowed. “As you can see, milord, this is an egregious annexation of an Innocent Dreamscape by a predatory nightmare entity. It contravenes—uh—Article 7: Non-Encroachment on Formative Sentimental Architecture. I am asking the Court to restore exclusive creative custodianship to myself and bar Mora from feeding in that dream.” He finished, cheeks pink. A very small heart-shaped light popped into existence over his head and then fled in embarrassment. Dream turned his gaze to Mora. She smiled with too many implications. “Your Nightfulness.” The faint cackle that followed ricocheted around the rafters, made a sleeping juror made of tangled headphones jerk upright. “Let us skip the flattery,” Dream said coolly. “Explain.” Mora rolled a thin shoulder. “The field is mine by right of utility. Nice boy, nice lungs, strong little panics. He lies down with his burgeoning confusions, and lo, a vacancy: ripeness of breath, open chest, throttled words. A buffet. I am what? A professional. I see opportunity; I sit.” “You invaded an established construct,” First Love protested. “I filed that field.” “You made him helpless,” Mora said, eyes glinting. “You pinned him with feelings he can’t articulate, locked his limbs with uncertainty, sat emotion on his breastbone so he can’t breathe properly until after he wakes. I merely… clarified. Rationalized the metaphor. Gave the weight a face. Mine.” “There is a distinction,” First Love insisted. “Mine was ephemeral; yours is literally feeding on—” “A girl’s gotta eat,” Mora said, spreading her hands. “You think existential dread grows on trees? Nutrition is down. Fewer villagers. Fewer feather mattresses. Half my accounts converted to ‘mindfulness and deep breathing apps.’” The word app came out like a slur. “I am starving. I find one tidy recurring dream with textbook supine boy, inviting posture, suggestive mounting. You left the door open.” Dream’s expression, carved and shadowed, shifted by a millimeter. In his realm, that counted as an eye-roll. From the gallery, a Nightmare in a suit of legal documents raised a tendril. “Your Lordship, if I may, we have schedules. The night terrors of overworked junior associates wait past midnight. Precedent demands swift resolution.” “Noted,” Dream said. Not that he intended to be swift. Irritation pulsed faintly behind his calm; squabbling between abstractions over one mortal’s hormones was rarely edifying, and yet here they were. He looked back to Mora. “You alter the emotional valence of the dream. The boy wakes shaken. Exhausted.” Mora shrugged, unapologetic. “He wakes relieved to be alive. Grateful to suck air. That’s formative too. Depth, your Gloominess. Character-building. And he still finds the girl… interesting. More so, even. Conflicted attraction plus brush with death. That’s premium developmental seasoning.” First Love made a strangled sound. “We do not season them with death!” “Honey, you’re First Love,” Mora said. “Half your portfolio ends in heartbreak playlists and poems written in math class margins. I’ve seen your work. Some of it’s messier than me.” The faint cackle rose again, threading needles in the upper dark. Dream tapped a long finger against the obsidian arm of his throne. The sound was like a gavel wrapped in velvet, striking bone. “Enough,” he said. Silence folded in. “The mortal belongs to neither of you,” Dream went on. “He belongs to himself. His dreams, however, are mine to steward.” Both entities bowed their heads, in their respective idioms: First Love deferent, Mora with a slight mocking flourish. “I acknowledge,” Dream said, “that First Love has prior claim over the architectural foundation: the field, the girl, the unresolved tenderness. I also acknowledge,” he added, though it tasted like ash, “that Mora has found a… plausible interpretive aperture.” Mora’s smile widened. First Love’s ears turned pinker. “The Court must weigh,” Dream said, “the principles of stability versus… innovation.” His gaze drifted upward as if listening to an argument only he could hear. The gallery fidgeted: a pile of teeth crossed its legs; an old teacher’s disembodied voice sighed. Dream’s annoyance nudged at him, slyly suggesting mischief. He could simply ban Mora. Restore the saccharine safety of the field. But safe dreams alone made dull mortals, and dull mortals bred dull dreams. He could give Mora free rein, but then every crush would curdle into sleep paralysis erotica, and paperwork would be unbearable. So. “Here is my judgment,” Dream said. Time leaned in. “First Love retains core custodianship over the dreamscape. The wildflowers, the sky, the recurring presence of the girl, the emotional gradations of innocent longing—all remain as designed. Mora is hereby restricted to limited, scheduled manifestation.” Both blinked. “Define ‘limited,’” Mora purred carefully. Dream’s lips almost, almost tilted. “One incursion every… third recurrence. On such nights, you may appear as you have: seated upon his chest, distorting his breath, crystallizing his fears. You will not, however, feed to excess. No lasting damage. Elevated heart rate, temporary paralysis, existential confusion are permissible. Trauma is not.” “That’s outrageous,” First Love burst out. “You’re letting her turn my work into a horror show every three nights!” “Compromise,” Dream said. “You wish him to feel the tremor of first vulnerability. She wishes him to taste the sharpness at the edges of desire. Both are true. Both are mine.” Mora’s faint cackle spooled delightedly through the rafters. “I find these terms… digestible.” “Additionally,” Dream added, voice like a latch closing, “on nights of Mora’s presence, the girl will not fully transform until after contact is initiated. Prolong the ambiguity. Let him lean up, almost kiss, reach. Then change.” First Love stared at him, horrified. “You are engineering a lifelong complex.” “An elegantly balanced one,” Dream said. “He will grow up uncertain whether intimacy means suffocation or salvation. Such men write very interesting books.” A small, private satisfaction cooled his irritation. “Also, as a matter of equity, Mora is forbidden from poaching from any dreamscape marked ‘Foundational Innocence’ without preliminary filing. I will not have you nesting in every prom night.” Mora sulked for a heartbeat. “Fine. But I’m keeping Max. He twitches delightfully.” “He is not yours,” Dream said. “He is a client.” The banners overhead shifted: a remembered locker hallway, a damp forest, a childhood bedroom door half-open. “It is so ordered,” Dream concluded. Instead of a gavel, he let the lights flicker. The sound of a thousand alarm clocks briefly filled the chamber, then died. Case closed. First Love gathered his folio, shoulders slumped. Mora sauntered past him, brushing his arm with spectral fingers. “Cheer up,” she murmured. “We’re co-parenting.” Another faint cackle. It lingered in the vaulted ceiling like the aftertaste of a bad idea. Dream watched them go. His face was again a perfectly carved absence of expression. Deep in the mortal world, Max Aronson slept. In his dream, the sky was soft, the field in bloom. His crush laughed, pushing him gently down into the flowers. His heart pounded. She leaned over him, hair curtaining his face. For one endless second, everything was perfect, confusing, bright. Then her smile… lengthened. Ambiguity ripened. Far away in his hall of judgment, Dream permitted himself the smallest inward smile, invisible to all. Some matters, at least, might prove… interesting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong execution of a complex prompt, successfully blending dark fantasy with courtroom comedy in the realm of Dream. The author creates a vivid, surreal courtroom setting that feels authentically otherworldly while maintaining familiar legal proceedings structure. The characterizations are particularly strong. Dream embodies the aloof, irritated authority figure perfectly - his barely contained annoyance at having to adjudicate such petty matters comes through clearly without breaking his mythic gravitas. First Love is endearingly earnest and bureaucratic, while Mora is deliciously predatory yet pragmatic. Her "a girl's gotta eat" defense is both darkly funny and logically consistent with her nature. The dialogue sparkles throughout, with each character having a distinct voice. Mora's casual menace ("Honey, you're First Love"), Dream's imperious boredom, and First Love's wounded sincerity all feel authentic. The legal terminology mixed with fantastical elements creates effective comedy without becoming forced. The prose strikes an excellent balance - descriptive enough to establish atmosphere ("banners of other people's half-remembered nightmares drifted overhead like lazy storm fronts") without becoming purple or overwrought. The writing maintains readability while creating genuinely evocative imagery. The resolution is particularly clever, subverting expectations by having Dream engineer a compromise that satisfies his own sense of mischief while appearing judicial. His final observation about creating "men who write very interesting books" adds layers to his character and motivations. The dark comedy emerges naturally from the absurd situation and character interactions rather than forced jokes. The piece maintains consistent tone throughout, never losing its fantastical gravitas despite the comedic elements. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the legal proceedings feel slightly repetitive, and a few instances where descriptive phrases approach purple prose territory, though they generally stay within bounds. The pacing is generally strong, though the middle section during arguments could be tightened slightly. Overall, this is sophisticated fantasy writing that successfully balances multiple tonal elements while delivering on all the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A crimson harvest moon casts ominous shadows on the deserted village streets. Wind prowls through the skeletons of cottages, setting loose shutters clapping like nervous teeth. Smoke stains the sky where chimneys once worked; now they gape, black and cold. The stench of old blood, damp wood, and something colder coils through the silence. He comes first. Alucard walks the central street like it belongs to him, the long red coat snapping behind him as though in a gale only he can feel. His hat's brim shades a grin that is all teeth and intent, orange lenses catching the moonlight and reflecting it back as ember-bright slits. He hums to himself. No heartbeat but his own hunger fills the village. Disappointing. "Humans," he says, stretching the word. "They never last long enough." The shadows at his feet wriggle. One of them rises, dark and eyeless, a slavering parody of a hound. It sniffs the air. "Nothing?" he asks it. It whines. Negative. "Mm. Then what are you?" Alucard tilts his head. Because there is something. Not human. Not vampire. Power, controlled rather than ravenous, threaded with steel-hard will and old, exquisite pain. She steps from the mouth of an alley as though the darkness were a curtain she has chosen to part. Yennefer of Vengerberg is the one splash of deliberate color in the dead street: midnight hair spilling over black and violet, a curve of hip in tight leather, white blouse open at the throat where a star-shaped pendant rests. Her eyes: impossible violet, bright as polished amethyst even under the blood moon. She smells of lilac and gooseberries, incongruous in this charnel air, cutting through decay with sharp sweetness. She sees a tall man in a garish red coat she recognizes from no court, no lodge. He is wrong in a way that sets her teeth on edge. They stop a few paces apart, facing each other across a cobblestone vein of shadow. "Well," Yennefer says, letting her gaze rake him. "You’re not human." Alucard’s grin widens. "And you, Miss Lilac-and-Gooseberries, are delightfully obvious. Tell me, which circle of hell polished you so nicely?" "If this is your attempt at charm," she replies, "I suggest you shoot yourself with one of those toys and try again in your next life." A chuckle, low and delighted, spills from him. "I like you." Her fingers twitch a fraction, feeling the familiar thrumming of chaos particles at her call. The air thickens. Reality watches her closely; it remembers her. His shadows curl higher, attentive. "So," Alucard says, lifting his glasses slightly to look at her with bare red eyes. "What killed this village, little witch?" "Little." Her jaw tightens. "Careful." He inhales theatrically. "Mmm. Not you. Shame. Would've been fun. No, this reeks of fledglings; the cheap, ungrateful sort. Pretenders." "Vampires did this," she says flatly. "Things that called themselves such. I corrected them." He shrugs. "They squealed. I got bored." The admission is casual, but there is a weight beneath it—a predator who has culled lesser predators. Yennefer studies him more carefully. "You enjoy this," she says. "Of course," he answers. "It’s what a monster does." She does not flinch at the word. Instead, her eyes narrow with interest. "You're honest, at least." "And you," he says, "are not entirely disgusted. Intriguing." She takes a slow step closer. Power hums between them, magic to monster, like flint near tinder. "You don't belong to this world," she says. "And you don't smell like your peasants." His gaze drifts down and up, not lecherous so much as appraising. Hunting. "You wear time poorly. It's clinging to you beneath the glamour. Hollow bones held together by stubbornness and regret." A flicker of rage threatens her composure, quick as lightning, gone as fast. "And you," she says, "are bound. Leashed. I can taste it on you. This isn't your leash-holder's land, is it, dog?" He laughs, loud, delighted. The sound startles crows from a burned roof; they burst up into the blood moon like torn scraps. "The bird of Hermes is my name," Alucard murmurs. "Eating my wings to make me tame." She hears the ancient riddle and hears, beneath it, the truth of self-mutilated restraint. The idea of something so destructive collared pleases her in a dark corner of herself. "Poetic," she says. "Did they teach you to fetch as well?" His grin cuts sharp. "Careful, sorceress. I'm not sweet, and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Her laugh is a soft, lethal spark. "Stole my line. Poorly." He moves. It's not speed humans can track; one moment he is yards away, the next his gloved hand is at her throat. Except it closes on static. Yennefer has already folded space. She reappears behind him, fingers already weaving. A pressure wave slams into his back, a disc of compressed air and force strong enough to pulp stone. It shreds his coat, snaps bone. Alucard’s torso detonates in a wet spatter, half his body evaporating into gore. He staggers, laughing even as he explodes. Flesh crawls back together like a film played in reverse, ribs knitting, spine rethreading, organs blooming wetly into place. Shadows drag his scattered parts back to him with slavish devotion. "Oh," he says, delighted. "You break things." "I warned you," she replies coolly. "Don't touch me without permission." She hides her own spike of unease. Regeneration that is not healing but re-formation. No sign of strain. No cost she can see. He tips his head. "My turn." The street darkens. Not night, but something deeper: his familiars unfurl. An ocean of eyes opens at his feet. Dogs with skeletal faces and rows of teeth spill from his coat; a pale, eyeless girl; bayonets; bats like shards of midnight. The pressure of him slams against her wards. Yennefer’s pulse quickens, but her lips curve. She lifts both hands. The cobblestones beneath the first charging hound erupt in violet fire, conflagration without heat, pure annihilation. It howls as it's stripped to ash mid-leap. She snaps her fingers, redirecting the blaze into a ring that carves a border between her and the swarm. They test it. They burn. "You're not chaos," she mutters, studying the creatures. "You're...history. Memory and meat." "Call them souls, if it amuses you," Alucard says. His shape is stretching now, hat and coat losing coherence, something vast and winged unfurling. His voice comes from everywhere. "Witch, you interest me." "Good," she says. "I’d hate this to be one-sided." She opens a portal—a tear hanging in the air, its edges rimmed in violet-white crackle. A gust of winter from a far-off peak roars through, colliding with his summoned beasts, flash-freezing spectral flesh. Another gesture, and stone spikes spear upward beneath them, shattering frozen bodies. He laughs, but there's a sharpened edge now. He fires; the Jackal roars in his hand, impossible gun conjured with a twitch. Silver-rune bullet, heavy with blessings foreign to this land, slams into her chest. Yennefer’s body jerks. She feels the puncture, the searing magic woven into the metal. For a heartbeat, breath is impossible. She refuses to give him the satisfaction of a cry. Her amulet flares. The bullet halts inches from her heart, embedded in a sudden crystalline shield that has grown inside her like ice. She exhales, hissing. Alucard’s eyes gleam. "Oh, very good." She answers by twisting her fingers and turning his shadow against him. For an instant, his own darkness tries to bind his limbs. It fails—she’s working with an unfamiliar substrate—but it slows him, enough that her next spell lands: a binding circle flares under his boots, sigils forming out of moonlight and bloodstain. He feels it: an attempt at compulsion. Command. Chains. The field smolders against his existence like cobwebs laid over a hurricane. "Ambitious," he purrs, testing the circle. It cracks. "Did you really think you could collar me, girl?" "I wanted to see," she says. "What you'd do." She watches the sigils split under the pressure of him. No fear. Calculation. "You remind me of my master," Alucard says. "A woman who thought she could point me at her enemies and live long enough to enjoy it." "Did she?" "Long enough." Something softens, almost imperceptibly, at the thought of Integra. Yennefer sees it. Files it away. Their eyes lock, predator to predator. "You want to die," she says quietly, suddenly certain. He smiles, slow, something old and tired peering out through the mania. "I want to be killed. There’s a difference." "And you think I could," she says, not a question but a taste of the possibility. "I think," he says, "you might make me work for it." Silence rests a moment between them, stretched taut as a drawn bow. Behind her steel, she recognizes him: the weight of centuries, the exhaustion of outliving purpose. Behind his bloodlust, he recognizes her: desperate for what has been taken, hungry for power enough to rewrite her own fate. "Help me, then," she says suddenly. The words surprise even her, but she does not retract them. "You know death. Old magics. Curses. You swim in them. There is a thing that was done to me. I intend to undo it." His tongue slips against his teeth. Interesting. "And what will you give me, sorceress?" "Entertainment," Yennefer says. "A war. Enemies worth the effort. And, perhaps, one day, an attempt at that death you yearn for." The wind rises. The blood moon looms huge and close, as if eavesdropping. Their power hums against each other, unbowed. "And if I grow bored," Alucard asks, "if I decide your spine isn't as straight as your posture?" She smiles, wicked and luminous. "Then you can try to kill me." He laughs again, softer. He holsters his gun. His familiars recede like a tide. The street brightens a shade. Yennefer lowers her hands, though the spells wait, coiled. Side by side now, they regard the ruined village, the handiwork of lesser monsters. "Well, Alucard," she says, tasting his name. "Are you coming?" "For now," he answers. "But remember, Yennefer of Vengerberg: I don't serve. I indulge." "Then consider this an indulgence." Under the crimson harvest moon, two ancient predators walk out of the dead village together, neither leading, neither following, each already plotting the day they'll finally decide which of them breaks first.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This is a sophisticated piece of crossover fiction that demonstrates strong technical writing skills and deep character understanding. The author successfully merges two distinct fictional universes while maintaining the essential characteristics of both Alucard and Yennefer. The atmospheric opening is particularly effective, establishing the gothic medieval setting with vivid imagery of the destroyed village. The prose maintains a consistent dark, gothic tone throughout that suits both characters perfectly. The author demonstrates excellent command of descriptive language, creating striking visual moments like the blood moon, the shadows writhing at Alucard's feet, and Yennefer's violet-fire magic. Character portrayal is exceptionally strong. Alucard's sadistic playfulness, his philosophical musings about his nature, and his underlying death wish are all authentically rendered. His dialogue captures his theatrical, mocking tone while revealing deeper layers of existential weariness. Yennefer is equally well-realized - her pride, magical prowess, political cunning, and hidden vulnerabilities all shine through. The author particularly excels at showing her refusal to be intimidated while acknowledging the genuine threat Alucard poses. The power dynamics shift convincingly throughout their encounter. Neither character is diminished; instead, they recognize each other as equals, which drives the tension effectively. The combat sequence is well-choreographed, showcasing both characters' abilities without feeling like mere spectacle. The magical descriptions are creative and visceral without becoming overwrought. The dialogue crackles with wit and menace. Each character maintains their distinct voice - Alucard's theatrical grandiosity versus Yennefer's sharp, cutting remarks. Their verbal sparring feels natural and advances both plot and characterization. The author successfully weaves in canonical quotes and references that feel organic rather than forced. The story's structure moves smoothly from initial confrontation through escalating conflict to an intriguing resolution. The pacing never drags, maintaining tension throughout. The ending, where they form an uneasy alliance, feels earned based on their mutual recognition of each other's capabilities and desires. Some minor criticisms: Occasionally the prose veers toward purple territory with phrases like "cobblestone vein of shadow," though this generally suits the gothic atmosphere. A few descriptions could be tightened. The piece sometimes tells us character motivations rather than showing them entirely through action, though this is relatively minor. The emotional complexity is notable - both characters are drawn to each other precisely because they recognize kindred spirits: ancient beings carrying centuries of pain and power. The author successfully implies deeper themes about immortality, purpose, and the burden of power without being heavy-handed. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 75.0
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A dim overhead light flickers in the prison corridor at irregular intervals. Each sputter of light stretches the shadows into long, skeletal shapes across the concrete floor. The air smells of bleach, rust, and the faint metallic tang of blood that someone tried too hard to wash away. Jolyne Cujoh leans against the bars of her cell, watching the corridor like it might open its mouth and speak. Stone Free’s strings lazily circle her wrist, unseen by everyone but other Stand users. Every third flicker, she sends one hair-fine thread out beyond the bars, feeling for vibrations, mapping guard positions, counting keys. Something is wrong in this place, and it isn’t the usual Green Dolphin Street type of wrong. Worse. Colder. Footsteps approach—measured, soft, too clean for this dump. Jolyne retracts the string, eyes narrowing. She comes into view between flickers: a woman in a neat black suit, white shirt buttoned to the collar, auburn hair braided professionally. Yellow eyes that catch the failing light and do something strange with it. She walks flanked by guards whose expressions are… slack. Not scared. Not bored. Just empty. “Who the hell are you?” Jolyne calls before the woman can even stop. “New warden? You look like you’d get murdered for your shoes in gen pop.” The woman stops at Jolyne’s cell. The guards halt a precise half-step behind her. Her smile is small, immaculate, and utterly calm. “Hello, Jolyne Cujoh,” she says. Her voice is pleasant, soft, smooth as a knife’s flat. “My name is Makima. I’ve been given oversight of this facility as of today.” “Yeah?” Jolyne crosses her arms. “If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney. You government or something?” A flicker—dark—then light. Makima’s eyes do not move from Jolyne’s face. “Something like that.” Stone Free whispers at the edge of Jolyne’s consciousness, an instinctive prickle she’s learned to trust. Jolyne watches the way the guards don’t look at Makima so much as orient around her. Not protective—possessed. Makima tilts her head, gaze lowering to Jolyne’s arm where the butterfly tattoo peeks out. “You’ve been causing incidents, Jolyne. Strange occurrences. Injured personnel. Cells breached. Hallways rewired with… string.” Jolyne smirks. “Guess I just have nimble fingers.” Makima steps closer to the bars. The guards’ heads turn an exact fraction, tracking her, leashes only they can feel. “We should have a conversation. I think we can help each other.” Jolyne’s skin crawls. That smile is wrong. Too careful. Like she practiced being kind in a mirror until it fit. “Hard pass,” Jolyne says. “I’ve had enough psycho authority figures for one lifetime.” Makima’s eyes soften, like a patient teacher humoring a child. “You’re very special, Jolyne. You have an ability that lets you become string, transmit sound, cut, bind, travel. You can unravel yourself without breaking. That is quite valuable.” “How the hell do you know about—” “I know many things.” Makima’s voice never changes volume. The lights buzz, pop, and resume their dying rhythm. “Your bloodline. Your father. Your destiny, twisted around Stands and fates. I know that you struggle with being seen as someone’s daughter rather than yourself. And I know you hate cages.” Jolyne goes still. Stone Free’s string curls tight around her fingers. “You got a file or are you just a stalker?” Jolyne says, forcing a scoff. She has fought priests obsessed with heaven and sea monsters in skin suits; she knows how words get weaponized. But something about Makima’s gaze feels like falling into a well with no bottom. “I work with devils,” Makima says. “Demons, if you’d like. Concepts born of fear. Unlike Stands, they’re more… communicable. Your ability exists in a related sphere. Strings can bind, can control. I’m very interested in that.” Jolyne barks out a laugh. “Lady, if you think you can control me with some creepy HR evaluation—” One of the guards suddenly steps forward, face blank, and slams his head into the bars so hard the clang echoes down the corridor. Blood runs instantly down his forehead. He doesn’t flinch. “Stop,” Makima says, without looking at him. He stops. Jolyne doesn’t move, but Stone Free explodes to life inside her like a coiled spring. That wasn’t a Stand attack. No aura she recognizes. Just a word. Makima smiles, the expression never reaching those concentric yellow eyes. “I dislike disrespect. But I’m very forgiving with dogs that don’t know the rules yet.” Another flicker of light plunges all of them into momentary near-darkness. In that beat, Jolyne flattens a thread through the air, reaching for Makima’s sleeve, her edge, something. The string grazes along Makima’s arm—and Jolyne feels it: a pressure, immense and indifferent, like pushing a finger into the event horizon of a black hole. She retracts instantly. Makima has felt it. Jolyne sees the infinitesimal shift of interest. “Incredible,” Makima murmurs. “You turn yourself into your own leash.” “The hell I do,” Jolyne snaps. “I don’t wear collars.” “You already do,” Makima says. “Your father. Your friends. Your sense of justice. You’re driven by them. I can offer you clarity. Freedom from bad leashes. Put a good one on instead.” “Wow, deep,” Jolyne says. “You rehearse that in the mirror? You smell like a cult brochure.” Makima’s smile widens. “Jolyne. Come closer to the bars.” The words have weight. They try to settle into Jolyne’s muscles, urging obedience, a soft suggestion that wants to become command. For a millisecond, her foot shifts. “Stone Free!” Threads burst from her arm, bracing against the walls, anchoring her body in place. The pressure slides over her like oil over braided steel. It doesn’t take. She grits her teeth. Makima notes this. She reaches up to adjust her tie, as if pleased. “You resisted,” she says simply. “That makes you more interesting, not less. Stands are the manifestations of will. The Control Devil’s power is less effective on those who stand outside conventional systems of fear, or who are…” Her gaze lingers. “Positioned differently. You’re not a normal human. Good.” “Keep talking like that,” Jolyne says, “and I’m gonna start charging admission.” “Jolyne,” Makima continues, voice still unbearably gentle, “I will be clear. This facility is no longer under your previous warden’s jurisdiction. I have made contracts. The inmates, the guards, the devils housed below—they belong to me. You are an anomaly I haven’t decided upon yet.” “Try ‘not for sale.’” Makima looks down the corridor, where cell after cell lies unnaturally quiet. Somewhere, a prisoner whispers a prayer; somewhere closer, one of Makima’s “pets” stands motionless, waiting. “I can protect you from what’s coming,” Makima says. “And from your enemies. I can ensure your father lives. Your allies survive. In return, you obey. It’s okay,” she adds, so softly it almost doesn’t register. “Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Jolyne’s heart jerks. Cold fury and disgust burn through her like acid. “You don’t get to say shit about my old man,” she says. “You don’t get to say shit about my friends. You try to use them as a leash, I’ll hang you with it.” Makima studies her as if evaluating a stray with sharp teeth. She raises her hand. “On your knees,” she says. The command slams into the corridor. Several guards drop instantly, kneeling, heads bowed. Farther down, a prisoner screams as his legs buckle without his consent. An invisible pressure drives at Jolyne, a mountainous intent to force her to submit. Stone Free’s strings burst from her spine and limbs, embedding into the walls, floor, ceiling, webbing her upright. “Not happening,” Jolyne growls between clenched teeth. The effort makes sweat bead at her temple, but she’s not moving. “I’m not your dog, bitch.” Makima’s placid expression never changes, but her eyes narrow, just barely. “How stubborn,” she says. “I like you.” Jolyne spits at her. A thread-guided fleck of saliva flies straight for Makima’s face. It stops midsair. Compresses. Implodes into nothing. The air distorts between them. For the first time, Jolyne glimpses—just a flicker—shapes behind Makima: silhouettes with weapons, hands pressed together in prayer, invisible executioners waiting for a name. An entire killing mechanism leashed to a single woman’s will. “This prison,” Makima says calmly, “is going to be an experiment ground. For devils. For humans. For chainsaws and strings. You can wander it freely if you like. You can fight me. Try to break my toys. It will make this more entertaining.” “You think this is a game?” Jolyne snaps. “Oh, Jolyne,” Makima says. “Everything is a game of control.” The lights flicker. Off. On. In that half-second of shadow, Jolyne extends Stone Free through the bars, a razor-thin fiber looping for Makima’s throat. The light returns. Makima is inside the loop, one step closer, unharmed. Her hand is gently holding the string between thumb and forefinger, like examining a piece of silk. “You’ll have to be more clever,” she says. “But please. Keep trying.” She releases the string. It snaps back to Jolyne’s hand with a sharp sting. Makima turns away, walking down the corridor. The kneeling guards rise in perfect unison and follow. As she passes each cell, eyes lower, breaths hitch, wills bend to hers like grass in gale. “Wait,” Jolyne calls, impulse bolting ahead of caution. “Why me? You’ve clearly got a whole pound of mutts already.” Makima does not look back. “Because, Jolyne,” she says, voice echoing mildly, “you’re the only one here who might bite.” The dim overhead light flickers again, making Makima’s silhouette shudder, fracture, then lengthen with each step until she vanishes around the corner. Alone, Jolyne exhales slowly. Her hands shake. She hates that. But Stone Free is already working, threads spiderwebbing from her fingertips into walls and pipes, tracing this twisted new territory, mapping exits, security patterns—and every point where Makima’s influence sits like a stain. “Battle of wills, huh?” Jolyne mutters. “Fine.” Her strings hum, taut with defiance. “You try to put a collar on me,” she whispers into the empty corridor, “I’ll show you how it feels when a leash snaps.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt, successfully creating a tense encounter between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima in a supernatural prison setting. The author captures both characters' essential traits effectively - Jolyne's defiant, hot-headed nature and crude speech patterns, and Makima's deceptively calm demeanor masking profound manipulation and control. The character portrayals feel authentic to their source materials. Jolyne's immediate suspicion and refusal to submit aligns perfectly with her established personality, while Makima's patient, predatory approach and casual demonstration of power over others rings true. The dialogue captures their distinct voices well, particularly Jolyne's profanity-laced defiance and Makima's eerily gentle commands. The writing establishes strong atmosphere through environmental details - the flickering lights, concrete corridors, and metallic scents create an appropriately oppressive prison setting. The author uses these elements symbolically, with light and shadow emphasizing the psychological tension. The story effectively builds tension through escalating demonstrations of power. Makima's casual control over the guards, followed by her attempt to command Jolyne directly, creates genuine stakes. Jolyne's resistance through Stone Free feels earned and consistent with Stand mechanics. The prose generally flows well, though there are moments where descriptions become slightly overwrought. Phrases like "event horizon of a black hole" and "mountainous intent" occasionally feel excessive for the tone. The writing sometimes tells rather than shows, particularly in explaining the characters' abilities and motivations. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively - advancing plot, revealing character, and building tension. Makima's philosophical manipulations contrast sharply with Jolyne's blunt responses, creating natural conflict. The ending maintains the established tension without resolving it artificially. Jolyne's defiant closing thoughts feel earned given her character arc and the escalation of threat. Some minor weaknesses include occasional redundancy in describing the characters' powers and motivations, and a few instances where the prose becomes unnecessarily elaborate. The pacing is generally strong but occasionally slows during expository moments. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 9.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 75.7
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
ITEM#: SCP-████ OBJECT CLASS: EUCLID (Pending escalation to Keter) SPECIAL CONTAINMENT PROCEDURES: (Excerpt) As of Incident Log ████-07, Dr. Elias Marris is to be monitored continuously via biometric tracking and audiovisual surveillance within Site-73. All handwritten materials in Dr. Marris’s vicinity are to be cataloged and scanned for anomalous properties. Standard Foundation memo paper is restricted; any appearance of non-issued sheets is to be treated as an active anomaly event. Psychological evaluations of Dr. Marris are to be conducted thrice weekly, focusing on reality testing and susceptibility to ontokinetic and cognitohazardous influence. All discovered notes (designated SCP-████-A) are to be stored in a secure locker and cross-referenced for predictive validity. No SCP-████-A instance is to be destroyed without O5 authorization. This document is an excerpt from the personal report filed by Dr. Marris, included as provisional primary source evidence. Editorial redactions have been minimized for temporal correlation analysis. — I remember the first note because it was almost boring. I found it at 07:42, taped to my monitor with blue painter’s tape. Standard Foundation memo stock. Header: SITE-73 INTERNAL. The watermark was correct. The microprint along the border checked out. The content was banal: “Log your 09:00 test with SCP-3114-Θ in triplicate. You’ll need the extra copy.” It was signed “—Elias.” I assumed it was from my assistant, or from myself, written late and forgotten. It was my handwriting, but neater. I did the test. At 11:15, the data in the primary and backup systems corrupted—some idiot in IT mis-patched a driver. My physical triplicate was the only complete record. I didn’t think anomaly. I thought: convenient. The second note arrived three days later. “Do NOT enter Containment Lab C at 16:00 on 03/09. —Elias (You)” I found that one folded in my left lab coat pocket while I was looking for my pen. Same memo stock. Same handwriting. I checked the CCTV from earlier in the day; I hadn’t folded paper, no one had approached me. No one had access to my locker. At 15:58 on 03/09, there was a minor coolant leak in Containment Lab C. The mist contained aerosolized sedative from the LCZ ventilation paths. Two techs lost consciousness and concussed themselves against the floor. Harmless, mostly, but if I’d been there, I would have been down too. I reported both incidents to Site Command. We’ve all seen weirder. Temporal echoes. Postcogs. Proto-cognition. Some Keter’s leaking metaphysics through the drywall. They logged it, nodded, told me to flag further occurrences. The further occurrences obliged. — [Note SCP-████-A-09, discovered in Dr. Marris’s closed notebook, timestamped 04/02, 02:13 by site motion-activated camera. No footage of insertion.] “Stop discarding these. Start a file. Correlate timestamps. Ask Carmen to double-blind. And for god’s sake, check who’s on shift Day 19. You always forget Day 19. —Elias P.S. This is not psychosis. Yet.” — By then I had a folder in my desk: SCP-████-A. One sheet became nine. They escalated from petty warnings—“Don’t drink the machine coffee, it’s contaminated” (true)—to specific outcome predictions with correct detail down to badge numbers and typographical errors in emails that hadn’t been sent yet. The memos were always Foundation standard stock. Even when I took precautions. At 05:00 on 04/04, I took all visible memo pads in my office, sealed them in a steel container, and signed it. I had Security sign as witness. We stored it in a separate wing. At 08:23, I opened my personal notebook. A memo sheet lay between pages 34 and 35, crisp, uncreased. “Good. You’re testing. You don’t trust this. That’s healthy. But you still used the word ‘we’ about it in your head. Note that. Whatever you do, do NOT approve the cross-test with SCP-4731 on Day 19. They’ll tell you it’s safe. It isn’t. —Elias” I hadn’t used the word “we,” I thought. I went back through my log. We’ve been receiving notes. I hadn’t written that, but it was there. I brought everything to Site Director Havel. Protocol. Possible temporal anomaly. Possible cognitohazard. The Foundation’s response was by the book: - Authentication: All SCP-████-A instances examined. Paper composition, ink chemistry, watermark integrity, batch trace. All matched Site-73 inventory, sometimes from boxes not yet opened. - Causality check: Correlation between predictions and events. First 12 notes ranged from trivial to significant; 11/12 were accurate. Number 7, referencing a minor structural failure on Sublevel D, didn’t manifest. (We later found a hairline crack in a support that would have failed under stress if not found.) - Contamination scan: Exposure of D-class to copies of the notes; no memetic trigger detected. No compulsive behavior, no infohazard markers beyond elevated anxiety. - Psychological evaluation: Me. Repeat assessments. Sleep logs. Cognitive exams. I passed. Mostly. They flagged mild stress, confirmation bias risk, and emerging hypervigilance. Simultaneously, they considered the other obvious option: manipulation. At Site-73 we house SCP-3114-Θ: an info-adaptive entity, limited range, known for fabricating documents to induce specific behaviors. Its cell is four wings away from my office. It has tried to breach via forged clearance forms in the past. The Ethics Committee liaison suggested—gently—that I might be the vector. I didn’t take that well. — [Note SCP-████-A-14, discovered in the sealed logbook locker. Locker lock and seal unbroken.] “They’re going to suspect 3114-Θ. They are wrong. It’s not smart enough. It’s decorative compared to what’s coming. Also: you will start resenting Carmen. Don’t. She’s not the one who betrays you. —Elias” — Carmen (Dr. Ruiz) ran the independent temporal analysis. She checked neutrino flux anomalies, local chronometric drift, baseline ontic field stability. No classical temporal interference markers. She also cross-referenced “Day 19.” Day 19 of what? We aligned the first note to a hypothetical zero point. Day 19 was due in two weeks. On Day 11, I woke to find three memos on my pillow. I sleep in on-site housing. The door was locked. Camera feed showed me sleeping, unmoving. No one entered. The notes: “(1) Don’t go to the West Observation Deck tonight. (2) Start trusting yourself less. Start trusting the paper more. (3) It’s not 3114-Θ. It’s below that.” Number 2 scared me more than 3. Foundation protocol demands skepticism of unverifiable future information. But the notes had been right so often that part of me already obeyed them reflexively. And now one was instructing me to surrender my own judgment. That line was not standard Foundation phrasing. That line felt like intrusion. I gave those three to Havel and requested amnestic treatment. He denied it, citing the need for a continuous subjective record. He ordered tighter surveillance instead. The more they watched, the more notes appeared in places they could not explain. In my glove, inside a sealed food pack, behind a wall panel whose screws were dust-filmed and untouched for years. All memo stock. All mine. The tone shifted around Day 15. — [Note SCP-████-A-21] “We’re running out of iterations. You never listen soon enough. The breach cascade starts with the 4731 cross-test. It desynchronizes local reality indexing. That’s why the readings looked normal; that’s the problem. Do not let them align 4731’s field with anything in Sublevel H. Especially not IT. Elias, please. You know I’m you. Who else would know about the scar on your left palm shaped like a question mark? Check. It’s there. It always is.” I checked. I have a faint scar on my left palm. I’d forgotten where it came from. Carmen confirmed, quietly, that I’d never mentioned it in my personnel file, never in our conversations, never in medicals. “Could have been gleaned visually,” she said. “Or implanted.” “Or I wrote the note,” I said. “Without remembering.” I heard how that sounded. — The investigation into SCP-3114-Θ turned aggressive. They tested it with prompts about my scar, about memo paper, about Day 19. Responses were noise; 3114-Θ remained limited, petulantly clever but not precognitive, not subtle. They screened all other entities on-site for temporal or mind-affecting traits. Nothing matched the precision of the predictions. Meanwhile, the contradictions began. — [Note SCP-████-A-27] “Day 19: Breach begins in Sublevel H server cluster. You are in the control room. You override the safety to ‘buy time.’ Do not do this again. The alarms will say SCP-3114-Θ breach. They are lying. Grab Ruiz. Go to Stairwell C. Not B. B doesn’t exist anymore. —Elias” Stairwell B most certainly existed. I walked it every morning. I went there immediately after reading. It was there: cold metal rails, concrete steps, fluorescent hum. I ran my hand down the bannister until my fingers ached, as if friction would prove something. I brought the note to Security. “Contradictory,” Havel said. “Nice try, 3114-Θ.” But they didn’t find any conduit. The cameras never caught a hand placing the memos. No audio of scratching pens. No access logs broken. Reality was intact. We were sure. We are always sure, right up until we’re not. On Day 18, I found a note that was barely legible. Same memo stock, ink smeared by what I hoped was water. “you are not in iteration 3 anymre this is 7 or 8 (we lost count, sorry) they learn faster than we do do not trust the fire doors if you smell oranges, STOP REMEMBERING I am trying I am trying I am trying —E—” No breach occurred that day. Instead, I started smelling oranges whenever I read the older notes. I didn’t report that part. Because by then I couldn’t tell if reporting created the anomaly or constrained it. Day 19 arrived. No cross-test with SCP-4731 was scheduled. I had, in fact, refused to sign off, citing “possible interference with ongoing unclassified site studies.” It felt like cheating destiny. At 10:02, a new directive hit my inbox: O5-attested override. Cross-test authorized, rescheduled: Day 19, 14:00, Sublevel H. I went straight to Havel’s office with the file. “That’s forged,” I said. He checked. Verification codes were valid. Origin servers clean. Chain of command intact. “Temporal interference,” he said. “Or a very sophisticated breach. Either way, we investigate with protocol, not panic.” “And we’re doing the test?” “We’re doing the test.” I left his office with my ears ringing. The hallway seemed fractionally too long. In my pocket, there was another note. I hadn’t felt it until then. “Don’t confront Havel yet. He’s compromised in 60% of trees and we don’t know which this is. Pull Ruiz off shift. Get her to Sublevel A archives. Make her lock the door. If you’re reading this after 13:45, skip to the last line: Do not override the safeties again. LET IT BREACH. —Elias (I’m begging you)” I checked the timestamp camera: no one had approached me. I brought the note directly to Carmen. “You’re shaking,” she said. “They want me to let it breach,” I said. “Or I want me to let it breach. Or something wearing my handwriting does.” “That’s exactly what a hostile entity would tell you,” she said. “Exploit your self-trust. Get you to sabotage containment.” “Or it’s exactly what future-me would say if containing it made things worse.” We stood there, trapped in that hinge. Foundation training says: protect containment above all, unless containment itself constitutes XK-class risk. But what if your only warning comes from uncertain causally-displaced scraps of paper that might be you? At 13:50, alarms began: “ANOMALOUS POWER DRAW – SUBLEVEL H.” At 13:52: “UNSCHEDULED FIELD ACTIVATION – SCP-4731 UPLINK.” I ran. Here is where the records diverge. Official log states: I entered Control Room H-2, authenticated, and manually overrode the lockout to initiate emergency dampening, preventing an uncontrolled cascade. My own memory—this memory—says: I stopped. I remembered the last line. I did not touch the console. In that hesitation, another note appeared, lying on the panel. I watched it exist: no hand, no fold, simply absent and then present. Standard memo paper. “Too early this time. We’ll try again. Remember: the oranges mean it’s winning. —Elias” I stared. I smelled oranges. The alarms cut out. Later, logs showed I had engaged the dampening at precisely 13:53:11. CCTV showed my hand on the control. There is no frame in which the note appears. Carmen swears she watched me save the site. I swear I did not. I am writing this from Observation. They say this is voluntary. We still don’t know if SCP-████ is: - A genuine temporal communication loop from one or more future instances of me. - A high-fidelity psychological exploit by an unidentified entity, potentially embedded in Site-73 systems or below them. - A localized reality instability centered on my perception, with the notes as artifacts of mis-synchronized timelines. Or all three. At night, I sort the memos in chronological order. They don’t stay that way. The phrasing of earlier ones twists when I reread them. Warnings invert. Instructions soften. One blank memo appeared this morning. Standard stock. My handwriting, not yet on it. I am afraid that the next thing I write will not be mine.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report demonstrates strong adherence to the Foundation's clinical documentation style while effectively maintaining the first-person researcher perspective. The author skillfully balances official SCP formatting with personal narrative, creating an authentic Foundation document that captures the paranoia and uncertainty central to the prompt. The piece excels in building psychological tension through escalating note content and contradictory information. The progression from mundane warnings to desperate, fragmented messages feels natural and unsettling. The ambiguity regarding whether the notes represent genuine temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation is well-maintained throughout, never definitively resolving in either direction. Character development is solid, with Dr. Marris portrayed as a competent researcher gradually losing confidence in his own perception. His actions remain believable within the Foundation context, from initial skepticism to growing paranoia to final uncertainty about his own agency. Supporting characters like Carmen and Havel serve their roles effectively without being fully developed, which is appropriate for the format. The prose maintains clinical precision while allowing emotional undertones to emerge naturally. Technical Foundation terminology is used correctly and enhances authenticity. The voice remains consistent throughout, balancing professional documentation with personal vulnerability. However, the piece suffers from some structural issues. The middle section becomes somewhat repetitive as notes appear and are analyzed in similar patterns. Some transitions between scenes feel abrupt, and certain plot elements (like the orange smell) are introduced but not fully integrated into the resolution. The ending is appropriately ambiguous and dark, fitting the SCP universe's themes of uncertainty and cosmic horror. The final image of a blank memo waiting to be filled is particularly effective, suggesting the protagonist's complete loss of agency. The writing occasionally veers toward exposition rather than showing, particularly in explaining Foundation procedures. Some dialogue feels functional rather than natural, though this partially serves the clinical tone. Overall, this is a competent SCP tale that captures the essence of Foundation documentation while delivering genuine psychological horror through temporal uncertainty. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 9 Tell-Don't-Show: 10 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 15 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
