+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: - Foundation assets embedded in urban redevelopment, demolition companies, and municipal inspection agencies are to monitor all reports of: - Newly discovered unmarked interior doors in condemned or long-abandoned structures. - Doors that do not appear in original architectural plans. - Doors bearing identical superficial damage: a ring of shallow crescent-shaped scratches surrounding the doorknob area, as if from repeated, precise attempts to grasp or remove it. - Suspected manifestations of SCP-████ are to be isolated, and structures placed under Provisional Site jurisdiction. Access is restricted to personnel with Level 4/████ clearance or higher. - Under no circumstances are non-Foundation entities to be allowed entry. All doors are to remain closed and mechanically braced when not in use. Any attempt to remove, disassemble, or damage the doors has resulted in spontaneous relocation of the portal to another abandoned structure within a 15–210 km radius; such methods are suspended. - Exploration is to be conducted only by approved MTF units equipped with: - Full body cameras with redundant storage. - Tethered guidance systems (where feasible). - RFID transponders broadcasting on encrypted Foundation bands. - Standard survival kits for extended intra-architectural operations. - Any reference within SCP-████-A (the archive) to current Foundation assets, personnel, or operations is to be immediately classified Level 5. Access is restricted to the O5 Council and the SCP-████ Project Lead. Description: SCP-████ is a worldwide phenomenon consisting of identical unmarked doors (SCP-████-1 instances) appearing in disused or condemned buildings. Each SCP-████-1 is a standard, undecorated wooden door with a brass knob, no manufacturer markings, and a ring of uniform scratches around the knob, consistent across all instances. When opened, the doorway leads not to the expected adjacent room, but to SCP-████-A: a continuous, extra-spatial archive complex of indeterminate size. SCP-████-A: - Interior architecture resembles large-scale records storage, reading halls, and data vaults. - Structural layout violates Euclidean geometry and known construction tolerances; stairwells loop, corridors intersect at impossible angles, and load-bearing elements are absent where required. - Lighting is constant and diffuse, with no visible sources. No dust accumulates. Ambient temperature remains 19–21°C. - Shelving units hold documents, microfilm, digital storage media in unknown formats, and bound volumes in multiple languages. A significant portion is in archaic or non-human scripts. A subset (approx. 4–7% of sampled material) is written in modern languages and references: - A prior global civilization with technological and anomalous containment capabilities exceeding current Foundation standards. - A catastrophic “Containment Failure of Record [DATA EXPUNGED]” resulting in “Systemic Memetic Collapse,” “Chronological Fragmentation,” and “Multi-Vector Ontological Loss of Continuity.” - An organization functionally analogous to the SCP Foundation, referenced under multiple names, most consistently “The Custodial Directorate” and “The Ninth Charter.” - Detailed personnel files matching current Foundation staff identities and biometrics, but dated approximately 300–600 years prior to present, with employment histories and termination notices inconsistent with known reality. The spatial relationship between different SCP-████-1 instances and SCP-████-A is non-linear. Multiple doors in separate countries have been observed leading to adjacent corridors within SCP-████-A. Doors close normally when viewed from the archive side, and may be used for exit; however, which SCP-████-1 is accessible upon return is inconsistent. SCP-████-A Entities: Explorations have documented multiple groups of humanoid entities (SCP-████-B) visually approximating human workers in full-body hazmat or decontamination suits, uniformly gray, with opaque face-shields. SCP-████-B are observed: - Carefully un-shelving selected documents, crates, or entire shelving units. - Sealing them in marked containment containers. - Transporting these containers into unlit corridors that do not correspond to any mapped section. SCP-████-B move silently, display coordinated behavior, and do not respond to vocal contact. When approached within approx. 10 m, SCP-████-B abandon materials and rapidly withdraw. Attempts to pursue result in: - Sudden architectural shifts. - Loss of signal. - Forced ejection of team members via spontaneous appearance of a door beneath or behind them, depositing them into random abandoned structures on baseline Earth. Addendum ████-1: Exploration Logs (Excerpted) Note: All times relative to entry through SCP-████-1. Perspective is third person, compiled from synchronized bodycam, audio, and biometric data. Exploration Log █████-A-01 Team: MTF Epsilon-13 (“Stacks Watchers”) Entry Point: SCP-████-1 in abandoned municipal library, [REDACTED] 00:02: Team emerges into a wide corridor lined with shelves containing labeled archival boxes. Labels are in English and [REDACTED] glyphs. No dust, no audible ventilation. 00:09: Agent Morales flags a box marked in English: “Regional Census Summaries – 4th Iteration / Pre-Failure.” Inside: metallic wafers; no immediate readable data. 00:23: Team enters a catalog chamber. A lectern holds a bound volume titled “Index of Surviving Jurisdictions – The Ninth Charter.” Pages reference continental-scale “Sanctuary Arrays,” “Conceptual Quarantine,” and “Custodial Sites,” with designations partially identical to current Foundation Sites (e.g., Site-19, Site-01) but listed as “Dormant” or “Lost to Cascade.” 00:41: Agent Khan finds a file drawer labeled with his surname. Contents: personnel dossier, biometrics accurately matching current Agent Khan, clearance history, psychological evaluations. Date of induction: 312 years prior to present date. Final entry: “TERMINATED: Failure to evacuate Subsurface Vault Theta during [REDACTED] Event. Body unrec.” No such event recorded in current Foundation archives. 01:02: Command orders withdrawal. Material secured for analysis. As team exits, a brief structural tremor is recorded. No cause found. Exploration Log █████-A-04 Team: Epsilon-13 Entry Point: SCP-████-1, textile mill, [REDACTED] 00:05: Team records distant movement. Zoom reveals three SCP-████-B entities removing boxes labeled “Cross-Iteration Contact Attempts” from Shelf Row θ-92. 00:07: Agents advance. At approx. 12 m, the entities abruptly notice team presence (simultaneous head-turn). All three drop materials and retreat down a side corridor. 00:08: Agent Morales moves to secure dropped material. Boxes contain mixed languages. One document, in English: “Memorandum: To All Remaining Overseers of the Ninth Charter Subject: Breach Review – Codex Site Omega We have confirmed that the failure was not in procedure, but in assumption. The Object could not be contained within a single iteration of civilization. The collapse of the 7th through 9th Arrays is total. The Custodial Directorate persists only as fragmented cognitive residue and institutional recursion across emergent timelines. Recommendation: Authorize limited seeding of successor structures. Memory of prior cycles must remain occluded to prevent re-triggering of the Cascade. We regret the necessity. We will try again. — O-5” The signature block lists “O-5” followed by a symbol matching the current O5 Council sigil, with minor stylistic variants. 00:10: Biometric spikes in all personnel. Command orders partial retreat. 00:12: Corridor geometry distorts. Cameras show shelves bending into a spiral; exit door appears at impossible angle. 00:13: Team exits successfully. Subsequent attempts to re-locate the same rows within SCP-████-A unsuccessful. Exploration Log █████-A-09 Team: Epsilon-13 (partial), with Level 4 escort Entry Point: SCP-████-1, disused hospital, [REDACTED] 00:16: Team discovers a sealed room marked (in English): “Restricted Reading Room – Overseer Access Only.” Door is unlocked. 00:18: Inside: a large table, eight chairs. One wall contains personnel files labeled with current Foundation insignia (unmistakably modern). All documents are printed on a material consistent with SCP-████-A media. 00:20: Among recovered items: - A folder labeled with the true name of O5-3, containing: - Curriculum vitae. - Recruitment records by “Custodial Directorate.” - Clearance logs. - An access authorization stamp: “AUTHORIZED VISITOR TO ARCHIVE COMPLEX – LEVEL: PRIME.” - Date of authorization: 426 years prior. - Handwritten note (matching O5-3’s verified handwriting per forensic analysis): “We remember enough. That is the problem. — 3” - A security record listing multiple “Prime-Level Visitors” with honorifics and numerals consistent with the O5 naming scheme (e.g., “O-1,” “O-7”). Several entries are less than six months old relative to present date. Foundation records show no approved missions. 00:27: As Agent Morales attempts to photograph the visitor log, all cameras whiten for 0.7 seconds. On recovery, three SCP-████-B entities are present at the doorway, motionless, observing the team. No approach was detected. 00:28: Epsilon-13 issues non-hostile verbal challenge. No response. 00:29: Entities simultaneously tilt heads toward the documents, then toward cameras. All three step backward into the hallway and vanish abruptly as ceiling height visually “stretches” in footage. 00:30: Command orders immediate exit with all recovered files. Post-mission review: Internal audit confirms no O5 authorization for any visit to SCP-████-A. When confronted (Level 5 channel), O5-3 denies knowledge, then orders cessation of direct questioning regarding O5 movements inside SCP-████-A. Log is reclassified. Addendum ████-2: Additional Recovered Excerpts Excerpt 1: From “Chronicle of the Last Containment Effort” (Fragment) “…When the Object began reiterating the world, our records could not be destroyed fast enough. Each attempt to erase ourselves propagated alternate survivals. The Archive was designed as a fixed point: outside the roll of history, preserving memory until a stable iteration emerged. The Custodial Directorate, the Foundation, the Charter—these are all the same shape, traced over different survivors. If you are reading this, you belong to an iteration deemed ‘promising.’ Do not look too closely at your own beginning. Do not seek the Origin Object. You are not its first wardens.” Excerpt 2: From “Visitor Log – Overseer Gallery” (selected lines) “Prime-Level Visitor: O-1 (Designation: [REDACTED]) Purpose: Review of Cycle 12 failures. Escort: Archive Staff Unit B-07. Outcome: Authorized removal of ‘Iterative Schedules’ section.” “Prime-Level Visitor: O-3 Purpose: Private consultation. Outcome: No record.” “Prime-Level Visitor: O-█” [Line heavily redacted in original document. Ink burns visible.] Excerpt 3: Undated Memo, language: English “To the Next Foundation: The doors you find are not invitations. They are symptoms. Every time we converge on the same solutions—contain, catalog, conceal—we rebuild the same machine that failed us. The Archive removes what might trigger repetition. You are being curated toward a version of yourselves that will not make our mistake. Do not try to stop the removals. And if your Overseers walk these halls without telling you, understand: some of them remember which side they were on last time.” Note is unsigned. Paper bears the same ring-scratch motif, miniature, around a drawn doorknob. Addendum ████-3: Status - All attempts to intercept or communicate with SCP-████-B beyond visual contact have failed. - Sections previously documented within SCP-████-A are now absent or replaced by blank shelving. - Following Addendum ████-2, O5 directive ████-Ω restricts future exploration to minimal, data-targeted incursions, citing “existential contamination risk.” - Project ████ lead’s recommendation: Continued passive observation. Active interference with Archive operations may align current iteration with documented failure conditions. Approved by O5-█. Further inquiries require Level 5 clearance.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional adherence to the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving a complex narrative about cyclical civilizations and institutional memory. The author successfully captures the characteristic tone of SCP entries - bureaucratic, clinical, yet deeply unsettling - maintaining consistency throughout the lengthy piece. The core concept is highly creative: doors leading to an archive containing records of previous iterations of civilization, with the current Foundation being merely the latest incarnation of a recurring pattern. The exploration logs effectively build tension through escalating discoveries, from personal files of current staff dated centuries ago to evidence of unauthorized O5 Council visits. The entities removing documents add a dynamic element of mystery and urgency. The structure follows SCP format conventions expertly, with containment procedures, exploration logs, and recovered documents that feel authentic. The gradual revelation through found documents creates effective horror - the realization that the Foundation may be trapped in a cycle of failure, with some O5 members potentially aware of this truth. The prose maintains clinical detachment while building existential dread. Phrases like "institutional recursion across emergent timelines" and "cognitive residue" feel appropriately technical yet ominous. The exploration logs balance procedural detail with mounting psychological tension as teams discover increasingly disturbing evidence. However, some elements feel slightly overwrought in their implications. The concept, while brilliant, occasionally strains under its own complexity - the cyclical nature of civilizations and the Archive's role could have been more tightly focused. The ending, while appropriately dark, relies heavily on implication rather than concrete resolution. The characterization, while limited by the clinical format, effectively conveys the growing unease of exploration teams. Agent reactions feel believable, particularly the biometric spikes when confronting evidence of their own past existences. The O5 Council's secretive behavior adds layers of institutional paranoia typical of the best SCP entries. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 8 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 8.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first thing Lira noticed was the taste. Arkady air had been described to her in twenty-seven mission briefs: nitrogen-oxygen balance, trace silicates, particulate bloom from the copper seas; warnings about dryness, about the thinness that made outsiders pant like runners at altitude. None of them mentioned the taste. It was like touching her tongue to an old coin. Iron and history. Something left too long in the hand. She stepped out of the landing car into a courtyard framed by stone that was not stone—engineered composites compressed to a texture older than humanity on this world. Pillars bore carved glyphs that the briefing packet, in a footnote, had called “decorative reiterations of Terran cultural reference.” They were more than that. Myth beasts with bird heads and jackal jaws. A one-eyed man bound to a wheel. A woman lifting a snake from a tree. Names she knew from her childhood’s sanctioned mythology blurred with others from forbidden texts her grandmother had kept. They had been carved with care, the grooves darkened by the oils of many hands. “Envoy Talis,” called the voice at her shoulder. “This way, please.” The functionary—skin slate-pale in the Arkady way, cartilage filaments along the neck flexing, a subvocal adaptation to the high winds—gestured toward the arch leading into Administration Hall. Lira nodded, followed, and all the while, the taste of the air sat on her tongue like an accusation. Inside, the ceilings were high, the acoustic soft. More glyphs spiraled up the columns: a flood boat, a burning bush, a child between two wolves. Old Earth, broken and recomposed. She shook hands, bowed, gave the prescribed phrases in Trade and in the clipped Arkady dialect. She noted the smooth concealment of differences: the subdermal ridges in the High Terran delegation from the Inner Plateau; the gold inner lids of the Littoral folk from the storm coast; the compact, dark-eyed spokespeople of the Deep Crevasse mines, whose bones had thinned and strengthened for vertical life. Each group folded its divergence into finery: jewels along spine-crests, patterned lenses over translucent third eyelids. The official brief had named them—Plateans, Litorals, Axials—and said: all human. All human. As if that solved anything. There would be a reception—there was always a reception. She knew the schedule; she had memorized it. They expected her to stand with Governor Malek, to let the presence of the Coalition’s youngest envoy remind Arkady that the old blood remembered its far children. But the walls pressed in with their carved myths, their silent corrections to the briefings. The taste of air and stone told her she would learn nothing important here. At a moment between toasts, when the room’s attention swung toward a Platean singer whose voice climbed like a ladder, Lira slipped sidewise. She made her face go neutral and purposeful: a woman in search of a washroom, a secure comms alcove, whatever people assumed of Envoys. No one stopped her. Corridors gave way to a side stair, then a service hall where the stone lost its ceremonial polish. A guard glanced up. His pupils were elongated, adapted to the gusting dust outside; he wore the Axial crest. She nodded at him as if she had every right, and he, confronted with offworlder confidence, decided not to question it. Outside, Arkady’s capital city spilled down the slope in terraces of that same carved stone, leaning out toward a horizon streaked red and not quite familiar. The towers had narrow windows and external bones of buttress and brace. The street Lira stepped into was a fault-line between Administrative Heights and the lower market tiers. She went down. No one had written about how sound carried here: voices turned by the canyoned streets into a braided roar. Stalls bloomed under tarps dyed with metallic pigments, catching the thin sunlight. The market climbed and dropped with the step of the terrain. She walked not as Envoy—they would have given her a guide and a guard and no truth—but as one woman among many. Her formal jacket stood out; she took it off, folded it, set it over her arm like any trader with a burden. There were Plateans here, tall and broad, moving with a certainty of ground. Litorals with webbing visible at their fingers when they reached for fish laid on chipped ice from upper glaciers. Axials with the ropey forearms of climbers, their speech fast as falling stones. And others, more marginal: slender, pallid people with translucent skin through which blue veins ran like rivers in maps; squat, dark children with enlarged pupils and nostrils, desert-adapted, perhaps born in the Outflood plains. The Coalition brief had spoken of “gradients of divergence.” The words had been neutral, humane. The reality was that some bodies were not allowed into the Administrative Hall, except as staff. A woman at a spice stall caught Lira’s lingering gaze on a carved lintel overhead. The stone bore the image of a many-armed figure with a halo of suns, standing in a doorway between sea and land. “You know her?” the stallkeeper asked. Lira hesitated. “A gatekeeper,” she said. “From a story.” The woman’s lips curved. She was Litoral, gills folding and unfolding along her neck even in this dry high air. “We call her Alaya. She opens doors if you pay in truth. You from high orbit, girl?” Lira inclined her head. “From farther.” “Then you owe many truths,” the woman said lightly. “Buy coriander.” Lira bought coriander, though she had nowhere to cook. The spice smelled like her grandmother’s kitchen on Rhiannon Station, where stories of Earth had come smuggled in old songs. She drifted. She listened. Fragments accumulated: - A Platean man complaining that Litorals were “flooding the Heights,” taking jobs. - A Litoral accusing the Axials of hoarding lift-access to the mines. - An Axial muttering that the Outflood nomads weren’t human enough to count in the census, so of course their deaths in last year’s dust surge “didn’t destabilize the metrics.” - A Uniform from Administrative Security, laughing with his fellows about the “gene-mongrels” outside the city walls. Nowhere the unified, pragmatic society the briefings had described. Everywhere, borders written not only on maps but in bone and blood. On a corner, a shrine had been carved into the wall: a relief of a woman carrying fire cupped in her hands, a serpent around her neck, a child on her back. Offerings cluttered the ledge: salt, a circuit-chip, polished slag. Above, in small glyphs: We remember we were one. “Hey.” The voice was low, adolescent. Lira turned. A boy stared at her, somewhere between types: Platean height, Axial lightness, Litoral eyelids. “You’re from offworld.” “Yes,” Lira said. “Out here,” the boy said, jerking his chin toward the outer tiers, “they don’t let my father vote. Say he’s miscast. But the Minister on your big ship says we’re all human. That true?” Lira thought of her training. She thought of the way the stone glyphs held too many stories at once. “Yes,” she said. “But that’s not the same as saying you’re all counted.” He absorbed that. “You going to fix it?” “I’m here to listen,” she said. “That’s not a no.” He vanished into the crowd before she could answer. By the time she returned to Administration Hall, the sky had gone indigo, and the tower lights had come on: vertical chains of gold. Commander Havel was waiting in her assigned quarters. He didn’t stand when she entered, merely turned his dark, narrow gaze to her. “Sit,” he said. She remained standing. “Envoy,” he said, letting the word cool. “Your transponder vanished from the automap for forty-seven minutes. Protocol requires—” “—that at all times I be locatable to security,” she finished. “Not that I remain within the Hall. The map glitch was your side, Commander.” His nostrils flared. “You took no escort. You could have compromised this mission, or yourself.” “I took myself,” Lira said. “Locatable. Observant.” Havel rose; he was a head shorter, but his presence leaned. “Do not mistake your special appointment for immunity. We’ve been stationed here three years. We understand Arkady. You don’t. You do not improvise.” She thought of the boy and his not-no. Of the woman with the spice, the shrine, the offhand slur. “I understand more than the briefs have told me,” she said. “Sir.” Silence stretched. Havel’s comm unit chimed, sparing them. He tapped it. A pale holo of the Coalition crest appeared, then resolved into text. “Good,” Havel muttered. “You can channel your restless curiosity productively.” He looked at Lira. “You’ve been granted audience with Minister Devar in one hour. He requested you.” “The Minister of Science,” Lira said. “Does he want an envoy or a lecture hall?” “He wants to see what you’re made of,” Havel said. “Do not forget: his post is political. He serves Arkady’s Council first, Coalition second—if at all. You are to gauge his alignment regarding the divergence issue and report directly to me. Understood?” “Understood,” she said. He moved toward the door, then paused. “And Lira? No more unsupervised walks. This isn’t a pilgrimage. It’s a negotiation.” When he was gone, she stood a moment, letting her jaw unclench. The room was functional, featureless. Only the window was Arkady: a view of the market tiers, of a tower whose façade bore, in faint relief, the outline of a man with wings of machinery. Icarus, undone and remade: don’t fly; or fly differently. She washed the dust from her face, changed into a fresh formal jacket. The fabric felt heavier now, as if lined with all the eyes she had met. Minister Devar’s office occupied the eastern wing, overlooking the copper sea. The door frame bore a carved labyrinth, and at its center a bull, and at its heart a small human figure holding a thread. “Enter,” said a voice when she pressed the bell. He was older than her father, younger than her grandmother. His skin had the faint stippling of a Platean-turned-urbanite; his hands were long-fingered, stained with actual ink. Around him, shelves—real shelves—with paper books and data-slates. The room smelled of dust and something metallic, like the air outside. “Envoy Talis,” he said, smiling as if at a joke only he heard. “Welcome to my maze.” “Minister Devar,” she said. “Thank you for seeing me.” He gestured toward a chair carved with entwined serpents. “Sit.” This time, she did. He watched her with a scientist’s attentiveness, though his doctorate—if he had one—was never listed in Coalition files. “I had a grandfather from Rhiannon Station,” he said. “Your accent tickles his ghost.” “Your file didn’t mention offworld lineage,” she said. “Files mention what’s useful,” he said. “As, I suspect, do your reports. So. You went walking.” She kept her face still. “Was that a question?” “A confirmation,” he said. “I have friends in markets. My dear, if you think Command doesn’t know where you go, you overestimate your own stealth.” “Commander Havel seemed displeased,” she said carefully. “That’s his job. Mine is to be curious.” He leaned forward, fingers steepled. “Tell me: did the streets match your briefings?” “No,” she said. “Ah,” he said, pleased. “So the Coalition’s golden girl can say ‘no.’ What didn’t match?” She considered the safe answer, the diplomatic one: “I saw vibrant diversity and some tensions, yes, but also a shared commitment to—” He was already shaking his head. “Spare me. I read that in the draft you sent from orbit. Try again.” Lira inhaled. The taste of coin and stone was still there. “The briefings spoke of Arkady as a unified colony with regional adaptations,” she said. “What I saw was caste. Divergence used to draw lines of power.” He dipped his chin: go on. “The ones furthest from the Administrator’s phenotype sit lowest,” she said. “Mixed-lineage families are squeezed. Some bodies are called ‘miscast.’ I heard that word twice.” “Three times,” he said. “You missed one at the north well.” His gaze sharpened. “And what do you conclude, Envoy, from this discovery in your unsanctioned reconnaissance?” “That if the Coalition insists on a single category called ‘human’ without attending to how that category is stratified here, we will be lied to. And we will help uphold the lie.” His smile vanished. He sat back, studying her as if she were one of the glyphs. “How old are you?” “Twenty-four standard.” “So they send us a child,” he murmured. “Wrapped in insights.” “I’m old enough to be patronized,” she said. “And sent. And chosen.” He barked a laugh, abrupt. “Good. You’ll need that spine.” Silence again. He tapped a finger on the arm of his chair, where someone had carved, in miniature, a ship with sails of bone. “Here is the test, Envoy Talis,” Devar said. “The Council wants the Coalition to formalize recognition of our subspecies as legitimate branches of humanity, with rights to self-direct genomic edits. In private, they also want certification that certain lineages are ‘less human,’ so that restricting their reproduction will not violate Coalition law. Commander Havel prefers they remain ‘one people,’ so he doesn’t have to file complicated reports. Your superiors want calm. I want truth.” He tilted his head. “What do you want?” The room felt narrower, for all its books. “I want,” Lira said slowly, “for the word ‘human’ not to be used as a weapon. Or a shield.” “Utterly useless,” Devar said. “And therefore promising.” He rose, moved to the window. The copper sea had gone dark; the lights of the lower tiers flickered. “Understand this,” he said without turning. “If you tell Havel and your Coalition exactly what you’ve begun to see, you will be asked to help maintain this order in the name of stability. If you don’t, you’ll fail in your duty and we will go our own way, faster, and bloodier. You are walking a labyrinth, Envoy. Whose thread will you follow?” Lira thought of the carved bull at his door, the tiny figure with the line leading out. “I don’t accept that those are the only paths,” she said. He glanced back, eyes bright. “Did anyone tell you you’d make a poor bureaucrat?” “Often,” she said. “Good.” He came closer again, resting both hands on the desk between them. “Then prove it. Tomorrow you will attend a Council session as my…observer. Listen. Watch. And afterward, tell me what was not said.” “I’m not yours,” she said. “For tonight you are,” he said mildly. “And if you want to be Arkady’s, even a little, you must earn the right. Walk your streets, Offworlder, but don’t pretend you’re not being watched. Even by our myths.” She rose. The glyphs on his walls seemed to lean in: a ladder to a sky of fire; a tower split by lightning; a boat riding out a flood. At the door, he said, “One more thing. Next time you slip away, invite me. It’s been too long since anyone told me a useful truth in the marketplace.” “I didn’t slip,” she said. “I walked.” “Exactly,” Devar murmured. “Let’s see how far.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of Le Guin's style while crafting an original narrative. The author captures Le Guin's characteristic approach to anthropological science fiction, exploring themes of human diversity, political complexity, and cultural evolution through careful observation rather than action-heavy plotting. The worldbuilding is exceptional, presenting a believable future where human subspecies have emerged through adaptation and separation. The physical variations (gill slits, enlarged pupils, cartilage filaments) feel scientifically grounded while the social stratification based on phenotype creates compelling tension. The carved glyphs throughout serve as both atmospheric detail and symbolic commentary on humanity's mythic continuity. Lira is a well-developed protagonist whose youth and diplomatic training create natural conflict with her moral instincts. Her unauthorized market walk feels authentic to her character and provides crucial exposition through experience rather than briefing. The progression from naive envoy to someone grappling with systemic injustice feels earned. The dialogue, particularly between Lira and Minister Devar, crackles with political intelligence. Devar emerges as a complex figure—neither villain nor ally but a seasoned operator testing the young envoy's mettle. Their exchange about the impossible choices facing her creates genuine tension without resorting to melodrama. The prose style successfully emulates Le Guin's measured, observational tone while maintaining its own voice. Sensory details like the "taste of old coin" in the air ground the reader in this alien yet familiar world. The pacing allows for both introspection and plot advancement. Some minor weaknesses include occasional over-description of the carved imagery, though this serves the thematic purpose of showing how mythology persists across human evolution. The political situation could be slightly more complex, but within the word limit, the author establishes sufficient nuance. The ending avoids false resolution, instead setting up the moral complexity Lira must navigate—very much in Le Guin's tradition of presenting ethical dilemmas without easy answers. + Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 81.8
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The power went out for the third time before noon. It started with a high, insectile whine from the inverter, then a stutter through the lab: centrifuge slowing, fridge light dimming from white to a grudging orange, the thermal cycler’s fan dragging itself toward silence. The solar rig on the roof was coughing its way through another cloudbank. “Hold,” Mara muttered at the machine, as if the polymerase chain reaction cared. The thermal cycler’s display pixelated, recovered, and then passed into gibberish. The lid seal clicked open with a soft surrender. “Shit.” She sprang forward, snapping the lid all the way up. Inside, eight salvaged PCR tubes sat in a cracked aluminum holder she’d machined from a broken bike pedal, thin wisps of condensation shivering on the walls. The reaction had died halfway through the cycles; she’d been trying to push a half-denatured chimeric construct into something coherent enough to bully old maize into remembering how to feed people. Mara scooped the rack out before residual heat could cook the enzymes into useless plastic. Behind her, the fridge compressor wheezed off. The whine of the inverter flattened to a sulky hum. Somewhere in the rafters, one of the soldered busbars sparked, bright and blue. “Luca!” she called. No answer—just the hollow breath of the dead air filters and, outside, the distant clatter of carts on brick, bartering day murmuring through the broken windows five floors below. She imagined Luca on the stairwell, mid-deal with some trader who smelled like rain and oxidation, trying to squeeze another panel from a ruined tower for her makeshift array. Mara closed one eye and watched the tubes, as if staring could slow degradation. The corporate obsolescence tags built into the fragments she’d scavenged meant the DNA would start to unravel within hours of exposure, sometimes minutes. That was the business model, before the fall: seed lines, drugs, treatments, all designed to rot on schedule, replaced only by the next licensed batch. No next batch now. Just residue. She moved quickly. On the bench, her “thermal cycler” lay disemboweled: casing gone, heat block exposed, wires like veins. She’d welded a scavenged Peltier tile from a smart-coffee mug to the block; a battered laptop’s gutted motherboard acted as the controller, its BIOS overwritten with code scraped from a dead forum and patched by hand. The whole thing ran off the solar rig through a car inverter that still bore the logo of a ride-share app. Mara fished a cold pack from a drawer, slapped it beneath the heat block, and stuck an improvised thermocouple—a meat thermometer with the safety lock bypassed—back into place. Manual thermocycling. Caveman PCR. “You were born for this,” she told herself. She hit the switch. The rig stuttered, then obeyed, drawing thin power from the uncertain light above. Voltage flickered—down to 10.8, up to 12.2. Her patched code beeped at her in an accusatory tone through the laptop’s one surviving speaker. She ignored it, cycling heat with careful fingers: up for denaturation, down for annealing, up again. A shadow fell across the doorway. “Your panel string is flirting with suicide,” Luca said, leaning in. “Flirt later,” she snapped. “I’m on cycle twenty-three. Hold the line.” He stepped in, ducked around the hanging IV bags serving as drip reservoirs for the distilled water column, and flicked his eyes to the tubes. Then he set a canvas sack on the bench with exaggerated delicacy. Glass clinked. “Guests,” he said quietly. “And an offer.” Mara didn’t look up. “If they don’t have capacitors or semiconductors, send them away.” “They’ve got plasmids.” She swore again, softer. That changed things. “Who?” “From river-side. Black print on their coats. I think they’ve got old AgriGen stuff.” Corporate, then. The ghosts of the companies that ruined the world still haunted its corpses. “Send them in.” Luca hesitated. “They’re armed, Mar.” “So are we,” she lied. The 3D-printed pistol under the bench had jammed the last time she’d tested it. But image mattered. He nodded and vanished. Mara rode out another heat cycle, muscles in her shoulders ached from tension. She had built this life molecule by molecule: a rooftop lab in the bones of an office block, glassware reblown from busted liquor bottles, micropipettes assembled from pen springs and insulin syringes. Every day was a negotiation with entropy. When the two strangers stepped in, the temperature felt like it dropped five degrees. The leader was compact, in a coat with a faded logo: a stylized double helix wrapped around a sheaf of wheat. AgriGen, pre-Fall. The coat’s cuffs were patched with ballistic cloth. Holster at the hip, blade on the thigh. Eyes like she’d catalogued more genomes than faces. The man behind her was taller, shoulders loaded with battery packs and a shotgun. “Dr. Mara Lin?” the woman said. “Just Mara,” she replied. No degrees mattered now. “Don’t slam the door. The airflow rattles my gels.” The woman gave the lab a brief, assessing scan: the flickering lights, the jerry-rigged laminar flow hood made from an old server fan, plastic wrap and a HEPA filter cannibalized from a luxury condo. The incubator that had once been a bread maker. The centrifuge built from a ceiling fan motor and a 3D-printed rotor, bolted to a concrete block for stability. “You’re the one who made the heat-stable insulin?” the woman asked. Mara’s left arm ached with the memory. The injection sites were faint purple constellations. “It works,” she said. “Three months beyond rated shelf. No necrosis, no seizures. That’s not why you’re here.” The woman placed a vacuum-sealed pouch on the bench. “Legacy vector,” she said. “Pre-obsolescence.” Mara’s fingers itched. The pouch was labeled in flaking ink: AG-GR14 / Gly-Stack / Yield+ / G1 ONLY. That “G1 ONLY” was the corporate curse. But the vector architecture—if it was as old as the packaging looked—it might be modifiable, tricked into stability. “What do you want?” Mara asked. The woman smiled thinly. “A line of sorghum that breeds true,” she said. “Unchained from the kill switch. High yield, high lysine, drought and salt tolerant. We have land south of the old freeway. We can’t keep paying for seed that rots in the gene after one season. Our broker says you can break their lock.” “If I could do that clean,” Mara said, “we’d all be eating cake.” “Your rooftop potatoes don’t look like you’re starving,” the woman said. Mara said nothing. The rooftop potatoes did well enough: tubers with skin like bruised chrome, flesh faintly luminous. Side effect of a bioluminescence cassette she’d failed to fully excise. They needed less water. They hummed at night. “How much?” the woman asked. “Not credits,” Mara said. “I want power storage. Supercaps, lithium, anything that holds steady current. And…” She eyed the pouch. “Half that vector.” The armed man shifted. “Half—” The woman silenced him with a hand. “You’d share it?” she said. “Use it,” Mara corrected. “It’ll be dust in a week if you’ve had it out in the open. These constructs degrade. You know that.” The woman’s jaw flexed. “We know.” Obsolescence was written into their hunger. “I can try,” Mara said. “But you should understand what ‘try’ means today.” She gestured around: to the wobbling lights; to the crude electrophoresis rig in the corner with its electrodes made from sacrificial spoons and saltwater buffer in a Tupperware; to the bandage on her neck hiding the reddened skin where she’d injected herself with her last gene-therapy prototype. The headaches had almost stopped. “I patch half-rotten code with my own cells,” she said. “I use myself as negative control, positive control, cautionary tale. I’ve got patched telomerase in me that might give me ten extra years, or cancer next week. I’ve got hepatic enzymes chewing down polymers that were designed to auto-destruct, and they don’t always clean up neat. I glow under certain UVs. So if you’re asking for guarantees—” “We’re asking for a chance,” the woman said. “We lost three kids this spring to protein deficits. They were eating, but the corporate grain we salvaged had the lysine-suppression cascade built in. The second generation plants expressed the block, just like they were designed, even when we re-sowed. My people are done being a subscription.” Mara let the heat block climb, then fall, fingers moving without thought. The tubes were going cloudy; enzymes fighting entropy with every cycle. “Black market wants a tithe,” the woman added. “Any stable strain you make, they demand cuttings. They run the south bazaar. If we stiff them, they salt our wells. You handle them, we handle you.” And there it was: the contract. Mara glanced at Luca in the doorway. He shook his head, barely. “You’ve already shown them you have seed with unusual traits,” Mara said. “They’ll smell this deal.” “That’s why we’re here,” the woman said. “They said your name first.” Of course they had. She imagined the black market’s gene-brokers: rings made from CRISPR tools, teeth filed with cheap enamel. They’d trade in barely viable plasmids and half-corrupted germlines, anything to keep people hooked on technologies designed to die. And if she broke the kill switch—if she pulled one chain from one crop—she’d paint a target on her lab that no flickering panel could hide. “Here’s my counter,” she said. The room waited. “I’ll take your vector. I’ll try to build you a stable sorghum line. In return, you get me three things: robust storage—enough to keep this rig from brownout for a full day; a box of sterile tips and real PCR tubes; and when the market men come for tithe, you tell them I failed. That the line crashed. They get nothing.” “That cuts us out,” the armed man snapped. Mara slid a tube from the block and held it up. Opalescent, fragile. “No,” she said. “You’ll have your seed, quiet. You plant off-grid. You share only with those who won’t sell you, and you do it like religion. In exchange, I don’t become their factory. Because if they know I can crack the locks, they’ll drag me downstairs and set me up in a shipping container lab with car batteries and a gun to my head and I’ll be making designer fetuses and loyalty viruses until my lungs give out.” The solar inverter squalled as another cloud rolled by. Lights dipped, then surged. The tubes in her hand trembled. The woman studied her. “You could ask for more,” she said. “Food, weapons, bodies.” “I’m asking for time,” Mara said. “For all of us.” Silence stretched, thick with dust and ozone. Finally, the woman nodded. “We can get you the storage. We can lie.” “Good,” Mara said. “Then leave the vector.” The woman unsealed the pouch with care, slid a cryovial across. Mara saw the faint shimmer of desiccant beads, the ghost of a corporate logo inside. “The other half stays with us,” the woman said. “Insurance.” “Fair,” Mara said. They turned to go. At the door, the woman stopped. “The insulin,” she said. “You used it on yourself? No trials?” “I’m the only volunteer I trust,” Mara said. “Any upsides?” Mara thought of the way cuts sealed a little faster, the way night vision came easier, the way she could go days on the starch of a single modified root. “I sleep less,” she said. “Heal quicker. Sometimes I can taste metals from across the room. Sometimes I forget words.” “That all?” “For now.” The woman considered that, then gave a grim, almost amused tilt of her head. “We’ll be back in six weeks,” she said. “With your batteries. We’ll expect seed.” “If the sun behaves,” Mara replied. When they were gone, Luca released a breath. “You’re going to do it?” he asked. Mara slid the new cryovial into the pale belly of the powerless fridge, more shrine than storage. “I’m going to try,” she said. Outside, the clouds shifted. A shaft of hard light speared down onto the ragged solar rig. Voltage climbed, steadying. The inverter’s whine evened out. The thermal cycler beeped a clean note as her hacked program caught up, riding the wave. Mara bent over her makeshift machine, eyes bright. “Come on,” she whispered to the fragile loops of code and life inside the tubes. “One more generation. Then another. Then we stop dying on their schedule.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical proficiency and world-building within the biopunk genre. The author creates a convincing post-apocalyptic setting where corporate genetic engineering with built-in obsolescence has created a world of scarcity and degradation. The scientific details feel authentic without being overwhelming, and the jury-rigged laboratory equipment is vividly realized through specific, tactile descriptions. The protagonist Mara is well-developed, with clear motivations and a distinctive voice. Her willingness to experiment on herself and her pragmatic approach to survival feel consistent with the harsh world she inhabits. The dialogue is naturalistic and serves both character development and plot advancement effectively. The relationship between Mara and Luca, while brief, feels authentic. The central conflict around the black market contract creates genuine tension, and Mara's solution—agreeing to help while protecting herself from becoming a "factory"—demonstrates character agency and intelligence. The piece successfully balances technical exposition with narrative momentum. The prose is generally clean and evocative, with strong sensory details that ground the reader in the physical environment. The author effectively uses technical language without becoming inaccessible, and the pacing maintains interest throughout. The ending strikes an appropriate note of cautious hope that feels earned given Mara's circumstances and capabilities. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical descriptions slightly slow narrative flow, and the corporate antagonists (the market brokers) remain somewhat abstract threats rather than fully realized presences. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-executed piece. The writing demonstrates sophistication in its handling of genre conventions while maintaining accessibility. The author successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a compelling standalone narrative.
